14 VKMR:

Portmanteau-Theorem
back:
[latex]
Let $S$ be a metric space and $P_n,P,\,n\in \N,$ be probability measures on $S$. Then the following are equivalent.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $P_n \tendsto{} P$ weakly,
    \item[(ii)] $\int_S f \dd P_n \tendsto{} \int_S f\dd P$ for all $f\in C_b^0(S)$,
    \item[(iii)] $\limsup_{n\to \infty} P_n(A) \le P(A)$ for all closed $A\subset S$,
    \item[(iv)] $\liminf_{n\to \infty} P_n(O) \ge P(O)$ for all open $O\subset S$,
    \item[(v)] $\lim_{n\to \infty} P_n(B) = P(B)$ for all $B\in \mathcal{C}(P)$,
    \item[(vi)] $\int_S f \dd P_n \tendsto{} \int_S f\dd P$ for all $f\in B(S)$ with $P(\mathcal{C}(f)) = 1$,
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front:
I.1 Space of closed sets:

Definition and characterisation upper- and lower semi-continuity.
back:
[latex]
Let $f\colon T\to \F$ be a map, where $(T, \mathcal{O}_T)$ is a topological space. Then $f$ is called
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \textbf{upper semi-continuous }\defiff \forall C\in\CE\colon f^{-1}\left(\F^C\right) \in \O_T\iff \forall t_i \to t\colon \lsup f(t_i) \subset f(t). \\
(2)& \ \textbf{lower semi-continuous } \defiff \forall G\in\G\colon f^{-1}\left(\F_G\right) \in \O_T \iff \forall t_i\to t\colon \linf f(t_i) \supset f(t).\\
\end{align*}
Then $f$ is continuous if and only if it is upper- and lower semi-continuous.
[/latex]

In particular, both sets are closed.

front:
I.2 Random closed sets:

Definition and (four) examples of random closed sets (racs).
back:
A random closed set (racs) is a mb map [$]Z\colon (\Omega,\A,\P) \to (\F,\B)[/$].

[latex]
\begin{align*}
&(1) \ Z \equiv F\in\F \text{ constant racs.}\\
&(2) \ Z_1, Z_2 \text{ racs} \implies Z_1 \cap Z_2 \text{ and } Z_1 \cup Z_2 \text{ are racs.}\\
&(3) \ \xi\colon \Omega \to E \text{ mb} \implies Z \defas \{\xi\} \text{ is racs.}\\
&(4) \ Z \text{ racs in } \R^n, t\in\R^n, \nu\in \textrm{SO}(n)\implies Z+t \text{ and } \nu Z \text{ are racs.}
\end{align*}
[/latex]


[Page 1]

front:
I.2 Random closed sets:

Definition stationarity and isotropy.
back:
A racs [$]Z[/$] in [$]\R^n[/$] is called
[latex]
\begin{align*}
&(1) \ \textbf{stationary} \defiff \forall t\in\R^n\colon Z + t \deq Z.\\
&(2) \ \textbf{isotropic} \defiff \forall \rho \in \text{SO}(n)\colon \rho Z \deq Z.
\end{align*}
[/latex]

front:

back:
If [$]Z[/$] is a stationary, compact racs in [$]\R^n[/$], then [$]Z = \varnothing \as{\P}[/$].

Corollary: If [$]Z[/$] is stationary and [$]\P\left( Z \text{ compact}\right) > 0[/$], then [$]\P\left(Z = \varnothing | Z \text{ compact}\right) = 1[/$].

I.3 Capacity functional:

Motivation and Definition.
back:
Motivation: [$]X\colon \Omega o \R[/$] has [$]F_X(t) = \P(X\le t) = \P\left(\{X\} \cap (-\infty,t] eq \varnothing ight)[/$].

Definition: Let [$]Z[/$] be a racs in [$]\F[/$]. Then its capacity functional is

[$$] T_Z\colon \CE o [0,1]; \ C \mapsto \P\left(Z\cap C eq \varnothing ight) = \P\left(Z otin \F^C ight) = \P^Z\left(\F_C ight).[/$$]


[Page 2]

front:
I.3 Capacity functional:

Properties of [$]T_Z[/$] (including uniqueness).
back:
[latex]
\begin{align*}
&(1) \ 0 \le T_Z \le 1, \ T_Z(\varnothing) = 0.\\
&(2) \ C_i \downarrow C \implies T_Z(C_i) \to T_Z(C).\\
&(3) \ S_k \ge 0, \text{ where } S_0(C_0) \defas 1 - T_Z(C_0), S_k(C_0;C_1\ldots C_k) \defas \\ & S_{k-1}(C_0;C_1\ldots C_{k-1}) - S_{k-1}(C_0\cup C_k; C_1\ldots C_{k-1}).\\
\end{align*}
[/latex]

If a map [$]T\colon \CE  \to [0,1][/$] satisfies (1) to (3), then there exists a unique probability measure [$]Q[/$] on [$]\F[/$] such that [$] T(C) = Q(\F_C)\forall C\in\CE[/$].

Let $\Phi$ be a pp. Then the \textbf{generating functional} of $\Phi$ is the map

back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a ppp in $E$ with i.m. $\Theta$. Then for any $n\in\N$ and $f\colon \N(E)\times E^n \to [0,\infty]$ measurable we have

II.3 Palm measures:

Definition of [$]\P_x[/$] for a pp [$]\Phi[/$]. Why is it a kernel? Relation to Mecke equation?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a point process in $E$. Then set
\[ \P_x(\cdot) \defas \P^{\Phi+\delta_x}(\cdot) = \P\left( \Phi+\delta_x \in \cdot\right).\]
Then $E\times\Ncal(E)\to [0,\infty], (x, A) \mapsto \P_x(A)$ is a stochastic kernel. The Mecke equation now reads, for a ppp $\Phi$ and $f\colon \N(E)\times E\to [0,\infty]$ measurable,
\[ \int_{\N(E)} \int_E f(\eta, x) \eta(\dd x) \P^\Phi(\dd \eta) = \int_E \int_{\N(E)} f(\eta, x) \P_x(\dd \eta) \Theta(\dd x).\]
[/latex]

front:
II.3 Palm measures:

Definition Borel and Polish spaces.

Definition vague convergence and why [$]\M(E)[/$] and [$]\N(E)[/$] are Polish spaces.
back:
[latex]
A topological space $X$ is called \textbf{Polish} iff $X$ is separable and completely metrizable.\\

A measurable space $(E, \mathcal{E})$ is called a \textbf{Borel space} iff $\exists B\in\B(\R)$ such that $(E, \mathcal{E}) \cong (B, \B(\R)\cap B),$ i.e. there is a bijective, bimeasurable map $\varphi\colon E\to B$. All Polish spaces are Borel spaces.\\

A sequence $(\mu_n)$ in $\M(E)$ is said to converge \textbf{vaguely} to $\mu\in\M(E)$ iff
\[ \int_E f \dd \mu_n \tendsto{n\to\infty} \int_E f \dd \mu\]
for all $f\colon E \to \R$ continuous with compact support. Vague convergence in $\M(E)$ can be completely metriced such that $\Mcal(E) = \B(\M(E))$, hence $(\M(E), \Mcal(E))$ is Polish. $\N(E)\subset \M(E)$ is closed, hence also Polish.
[/latex]

front:
II.3 Palm measures:

Definition Campbell measure. What do [$]C(A\times B)[/$] and in particular [$]\pi_2 C[/$] look like?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a random measure in $E$ (with locally finite intensity measure $\Theta$). Then the \textbf{Campbell measure} of $\Phi$ is
\[ C\colon \Ncal(E)\times \B(E)\to [0,\infty], F\mapsto \int_{\N(E)} \int_E \ind_F(\eta, x) \eta(\dd x) \P^\Phi(\dd \eta) = \E \left[ \int_E \ind_F(\Phi, x) \Phi(\dd x) \right].\]
Then, in particular, we have
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \text{If } A\in\Ncal(E), B\in \B(E)\colon C(A\times B) = \E \left[ \ind\{\Phi\in A\} \Phi(B)\right] \le \Theta(B).\\
(2)& \ \text{In particular, } \pi_2 C = \Theta \text{ is locally finite and hence $\sigma$-finite}.
\end{align*}
[/latex]

front:
II.3 Palm measures:

Definition Palm distributions and Palm pair.

Palm family for a poisson process?
back:
[latex]
By disintegration of the Campbell measure, for any random measure $\Phi$ with i.m. $\Theta$ there exists a probability kernel $(\P_x)_{x\in E}$ such that for any $f\colon \N(E)\times E\to [0,\infty]$ measurable we have
\[\int_{\N(E)} \int_E f(\eta, x) \eta(\dd x) \P^\Phi(\dd \eta) = \int_E \int_{\N(E)} f(\eta, x) \P_x(\dd \eta) \Theta (\dd x).\]
The family $(\P_x)$ is called a family of \textbf{Palm distributions} of $\Phi$. The pair $(\P_x, \Phi)$ is called a \textbf{Palm pair}. For two such kernels $\P_x, \tilde{\P}_x$, we have $\P_x = \tilde{\P}_x$ for $\Theta$-a.a $x\in E$.\\

If $\Phi$ is a ppp, then $\P_x \defas \P^{\Phi+\delta_x}$ is a Palm family of $\Phi$ by Mecke.
[/latex]

(1) Property of [$]\P_x[/$] that justifies the definition of [$]\P_x^![/$].
(2), (3) [$]\Theta[/$] and [$](\P_x)[/$] determine [$]\P^\Phi[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a point process in $E$ and $(\P_x)$ a family of Palm distributions of $\Phi$ . Then
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \text{For }\Theta\text{-a.a. } x\in E\colon \P_x \left( \{\eta\colon \eta(\{x\} ) \ge 1\} \right) =1.\\
(2)& \ \exists h \colon \N(E)\times E \to [0,\infty) \text{ mb s.t. }\forall \eta\in \N(E)\setminus \{0\} \colon \int_E h(\eta, x) \eta(\dd x) = 1.\\
(3)& \ \text{For } A\in \mathcal{N}(E), 0 \not\in A\colon \P\left( \Phi \in A \right) = \int_E \int_{\N(E)}\ind_A(\eta)h(\eta, x) \P_x(\dd \eta) \Theta(\dd x).

II.3 Palm measures:

Definition reduced Palm measures. What does [$]\P_x^![/$] look like for a poisson process?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a point process in $E$ with Palm distributions $(\P_x)$. Then for $x\in E$ we set
\[
\P_x^!(\cdot ) \defas \P_x\left( \eta\setminus \delta_x\in \cdot \right) = \int_{\N(E)} \ind\{\eta\setminus \delta_x\in \cdot \}\P_x(\dd \eta)
\] and call $(\P_x^!)$ the \textbf{family of reduced Palm distributions of} $\Phi$.\\

If $\Phi$ is a poisson process, then \[
\P_x^!(\cdot ) = \P\left( (\Phi + \delta_x)\setminus \delta_x\in \cdot \right) = \P^\Phi(\cdot ).
\]
[/latex]

[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a pp with i.m. $\Theta$ and Palm families $(\P_x)$. Then for $x_0\in E$ with $\Theta(\{x_0\} )> 0$ (in particular, $\P_{x_0}$ is uniquely determined), we have
\[
\int_E h(\eta)\P_{x_0}(\dd \eta) = \frac{\E \left[ h(\Phi) \Phi(\{x_0\} ) \right] }{\E\left[ \Phi(\{x_0\} ) \right] }.
\]
for any $h \colon \N(E) \to [0,\infty]$. In particular, if $\Phi$ is simple, we have \[
\P_{x_0}(\cdot ) = \P\left( \Phi\in\cdot \ | \ x_0\in \Phi \right).

back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Cox process with directing measure $\Q$. Then if $A_1,\ldots , A_m\in \B(E), k_1,\ldots ,k_m\in \N_0,$ \[
\P\left( \forall i\colon \Phi(A_i) = k_i \right) = \sum_{m\in M} \int_{\M(E)} \prod_{I\subset [m]} \e^{-\Theta(B_I)} \frac{\Theta(B_I)^{m_I}}{m_I!} \Q(\dd \Theta)

\P\left( \forall i\colon \Phi(A_i) = k_i \right) = \int_{\M(E)} \prod_{j=1}^m \e^{-\Theta(A_j)} \frac{\Theta(A_j)^{k_j}}{k_j!} \Q(\dd \Theta)

\E\left[ \Phi(B) \right] = \int_{\M(E)}\Theta(B) \Q(\dd \Theta) = \Lambda_\Q(B)

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Definition of Cox process with directing measure [$]\chi[/$]. Relation to definition via [$]\Q[/$]?
back:
[latex]
Let $\chi$ be a random measure in $E$. Then $\Phi$ is called a \textbf{Cox process with directing measure} $\chi$ if \[
\P \left( \Phi \in \cdot \ | \ \chi \right) = \Pi_\chi(\cdot) \as{\P}
\] In other words, \(
\Omega \times \mathcal{N}(E) \ni (\omega, A) \mapsto \Pi_{\chi(\omega)}(A) \in [0,1]
\) is a version of $P_{\Phi | \chi}$. This means that \[
\P^{(\Phi, \chi)}(C) = \int_{\M(E)}\int_{\N(E)} \ind_{C}(\eta, \Theta) \Pi_\Theta(\dd \eta) \P^\chi(\dd \Theta)
\] for any $C\in \mathcal{M}(E) \otimes \mathcal{N}(E)$. In particular, $\P(\Phi\in \cdot ) = \int_{\M(E)}\Pi_\Theta(\cdot) \P^\chi(\dd \Theta)$, so the previous definition is retrieved via $\Q = \P^\chi$.
[/latex]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Example of a directing measure via intensity field [$]Y[/$].

Why / when is it a random measure (measurable, locally finite)?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Theta\in \M(E)$ be fixed and $Y \colon \Omega\times E \to [0,\infty)$ measurable. Then set \[
\chi(B) \defas \int_B Y \dd \Theta, \ B\in \B(E).
\] Special case: $Y$ depends only on $\omega\in \Omega$, i.e. $\chi = Y \Theta_0$. Then $\P_\chi(\cdot) = \int_0^\infty \ind\{t\Theta_0\in \cdot \}\P^Y(\dd t)$ and hence \[
P^\Phi(\cdot ) = \int_0^\infty \Pi_{t\Theta_0}(\cdot ) \P^Y(\dd t).
\]
[/latex]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

[$]\E \left[ \Phi(B) \right][/$] and [$]\mathbb{V}(\Phi(B))[/$] for a Cox process. Can a Cox process be a poisson process?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Cox process with directing measure $\chi$. Then $\E\left[ \Phi(B) \right] = \E \left[ \chi(B) \right] $ and \[
\mathbb{V}(\Phi(B)) = \mathbb{V}(\chi(B)) + \E\left[ \Phi(B) \right].
\] In particular, if $\tilde{\Phi}$ is a poisson process with the same intensity measure, then \[
\mathbb{V}(\Phi(B)) = \mathbb{V}(\tilde{\Phi}(B)) + \mathbb{V}(\chi(B)).
\] Hence for non-constant $\chi$, a Cox process cannot be a poisson process.
[/latex]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Mecke characterisation of a Cox process.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a point process in $E$ and $\chi$ a random measure in $E$. Then $\Phi$ is a Cox process with directing measure $\chi$ if and only if \[
\E \left[ \int_E f(\Phi,\chi,x)\Phi(\dd x) \right] =\E\left[ \int_E f(\Phi+\delta_x, \chi, x)\chi(\dd x) \right]
\] for all $f\colon \N(E)\times \M(E)\times E\to[0,\infty]$ measurable.
[/latex]


[Page 7]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Multivariate Mecke formula.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Cox process in $E$ with directing measure $\chi$. Then for $n\in \N$ and $f\colon \N(E)\times \M(E)\times E^n\to[0,\infty]$ measurable we have \[
\E \left[ \int_{E^n} f\left(\Phi, \chi, x\right) \Phi^{(n)}(\dd x) \right] = \E \left[ \int_{E^n} f\left( \Phi+\sum_{i=1}^n \delta_{x_i}, \chi, x \right) \chi^n(\dd x) \right] .
\] In particular, $\E\left[ \Phi^{(n)}(\cdot ) \right] = \E \left[ \chi^n(\cdot ) \right] $.
[/latex]


[Page 7]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Reduced Palm measures of a Cox process.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Cox process with directing measure $\chi$ and \textbf{locally finite} intensity measure $\Theta$. Let $K(x,\cdot )$ be a Palm family of $\chi$, i.e. \[
\int_{\M}\int_E f(\mu, x)\mu(\dd x) \P_\chi(\dd \mu) = \int_E \int_\M f(\mu, x) K(x, \dd \mu) \Theta(\dd x).
\] Then for $\Theta$-a.a. $x\in E$, we have \[
\P_x^!(\cdot ) = \int_\M \Pi_\mu(\cdot ) K(x, \dd \mu).
\]
[/latex]


[Page 7]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Generating functional of a Cox process.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Cox process with directing measure $\chi$. Then for $f\colon E\to[0,1]$ measurable,\[
G_\Phi(f) = L_\chi(1-f).
\]
[/latex]

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Let [$]\chi[/$] be a random measure on [$]\R^n[/$] derived from an intensity field [$]Y[/$]. What is meant by stationarity of [$]Y[/$] and what does it imply for [$]\chi[/$]?

What does the intensity measure of [$]\chi[/$] look like in that case?
back:
[latex]
Let $Y\colon \Omega\times \R^n\to [0,\infty)$ be measurable and $\chi(A)\defas \int_A Y \dd \lambda^n, A\in \B^n$. Then $Y$ is called \textbf{stationary} iff $T_t Y \deq Y$ as random fields, or equivalently if \[
\forall x_1,\ldots x_k, t\in \R^n\colon (Y(x_1),\ldots Y(x_k)) \deq (Y(x_1+t),\ldots ,Y(x_k+t)).
\] Now if for $\P$-a.a. $\omega\in \Omega$, $Y(\omega,\cdot )$ is Riemann-integrable on compact sets, then stationarity of $Y$ implies stationarity of $\chi$ (which implies stationarity of $\Phi\sim \text{Cox}(\chi)$). In that case, \[
\E\left[ \chi(\cdot ) \right] = \Theta \lambda^n,
\] where $\Theta \defas \E \left[ Y(0) \right] \in [0,\infty)$ is called the \textbf{intensity} of $\Phi$.
[/latex]

If [$]\Phi\sim \text{Cox}(\chi)[/$] and [$]\chi[/$] is stationary (in [$]\R^n[/$]), then [$]\Phi[/$] is stationary.

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Neyman-Scott processes.
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition:} Let $E=\R^n$. Let $\Theta_0 = \vartheta_0 \lambda^n$ be locally finite and $\Phi_0 = \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{\xi_i}\sim \text{Po} (\Theta_0)$. Let $\Theta_1 = \vartheta_1 \lambda^n$ be finite such that \[
\int_B \int_E \vartheta_1(x-y)\vartheta_0(y) \dd y\dd x < \infty \ \forall B\in \mathcal{C}
\] and let $\Phi^{(i)}\sim \text{Po} (\Theta_1)$ i.i.d. Then set $\Phi \defas \sum_{i=1}^\tau \left( \Phi^{(i)}+\xi_i \right) $.\\

\textbf{Cox process:} $\Phi$ is a Cox process with intensity field $Y(x) = \int_E \vartheta_1(x-y)\Phi_0(\dd y)$ (w.r.t. $\lambda^n)$, i.e. with directing measure \[
\chi(B) = \int_E \int_E \ind_{B}(x) \vartheta_1(x-y) \dd x \Phi_0(\dd y), B\in\B(E).
\]

\textbf{Stationarity:} Furthermore, if $\Phi_0$ is stationary (i.e. $\vartheta_0 \equiv \overline{\vartheta}_0 $), then $\Phi$ is stationary with intensity \[\Theta = \overline{\vartheta}_0\int_E \vartheta_1(x) \dd x\].
[/latex]

Matern-Cluster processes.
back:
[latex]
Let $\overline{\vartheta}_1, r>0$. Then a Matern-Cluster process is a Neyman-Scott process with \[
\vartheta_1(x) \defas \overline{\vartheta}_1 \ind\{\|x\|\le r\}.
\].

front:
II.4 Cox processes:

Estimator [$]\tilde{\Theta}_W[/$] for the intensity of a stationary Neyman-Scott process.
(Definition, Variance, weak and [$]\sqrt{n}[/$]-consistency).
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a stationary Neyman-Scott process (i.e. $\vartheta_0 \equiv \overline{\vartheta}_0$ ). Then $\tilde{\Theta}_W \defas \frac{\Phi(W)}{|W|}$ is an unbiased estimator for its intensity $\Theta = \overline{\vartheta}_0 \int \vartheta_1 \dd \lambda^n$. The following properties hold:

\begin{align*}
&(1) \ \mathbb{V}(\tilde{\Theta}_W) = \frac{\overline{\vartheta}_0}{|W|}\left( \int_E \vartheta_1(x) \dd x + \int_E \int_E \frac{|W \cap \left( W - (x_2-x_1) \right) |}{|W|}\vartheta_1(x_1)\vartheta_1(x_2) \dd x_1\dd x_2\right) .\\
&(2) \ \tilde{\Theta}_W \text{ is weakly consistent, i.e. } \tilde{\Theta}_{W_k}\tendsto{\P} \Theta \text{ if } W_k \in \B^n \text{ bounded and } |W_k| \to \infty.\\
&(3) \ \text{If } \forall x\in \R^n, \frac{|W_k\cap (W_k-x)|}{|W_k|} \to 1, \text{ then } \sqrt{|W_k|} \left( \tilde{\Theta}_{W_k}-\Theta\right) \vk \mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^2) \text{ where}\\
& \ \ \ \ \sigma^2 \defas \lim_{k\to\infty}\left( |W_k|\cdot \mathbb{V}(\tilde{\Theta}_{W_k})\right) = \overline{\vartheta}_0 \left( \int \vartheta_1 \dd \lambda^n + \left( \int \vartheta_1 \dd \lambda^n \right)^2 \right) .
\end{align*}
[/latex]

front: Let [$]X, Y[/$] be random variables. Connection between conditional distribution [$]K(Y,\cdot) = P_{X|Y}[/$] and [$]\P^{(X,Y)}[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $X\colon \Omega\to E$ and $Y\colon \Omega\to E'$ be measurable and $K\colon E'\times \mathcal{E}\to [0,1]$ a stochastic kernel. Then the following are equivalent:
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ K(Y,\cdot )\colon \Omega\times \mathcal{E}\to[0,1] \text{ is a conditional distribution } P_{X|Y}.\\
(2)& \ \P^{(X,Y)} = \P^Y \otimes K, \text{ i.e. } \P^{(X,Y)}(\cdot ) = \int_{E'}\int_E \ind\{(x,y)\in \cdot \}K(y,\dd x) \P^Y(\dd y).
\end{align*}

front:
II.5 Markings and Cluster processes:

Definition [$]K[/$]-marking.

Does the definition depend on the concrete choice of the [$](\xi_i)[/$]?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi_0 = \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{\xi_i}$ be a point process in $E$ and $K\colon E\times \mathcal{N}(E)\to[0,1]$ a stochastic kernel. Then a point process $\Psi$ on $E\times \N(E)$ with distribution \[
\P^\Psi(\cdot ) = \int \int \ind\left\lbrace\sum_{i=1}^k \delta_{(x_i,y_i)}\in \cdot \right\rbrace\left( \bigotimes_{i=1}^k K(x_i,\cdot ) \right) (\dd (y_1,\ldots )) \P^{(\tau,\xi_1,\ldots )}(\dd (k, x_1,\ldots ))
\] is called a \textbf{$K$-marking of $\Phi_0$}. If $K(x,\cdot ) = \Q(\cdot )$, then $\Psi$ is called an \textbf{independent $\Q$-marking of $\Phi_0$}.\\

Since the Laplace-functional of $\Psi$ only depends on the distribution of $\Phi_0$, this is well-defined.
[/latex]

front:
II.5 Markings and Cluster processes:

Representation of a [$]K[/$]-marking as [$]\Psi \deq \sum_{n=1}^\tau \delta_{(\xi_n, \chi_n)}[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi_0 = \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{\xi_i}$ be a point process in $E$ and $\Psi$ a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$. Let $(\chi_i)$ be point processes in $E$ (on the same probability space as $\Phi_0$) such that
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ (\chi_i) \text{ are conditionally independent given } \tau, (\xi_i).\\
(2)& \ \P\left( \chi_n\in \cdot \ | \ \tau, (\xi_i) \right) = K(\xi_n,\cdot ) \ \P\text{-a.s.}
\end{align*}
Then $\Psi \deq \sum_{n=1}^\tau \delta_{(\xi_n, \chi_n)}$.
[/latex]

Let [$]\Psi \deq \sum_{n=1}^\tau \delta_{(\xi_n, \chi_n)}[/$] be a [$]K[/$]-marking of [$]\Phi_0[/$]. If [$]K(x,\cdot) = \Q(\cdot)[/$], what do we know about [$]\Phi_0, \chi_1, \chi_2,\ldots[/$]?
back:
They are independent.

front:
II.5 Markings and Cluster processes:

Laplace functional of a [$]K[/$]-marking.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Psi$ be a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$. Then for $f\colon E\times \N(E)\to [0,\infty]$ measurable, \[
L_\Psi(f) = L_{\Phi_0}(f^\star),
\] where $f^\star\colon E\to [0,\infty], \ x\mapsto -\log \left( \int_{\N(E)} \e^{-f(x,\eta)}K(x,\dd \eta) \right) $. In particular, $\Psi$ does not depend on the concrete choice of the $(\xi_i)$.
[/latex]

front:
II.5 Markings and Cluster processes:

Definition Cluster process.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Psi = \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{(\xi_i, \chi_i)}$ be a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$. Define \[\Phi \defas \sum_{i=1}^\tau \chi_i.\] If for any $B\in \B(E)$ relatively compact, $\P(\Phi(B) < \infty) = 1$ (by properties of $E$, this implies $\P(\Phi(B) < \infty \ \forall B\in \B(E) \text{ r.c.} ) = 1$), then $\Phi$ is called a \textbf{Cluster process with Kernel (cluster field) $K$ (and mother process $\Phi_0$)}.
[/latex]

II.5 Markings and Cluster processes:

Neyman-Scott process as Cluster process.
back:
[latex]
A Neyman-Scott process with parent $\Phi_0$ and child intensity $\Theta_1$ is a Cluster process with parent $\Phi_0$ and cluster field \[
K(x,\cdot ) = \Pi_{\Theta_1}(\cdot -x) = \int_{\N(E)} \ind\{\mu + x\in \cdot \}\Pi_{\Theta_1}(\dd \mu).
\]
[/latex]

front:
II.5 Markings and cluster processes:

Intensity measure of a cluster process.

Don't use the conditional independence of the [$](\chi_i)[/$] in the proof!
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a cluster process with parent $\Phi_0$ and kernel $K$. Then the intensity measure of $\Phi$ is given by \[
\E \left[ \Phi(B)\right] = \int_E \int_{\N(E)} \mu(B) K(x, \dd \mu) \Theta_0(\dd x) = \int_E \Theta_x(B) \Theta_0(\dd x),
\] where $\Theta_x(B) \defas \int_{\N(E)} \mu(B) K(x, \dd \mu)$ is the intensity measure of $K(x, \cdot )$.
[/latex]

front:
II.5 Markings and cluster processes:

Three examples of cluster processes.

(location dependent shift (or deletion), [$]p[/$]-thinning)
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a cluster process with kernel $K$. Then $\Phi$ is called a
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \textbf{location dependent shift (of $\Phi_0$) if } K(x, \{\mu(E) = 1\} ) = 1 \ \forall x\in E.\\
(2)& \ \textbf{location dependent shift or deletion (of $\Phi_0$) if } K(x, \{\mu(E) \in \{0,1\}\}) = 1 \ \forall x\in E.\\
(3)& \ \textbf{$p$-thinning (of $\Phi_0$) if } K(x, \cdot ) = (1-p(x)) \delta_0 + p(x) \delta_{\delta_x} \ \forall x\in E \text{ for some mb } p\colon E\to [0,1].
\end{align*}
[/latex]

front: Bedingte Version von Borel-Cantelli.
back:
[latex]
Seien $(X_i\colon \Omega \to E)$ Zufallsvariablen in polnischem $(E, \mathcal{E})$ mit abzählbar erzeugtem $\mathcal{E}$. Seien $P_i\defas P_{X_i|\mathcal{F}}\colon \Omega \times \mathcal{E}\to [0,1]$ und $\mathcal{F}\subset \A$ eine sub-$\sigma$-Algebra. Seien $A_i\in \mathcal{E}, i\in \N$. Dann gelten:
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \P(X_n\in A_n \ | \ \mathcal{F}) < \infty \as{\P} \implies \P\left( X_n \in A_n \text{ für $\infty$ viele $n\in \N$} \ | \ \mathcal{F} \right) =0 \as{\P}.\\
(2)& \ \sum_{n=1}^\infty \P(X_n\in A_n \ | \ \mathcal{F}) = \infty \as{\P} \text{ und $(X_n)$ bedingt unabhängig gegeben $\mathcal{F}$} \\ & \implies \P\left( X_n \in A_n \text{ für $\infty$ viele $n\in \N$} \ | \ \mathcal{F} \right) =1 \as{\P}.
\end{align*}

front:
II.5 Markings and cluster processes:

Definition Poisson cluster process and KLM-measure. By what is [$]\Phi[/$] already determined?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi_0$ be a poisson process with intensity measure $\Theta_0$ and $K$ a kernel from $E$ to $\N(E)$. Then $\Phi_0$ and $K$ give a cluster process $\Phi$ if and only if \[
\forall B\in \mathcal{C}(E)\colon \tilde{\Theta}\left( \{\mu(B) > 0\} \right) < \infty,
\] where \[
\tilde{\Theta}\colon \mathcal{N}(E)\to [0,1], A \mapsto \int_{E} K(x, A) \Theta_0(\dd x).
\] In that case, $\Phi$ is called \textbf{Poisson cluster process} with \textbf{KLM-measure} $\tilde{\Theta}$. Then \[
\E \left[ \Phi(B) \right] = \int_{\N(E)} \mu(B) \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu).
\] The distribution of $\Phi$ is already determined by $\tilde{\Theta}$.
[/latex]


[Page 9]

front:
II.5 Markings and cluster processes:

Laplace functional of a poisson cluster process.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Poisson cluster process with KLM-measure $\tilde{\Theta}.$ Then for any $h\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ we have \[
L_\Phi(h) = \exp\left( - \int_{\N(E)}\left( 1 - \e^{-\int_E h \dd \mu} \right) \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu) \right).
\] In particular, the distribution of $\Phi$ only depends on $\tilde{\Theta}$.
[/latex]


[Page 9]

front:
II.5 Markings and cluster processes:

[$]\E[/$] and [$]\mathbb{V}[/$] of [$]\int_E h \dd \Phi[/$] for a Poisson cluster process [$]\Phi[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Poisson cluster process with KLM-measure $\tilde{\Theta}$ and intensity measure $\Theta$. Then for any $h\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ satisfying $\int_{\N} \mu(h) \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu), \int_{\N} \mu(h)^2 \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu) < \infty$ we have \[
\E \left[ \Phi(h)^2 \right] = \Theta(h)^2 + \int_{\N} \mu(h)^2 \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu) (<\infty),
\] or, equivalently, \[
\mathbb{V}(\Phi(h)) = \int_{\N} \mu(h)^2 \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu).
\]

Here, we have denoted, for $\mu\in \N(E),$ \[
\mu(h) \defas \int_E h \dd \mu.
\]
[/latex]

front:
II.5 Markings and cluster processes:

Poisson cluster processes have higher variances than comparable Poisson processes (when are they equal?)
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a Poisson cluster process with KLM-measure $\tilde{\Theta}$ and intensity measure $\Theta$. Let $\Phi'$ be a poisson process with intensity measure $\Theta$. Then, for $B\in \mathcal{C}(E),$ \[
\mathbb{V}(\Phi(B)) = \int_{\N}\mu(B)^2 \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu) \ge \int_{\N} \mu(B) \tilde{\Theta}(\dd \mu) = \Theta(B) = \mathbb{V}(\Phi'(B)).
\] Equality holds iff $\mu(B) \in \{0,1\} $ for $\tilde{\Theta}$-a.a. $\mu\in \N(E)$.
[/latex]

front:
II.6 Point processes in [$]\R^n[/$]:

Palm distribution [$]\P^0[/$] of a stationary point process [$]\Phi[/$] in [$]\R^n[/$].

Connection with palm family?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a stationary point process in $\R^n$ with intensity $\gamma > 0$ and Campbell measure $C$. Then there exists a probability measure $\P^0$ on $\mathcal{N}(E)$, the \textbf{Palm distribution of $\Phi$}, such that for $A\in \mathcal{N}(E), B\in \B^n$, \[
C(A\times B) = \gamma \int_E \P^0 (A-x) \lambda^n(\dd x).
\] or equivalently, \[\int_{E\times \N(E)}f(\eta, x) C\left( \dd (\eta, x) \right) = \gamma \int_E \int_{\N(E)} f(\eta+x, x)\P^0(\dd \eta) \lambda^n(\dd x).\]
If $B\in \B^n$ with $\lambda^n(B) > 0,$ \[
\P^0(A) = \frac{1}{\gamma \lambda^n(B)}\E \left[ \int_B \ind\{\Phi-x\in A\}\Phi(\dd x) \right].
\]

Then if $(\P_x)$ is a Palm family of $\Phi$, \[
\P_x (\cdot ) = \P^0(\cdot -x) \text{ for $\lambda^n$-almost all } x\in \R^n.
\]
[/latex]

front:
II.7 Marked processes:

Example of a marked process [$]\Phi[/$] obtained from a point process [$]\eta[/$] in [$]E_0[/$] (with locally finite i.m.).

If [$]E_0 = \R^n[/$] and [$]\eta[/$] is stationary, what about [$]\Phi[/$]?
back:
[latex]
Let $\eta$ be a point process in $E_0$. Then \[
\Phi \defas \sum_{x\in \eta}\delta_{(x,\eta(x))} = \int_{E_0} \ind\{(x, \eta(x))\in \cdot \} \eta(x)^{-1}\eta(\dd x)
\] is a marked process in $E_0\times \N$. If $\eta$ is stationary in $\R^n$, then so is $\Phi$. (We have abbreviated $\eta(x) \defas \eta(\{x\} ).$
[/latex]


[Page 10]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Intensity measure of a stationary marked process in [$]\R^n[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a stationary marked process in $\R^n$ with i.m. $\Theta \neq 0 $. Then there is a probability measure $\mu$ on $M$ and $\gamma > 0$ such that \[
\Theta = \gamma \lambda^n \otimes \mu.
\] $\gamma$ is called the \textbf{intensity} of $\Phi$ and $\mu$ its \textbf{marked distribution}.
[/latex]


[Page 10]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

If [$]\Phi[/$] is a stationary marked process in [$]\R^n[/$], then so is [$]\Phi_0[/$]. What is the intensity of [$]\Phi_0[/$]?
back:
Intensity is the same.


[Page 10]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Definition independent [$]\Q[/$]-marking.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi_0 = \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{\xi_i}$ be a point process in $E_0$ and let $(\zeta_i)$ be i.i.d. random variables in $M$ with distribution $\Q$, indepedent of $\Phi_0$. Then \[
\Phi \defas \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{(\xi_i, \zeta_i)}
\] is called \textbf{independent $\Q$-marking of $\Phi_0$}.
[/latex]


[Page 10]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Defintion [$]K[/$]-marking.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi_0 = \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{\xi_i}$ be a point process in $E_0$ and let $K$ be a stochastic kernel from $E_0$ to $M$. Let $(\zeta_i)$ be random variables in $M$ such that $(\zeta_i)$ are independent given $\Phi_0$ and $\forall i\in \N\colon \P\left( \zeta_i\in \cdot \ | \ \Phi_0 \right) = K(\xi_i,\cdot ) \ \P\text{-a.s.}$.\\

Then $\Phi \defas \sum_{i=1}^\tau \delta_{(\xi_i,\zeta_i)}$ is called a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$. The distribution of $\Phi$ is given by \[
\P^\Phi(\cdot ) = \int \int \ind\left\lbrace\sum_{i=1}^k \delta_{(x_i,y_i)}\in \cdot \right\rbrace\left( \bigotimes_{i=1}^k K(x_i,\cdot ) \right) (\dd (y_1,\ldots )) \P^{(\tau,\xi_1,\ldots )}(\dd (k, x_1,\ldots )).\]
[/latex]


[Page 10]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Intensity measure of a [$]K[/$]-marking.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$ in $E_0\times M$ with intensity measures $\Theta$ and $\Theta_0$ respectively. Then $\Theta = \Theta_0\otimes K$, i.e. \[
\Theta(\cdot ) = \int_{E_0} \int_M \ind\{(x,m)\in \cdot \}K(x, \dd m) \Theta_0(\dd x).
\] If $K(x,\cdot ) \equiv \Q(\cdot )$, then $\Theta = \Theta_0 \otimes \Q$ is the product measure.
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Laplace functional of a [$]K[/$]-marking.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$ in $E_0\times M$. Then, if $f\colon E_0\times M\to [0,\infty]$ is measurable, \[
L_{\Phi}(f) = L_{\Phi_0}(f^\star),
\] where \[
f^\star(x) \defas - \log \left( \int_M \e^{-f(x,m)}K(x,\dd m) \right) .
\]
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

A [$]K[/$]-marking of a ppp is a ppp.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a $K$-marking of $\Phi_0$ in $E_0\times M$. Then if $\Phi_0$ is a poisson process in $E_0$ with intensity measure $\Theta_0$, $\Phi$ is a poisson process in $E_0\times M$ with intensity measure $\Theta_0\otimes K$.
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Is a ppp in [$]E_0\times M[/$] a [$]K[/$]-marking of a ppp in [$]E_0[/$]?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a poisson process in $E_0\times M$ with intensity measure $\Theta = \Theta_0\otimes K$, where $\Theta_0$ is a locally finite measure on $E_0$ and $K$ is a stochastic kernel from $E_0$ to $M$. Then $\Phi$ is the $K$-marking of $\Phi_0\defas \Phi(\cdot \times M)$.\\

Sufficient for the disintegration of $\Theta$ is that $\Theta_0 \defas \Theta(\cdot \times M)$ is locally finite and $M$ is a Polish space.
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
II.7 Marked point processes:

Can a stationary poisson process in [$]\R^n\times M[/$] be obtained as a marking?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a stationary poisson process in $\R^n\times M$. Then $\Phi$ is the independent $\Q$-marking of $\Phi_0\defas \Phi(\cdot \times M)$.
[/latex]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition random field and fidis.
back:
[latex]
Let $T\neq \varnothing$, $E_t, \mathcal{E}_t$ measurable spaces. Set $S\defas \{f\colon T\to \bigcup_{t \in T} E_t \colon f(t)\in E_t \forall t\in T\} $ and $\B_T \defas \bigotimes_{t\in T}\mathcal{E}_t = \sigma \left( \pi_t\colon t\in T \right) $. Then a measurable map \[
X\colon (\Omega, \A, \P) \to (S, \B_T)
\] is called a random field. The measures \[
\P_{t_1,\ldots t_k}\defas \P^{(X_{t_1},\ldots ,X_{t_k})} \colon \bigotimes_{i=1}^k \mathcal{E}_{t_i} \to [0,1]
\] are called \textbf{finite dimensional marginal distributions (fidis)} of $X$ and determine its distribution.
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Projective families and connection with probability measures on [$]S[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $(\P_I), \varnothing \neq I \subset T, |I| < \infty$ be a family of probability measures on $ \bigotimes_{t\in I}\mathcal{E}_t$. It is called a \textbf{projective family} iff for any $I\subset J\subset T, 0 < |I|, |J| < \infty$, \[
\pi_I^J (\P_J) = \P_I.
\] If $\P$ is a probablity measure on $(S, \B_T)$, then $\P_I \defas \pi_I (\P)$ defines a projective family. If $E_t$ is Borel for any $t\in T$, then for any projective family $(\P_I)$ there exists such a probability measure $\P$ on $(S,\B_T)$.
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition and basic properties of characteristic function.

For what kind of measures is it defined?
back:
Defined for finite Borel-measures [$]\mu[/$] on [$]\R^k[/$].

Properties: [$]\varphi_\mu(0)[/$], continuity, positive semi-definite.

If [$]f\colon \R^k \to \C[/$] is positive semi-definite and continuous at [$]0[/$], then [$]f = \varphi_\mu[/$] for some [$]\mu[/$].


[Page 11]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Levy's continuity theorem.
back:
[latex]
Let $P_i, i\in \N, P$ be probability measures on $\R^d$ with characteristic functions $\varphi_i, i\in \N$ and $\varphi$. Then the following holds:
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \text{If } P_i \vk P, \text{ then } \varphi_i \tendsto{}\varphi \text{ pointwise and uniformly on compact sets.} \\
(2)& \ \text{If } \varphi_i \tendsto{}f \text{ ptw. and $f$ continuous at $0$, then }f = \varphi_\mu \text{ for some} \\
& \text{probability measure $\mu$ on $\R^d$ and } P_i \vk \mu.
\end{align*}
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition and construction of Gaussian distributions / Gaussian random fields.
back:
[latex]
Set $E_t\defas \R, t \in T$. A \textbf{($\infty$-dim.) Gaussian distribution} on $(\R^T, \B_T)$ is a probability measure $\Q$ such that all marginals $\Q_I$ are multivariate Gaussians. A \textbf{Gaussian random field} is a random field with a Gaussian distribution.\\

Let $\Q_I \sim \mathcal{N}(a_I, \Sigma_I)$. Then $(\Q_I)$ forms a projective family iff there is a map $a\colon T\to\R$ and a symmetric, positive semi-definite map $K\colon T\times T\to \R$ such that for all $\varnothing \subset I\subset T, |I| < \infty$, \[
a_I = a\restriction_I \text{ and } \Sigma_I = K\restriction_{I\times I}.
\] $a$ is called \textbf{mean value map} and $K$ is called \textbf{covariance function}.
[/latex]


[Page 11]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Examples for Gaussian random fields: Wiener process and Brownian bridge.
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Wiener process:} $T = [0,\infty)$, $a\equiv 0$, $K(t,s) = \sigma^2 \left( t\wedge s\right) $.\\

\textbf{Brownian bridge:} $T=[0,1]$, $a\equiv 0$, $K(t,s) = \sigma^2 \left( t\wedge s - ts \right) $.
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Examples for Gaussian random fields: Ohrnstein-Uhlenbeck process.
back:
[latex]
$T=[0,\infty), a\equiv 0, K(s,t) = \e^{-|t-s|}$. Can be obtained via \[
U_t \defas \e^{-t}B_{e^{2t}},
\] if $B$ is a Wiener process.
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Shot-noise field (Definition, mean-value, covariance function).
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a stationary poisson process in $\R^n$ with intensity $\gamma > 0$. Let $g\colon \R^n\to \R$ mb and $g\in L^1\cap L^2$. Define \[
X_t \defas \sum_{x\in \Phi} g(t-x) = \int_{\R^n}g(t-x) \Phi(\dd x).
\] Then $(X_t)$ is a random field with
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \E\left[ X_t \right] = \gamma \int g(t-x) \dd x.\\
(2)& \ \text{Cov} (X_s, X_t) = \gamma \int g(t-x) g(s-x) \dd x.
\end{align*}
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition  [$]m, C, D, K[/$] for a complex random field.
back:
[latex]
Let $Z\colon \Omega \to \C^T$ be a complex random field with $\E\left[ |Z_t|^2 \right] < \infty \forall t\in T$. Then we define
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ m(t) \defas \E\left[ Z_t \right], \text{ the } \textbf{mean value function.} \\
(2)& \ C(t, s) \defas \E \left[ Z_t \overline{Z_s} \right] , \text{ the } \textbf{correlation function.} \\
(3)& \ D(t, s) \defas \E \left[ Z_t Z_s \right] , \text{ the } \textbf{pseudo-correlation function} .\\
(4)& \ K(t, s) \defas \text{Cov} (Z_t,Z_s) \defas \E \left[ (Z_t - m_t) \overline{(Z_s - m_s)} \right] = C(t, s) - m(t)\overline{m(s)},\\
& \text{ the } \textbf{covariance function.}
\end{align*}
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition of a positive semi-definite map [$]\alpha\colon T\times T \to \C[/$] (and [$]f\colon T\to \C[/$]).

What do you know about [$]\alpha(s,t), \alpha(t,s)[/$] and [$]\alpha(t,t)[/$]?
back:
[latex]
A map $\alpha\colon T\times T\to \C$ is called \textbf{positive semi-definite} iff \[
\forall n\in \N, c_i\in \C, t_i\in T\colon \sum_{i,j=1}^n c_i \overline{c_j}\alpha(t_i,t_j) \ge 0.
\] In that case, if $s,t\in T$, we have \[
\alpha(t,s) = \overline{\alpha(s,t)}.
\] In particular, $\alpha(t,t) \ge 0 \ \forall t\in T$.\\

If $f\colon T\to\C$ and $T$ is an additive group, then $f$ is called positive semi-definite if $(s,t) \mapsto f(s-t)$ is positive semi-definite.
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition complex Gaussian field.

By what is the distribution of [$]Z[/$] already determined?
back:
[latex]
A random field $Z\colon \Omega \to \C^T$ is called a \textbf{complex Gaussian field} iff for any $n\in \N, t_1,\ldots ,t_n\in T$, \[
(\Re Z_{t_1},\Im Z_{t_1},\ldots ,\Re Z_{t_n}, \Im Z_{t_n}) \sim \mathcal{N}_{2n}.
\] Hence, the distribution of $Z$ is already determined by $m, C, D$.
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Definition and characterisation of spherical symmetry of a complex Gaussian rf.
back:
[latex]
Let $Z$ be a complex random Gaussian field. It is called \textbf{spherically symmetric} iff for any $\varphi \in \R$, \[
\e^{\i\varphi}Z\deq Z.
\] Equivalently, for any $s,t\in T,$ \[
\E \left[ Z_t \right] = 0 \text{ and } \E \left[ Z_s Z_t \right] = 0.
\]
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.1 Foundations:

Existence of complex Gaussian rf's with prescribed mean and covariance.
back:
[latex]
Let $m\colon T\to\C$ and $K\colon T\times T\to \C$ positive semi-definite. Then there exists a unique (in distribution) Gaussian random field with mean $m$ and covariance function $K$ such that $(Z-m)$ is spherically symmetric (i.e. $\E\left[ Z_s Z_t \right] = m_s m_t \ \forall s, t\in T$).
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.2 Stationarity and isotropy ([$]T=\R^k[/$]):

Definition (weak) stationarity (isotropy). What is the relationship between weak and not weak?
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_t)_{t\in T}$ be a real or complex random field. Then $X$ is called
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \textbf{stationary} \defiff \forall u\in T\colon (X_{t+u})_t \deq (X_t)_t.\\
(2)& \ \textbf{weakly stationary} \defiff \forall t\in T\colon \E \left[ |X_t|^2 \right] < \infty \text{ and } \forall s, t, u\in T\colon \\
& \E\left[ X_t \right] = \E\left[ X_s \right],\\
& \text{Cov} (X_{t+u}, X_{s+u}) = \text{Cov} (X_t, X_s),\\
& \E\left[ (X_t - m_t)(X_s - m_s) \right] = \E\left[ (X_{t+u} - m_{t+u})(X_{s+u} - m_{s+u}) \right].
\end{align*}
For isotropy, replace translations by rotations. $(1)$ together with $\E\left[ |X_t|^2 \right] < \infty\forall t\in T$ implies $(2)$. The converse holds if $X$ is Gaussian.
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.2 Stationarity and isotropy ([$]T=\R^k[/$]):

Definition [$]L^2[/$]-continuity of a real or complex rf and connection with continuity of [$]C[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $Z$ be a real or complex random field. Then $Z$ is called \textbf{$L^2$-continuous} iff for any $t_0\in T$ we have \[
\E \left[|Z_t - Z_{t_0}|^2\right] \tendsto{t\to t_0} 0.
\] Then the following holds:
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ Z \text{ is $L^2$-continuous at $t_0\in T$ iff $C$ is continuous at $(t_0,t_0)$}.\\
(2)& \ \text{If $C$ is continuous at $(t,t)$ and $(s,s)$, $C$ is also continuous at $(t,s)$ and $(s,t)$.}
\end{align*}
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.2 Stationarity and isotropy ([$]T=\R^k[/$]):

Theorem (Bochner).
back:
[latex]
Let $f\colon \R^d\to\C$ be continuous at $0$. Then
$f$ is positive semi-definite iff there exists a (unique) finite measure $\mu$ on $\R^d$ such that $f = \varphi_\mu$.
[/latex]


[Page 12]

front:
III.2 Stationarity and isotropy ([$]T=\R^k[/$]):

Theorem (Polya, Askey).
back:
[latex]
A function $f\colon \R^d\to\R$ with $f(t) = g(\|t\|), t\in \R^d$, for some $g\colon \R\to\R$ is positive semi-definite if
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ g \text{ is continuous on } [0,\infty),\\
(2)& \ g(0) = 1,\\
(3)& \ g(t) \tendsto{t\to \infty} 0,\\
(4)& \ (-1)^k g^{(k)} \text{ is convex, where } k = \left\lfloor \frac{d}{2} \right\rfloor.
\end{align*}
[/latex]


[Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Definition (semi-)ring, measure on a (semi-)ring, Caratheodory.
back:
[latex]
Let $E$ be a set. A family $\mathcal{K}(E)\subset \mathcal{P}(E)$ is called a \textbf{semi-ring} if
\begin{align*}
&(1) \ \varnothing \in \mathcal{K}(E)\\
&(2) \ \forall A,B\in \mathcal{K}(E)\colon A\cap B\in \mathcal{K}(E)\\
&(3) \ \forall A,B\in \mathcal{K}(E) \exists n\in \N, B_1,\ldots ,B_n\in \mathcal{K}(E) \text{ p.d.} \colon A\setminus B = \bigcup_{i = 1}^n B_i
\end{align*}
It is called a \textbf{ring} if it contains $\varnothing$ and is stable under $\cup$ and $\setminus $. A \textbf{measure} on a (semi-)ring is a $\sigma$-additive set-function (here: $\mu(E) < \infty$!).\\

\textbf{Caratheodory:} A measure on a semi-ring $\mathcal{K}(E)$ can be extended to a (unique and $\sigma$-finite) measure on $\sigma\left( \mathcal{K}(E) \right) $.
[/latex]


[Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Definition complex [$]\nu[/$]-noise.
back:
[latex]
Let $\mathcal{K}(E)$ be a semi-ring and $ u$ a measure on $\mathcal{K}(E)$. A collection $W = (W(A))_{A\in \mathcal{K}(E)}$ of complex random variables on $(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\P)$ is called a extbf{complex $ u$-noise} if
egin{align*}
(1)& \ orall A\in \mathcal{K}(E)\colon W(A) \in L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\P).\
(2)& \ orall A,B\in \mathcal{K}(E)\colon \E \left[ W(A) \overline{W(B)} ight] = u(A\cap B).
\end{align*}
In particular, $ u(A) = \E \left[ |W(A)|^2 ight] $ and $W(\varnothing) = 0 \ \P ext{-a.s.} $
[/latex]


[Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Characterisation of a complex [$]\nu[/$]-noise.
back:
[latex]
Let $\mathcal{K}(E)$ be a semi-ring and $(W(A))_{A\in \mathcal{K}(E)}$ a collection of complex random variables. Then $(W(A))$ is a complex $\nu$-noise (for some measure $\nu$ on $\mathcal{K}(E)$) iff
\begin{align*}
(1)& \ \forall A\in \mathcal{K}(E)\colon W(A) \in L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\P).\\
(2)& \ \forall A, B\in \mathcal{K}(E) \text{ disjoint} \colon \E \left[ W(A) \overline{W(B)} \right] = 0.\\
(3)& \ \forall (A_i)\in \mathcal{K}(E)^\N \text{ p.d. such that } A\defas \bigcup_{i \in \N} A_i\in \mathcal{K}(E)\colon W(A) = \sum_{i\in \N}W(A_i).
\end{align*}
In $(3)$, convergence is meant in $L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\P)$. For finite sums, the equality holds $\P$-a.s.
[/latex]


[Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

(Real and complex) Gaussian noise.
back:
[latex]
Let $E=\R^n$ and $ u$ be a measure on $\B^n$. Then $\mathcal{K}(E) \defas \{B\in \B^n\colon u(B)<\infty\} $ is a ring. Let $W$ be the centred Gaussian process with index set $\mathcal{K}(E)$ and $K(A,B) \defas u(A\cap B)$. Then $W$ is a (real) $ u$-noise, called extbf{Gaussian noise}.\

Let $W_1, W_2$ be independent (real) $ u$-noises. Then $W(A) \defas W_1(A) + \i W_2(A)$ defines a complex $(2 u)$-noise.
[/latex]


[Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Let [$] u[/$] be a measure on a semi-ring [$]\mathcal{K}(E)[/$]. Explicit construction of a centred complex [$] u[/$]-noise on [$]\{B\in \sigma(\mathcal{K}(E))\colon u(B) < \infty\}[/$].

([$] u[/$] also denotes the unique [$]\sigma[/$]-finite extension of [$] u[/$] to [$]\sigma(\mathcal{K}(E))[/$]).
back: [Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Setup and aim.
back:
[latex]
extbf{Setup:} Let $E eq \varnothing$, $\mathcal{K}(E)$ a semi-ring with measure $ u$ and $W$ a complex $ u$-noise. Set $ ilde{\A}\defas \mathcal{R}(E), \mathcal{A}\defas \sigma(\mathcal{K}(E))$. Then $ u$ can be uniquely extended to a $\sigma$-finite measure on $\A$.\

extbf{Aim:} Define a linear isometry $I_W\colon L^2(E, \A, u) o L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ and set \[
\int_E f \dd W \defas I_W(f).
\]

$W$ can be extended to $ ilde{\A}$ via $W\left( igcup_{i=1}^k A_i ight) \defas \sum_{i=1}^k W(A_i).$
[/latex]


[Page 13]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Definition of [$]I_W(f)[/$] for simple functions. (well-defined)?
back:
[latex]
A function $f\colon E\to\C$ is called \textbf{simple} if there are $n\in \N, a_i\in \C, A_i\in \mathcal{K}(E)$ p.d. such that $f = \sum_{i=1}^k a_i \ind_{A_i}$. In that case, we define \[
I_W(f) \defas \sum_{i=1}^k a_i W(A_i).
\] This is well-defined (as an element of $L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$).
[/latex]


[Page 14]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

[$]I_W[/$] for simple functions is linear and isometric.
back:
[latex]
Let $f, g\colon E\to\C$ be simple and $a, b\in \C$. Then \[
I_W(af+bg) = aI_W(f) + b I_W(g)
\] and \[
\left<I_W(f), I_W(g) \right>_{L^2(\P)} = \left<f, g \right>_{L^2(\nu)}, \text{ i.e. } \E \left[ I_W(f) \overline{I_W(g)} \right] = \int_E f\overline{g} \dd \nu.
\]
[/latex]


[Page 14]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Definition of [$]I_W(f)[/$] for general [$]f\colon E\to\C[/$].
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma:} Simple functions are dense in $L^2(E, \A, \nu)$.\\

Let $f\colon E\to\C$ and $f_n \tendsto{L^2}f $ where $f_n$ are simple. Then set $I_W(f) \defas \lim_{L^2}I_W(f_n)$.
[/latex]


[Page 14]

front:
III.3 Stochastic integration:

Final result: Properties of the map [$] I_W\colon L^2(E, \A, \nu) \to L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)[/$].
back:
[latex]
The map $I_W\colon L^2(E, \A, u) o L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ has the following properties:
egin{align*}
(1)& \ I_W ext{ is a linear isometry.} \
(2)& \ W ext{ can be extended from $ ilde{\A}$ to $\{A\in \A\colon u(A) < \infty\} $ via } W(A) \defas I_W( \ind_{A}).\
(3)& \ ext{If $W$ is centred, then } \E\left[ I_W(f) ight] = 0 \ orall f\in L^2(E, \A, u).
\end{align*}
[/latex]

front:
III.4 Spectral representations:

Motivation.
back:
[latex]

then ($\Theta$ is locally finite and diffusive and) $\Phi\sim \text{Po} (\Theta)$.
[/latex]

front:
II.2 Poisson processes:

In what sense does the second defining property of a ppp (independence) imply the first for simple point processes?
back:
[latex]
Let $\Phi$ be a simple point process in $E$ with locally finite and diffusive intensity measure $\Theta$. Then if $\Phi(A)$ and $\Phi(B)$ are independent for all disjoint $A, B\in \B(E)$, then $\Phi \sim \text{Po} (\Theta)$.
[/latex]

front:
II.2 Poisson processes:

[$]\text{Cov}(\Phi(A),\Phi(B))[/$] for a poisson process.
back:
[$$] \text{Cov}(\Phi(A),\Phi(B)) = \Theta (A\cap B)[/$$]

II.4 Cox processes:

II.4 Cox processes:

If [$]\Phi_{1,2} \sim \text{Cox}(\chi_{1,2})[/$], then [$]\Phi_1\deq\Phi_2 \stackrel{?}{\leftrightsquigarrow} \chi_1\deq\chi_2[/$].

II.2 Poisson processes:

Mapping theorem.
back:
[latex]
If $\Phi\sim\text{Po} (\Theta)$ and $T\colon E\to E'$ is proper, then $T(\Phi) \sim \text{Po} (T(\Theta))$.
[/latex]


[Some extra page]

front:
III.4 Spectral representations:

Example with [$]W = \sum_{j=1}^\infty X_j \delta_{t_j}[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $(E,\A)$ be a measurable space, $(t_i)\subset E$ p.d. and $(X_i)\subset L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F},\P)$ pairwise orthogonal with $\sum_{i=1}^\infty \|X_i\|^2 < \infty$. Then $ u \defas \sum_{i=1}^\infty \|X_i\|^2 \delta_{t_j}$ is a finite measure on $E$ with \[
f_n endsto{L^2} f \iff \sum_{i=1}^\infty \|X_i\|^2 |f(t_i) - f_n(t_i)|^2 endsto{} 0.
\] In this setting, \(
W\defas \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} X_i \delta_{t_i}\in L^2(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)
\) defines a complex $ u$-noise, where the limit is taken pointwise in $L^2$. Then if $f\in L^2(E,\A, u),$ \[
\int_E f \dd W = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} X_i f(t_i),
\] where the limit is again taken in $L^2$.\

Now if $E=\R^d, \A = \B(E)$ and $\E \left[ X_i ight] = 0 \ orall i\in \N$, then
\[Z(t) \defas \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} X_i \e^{\i\left<t, t_i ight>}
\] defines a centred, square-integrable, $L^2$-continuous and weakly stationary random field with $C_0 = \varphi_ u$ and $Z(t) = \int \e^{\i\left<t, x ight>}W(\dd x)$.
[/latex]


[Some extra page]

front: Martingale transform (discrete stochastic integral).
back:
[latex]
Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ be a probability space, $(Y_n)$ an $(\mathcal{F}_n)$ (sub/super-)martingale and $(V_n)$ predictable (and non-negative). Then, subject to integrability, \[
    (V\circ Y)_n \defas \sum_{k=1}^n V_k (Y_k - Y_{k-1})
\] defines a (sub/super-)martingale.
[/latex]

[Probability B1, Page 1]

front: Doob decomposition of integrable sequence [$](X_n)[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ be a probability space, $(X_n)$ integrable and $(\mathcal{F}_n)$-adapted. Then there exists a martingale $(M_n)$ and a predictable sequence $(A_n)$ with $M_0 = A_0 = 0$ such that \[
X_n = X_0 + M_n + A_n
\] for all $n\in \N$. $(M_n)$ and $(A_n)$ are a.s. unique. $(X_n)$ is a sub-/supermartingale if and only if $(A_n)$ is a.s. increasing/decreasing.
[/latex]

[Probability B1, Page 1]

front: Stopped (discrete) *martingales are *martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ be a probability space, $(M_n)$ a *martingale and $\tau$ a stopping time. Then $(M_{\tau \wedge n})$ is a *martingale.

Furthermore, if $(M_n)$ is a (super-)submartingale, then, for all $n\in\N$, \[
\E \left[ M_{n\wedge \tau}\right] (\ge) \le \E \left[ M_n\right].
\]
[/latex]

[Probability B1, Page 1]

front: [latex]Doob's Optional Stopping for discrete martingales (conditions under which $\E[M_\tau] = \E[M_0]$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ be a probability space, $(M_n)$ a *martingale and $\tau$ a stopping time. Suppose that one of the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\tau$ is bounded.
    \item[(ii)] $\tau < \infty$ a.s. and, for some $K > 0$, $|M_n| \le K$ a.s. for all $n\in \N$.
    \item[(iii)] $\E \left[ \tau \right] <\infty$ and there exists $L > 0$ such that \[
    \E \left[\left| M_{n+1}-M_n \right|  \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_n\right] \le L \quad \text{a.s.}
    \] for all $n\in \N$.
\end{enumerate}
Then $M_\tau$ is integrable and $\E \left[ M_\tau \right] = \E \left[ M_0 \right] $.
[/latex]

[Probability B1, Page 1]

front: Sufficient condition for [$]\E \left[ \tau \right] < \infty[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ be a probability space and $\tau$ a $(\mathcal{F}_n)$-stopping time. Then if there exist $K \in \N$ and $\varepsilon>0$ such that \[
\P \left(\tau \le n + K \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_n\right) \ge \varepsilon \quad \text{a.s.}
\] for all $n\in \N$, then $\E \left[ \tau \right] < \infty$.
[/latex]

[Probability B1, Page 2]

front: Doob's maximal inequality.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_n)$ be a non-negative submartingale. Then for any $\lambda>0$ and $n\in \N$, \[
    \P\left( \max_{k\le n}X_k \ge \lambda \right) \le \frac{\E \left[ X_n \right] }{\lambda}.
\] If $(M_n)$ is a martingale and $f\colon \R\to \R$ is non-negative, increasing and convex such that $\E \left[ f(|M_n|) \right] <\infty$ for all $n\in \N$, then for all $\lambda>0$ and $n\in \N$, \[
\P\left( \max_{k\le n}|M_k| \ge \lambda \right) \le \frac{\E \left[ f(|M_n|) \right] }{f(\lambda)}.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 2]

front: Definition upcrossings and connection with convergence.
back:
[latex]
Let $x = (x_n)\in \R^\N$ and $a < b$. Then define $(S_k)_{k\ge 0}= (S_k(x,[a,b]))$ and $(T_k)_{k\ge 0} = (T_k(x,[a,b]))$ recursively by $T_0 = 0$ and \[
S_k \defas \inf \left\{ n\ge T_{k-1}\colon x_n \le a \right\}, \qquad T_k \defas \inf \left\{ n\ge S_k\colon x_n \ge b \right\}
\] for $k\ge 1$. Then set
\begin{align*}
    U_n(x,[a,b]) &\defas \max\left\{ k\ge 0\colon T_k \le n \right\}, \\
    U(x,[a,b]) &\defas \sup\left\{ k\ge 0\colon T_k < \infty \right\} \left(= \sup_{n\in\N} U_n(x,[a,b]\right),
\end{align*}
the number of upcrossings of $x$ up to time $n$ and in total respectively.\\

\textbf{Connection with convergence:} $x$ converges if and only if $U(x,[a,b]) < \infty$ for all $a,b\in \Q, \, a < b$.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 2]

front: Doob's upcrossing lemma for discrete supermartingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_n)$ be a supermartingale and $a < b$. Then for every $n\in \N$, \[
    \E \left[ U_n\left( X, [a,b] \right)  \right] \le \frac{\E \left[ \left( X_n - a \right) ^- \right] }{b-a}.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 2]

front: Forward convergence for [$]L^1[/$]-bounded discrete *martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_n)$ be an $L^1$-bounded sub-/supermartingale. Then there exists an integrable $X_\infty$ such that \[
X_n \tendsto{} X_\infty \quad \text{a.s.}
\] This, in particular, applies to supermartingales bounded from below and to submartingales bounded from above.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 2]

front: Pythagoras for square-integrable martingales and characterisation of [$]L^2[/$]-boundedness.
back:
[latex]
Let $(M_n)$ be a square-integrable martingale. Then for $n,m\in \N, \, m > n,$
\begin{align*}
    \E \left[ M_n^2 \right] = \E \left[ M_0^2 \right] + \sum_{k=1}^n \E \left[ (M_k - M_{k-1})^2 \right] ,\\
    \E \left[ (M_m - M_n)^2 \right] = \sum_{k=n+1}^m \E \left[ (M_k-M_{k-1})^2 \right] .
\end{align*}
Consequently, a martingale $(M_n)$ is bounded in $L^2$ if and only if \[
    \E \left[ M_0^2 \right] <\infty \quad \text{and} \quad \sum_{k=1}^\infty \E \left[ (M_k - M_{k-1})^2 \right] <\infty.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 2/3]

front: Forward convergence for [$]L^2[/$]-bounded discrete martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(M_n)$ be an $L^2$-bounded martingale. Then there exists a random variable $M_\infty\in L^2$ such that \[
M_n \tendsto{\text{a.s.}}  M_\infty \quad \text{and} \quad M_n \tendsto{L^2}  M_\infty.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Definition and tail characterisation of uniform integrability.
back:
[latex]
A collection $\mathcal{C}$ of real random variables is called \emph{uniformly integrable} if \[
    \sup_{X\in \mathcal{C}} \E \left[ |X| \ind\left\{|X| \ge K\right\} \right] \tendsto{} 0, \quad K\to \infty.
\] This is the case if and only if \[
\sup_{X\in \mathcal{C}}\E \left[ \left( |X| - K \right) ^+ \right] \tendsto{} 0, \quad K\to \infty.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Connection between boundedness in [$]L^p[/$] and uniform integrability.
back:
[latex]
Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a collection of random variables and $p > 1$. Then \[
\mathcal{C} \text{ is bounded in $L^p$} \implies \mathcal{C} \text{ is uniformly integrable} \implies \mathcal{C} \text{ is bounded in $L^1$} \implies \mathcal{C} \text{ is tight.}
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Characterisation of uniform integrability (involving [$]\E\left[ |X| \ind_A\right][/$]).
back:
[latex]
Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a collection of random variables. Then $\mathcal{C}$ is uniformly integrable if and only if
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\mathcal{C}$ is tight,
    \item[(ii)] $\sup_{X\in \mathcal{C}} \E \left[ |X| \ind_{A} \right] \tendsto{} 0$ if $\P(A) \to 0$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Vitali's Convergence Theorem.
back:
[latex]
Let $X_n \sk X$ and $X_n$ integrable for all $n\in \N$. Then the following are equivalent.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $(X_n)$ is uniformly integrable,
    \item[(ii)] $X_n \tendsto{L^1} X$,
    \item[(iii)] $\E \left[ |X_n| \right] \tendsto{} \E \left[ |X| \right] <\infty$.
\end{enumerate}
In particular, for any sequence $(X_n)$ we have $X_n \tendsto{L^1} X$ if and only if $X_n \sk X$ and $(X_n)$ is uniformly integrable.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Families of the form [$]\left( \E \left[ X\,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_\alpha\right]\right)_\alpha[/$] are uniformly integrable.
back:
[latex]
Let $(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\P)$ be a probability space and $(\mathcal{F}_\alpha)_{\alpha\in I}$ a family of sub-$\sigma$-algebras of $\mathcal{F}$. Then if $X$ is integrable, the family $(X_\alpha)$ defined by \[
X_\alpha \defas \E \left[X \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_\alpha\right], \quad \alpha \in I
\] is uniformly integrable.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Discrete Martingale convergence theorem.
back:
[latex]
Let $(M_n)$ be an $(\mathcal{F}_n)$-martingale. The following are equivalent.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $(M_n)$ is uniformly integrable,
    \item[(ii)] There exists an integrable $M_\infty$ such that $M_n \tendsto{\text{a.s.}} M_\infty$ and $M_n \tendsto{L^1} M_\infty$.
    \item[(iii)] There exists an integrable $M_\infty$ such that $M_n = \E \left[M_\infty \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_n\right]$ a.s. for all $n\in \N$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 3]

front: Discrete Optional Stopping for uniformly integrable martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(M_n)$ be a uniformly integrable martingale and $\tau$ a stopping time ($\P(\tau = \infty) > 0$ is allowed!). Then $M_\tau$ is integrable and $\E \left[ M_\tau \right] = \E \left[ M_0 \right] $.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 4]

front: Variant of Tschebyscheff's inequality.
back:
[latex]
Let $X$ be a real random variable and $t > 0$. Then \[
    \P\left( X - \E \left[ X \right] \ge t \right) \le \frac{\Var(X)}{t^2 + \Var(X)}.
\] This improves the Tschebyscheff if $\Var(X) < t^2$.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 1]

front: Hoeffding's lemma and theorem (Concentration for [$]a_i \le X_i \le b_i[/$]).
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Hoeffding's lemma:} Let $a \le X \le b$ a.s. and $\E \left[ X \right] = 0$. Then \[
    \E \left[ \e^{sX} \right] \le \exp \left(\frac{s^2 (b-a)^2}{8} \right) .
\]

\textbf{Hoeffding's theorem:} Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ be independent with $a_i \le X_i \le b_i$ a.s. and $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$. Then \[
    \P\left( S_n - \E \left[ S_n \right] \ge t(\le -t) \right) \le \exp\left( - \frac{2t^2}{\sum_i (b_i-a_i)^2} \right)
\] for all $t > 0$.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 1]

front: Concentration of Binomial distribution (Okamoto and Chernoff)
back:
[latex]
Let $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$, where $X_i \sim \text{Bin}(1,p_i)$ are independent and set $p \defas \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n p_i$. Then, for any $\varepsilon > 0$,
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] If $p \ge \frac{1}{2}$, then $\P\left( S_n - np \ge \varepsilon n \right) \le \exp\left( -\frac{n\varepsilon^2}{2p(1-p)} \right) $.
    \item [(ii)] If $p\le \frac{1}{2}$, then $\P\left( S_n - np \le -\varepsilon n \right) \le \exp \left( - \frac{n\varepsilon^2}{2p(1-p)} \right) $.
    \item[(iii)] $\P\left( |S_n-np| \ge \varepsilon n \right) \le 2\exp \left( -2n\varepsilon^2 \right) $.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 1]

front: Bernstein's inequality (Concentration for [$]|X_i - \E X_i| \le c[/$]).
back:
[latex]
Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ be independent and $\left| X_i - \E \left[ X_i \right]  \right| \le c$ a.s., set $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$ and $\sigma^2 \defas \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \Var(X_i)$. Then, for $t > 0$, \[
    \P\left( S_n - \E \left[ S_n \right] \ge t (\le -t) \right) \le \exp \left( - \frac{t^2}{2\sigma^2n + \frac{2ct}{3}} \right) .
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 1]

front: Concentration for [$]0 \le X_i \le 1[/$] (Corollary to Bernstein).
back:
[latex]
Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ be independent and $0\le X_i \le 1$ a.s., set $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$. Then if $t > 0$ and $\varepsilon > 0$,
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\P\left( S_n - \E \left[ S_n \right] \ge t \right) \le \exp\left( - \frac{t^2}{2 \E \left[ S_n \right] + \frac{2t}{3}} \right) $,
    \item[(ii)] $\P\left( S_n - \E \left[ S_n \right] \ge \varepsilon \E \left[ S_n \right]  \right) \le \exp \left( - \frac{\varepsilon^2 \E \left[ S_n \right] }{2 + \frac{2\varepsilon}{3}} \right) $.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 1]

front: Definition backwards martingale.
back:
[latex]
Given $\sigma$-algebras $(\mathcal{F}_{-n})_{n\in \N_0}$ with $\mathcal{F}_{-n -1}\subset \mathcal{F}_{-n}$ for all $n\in \N_0$, an adapted sequence $(M_{-n})_{n\in \N_0}$ of integrable real random variables is called a \emph{backwards martingale} if \[
\E \left[M_{-n+1} \,\middle\vert\,\mathcal{F}_{-n} \right] = M_{-n} \quad \text{a.s.}
\] for all $n\in \N_0$. In that case, since $M_{-n} = \E \left[M_0 \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{-n}\right]$ for all $n\in \N_0$, $(M_{-n})$ is automatically uniformly integrable.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 4]

front: Backward martingale convergence.
back:
[latex]
Let $(M_{-n})$ be a backwards martingale. Then there exists an integrable random variable $M_{-\infty}$ such that \[
M_{-n} \tendsto{\text{a.s.}}  M_{-\infty} \quad \text{and} \quad M_{-n} \tendsto{L^1} M_{-\infty}.
\] Furthermore, if $\mathcal{F}_{-\infty} \defas \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \mathcal{F}_{-n}$, \[
M_{-\infty} = \E \left[M_{-n} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{-\infty}\right]
\] for all $n\in \N$.
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 4]

front: Proof of Kolmogorov's strong law using backwards martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_n)$ be integrable i.i.d. real random variables with $\mu \defas \E \left[ X_1 \right] $. Then \[
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n X_k \tendsto{} \mu \quad \text{a.s. and in $L^1$}.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B1, Page 4]

front: Quadratic variation of Brownian motion.
back:
[latex]
Let $B$ be a standard real Brownian motion. Then  \[
    QV_t^\pi(B) \tendsto{L^2} t
\] if $\delta(\pi)\to 0$, so in particular $\left<B \right> _t = t$ for all $t\ge 0$.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 1]

front: Brownian paths are almost surely of infinite variation on every interval.
back: [Probability B8.2, Page 1]

front: Brownian paths are almost surely nowhere Hoelder continuous of order [$]\gamma > 1/2[/$].
back: [Probability B8.2, Page 1]

front: Blumenthal's 0-1-law.
back:
[latex]
Let $B$ be a standard real Brownian motion. Let $\mathcal{F}_t \defas \sigma\left(\mathcal{F}_t^B \cup \mathcal{N}(\P)\right)$ (augmented natural filtration) and $\mathcal{F}_{t+} \defas \bigcap_{s>t}\mathcal{F}_s$. Then $\mathcal{F}_{0+}$ is trivial, that is, \[
    \P(A) \in \left\{ 0,1 \right\}, \quad A\in \mathcal{F}_{0+}.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 1]

front: Brownian motion is almoset surely surjective.
back: [Probability B8.2, Page 1]

front: Behaviour of Brownian motion around the origin (Corollary to Blumenthal).
back:
[latex]
Let $B$ be a standard real Brownian motion and $\varepsilon > 0$. Then with probability one, \[
\sup_{s< \varepsilon}B_s > 0 \quad \text{and} \quad \inf_{s < \varepsilon} B_s < 0.
\] In particular, $\inf \left\{ t> 0\colon B_t = 0 \right\} = 0$ a.s.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 1]

front: The usual conditions.
back:
[latex]
A filtration $(\mathcal{F}_t)$ on $(\Omega, \A, \P)$ satisfies the \emph{usual conditions} if it is right-continuous and $\mathcal{N}(\P)\subset \mathcal{F}_0$. If $(\mathcal{F}_t)$ is a filtrations, then \[
    \widetilde{\mathcal{F}}_t \defas \sigma \left( \mathcal{F}_{t+} \cup \mathcal{N}(\P) \right)
\] satisfies the usual conditions.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 2]

front: Definition progressively measurable and connection with measurable and adapted.
back:
[latex]
A stochastic process $(X_t)$ on $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ is \emph{progressively measurable (with respect to $(\mathcal{F}_t))$} if for all $t\ge 0$, \[
    [0,t] \times \Omega \to \R; \, (s, \omega) \mapsto X_s(\omega)
\] is $\B([0,t]) \otimes \mathcal{F}_t - \B(\R)$ measurable. In that case, $X$ is adapted and measurable.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 2]

front: Continuity criterion for progressive measurability.
back:
An adapted process with (left-)right-continuous paths is progressively measurable.


[Probability B8.2, Page 2]

front: First hitting times and two examples.
back:
[latex]
Let $X$ be an adapted stochastic process on $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \P)$ with respect to a filtration $(\mathcal{F})_t$ and $\Gamma \in \B(\R)$. Then \[
H_\Gamma \defas \inf\left\{ t\ge 0\colon X_t \in \Gamma \right\} \colon \Omega \to [0,\infty]
\] is called a \emph{first hitting time}.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] If $X$ has right-continuous paths and $\Gamma$ is open, then $H_\Gamma$ is a stopping time with respect to $(\mathcal{F}_{t+})$.
    \item[(ii)] If $X$ has continuous paths and $\Gamma$ is closed, then $H_\Gamma$ is a stopping time with respect to $(\mathcal{F}_t)$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 2]

front: Definition and connection between [$]\mathcal{F}_\tau[/$] and [$]\mathcal{F}_{\tau+}[/$] for a stopping time [$]\tau[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $\tau$ be a stopping time with respect to $(\mathcal{F}_t)$. Then define the $\sigma$-algebras
\begin{align*}
    \mathcal{F}_\tau &\defas \left\{ A\in \mathcal{F}\colon \forall t\ge 0\colon A \cap \left\{ \tau \le t \right\} \in \mathcal{F}_t \right\} ,\\
    \mathcal{F}_{\tau+} &\defas \left\{ A\in \mathcal{F}\colon \forall t\ge 0\colon A \cap \left\{ \tau < t \right\} \in \mathcal{F}_t \right\} \\
                        &= \left\{ A\in \mathcal{F}\colon \forall t\ge 0 \colon A\cap \left\{ \tau \le t \right\} \in \mathcal{F}_{t+} \right\} .
\end{align*}
Then $\tau$ is $\mathcal{F}_\tau$-measurable, $\mathcal{F}_{\tau}\subset \mathcal{F}_{\tau+}$ and if $(\mathcal{F}_t)$ is right-continuous, then $\mathcal{F}_\tau = \mathcal{F}_{\tau+}$. If $\tau \equiv t\ge 0$, then $\mathcal{F}_{\tau(+)}= \mathcal{F}_{t(+)}$.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 2]

front:
[latex]Let $\tau,\rho$ be stopping times.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\tau\wedge\rho$, $\tau\vee\rho$ and $\tau + \rho$ are stopping times,
    \item[(ii)] $\left\{ \tau \le \rho \right\} \in \mathcal{F}_{\tau \wedge \rho}$,
    \item[(iii)] If $\tau \le \rho$, then $\mathcal{F}_\tau \subset \mathcal{F}_\rho$.
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
back: [Probability B8.2, Page 2]

front: Stopped (pr.) measurable process is (pr.) measurable.
back:
[latex]
Let $\tau$ be a stopping time and $X$ (progressively) measurable. Then $(X_{t\wedge \tau})_{t\ge 0}$ is (progressively) measurable.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 3]

front: Sufficient condition for first hitting time [$]H_\Gamma[/$] to be a stopping time for all [$]\Gamma \in \B(\R)[/$].
back:
[$]X[/$] progressively measurable with respect to a filtration that satisfies the usual conditions.


[Probability B8.2, Page 3]

front: Strong markov property of Brownian motion.
back:
[latex]
Let $B$ be a standard Brownian motion on $(\Omega,\mathcal{F}, (\mathcal{F}_t), \P)$ and $\tau$ a stopping time. Then conditional on $\tau < \infty$, the process \[
    B^{(\tau)}_t \defas B_{\tau + t}- B_\tau, \quad t\ge 0
\] defines a standard Brownian motion independent of $\mathcal{F}_\tau$.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 3]

front: Reflection principle for Brownian motion.
back:
[latex]
Let $B$ be a standard Brownian motion and set $S_t \defas  \sup_{s\le t}B_s$. Then for $t\ge 0$ and $0 \le b \le a$, \[
    \P(S_t \ge a, B_t \le b) = \P(B_t \ge 2a - b).
\] In particular, $S_t$ and $|B_t|$ have the same distribution.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 3]

front: Occupation of bins: Upper bound.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_1,\ldots ,X_n) \sim \text{Mult} \left( n; \frac{1}{n},\ldots ,\frac{1}{n} \right) $ and set $Z_n \defas \max_{1\le k\le n} X_k$. Then \[
    \P\left( Z_n \le 2e \frac{\log n}{\log \log n} \right) \ge 1 - \frac{1}{e} \left( \frac{1}{n} \right) ^{e-1}
\] for all $n\ge 16$.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 2]

front: Poisson approximation.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_1,\ldots ,X_n) \sim \text{Mult}\left( m; p_1,\ldots ,p_n \right) $ and $Y_i \sim \text{Po}(mp_i)$ independent. Then the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\P\left( (Y_1,\ldots ,Y_n) \in \cdot \mid \sum_{i=1}^n Y_i = m \right) = \P\left( (X_1,\ldots ,X_n) \in \cdot  \right) $.
    \item[(ii)] If $f\colon (\N_0)^n \to [0,\infty)$, then  \[
            \E \left[ f(X_1,\ldots ,X_n) \right] \le \e \sqrt{m} \E \left[ f(Y_1,\ldots ,Y_n) \right] .
        \] In particular $\P\left( (X_1,\ldots ,X_n)\in \cdot  \right) \le \e \sqrt{m} \P\left( (Y_1,\ldots ,Y_n) \in \cdot  \right) $.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 2]

front: Occupation of bins: Lower bound.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_1,\ldots ,X_n) \sim \text{Mult} \left( n; \frac{1}{n},\ldots ,\frac{1}{n} \right) $ and set $Z_n \defas \max_{1\le k\le n} X_k$. Then \[
    \P\left( Z_n \ge \frac{\log n}{\log \log n} \right) \ge 1 - \frac{1}{n^2}
\] for almost all $n\in \N$.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 2]

front: Efron-Stein inequality, I
back:
[latex]
Let $X_i\colon \Omega\to \Gamma_i$ be independent random variables and $f\colon \bigtimes_{i=1}^n \Gamma_i \to \R$ measurable such that $Y\defas f(X_1,\ldots ,X_n)$ is square-integrable. Set $\mathcal{C}_i' \defas \sigma \left( X_j\colon j \neq i \right) $. Then \[
    \Var(Y) \le \sum_{i=1}^n \E \left[ \left( Y - \E \left[Y \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{C}_i'\right] \right) ^2 \right] .
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 2]

front: Efron-Stein inequality, II.
back:
[latex]
Let $X_i\colon \Omega\to \Gamma_i$ be independent random variables and $f\colon \bigtimes_{i=1}^n \Gamma_i \to \R$ measurable such that $Y\defas f(X_1,\ldots ,X_n)$ is square-integrable. Let $(X_1',\ldots ,X_n')$ be an independent copy and set $Y_i' \defas f(X_1,\ldots ,X_i',\ldots ,X_n)$. Then \[
    \Var(Y) \le \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^n \E \left[ (Y - Y_i')^2 \right] .
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 3]

front: Doobs maximal inequality for discrete supermartingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_n)$ be a supermartingale. Then for $n\in \N$ and $\lambda > 0$, \[
    \P\left( \max_{k\le n}|X_k| \ge \lambda \right) \le \frac{1}{\lambda} \left( \E \left[ X_0 \right] + 2 \E \left[ |X_n| \right]  \right) .
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B8.1, Page 4]

front: Doob's [$]L^p[/$]-inequality.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_n)$ be a martingale or a non-negative submartingale. Then for $n\in \N$ and $p > 1$, \[
    \E \left[ \max_{k\le n}|X_k|^p \right] \le \left( \frac{p}{p-1} \right) ^p \E \left[ \left| X_n \right| ^p \right] .
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B8.1, Page 4]

front: Martingales obtainable from an adapted process with independent increments. Specifically in the case of Brownian motion.
back:
[latex]
Let $(Z_t)$ be a process adapted to $(\mathcal{F}_t)$ such that $Z_t - Z_s$ is independent of $\mathcal{F}_s$ for $0\le s < t$. Then
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\widetilde{Z}_t \defas Z_t - \E \left[ Z_t \right] $ defines a martingale,
    \item[(ii)] If $Z$ is square-integrable, then $\widetilde{Z}_t^2 - \E \left[ \widetilde{Z}_t^2 \right] $ defines a martingale,
    \item[(iii)] If $\vartheta \in \R$ such that $\E \left[ \e^{\vartheta Z_t} \right] <\infty$ for all $t\ge 0$, then $\frac{\e^{\vartheta Z_t}}{\E \left[ \e^{\vartheta Z_t} \right] }$ defines a martingale.
\end{enumerate}

If $(B_t)$ is a Brownian motion, then $B_t$, $B_t^2 - t$ and $\e^{\vartheta B_t - \vartheta^2 t / 2}, \, \vartheta \in \R,$ define martingales.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 3]

front: Doob's (sub-)martingale inequalities in continuous time (for non-continuous processes)
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_t)$ be a martingale or a non-negative submartingale. Then for $T\ge 0$ and $\lambda > 0$,
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\displaystyle\forall p\ge 1\colon  \P\left( \sup_{t\in [0,T]\cap \Q} |X_t| \ge \lambda \right) \le \frac{1}{\lambda^p} \E \left[ \left| X_T \right| ^p \right] $,
    \item[(ii)] $\displaystyle \forall p > 1\colon  \E \left[ \sup_{t\in [0,T]\cap \Q} |X_t|^p \right] \le \left( \frac{p}{p-1} \right) ^p \E \left[ \left| X_T \right| ^p \right] $.
\end{enumerate}
In particular, $\sup_{t\in [0,T]\cap \Q}|X_t| < \infty$ a.s. for all $T\ge 0$.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 4]

front: Doob's maximal inequality for supermartingales in continuous time (as a consequence of the discrete version).
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_t)$ be a supermartingale. Then for $T\ge 0$ and $\lambda > 0$, \[
    \P\left( \sup_{t\in [0,T]\cap \Q}|X_t| \ge \lambda \right) \le \frac{1}{\lambda} \left( \E \left[ X_0 \right] + 2\E \left[ |X_T| \right]  \right) .
\] In particular, $\sup_{t\in [0,T]\cap \Q}|X_t| < \infty$ a.s. for all $T\ge 0$.
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 4]

front: Bound on [$]\P\left( \sup_{s\le t}B_s \ge \lambda t \right)[/$], respectively [$]\P\left( \left| \mathcal{N}(0,1) \right| \ge x \right)[/$].
back:
[latex]
If $t\ge 0$ and $\lambda > 0$, then \[
    \P\left( \sup_{s\le t}B_s \ge \lambda t \right) \le \e^{-\lambda^2 t / 2}.
\] Equivalently, for any $x\in \R$, \[
\P\left( \left| \mathcal{N}(0,1) \right| \ge x \right) \le \e^{-\frac{x^2}{2}}.
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B8.2, Page 4]

front: Gaussian Poincaré inequality
back:
[latex]
Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ and $f\colon \R^n\to \R$ continuously differentiable such that $\E \left[ f(X)^2 \right] <\infty$, where $X \defas (X_1,\ldots ,X_n)$. Then \[
    \Var(f(X))\le \E \left[ \left\|\nabla f(X)\right\|^2 \right] = \sum_{j=1}^n \E \left[ \partial_j f(X)^2 \right] .
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 3]

front: Variance bound for [$]f(X_1,\ldots,X_n)[/$] if [$]f[/$] has the BDP property.
back:
[latex]
Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ be independent and $Y=f(X_1,\ldots ,X_n)$ square-integrable with $f$ having the BDP for constants $c_1,\ldots ,c_n \ge 0$. Then \[
    \Var(Y) \le \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k=1}^n c_k^2.
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 3/4]

front:
Variance bound for [$]g_n(X_1,\ldots,X_n)[/$] if [$]g_n[/$] is a configuration function.
(Two examples)
back:
[latex]
Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ be $S$-valued and independent and $g_n\colon S^n \to \N_0$ a configuration function, $Y\defas g_n(X_1,\ldots ,X_n)$ square-integrable. Then \[
    \Var(Y) \le \E \left[ Y \right] .
\]

\textbf{Examples:}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)]  $g_n(x_1,\ldots ,x_n) = \left| \left\{ x_i\colon 1\le i\le n \right\}  \right| $. If $S = \N$ and $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ independent, then $\E \left[ Y_n \right] /n \longrightarrow 0$ and thus $\Var(Y) = o(n)$.
    \item[(ii)] $S=\R$ and $\text{inc} (x_1,\ldots ,x_n)$ longest increasing subsequence. Then if $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ independent and absolutely continuous, we have (literature) $\E \left[ \text{inc} (X_1,\ldots ,X_n \right] \sim 2\sqrt{n} $ and thus $\Var(\text{inc} (X_1,\ldots ,X_n)) = O(\sqrt{n} )$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 4]

front: McDiarmid's inequality (concentration for [$]f(X_1,\ldots,X_n)[/$] if [$]f[/$] has BDP).
back:
[latex]
Let $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ be indepentent and $Y=f(X_1,\ldots ,X_n)$ integrable, where $f$ has the BDP with constants $c_1,\ldots ,c_n \ge 0$. Then \[
    \P\left( \left| Y - \E \left[ Y \right]  \right| \ge t \right) \le 2 \exp \left( -\frac{2t^2}{\sum_{i=1}^n c_i^2} \right) .
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 4; Proof of simple version of Page 5]

front: Application of McDiarmid to random graphs.
back:
[latex]
For $n\in \N$ let $G[n] \defas \left\{ G = (V,E) ext{graph} \colon V = \left\{ 1,\ldots ,n ight\}  ight\} $ and for $p \in [0,1]$ let $G_{n,p}\colon \Omega o G[n]$ denote the Erdos-Renyi random graph.\

oindent extbf{Lemma.} Let $ inom{V}{2} = \sum_{j=1}^m B_j$ and $f\colon G[n] o \R$ such that $\left| f(G) - f(G') ight| \le 1$ whenever $E(G) \Delta E(G') \subset B_k$ for some $k\in \left\{ 1,\ldots ,m ight\} $. Then \[
    \P\left(\left| f(G_{n,p}) - \E \left[ f \left( G_{n,p} ight)  ight]  ight| \ge t ight) \le 2\exp \left( - rac{2t^2}{m} ight) .
\]

oindent extbf{Corollary.} Let $f\colon G[n] o \R$ such that $\left| f(G) - f(G') ight| \le 1$ whenever $G$ and $G'$ differ only by edges incident to a common vertex. Then \[
    \P\left( \left| f(G_{n,p})-\E \left[ f(G_{n,p}) ight]  ight| \ge t ight) \le 2\exp\left( - rac{2t^2}{n-1} ight) .
\]

oindent extbf{Example.} $f = \chi\colon G[n] o \N$ chromatic number.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 4]

front: Backwards (super-)submartingale convergence theorem.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_{-n})$ be a (super-)submartingale for which one of the two equivalent conditions hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $(X_{-n})$ is $L^1$-bounded.
    \item[(ii)] $\lim\limits_{n\to \infty} \E \left[ X_{-n} \right] $ exists.
\end{enumerate}
Then $(X_{-n})$ is uniformly bounded and there exists $X_{-\infty}\in L^1$ which is $\mathcal{F}_{-\infty} \defas \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \mathcal{F}_{-n}$-measurable and such that \[
    X_{-n} \tendsto{} X_{-\infty} \text{ almost surely and in $L^1$.}
\] Furthermore, \[
\E \left[X_{-n} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{-\infty}\right] \downarrow (\uparrow) \, X_{-\infty} \text{ almost surely and in $L^1$.}
\]
[/latex]


[Probability B8.1, Page 4/5]

front: Existence of [$]\lim\limits_{t\to \infty} X_t[/$] for *martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_t)$ be a (right-/left-)continuous *martingale such that $\sup\limits_{t\ge 0}\E \left[ X_t^- \right] <\infty$. Then $\lim\limits_{t\to \infty}X_t$ exists almost surely.
[/latex]


[Probability Theory B8.2, Page 4]

front: Existence of rational limits for *martingales.
back:
[latex]
Let $(X_t)$ be a *martingale. Then for $\P$-almost all $\omega\in \Omega$, \[
    \forall t > 0\colon \, \lim_{\substack{r\uparrow t \\ r\in \Q}} X_r(\omega) \text{ and } \lim_{\substack{r\downarrow t\\r\in \Q}}X_r(\omega) \text{ exist and are finite} .
\]
[/latex]


[Probability Theory B8.2, Page 4]

front: Regularisation theorem for *martingales (Existence of càdlàg modification of a *martingale).
back:
[latex]
If $(X_t)$ is a *martingale with respect to a filtration $(\mathcal{F}_t)$ that satisfies the usual conditions such that $t\mapsto \E \left[ X_t \right] $ is right-continuous, then $X$ admits a modification $\widetilde{X}$ which is also a $(\mathcal{F}_t)$-*martingale and has càdlàg paths.
[/latex]


[Probability Theory B8.2, Page 4]

front: Conditional Hoeffding inequality.
back:
[latex]
Let $Y$ be a random variable on $(\Omega, \A, \P)$, $\mathcal{F}\subset \mathcal{A}$ and $X$ a random variable such that
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $X \le Y \le X + c$ a.s. for some $c \ge 0$ and $\E \left[Y \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}\right] = 0$,
    \item[(ii)] $X$ is $\mathcal{F}$-measurable and $\E \left[ \e^{sX} \right] < \infty$ for all $s > 0$.
\end{enumerate}
Then \[
    \E \left[\e^{sY} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}\right]\le \exp \left( \frac{s^2 c^2}{8} \right)
\] almost surely for all $s > 0$.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 4]

front: Azuma-Hoeffding inequality (and its generalisation).
back:
[latex]
Let $\left\{ \varnothing, \Omega \right\} = \mathcal{F}_0 \subset \ldots \subset \mathcal{F}_n$ be a filtration, $(Z_i)$ be a predictable sequence and $c_i \ge 0$ such that either hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(1)] $X$ is an $\mathcal{F}_n$-measurable random variable such that $Z_i \le \E \left[X \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_i\right] \le Z_i + c_i$ almost surely,
    \item[(2)] $(D_i)$ is an $(\mathcal{F}_i)$-MDS with $Z_i \le D_i \le Z_i + c_i$ almost surely.
\end{enumerate}
Then for all $t > 0$, \[
    \P\left( \begin{cases}
        \left| X - \E \left[ X \right]  \right| \\
        \left| \sum_{i=1}^n D_i \right|
\end{cases} \ge t \right) \le 2 \exp \left( -\frac{2t^2}{\sum_{i=1}^n c_i^2} \right) .
\]

\textbf{Azuma-Hoeffding inequality:} Let $(D_i)$ be a $(\mathcal{F}_i)$-MDS with $\mathcal{F}_0 = \left\{ \varnothing, \Omega \right\} $ and $D_i \in [a_i,b_i]$ for all $i$ for some $a_i,b_i$. Then \[
    \P\left( \left| \sum_{i=1}^n D_i \right| \ge t \right) \le 2\exp \left( - \frac{2t^2}{\sum_{i=1}^n (b_i-a_i)^2} \right) .
\] One-sided versions hold in all cases.
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 5]

front: Definition (weighted) Hamming distance.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Gamma = \bigtimes_{i=1}^n \Gamma_i$ and $\alpha \in [0,\infty)^n$. Then for $x,y\in \Gamma$ and $A \subset \Gamma$ measurable set \[
    d_\alpha(x,y) \defas \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i \ind\left\{x_i \neq y_i\right\}, \qquad d_\alpha(x,A) \defas \inf_{y\in A} d_\alpha(x, y).
\] This is a pseudo-metric and a metric if $\alpha_i > 0$ for all $i$.\\
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 5]

front: Definition Talagrand-distance [$]d_T(x,A)[/$] and connection with [$]d_H(x,A)[/$].
back:
[latex]
Let $\Gamma = \bigtimes_{i=1}^n \Gamma_i$. Then for $x\in \Gamma$ and $A \subset \Gamma$ measurable set \[
    d_T(x,A) \defas \sup_{\left\|\alpha\right\|=1} d_\alpha(x,A).
\] Then \[
\frac{1}{\sqrt{n} } d_H(x,A) \le d_T(x,A) \le \sqrt{d_H(x,A)} \le d_H(x,A).
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 5]

front: Talagrand's theorem.
back:
[latex]
Let $\Gamma = \bigtimes_{i=1}^n \Gamma_i$, $X_1,\ldots ,X_n$ independent, and $A\subset \Gamma$ measurable. Then \[
    \P(X\in A) \P^\star(d_T(X,A) \ge t) \le \exp\left( -\frac{t^2}{4} \right) .
\]
[/latex]


[Probabilistic Combinatorics, Page 5]

front: Definition [$]c[/$]-configuration function and connection with configuration function of a hereditary property.
back:
[latex]
