\] Thus $\P(X \le \mu) > 0$, so there exists a colouring with $m\le \mu$ defects. Delete one vertex from each of them to obtain a good colouring of $K_{n-m}$, so $R(k,k) > n - m \ge n - \mu$.

For the explicit lower bound, take $n = \left\lfloor \e^{-1} k 2^{k / 2}\right\rfloor$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Let $S\subset \Z\setminus \left\{ 0 \right\} $. Then there exists a sum-free $A\subset S$ with $\left| A \right| >\, ?$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $S\subset \Z\setminus \left\{ 0 \right\} $. Then there exists a sum-free $A\subset S$ with $\left| A \right| > \left| S \right| / 3$.

\begin{proof}
    Suppose $S = \left\{ s_1,\ldots ,s_n \right\} $. Take $p\in \P$ of the form $p = 3k + 2$ and $p > 2 \max_i \left| s_i \right| $. Then $I \coloneqq \left\{ k+1,\ldots ,2k+1 \right\} $ is sum-free modulo $p$ (!). Take $r \sim \text{Unif}(\left\{ 1,\ldots ,p-1 \right\} )$ and put $A =  \left\{ s\in S\colon rs \in I \right\} $, so $A$ is always sum-free. Indeed, if $a+b=c$ in $A$, then $ra + rb = rc$ in $I$, a contradiction. Now \[
        \E \left[ \left| A \right|  \right] = \sum_{i=1}^n \P(rs_i \in I) = n \frac{|I|}{p-1} = n \frac{k+1}{3k+1} > \frac{n}{3},
    \] so $\P\left( \left| A \right| > n / 3 \right) > 0$, so there exists $A\subset S$ sum-free with $\left| A \right| > n / 3$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition colouring of a hypergraph and trivial upper bound on $m(r)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} A hypergraph $H$ is \emph{$k$-colourable} if there exists a $k$-colouring such that no edge of $H$ is monochromatic. Then \[
    m(r) \coloneqq \min \left\{ e(H)\colon  \text{$H$ is an $r$-uniform hypergraph that is not $2$-colourable} \right\} .
\] Since the complete $r$-uniform hypergraph on $2r$ vertices is not $2$-colourable, $m(r) \le \binom{2r}{r} \le 4^r$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]$2$-colourings of hypergraphs: Lower bound on $m(r)$[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} $m(r) \ge 2^{r-1}$ for all $r\ge 2$.

\begin{proof}
    Let $H$ be an $r$-uniform hypergraph with $e(H) < 2^{r-1}$, and colour every vertex blue and red with probability $1 / 2$ each, independently. Then for $e\in E(H)$, $\P(\text{$e$ is monochromatic}) = 2^{1-r}$, so \[
        \P(\exists \text{ monochromatic edge}) \le e(H) 2^{1-r}< 1,
    \] so there exists a good colouring of $H$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]$2$-colourings of hypergraphs: Strong upper bound on $m(r)$ (for large $r$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} $m(r) \le 3r^2 2^r$ for large $r\in \N$.

\begin{proof}
    Let $|V| = n \coloneqq  r^2$ and $H = (V,\left\{ e_1,\ldots ,e_m \right\} )$, where $e_i \sim \text{Unif}(\binom{V}{r} )$ i.i.d. Then $H$ is a random $r$-uniform hypergraph with at most $m$ edges. If $c$ is a fixed $2$-colouring of $V$, then \[
        \P(\text{$c$ is proper}) = \prod_{i=1}^m \P(\text{$e_i$ is not $c$-monochromatic}) = (1 - \P(\text{$e_1$ is $c$-monochromatic}))^m,
    \] and
    \begin{align*}
    \P(\text{$e_1$ is $c$-monochromatic})
    &\ge \binom{\left\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \right\rfloor }{r} / \binom{n}{r} = \frac{n / 2}{n} \frac{n / 2 - 1}{n - 1} \cdots \frac{n / 2 - r + 1}{n - r + 1} \\
    &\ge \left( \frac{n / 2 - r}{n - r} \right) ^r = 2^{-r} \left( 1 - \frac{r}{n-r} \right) ^r\\
    &= 2^{-r} \left( 1 - \frac{1}{r-1} \right) ^r \ge \frac{1}{3 \cdot 2^r} \eqqcolon p_0
\end{align*} for large $r$. Thus \[
\P\left( \text{$H$ is $2$-colourable} \right) \le 2^n (1-p_0)^m \le 2^{n} \e^{-m p_0} = 2^{r^2} \e^{-r^2}< 1,
    \] so there exists an $r$-uniform hypergraph with at most $m$ edges which is not $2$-colourable, so $m(r) \le m$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of tightness in $C([0,\infty),\R^d)$, special case of sequences.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $\mathcal{L}\subset M_1(C(\R^d))$. Then $\mathcal{L}$ is tight if and only if
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\sup_{P\in \mathcal{L}} P\left[ x\in C\colon \left| x(0) \right| \ge L \right] \tendsto{} 0 $ as $L \to \infty$ (that is, $(P^{\pi_0})_{P\in \mathcal{L}}$ is tight),
    \item[(ii)] For all $T > 0$ and $\lambda > 0$, $\sup_{P\in \mathcal{L}} \P\left[ x\in C\colon w_T(x,\delta) \ge \lambda \right] \tendsto{} 0$ as $\delta \to 0$.
\end{enumerate}
For a sequence $(X_n)$ of $C$-valued stochastic processes, this means that $(X_n(0))$ is tight and $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \P\left( w_T(X_n,\delta) \ge \lambda \right) \to 0$ as $\delta \to 0$ for all $T,\lambda > 0$.

\begin{proof}
    \textbf{\enquote{$\implies$}:} Let $\varepsilon>0$ and choose $K_\varepsilon \subset C$ compact with $P(K_\varepsilon) \ge 1 - \varepsilon$ for all $P\in \mathcal{L}$. Then there exists $\alpha > 0$ such that $\sup_{x\in K_\varepsilon} \left| x(0) \right| < \alpha$, so \[
        P\left[ x\in C\colon \left| x(0) \right| \le L \right] \ge P\left( K_\varepsilon  \right) \ge 1 - \varepsilon
    \] for all $L > \alpha$ and $P\in \mathcal{L}$. Now if $T,\lambda > 0$, there exists $\delta_0> 0$ such that $\sup_{x\in K_\varepsilon} w_T(x,\delta) < \lambda$ for all $0<\delta<\delta_0$, so that \[
    P\left[ x\in C\colon w_T(x,\delta) < \lambda \right] \ge P(K_\varepsilon) \ge 1 - \varepsilon
    \] for all such $\delta$ and $P\in \mathcal{L}$.

    \textbf{\enquote{$\impliedby$}:} Let $\varepsilon > 0$. Then choose $L > 0$ with \[
        P(B) = P\left[ x\in C\colon \left| x(0) \right| \le L \right] \ge 1 - \frac{\varepsilon}{2},
    \] and, for $n\in \N$, $\delta_n > 0$ with \[
    P(B_n) = P\left[ x\in C\colon  w_n(x,\delta) \le \frac{1}{n}\right] \ge 1 - \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{n+1}}
\] for all $0<\delta<\delta_n$ and $P\in \mathcal{L}$. Then $K_\varepsilon \coloneqq B \cap \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty B_n$ is relatively compact by Arzela-Ascoli and closed, and  \[
P(K^{c}) \le \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{n+1}} + \frac{\varepsilon}{2} = \varepsilon
\] for all $P\in \mathcal{L}$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of entropy number $\mathcal{N}(X,\varepsilon,T)$ (and $\delta(X,\varepsilon,T)$, and stopping times $(T_j)$) for continuous process $(X_t)$. Upper bound on $\P\left( w_T(X,\delta) > \varepsilon \right) $ in terms of $\delta(X,\varepsilon,T)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} Let $(X_t)$ be a $C(\R^d)$-valued stochastic process. Fix $\varepsilon > 0$. Define stopping times $T_0 \coloneqq 0$ and \[
    T_{j+1}\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t > T_j\colon \left| X(t) - X(T_j) \right| \ge \frac{\varepsilon}{4} \right\} , \quad j\in \N_0.
\] For $T > 0$, define
\begin{align*}
    \mathcal{N}(X,\varepsilon,T) &\coloneqq \sup \left\{ j\in \N\colon T_j \le T \right\} < \infty, \\
    \delta(X,\varepsilon,T) &\coloneqq \min \left\{ T_j - T_{j-1}\colon 1\le j \le \mathcal{N}(X,\varepsilon,T) \right\} > 0 ,
\end{align*} called the \emph{entropy number} and the \emph{minimal gap}, respectively.\\

\textbf{Lemma.} In this situation, we have $w_T(X,\delta(X,\varepsilon,T)) \le \varepsilon$ and thus \[
    \P\left( w_T(X,\delta) > \varepsilon  \right) \le \P\left( \delta(X,\varepsilon,T) < \delta \right)
\] for all $\delta > 0$.

\begin{proof}
    If $t,s\le T$ and $\left| t-s \right| < \delta(X,\varepsilon,T)$, then at most one $T_j$ lies between $s$ and $t$, and the variation on each interval $[T_{j-1},T_j]$ is bounded by $\varepsilon / 2$. In particular, $\delta \le \delta(X,\varepsilon,T)$ implies $w_T(X,\delta) \le w_T(X,\delta(X,\varepsilon,T)) \le \varepsilon$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Entropy: Bounds on $\E \left[ \ind_{\left\{ T_j - T_{j-1} \le \delta, T_{j-1}<\infty \right\} } \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}}\right]$ and $\P\left( \mathcal{N}(X,\varepsilon,T)\ge k \right) $ for continuous semimartingale $X$ (under suitable assumption).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} Suppose $X = X_0 + M + A$ is a $d$-dimensional continuous semimartingale such that there exists $C > 0$ with \[
    \left| \dd A_t \right| \le C\dd t,\quad \sum_{i,j}\left| \dd \left<M^i,M^j \right>   \right| \le C \dd t.
\] Then for any $\varepsilon > 0$, there exist constants $K > 0$ and $\alpha \in (0,1)$, depending only on $\varepsilon$ and $C$, such that the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] If $T_0 = 0, T_j = \inf \left\{ t > T_{j-1}\colon \left| X(t) - X(T_{j-1}) \right| \ge \varepsilon / 4 \right\} $, then \[
    \P \left(T_j - T_{j-1} \le \delta, T_{j-1} < \infty \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}}\right) \le K \delta
    \] for all $\delta > 0$.
\item[(ii)]  $\P \left( \mathcal{N}(X,\varepsilon,T) \ge k \right) \le \e^T \alpha ^k$ for any $T > 0$ and $k\in \N_0$.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Let $f \in C_c^\infty(\R^d,\R)$ non-negative with $f(x) = 1$ if $\left| x \right| = \varepsilon / 4$ and $f(0) = 0$. Applying Ito to $(X_{T_{j-1} + t} - X_{T_{j-1}})_{t\ge 0}$ on the probability space $\left\{ T_{j-1}< \infty \right\} $ yields
    \begin{equation*}
        f(X_{T_j \wedge (T_{j-1} + \delta)} - X_{T_{j-1}})
        = \int_{T_{j-1}}^{T_j \wedge (T_{j-1} + \delta)} \nabla f \dd X_s + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i,j} \int \nabla ^2 f \dd \left<M^i,M^j \right> _s
        \end{equation*} on $\left\{ T_{j-1} < \infty \right\} $, and so (since $M$ is a true martingale), \[
        \E \left[  \ind_{\left\{T_j - T_{j-1}< \delta, T_{j-1}< \infty\right\}} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}} \right] \le \E \left[f(X_{T_j \wedge (T_{j-1} + \delta)} - X_{T_{j-1}}) \ind_{\left\{T_{j-1}< \infty\right\}} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}} \right] \le K \delta,
    \] with $K$ depending on $C$ and $f$.
\item[(ii)] For $\beta > 0$ and $j\in \N$ we have
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[\e^{-(T_{j}-T_{j-1})} \ind_{\left\{ T_{j-1}< \infty \right\} } \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}}\right]
        &\le \e^{-\beta} + (1-\e^{-\beta}) \P \left(T_{j} - T_{j-1} \le \beta, T_{j-1}<\infty \,\middle\vert\,\mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}} \right) \\
        &\le \e^{-\beta} + (1-\e^{-\beta})K\beta \eqqcolon \alpha < 1
    \end{align*} if $ 0 < K\beta < 1 / 2$. Then \[
    \E \left[\e^{-T_j} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}}\right] = \E \left[\e^{-(T_j - T_{j-1})}\e^{T_j} \ind_{\left\{ T_{j-1} < \infty \right\} } \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{T_{j-1}}\right] \le \alpha \e^{-T_{j-1}}
    \] for all $j\in \N$, so $\E \left[ \e^{-T_j} \right] \le \alpha^j, \, j\in \N_0$. We conclude \[
    \P\left( \mathcal{N}(X,\varepsilon,T) \ge k \right) = \P\left( T_k \le T \right) \le \E \left[ \e^{T - T_k} \right] \le \e^T \alpha^k
    \] for $k\in \N$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Tightness criterion for sequence $(X^{(n)})$ of continuous semimartingales.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $(X^{(n)})$ be a sequence of $d$-dimensional continuous semimartingales such that $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \P\left( \left| X^{(n)}_0 \right| \ge L \right) \to 0$ as $L\to \infty$ and  \[
    \left| \dd A^{(n)}_t \right| \le C \dd t, \quad \sum_{i,j}\left| \dd \left<M^{(n)}_i, M^{(n)}_j \right>_t  \right|  \le C\dd t,\qquad n\in \N,
\] for some constant $C > 0$. Then $(X^{(n)})$ is tight.

\begin{proof}
    For $T > 0$, $\varepsilon> 0$, we have
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( w_T(X^{(n)},\delta) > \varepsilon \right)
        &\le \P\left( \delta(X^{(n)},\varepsilon,T) < \delta \right)\\
        &\le \P\left( \mathcal{N}(X^{(n)},\varepsilon,T) > k \right) + \P\left( \inf_{1\le j\le k} (T_j - T_{j-1}) < \delta \right) \\
        &\le \e^T \alpha^k + k K \delta
    \end{align*} Thus \[
    \limsup_{\delta \to 0} \sup_{n\in \N} \P\left( w_T(X^{(n)},\delta) \ge \varepsilon \right) \le \e^T \alpha^k \downarrow  0 \quad (k\to \infty)
    \] for all $k\in \N$, which finishes the proof.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of $\mathcal{P}_p(E)$ and Wasserstein metric $W_p$ for Polish space $E$, and characterisation of convergence in $W_p$ (without proof).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} Let $(E,\rho)$ be a Polish space and $p\ge 1$, and put \[
    \mathcal{P}_p(E) \coloneqq \left\{ P\in M_1(E)\colon \int_E \rho(x,y)^p P(\dd x) < \infty \text{ for all (any) $y\in E$} \right\} .
\] If $P,Q\in M_1(E)$, let $\Pi(P,Q) \subset M_1(E\times E)$ be the set of couplings of $P$ and $Q$. Then the Wasserstein metric on $\mathcal{P}_p(E)$ is defined by \[
W_p(P,Q) \coloneqq \left[ \inf_{\Theta \in \Pi(P,Q)} \int_{E\times E} \rho(x,y)^p \Theta(\dd x,\dd y) \right] ^{1 / p},\quad P,Q\in \mathcal{P}_p(E).
\]

\textbf{Fact.} If $P_n,P\in \mathcal{P}_p(E),\, n\in \N,$ then $W(P_n,P) \to 0$ if and only if $P_n(f) \to P(f)$ for all $f\in C(E)$ with \[
    \left| f(x)  \right| \le C \left( 1 + \rho(x,y)^p \right) ,\quad x\in E,
\] for some constant $C > 0$ and for any (thus all) $y\in E$. In particular, $P_n \to P$ weakly.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Dual representation of Wasserstein metric $W_1$ using Lipschitz functions (without proof).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $(E,\rho)$ is a Polish space, then \[
    W_1(P,Q) = \sup_{\substack{f\in \text{Lip}(E)\\ \left\|f\right\|_L \le 1}} \left( \int_E f \dd P - \int_E f \dd Q \right) ,\quad P,Q\in \mathcal{P}_1(E),
\] where $\left\|f\right\|_L = \inf \left\{ L > 0\colon \left| f(x) - f(y) \right| \le L\rho(x,y) \forall x,y\in E \right\} $ for a Lipschitz function $f\in C(E)$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Four equivalent conditions under which weak convergence implies $W_p$-convergence. Thus briefly put, what is the connection between weak and $W_p$-convergence?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} Suppose $(E,\rho)$ is a Polish space, $p\ge 1$ and $P_n,P\in \mathcal{P}_p(E),\,n\in \N,$ and $P_n\to P$ weakly. Then the following are equivalent.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] For some (all) $y\in E$, \[
            \int_E \rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x) \tendsto{}  \int_E \rho(x,y)^p P(\dd x),
        \]
    \item[(ii)] For some (all) $y\in E$, \[
            \limsup_{n\to \infty}\int_E \rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x) \le \int_E \rho(x,y)^p P(\dd x),
        \]
    \item[(iii)] For some (all) $y\in E$, \[
            \limsup_{n\to \infty} \int\limits_{\left\{ y\colon \rho(x,y) > R \right\} } \rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x) \tendsto{}  0 \quad (R\to \infty),
        \]
    \item[(iv)] $W_p(P_n,P) \tendsto{} 0$.
\end{enumerate}
Thus, convergence in $W_p$ is equivalent to weak convergence plus convergence of $p$'th moments.

\begin{proof}
    \textbf{\underline{(i)$\iff$(ii):}} We have $\rho(\cdot ,y)^p \in C(E)_+$, so $\liminf_{n\to \infty} \int \rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x) \ge \int \rho(x,y)^p P(\dd x)$ holds by $P_n \tendsto{d} P$.

\textbf{\underline{(ii)$\iff$(iii):}} We have $1 = \ind_{\left\{x\colon \rho(x,y) \le R\right\}} + \ind_{\left\{ x\colon \rho(x,y) > R \right\} }$, so by $P_n \tendsto{d} P$,
    \begin{align*}
    \limsup_{n\to \infty} \int \rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x) = \int\limits_{\left\{ \rho(x,y)\le R \right\} }\rho(x,y)^p P(\dd x) + \limsup_{n\to \infty} \int\limits_{\left\{ \rho(x,y) > R \right\} }\rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x).
    \end{align*}

    \textbf{\underline{$\exists \implies \forall $ in (iii):}} Suppose (iii) holds for $y\in E$. Let $z\in E$. Then \[
        \int\limits_{\left\{\rho(x,z) > R\right\} } \rho(x,z)^p P_n(\dd x) \le K \rho(y,z)^p P_n(\rho(x,z) > R) + K \int\limits_{\left\{\rho(x,y) > R - \rho(x,z)\right\} } \rho(x,y)^p P_n(\dd x),
    \] for some $K > 0$, and $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \text{RHS} \to 0$ as $R\to \infty$.

    \textbf{\underline{(iii)$\implies$(iv):}} Let $f\in C(E)$ with $\left| f(x) \right| \le C(1 + \rho(x,y)^p)$ for some $C > 0$ and $y\in E$, WLOG $f\ge 0$. Then \[
        \int f \dd P_n \le \int\limits_{\left\{ \rho(x,y) \le R \right\} } f(x) P_n(\dd x) + C\int\limits_{\left\{ \rho(x,y) > R \right\} } ( 1 + \rho(x,y)^p) P_n(\dd x)
    \] and $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \text{RHS} \tendsto{} \int f \dd P + 0$ as $R \to \infty$, so $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \int f \dd P_n \le \int f \dd P$, and $\liminf_{n\to \infty} \int f \dd P_n \ge \int f \dd P$ follows from weak convergence.

    \textbf{\underline{(iv)$\implies$(i):}} Clear.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Criterion for tightness of sequences $(P_n)\in \mathcal{P}_1(E)^\N$ involving the Wasserstein metric.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $(E,\rho)$ be a Polish space. Then any $W_1$-Cauchy sequence $(P_n)\in \mathcal{P}_1(E)^{\N}$ is tight.

\begin{proof}
    Let $\varepsilon > 0$. For $l\in \N$, there exists $n_l \in \N$ such that $W_1(P_n,P_m) \le \frac{\varepsilon}{l 2^{l+1}}$ for all $n,m\ge n_l$. Let $K_l \subset E$ be compact with $P_j(K_l) \ge 1 - \varepsilon / 2^{l+1}$ for $j\le n_l$. $K_l$ is totally bounded, so let $G_l$ be a cover of $K_l$ with $1 / l$-balls, and let $U_l = \left\{ \rho(\cdot ,G_l) < \frac{1}{l} \right\} $. Define \[
        \phi_l \coloneqq 0 \vee \left( 1 - l\rho(\cdot ,G_l) \right) ,
    \] so that $\left\|\phi_l\right\|_L \le l$ and $ \ind_{G_l}\le \phi_l \le \ind_{U_l}$. Then for $n > n_l$,
    \begin{equation*}
        P_n(U_l) \ge \int \phi_l \dd P_n \ge \int \phi_l \dd P_{n_l} - \left\|\phi_l\right\|_L W_1(P_n,P_{n_l}) \ge P_{n_l}(G_l) - l \frac{\varepsilon}{l 2^{l+1}} \ge 1 - \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{l}},
        \end{equation*} and the same holds for $n\le n_l$ by assumption, so with $A \coloneqq \bigcap_{l=1}^\infty U_l$ totally bounded ($U_l$ is $2 / l$-coverable), so relatively compact, we have \[
    P_n(A^{c}) \le \sum_{l=1}^\infty \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{l}} = \varepsilon,\quad n\in \N.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $P_n \tendsto{d} P$ on a metric space $S$ and $f\in C(S)_+$, then $\int f \dd P \le \liminf \int f \dd P_n$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $S$ be a metric space and $P_n \tendsto{d} P$ on $S$. Then for all non-negative $f\in C(S)$ we have \[
\int f \dd P \le \liminf_{n\to \infty} \int f\dd P_n.
\]

\begin{proof}
    For any $R > 0$, we have \[
        \int (f\wedge R) \dd P = \lim_{n\to \infty} \int (f\wedge R) \dd P_n \le \liminf_{n\to \infty} \int f \dd P_n,
    \] and LHS converges to $\int f \dd P$ as $R \to \infty$ by MCT.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Expected number of $r$-cycles in $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$.[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
\textbf{Claim.} $\displaystyle \E \left[ \#\text{cycles} \right] = \frac{n!}{2r (n-r)!}p^r$.

\begin{proof}
    The number of $r$-tuples of vertices with no duplicates is $r! \binom{n}{r} $, and every cycle corresponds to exactly $2r$ such tuples (freedom in direction and starting vertex), so number of cycles is that number divided by $2r$, so \[
        \E \left[ \#\text{cycles} \right] = \sum_{\text{cycles } C} \P\left( C \subset E(G) \right) = \frac{n!}{2r(n-r)!} p^r.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front: There exist graphs with arbitrarily large girth and chromatic number.
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $k,l\ge 1$. Then there exists a graph $G$ with $g(G) \ge l$ and $\chi(G) \ge k$.

\begin{proof}
    WLOG $k,l\ge 3$. For $n\in \N$ put $p = p(n) = n ^{1 / l - 1} \in [0,1]$. Then let $X$ be the number of cycles in $G\sim \mathcal{G}(n,p)$ of length less than $l$. Then \[
        \E \left[ X \right] = \sum_{r=3}^{l-1} \frac{n(n-1)\cdot \ldots \cdot (n-r+1)}{2r} p^r \le \sum_{r=3}^{l-1} (np)^r = O((np)^{l-1}) = O(n^{1 - 1/l}) = o(n),
        \] so $\P\left( X \ge n / 2 \right) \le 2 \E \left[ X  \right] / n \to 0$. Now let $m = m(n) = \left\lfloor  n^{1 - 1 / (2l)} \right\rfloor$ and $Y$ the number of independent sets of size $m$ in $G$, so \[
    \E \left[ Y \right] = \binom{n}{m} (1-p)^{\binom{m}{2} } \le \left( \frac{\e n}{m} \right) ^m \e^{-p \binom{m}{2} } = \left( \frac{\e n}{m} \e^{-p(m-1) / 2} \right) ^m \tendsto{} 0
\] because $mp \sim n^{1 / l - 1} n^{1 - 1 / (2l)} = n^{1 / (2l)}$. Thus $\P(Y\ge 1) = \P(\alpha(G) \ge m) \to 0$, so \[
\P(\alpha(G) < m \text{ and } X < n / 2)  \tendsto{} 1,
\] so there exists $G$ with arbitrarily large $n$, fewer than $n / 2$ short cycles and $\alpha(G) < m$. Delete one vertex from each short cycle to obtain $G'$ with no short cycles, so $g(G') \ge l$, and \[
\chi(G') \ge \frac{\left| G' \right| }{\alpha(G')} \ge \frac{n}{2 \alpha(G)} \ge \frac{n^{1 / (2l)}}{2} > k.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Lower bound on $\P(X\neq 0)$ involving $\E \left[ X \right] $ and $\E \left[ X^2 \right] $ for real random variable $X$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
extbf{Lemma.} If $X$ is a real random variable, then  \[
    \P(X eq 0) \ge rac{\E \left[ X ight]^2 }{\E \left[ X^2 ight]},
\] that is, $\E \left[ X ight] ^2 \le \P(X eq 0) \E \left[ X^2 ight] $.

egin{proof}
    We have $\E \left[ X ight]^2 = \P(X eq 0)^2 \E \left[X \,\middle\vert\, X eq 0 ight]^2 $ and \[
        \E \left[X \,\middle\vert\, X eq 0 ight]^2 \le \E \left[X^2 \,\middle\vert\, X eq 0 ight] = rac{\E \left[ X^2 \,\ind\!\left\{X eq 0 ight\} ight] }{\P(X eq 0)} = rac{\E \left[ X^2 ight] }{\P(X eq 0)}.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Condition under which $\P(X_n > 0) \tendsto{} 1$ for counting random variables $(X_n)$ (involving only variance and expectation).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $(X_n)$ are counting random variables with $\V(X_n) = o(\mu_n^2)$, then $\P(X_n = 0) \tendsto{} 0$. In fact, \[
    \P\left( (1-\varepsilon)\mu_n < X_n < (1+\varepsilon) \mu_n \right) \tendsto{} 1,\quad n\to \infty,
\] for all $\varepsilon > 0$. An equivalent condition is $\E \left[ X_n^2 \right] \sim \mu_n^2$ (that is, $\E \left[ X_n^2 \right] = (1+o(1)) \mu_n^2$).

\begin{proof}
    By Cheybysheff, \[
        \P\left( \left| X_n - \mu_n \right| \ge \varepsilon \mu_n \right) \le \frac{\V(X_n)}{\varepsilon^2 \mu_n^2} \tendsto{} 0.  
    \] Equivalence of the conditions follows from $\V(X_n) = \E \left[ X_n^2 \right]  - \mu_n^2 \in o(\mu_n^2)$ iff $\V(X_n) / \mu_n^2 = \E \left[ X_n^2 \right] / \mu_n^2 - 1 \tendsto{} 0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of threshold function (for $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $\mathcal{P}$ is a graph property, then $p^*(n)$ is called a \emph{threshold function for $\mathcal{P}$ (in the model $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$)} if
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $p(n) / p^*(n) \to 0$ implies $\P(\text{$\mathcal{G}(n,p(n))$ has property $\mathcal{P}$}) \to 0$,
    \item[(ii)] $p(n) / p^*(n) \to \infty$ implies $\P(\text{$\mathcal{G}(n,p(n))$ has property $\mathcal{P}$}) \to 1$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Threshold function for $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$ to contain a $K_4$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} $p^*(n) = n^{-2 / 3}$ is a threshold function for $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$ to contain a $K_4$.

\begin{proof}
    Let $X$ be the number of $K_4$'s in $G \sim \mathcal{G}(n,p)$, so that \[
        \mu = \binom{n}{4} p^6 \sim \frac{n^4}{4!} p^6 = \frac{(n^{2 / 3}p)^6}{4!},
    \] which already finishes the first part by Markov. Now if $n^{2 / 3}p \to \infty$, then
    \begin{align*}
    \E \left[ X^2 \right] &= \sum_{S,T \in \binom{V}{4} } \P(S,T\subset E(G)) = \sum_{k=0}^4 \sum_{\left| S\cap T \right| = k} \P(S,T\subset E(G))\\
                          &= \underbrace{\mu + \sum_{k=1}^3(\ldots )}_{= o(\mu^2)} + \underbrace{\binom{n}{4} \binom{n-4}{4} p^{12}}_{\sim\mu^2} \sim \mu^2,
\end{align*} so $\P(X > 0) \tendsto{} 1$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Condition on counting random variables $X = \sum_{i} \ind_{A_i}$ to satisfy $\V(X) = o(\mu^2)$, and thus $\P(X > 0) \to 1$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $\mu \to \infty$ and $\Delta \coloneqq \sum_i \sum_{j\sim i}\P(A_i\cap A_j) = o(\mu^2)$, then $\V(X) = o(\mu^2)$, in particular $\P(X > 0) \tendsto{} 1$. Here $i\sim j \iff i\neq j$ and $A_i$ and $A_j$ are independent.

\begin{proof}
    We have
    \begin{align*}
        \V(X)
        &= \sum_{i,j} \Cov \left( \ind_{A_i}, \ind_{A_j} \right) \\
        &= \sum_i \left( \P(A_i) - \P(A_i)^2 \right) + \sum_i \sum_{j\sim i} \left( \P(A_i \cap A_j) - \P(A_i) \P(A_j) \right) \\
        &\le \sum_i \P(A_i) + \Delta = \mu + \Delta.
    \end{align*}
    Thus, $\V(X) / \mu^2 = 1 / \mu + \Delta / \mu^2 \to 0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition ((uniformly) elliptic) second order differential operator and maximum principle.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} A \emph{second order differential operator} is of the form \[
    L u = \sum_{i,j=1}^d a_{ij}(\cdot ) \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} + \sum_{i=1}^d b_i(\cdot ) \frac{\partial u}{\partial x_i} - c(\cdot ) u.
\] It is called \emph{elliptic} if $A(x) \coloneqq \left( a_{ij}(x) \right) _{i,j=1}^d$ is positive definite for all $x\in \R^d$, so, putting $\mu(x) \coloneqq \min_{\left\|z\right\|=1}z^\top A(x) z > 0$, \[
    z^\top A(x) z \ge \mu(x) \left\|z\right\|^2
\] for all $z\in \R^d$. It is called \emph{uniformly elliptic} if $\mu \coloneqq \inf_{x\in \R^d} \mu(x) > 0$, so if the above holds with a uniform $\mu > 0$.\\

\textbf{Lemma.} If $L$ is elliptic with $c(\cdot ) \ge 0$ and $Lu \ge 0$ on some domain $E\subset \R^d$, and $u$ takes a non-negative maximum in the interior of $E$, then $u$ is constant on $E$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Number of copies of a graph $H$ in $K_n$, thus expected number of copies in $G(n,p)$ and suggested threshold function. Why is this not the correct threshold function in general?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Denote by $\text{aut}(H)$ the number of automorphisms of $H$ (f.ex. $\text{aut}(C_n) = 2n$). Then the number of copies is $\frac{n(n-1)\cdot \ldots \cdot (n-v+1)}{\text{aut}(H)}$. Thus \[
    \E \left[ X \right] = \frac{n(n-1)\cdot \ldots \cdot (n-v+1)}{\text{aut}(H)}p^e = \Theta(n^vp^e).
\] However $p^*(n) = n^{-v / e}$ is not a threshold function in general. For $H$ a $K_4$ plus one edge we have $n^{- 5 / 7} \ll n^{- 2/3}$, but $H$ can only appear if $K_4$ appears. The problem is that in the regime between, it is extremely unlikely that $K_4$ appears, but if it does, then a shitton of copies of $H$ are there, so the expectation explodes even still.

\begin{proof}
    Every injection $\phi \colon V(H) \to [n]$ (so any labelled $v$-element subset) is a copy of $H$, and for every copy there exist exaclty $\text{aut}(H)$ injections (injections for fixed copy $H'$ are precisely automorphisms from $H$ to $H'$, of which there are $\text{aut}(H)$).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition edge density of a graph, and (strictly) balanced graphs.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} For a graph $H$, the \emph{edge density} is $d(H) \coloneqq \frac{e(H)}{\left| H \right| }$, which is just half the average degree. $H$ is called \emph{balanced} if $d(H') \le d(H)$ for all $H' \le H$, and \emph{strictly balanced} if $d(H') < d(H)$ for all $H' < H$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Threshold function for a copy of a balanced graph $H$ to appear in $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$. What if $H$ is not balanced?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $H$ be a fixed, balanced graph. Then $p^*(n) = n^{-v / e} = n^{-1/d(H)}$ is a threshold function for a copy of $H$ to appear in $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$.\\

\textbf{Remark.} For general $H$, the threshold function is $p^*(n) = n^{-1/d(H')}$ with $H'$ the densest subgraph of $H$, essentially by the same proof.

\begin{proof}
    Let $G\sim \mathcal{G}(n,p)$, and $X$ the number of copies of $H$ in $G$. Then we already know that $\mu \coloneqq \E \left[ X \right] = \Theta(n^vp^e)$. Thus if $p / p^* \to 0$, we are done by Markov. Now assume that $p / p^* \to \infty$, so $\mu \to \infty$. Denote by $A_i$ the event that the $i$'th copy $H_i$ of $H$ in $K_n$ appears in $G$, and put $\Delta \coloneqq \sum_i \sum_{j\sim i}\P(A_i\cap A_j)$, so that we have to show $\Delta = o(\mu^2)$. Then $\P(A_i\cap A_j) = p^{e(H_i\cup H_j)}$, so \[
    \Delta = \sum_{r=2}^v \sum_{s=1}^e N_{r,s} p^{2e - s} = \sum_{r,s} \Delta_{rs},
\] where $N_{rs}$ is the number of pairs $(i,j)$ such that $\left| H_i\cap H_j \right| = v$ and $e(H_i\cap H_j) = s$. Given $V(H_1\cup H_2)$, there is only a finite (independent of $n$) number of ways to place to copies of $H$ in there (say $|V|^{v} \cdot |V|^v$), so $N_{rs} = O(n^{2v - r})$, so \[
\Delta_{rs} = O\left(\frac{\mu^2}{n^rp^s}\right) = o(\mu^2),
\] because $s / r \le e / v$ by balancedness, so $n^rp^s \ge n^r p^{e r / v}= (n^v p^e)^{r / v} \to \infty$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front:
Unique solution to martingale problem [$](A,x)[/$] if [$]E[/$] is separable and compact and [$]\bar{A}[/$] is a Markov generator.

Uniqueness.
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} If $E$ is separable and complete and $A$ is a Markov pregenerator on $C(E)$ such that $\overline{A}$ is a Markov generator, then the unique solutions $(\P^x)_{x\in E}$ to the martingale problem $(A,x)$ for $x\in E$ are given by the unique Feller process associated with $\overline{A}$.

\begin{proof}
    \emph{Uniqueness}. Suppose $X$ is a solution to $(A,x)$, and thus (!) to $(\overline{A},x)$. Let $g\in C(E)$, $\lambda > 0$ and $f\in D(\overline{A})$ with $(\lambda - \overline{A})f = g$. Then, \[
        \E \left[f(X_t) - \int_r^t \overline{A} f(X_s) \dd s \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_r\right] = f(X_r),\quad 0\le r\le t.
    \] Applying $\int_r^\infty \lambda \e^{-\lambda t} \, \cdot \, \dd t$ to both sides yields \[
\int_r^\infty \e^{-\lambda t} \E \left[g(X_t)\,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_r\right] \dd t  = \e^{-\lambda r} f(X_r).
\] Putting $r=0$ fixes the Laplace transform of $t\mapsto \E \left[ g(X_t) \right] $ for all $g\in C(E)$ and thus the one-dimensional distributions of $(X_t)$. Now let $n\in \N$ and $h_i \in C(E)$, $\lambda_i \ge 0$. Then
\begin{multline*}
\int_0^\infty \dd s_1 \int_{s_1}^\infty \dd s_2 \ldots \int_{s_n}^\infty \dd s_{n+1} \exp \left( -\sum_{i=1}^{n+1}\lambda_i s_i \right) \E \left[ \prod_{i=1}^{n+1}h_i(X_{s_i}) \right] \\
= \int_0^\infty \dd s_1 \ldots \int_{s_{n-1}}^\infty \dd s_n \exp \left( -\sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i s_i - \lambda_{n+1}s_n \right) \E \left[ h_{n+1}(X_{s_n}) \prod_{i=1}^n h_i(X_{s_i}) \right] ,
\end{multline*}
which fixes all fidis by induction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]


[Also Stochastic Analysis and PDEs, Page 5]

front: When can integration and differentiation be exchanged?
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose $(\Omega,\A,\mu)$ is a measure space, $O\subset \R$ is open, and $f\colon O \times \Omega \to \R$ is measurable such that
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $f(x,\cdot )$ is integrable for all $x\in O$,
    \item[(ii)] $f(\cdot ,\omega)$ is differentiable for $\mu$-almost all $\omega\in \Omega$,
    \item[(iii)] There is $g \in L^1(\mu)$ such that $\left| \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,\cdot ) \right| \le g$ $\mu$-a.e.
\end{enumerate}
Then, \[
    \frac{\dd }{\dd x} \int_\Omega f(x,\omega) \mu(\dd \omega) = \int_\Omega \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,\omega) \mu(\dd \omega).
\]
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of dependency digraph and Lovász local lemma [/latex]
back:
[latex]
extbf{Definition.} Let $A_1,\ldots ,A_n$ be events in a probability space $(\Omega, \A, \P)$. Then a \emph{dependency digraph} for $(A_i)$ is a directed graph on $[n]$ such that $A_i \indep (A_j\colon i ot o j)$ for every $i\in [n]$.\

extbf{Theorem (local lemma).} If $A_1,\ldots ,A_n$ are events with given dependency digraph, and there are $x_i \in [0,1)$ such that \[
    \P(A_i) \le x_i \prod_{j\colon i o j} (1-x_j),\quad i\in [n],
\] then $\P\left( igcap_{i=1}^n A_i^{c} ight) \ge \prod_{i=1}^n (1-x_i) > 0$.
egin{proof}
    Claim that for any $S \subset [n]$, and $i\in [n]$ it holds that $\P\left( igcap_{j\in S} A_j^{c} ight) > 0$ and \[
        \P \left(A_i \,\middle\vert\, igcap_{j\in S} A_j^{c} ight) \le x_i,
        \] which implies the claim with $S = [n]$. The case where $\left| S ight| =0$ is trivial. Now consider general $i,S$ (wlog $i ot\in S$), then by induction hypothesis \[
        \P\left( igcap_{j\in S} A_j ^{c} ight) = \prod_{j\in S} \P\left( A_j^{c} \,\middle\vert\, igcap_{S i l < j} A_l^{c} ight) \ge \prod_{j\in S} (1- x_j) > 0,
        \] and put $B \coloneqq igcap_{\substack{j\in S\ i o j}} A_j^{c}$, $C \coloneqq igcap_{\substack{j\in S \ i ot o j} } A_j^{c}  $. Then, \[
\P \left(B \,\middle\vert\, C ight) = \prod_{\substack{j\in S \ i o j}} \P \left( A_j^{c}\,\middle\vert\, C\cap igcap_{l<j} A_l^{c} ight) \ge \prod_{j\colon j o i} (1-x_j).
\] Thus \[
    \P \left(A_i \,\middle\vert\, B\cap C ight) = rac{\P \left(A_i \cap B \,\middle\vert\, C ight)}{\P \left(B \,\middle\vert\, C ight)} \le rac{\P \left(A_i \,\middle\vert\, C ight)}{\P \left(B \,\middle\vert\, C ight)} = rac{\P(A_i)}{\P \left(B \,\middle\vert\, C ight)} \le x_i.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Natural dependency digraph in the case where $A_1,\ldots ,A_n \in \sigma\left( X_\alpha\colon \alpha \in J \right) $, with $(X_\alpha)_{\alpha \in J}$ an independent family of random variables.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Fact.} If $(X_\alpha)_{\alpha \in J}$ is a family of independent random variables, and $A_i \in \sigma\left( X_\alpha \colon \alpha \in F_i \right)$ for $i\in [n]$, then putting $i\leftrightarrow j$ if $F_i \cap F_j \neq \varnothing$ and $i\neq j$ gives a (symmetric) dependency digraph.

\begin{proof}
    For $i\in [n]$, we have \[
        A_i \in \sigma\left( X_\alpha\colon \alpha \in F_i \right) \indep \sigma \left( X_\alpha\colon \alpha \in \bigcup_{j\colon i\to j} F_j \right) \supset \sigma\left( A_j\colon i\to j \right).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: Symmetric version of Lovász local lemma.
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma (Local lemma, symmetric version).} If $A_1,\ldots ,A_n$ and a dependency digraph are given, and \[
    \P(A_i) \le \frac{1}{\e (d+1)}, \quad i\in [n],
\] where $d = \max_{i\in [n]} \text{deg}(i)$, then $\P\left( \bigcap_{i=1} ^n A_i ^{c} \right) > 0$.
\begin{proof}
    Put $p = \max_i \P(A_i)$, and $x_i = \frac{1}{d+1}$ for all $i$ (note that this maximizes $x_i(1-x_i)^{d}$). Then \[
        x_i \prod_{j\colon i\to j} (1-x_i) \ge \frac{1}{d+1}\left( \frac{d}{d+1} \right) ^d \ge \frac{1}{\e (d+1)} \ge p \ge \P(A_i),\quad i\in [n],
    \] so the local lemma applies.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Remark.} This can't be true without the $\e$, just take $\sum_{i=1}^{d+1}A_i = \Omega$ and $\P(A_i) = \frac{1}{d+1}$ for all $i$, then $\P\left( \bigcap_{i=1} ^{d+1}A_i^{c} \right) = 0$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Condition for $2$-colourability of $r$-uniform hypergraph (by Local lemma).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $H$ be an $r$-uniform hypergraph such that every edge meets at most $d$ other edges, and $\e (d+1) \le 2^{r-1}$. Then $H$ is $2$-colourable.
\begin{proof}
    Colour vertices randomly and build a dependency digraph for the events $A_e \coloneqq \left\{ \text{$e$ is monochromatic} \right\} ,\,e\in E(H),$ by $A_e \leftrightarrow A_f$ iff $e\cap f\neq \varnothing$. Then every event has at most $d$ neighbours, and $\P(A_e) \eqqcolon p = 2^{1-r}$ for all $e\in E$. The symmetric version of the local lemma gives $\P\left( \bigcap_{e\in E} A_e^{c} \right)  > 0$, so there exists a good colouring.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Lower bound on Ramsey-number $R(k,k)$ by Local lemma.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} For $n,k\ge 3$, if $\e \binom{k}{2} \binom{n}{k-2} 2^{1-\binom{k}{2} }\le 1$, then $R(k,k) > n$.
\begin{proof}
    Have to show that there exists a good colouring of $K_n$. Consider a random colouring of, and consider events $A_S \coloneqq \left\{\text{$S$ is monochromatic}\right\} $ for $S\in V^{(k)} $. Build a dependency digraph by joining $A_S \leftrightarrow A_T$ iff they share an edge, so if $\left| S\cap T \right| \ge 2$. Thus, every $A_S$ has at most, roughly, $d \coloneqq \binom{k}{2} \binom{n}{k-2} - 1$ neighbours, and $p \coloneqq \P(A_S) = 2^{1-\binom{k}{2} }$. Then, by assumption, $\e (d+1) p \le 1$, so $\P\left( \bigcap_{S} A_S^{c} \right) > 0$ by the Local lemma.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Corollary.} $R(k,k) \ge \sqrt{2} \frac{k}{\e} 2^{k / 2} (1 + o(1))$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition $D(S)$ for metric space $S$, modulus of continuity $\omega_D$, and connection with ordinary modulus of continuity.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} Let $(S,d)$ be a metric space, and denote by $D(S)$ the space of c\`adl\`ag paths from $[0,\infty$ to $S$. Then, if $\delta ,T > 0$, and $x\colon [0,\infty)\to S$, define \[
    \omega_D (x,\delta,T) \coloneqq \inf_{(t_i) \text{ $\delta$-thin}} \max_{j=1,\ldots ,k} \omega\left( x, [t_{j-1},t_j) \right) ,
\] where the infimum is taken over all finite partitions $0 = t_0 < t_1 < \ldots < t_k = T$ with $t_j - t_{j-1} > \delta$ for all $1\le j\le k-1$ (no restriction on $\left| T - t_{k-1} \right| $).\\

\textbf{Lemma.} For $\delta,T > 0$, and any $x\colon [0,\infty) \to S$, we have \[
    \omega_D(x,\delta,T) \le \omega (x,2\delta,T),
\] where $2$ may be replaced by any constant larger than one. If $x\in D(S)$, we also have \[
    \omega(x,\delta,T) \le 2 \omega_D(x,\delta,T) + j(x,T),
\] where $j(x,T) \coloneqq \sup_{t\le T} d(x(t),x(t-))$ is the maximum jump size of $x$ on $[0,T]$.
\begin{proof}
    Take any finite partition of $[0,T]$ with $\left| t_j - t_{j-1} \right| \in (\delta,2\delta)$ for all $j\le k-1$, and $\left| t_{k-1}-T \right| < 2\delta$. Then
    \begin{equation*}
        \omega_D(x,\delta,T) \le \max_{j\le k} \omega(x,[ t_{j-1},t_j)) \le \omega(x,2\delta,T).
    \end{equation*}
    For the second claim, note that for any $\delta$-thin partition $(t_j)$, and any $0\le s,t\le T$ with $\left| s - t \right| < \delta$, we have at most one of the $t_j$ in $[s,t]$, in which case
    \begin{align*}
        d(x(s),x(t))
        &\le d(x(s),x(t_j-)) + d(x(t_j-),x(t_j)) + d(x(t_j),x(t)) \\
        &\le 2 \max_{j\le k} \omega(x,[t_{j-1}, t_j)) + j(x,T).
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $x\in D(\R_+,S)$, then $\omega_D(x,\delta,T) \to 0$ as $\delta \to 0$. When does the converse hold? Corollary on local boundedness, measurability, and number of discontinuities of c\`adl\`ag paths.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $x\in D(\R_+,S)$ and $T > 0$, then $\omega_D(x,\delta,T) \tendsto{} 0$ as $\delta \to 0$. If $S$ is complete, the converse holds.
\begin{proof}
    Let $\varepsilon > 0$. Denote by $\tau \le T$ be the supremum of all $t\in [0,T]$ for which there exists a finite partition $0 = t_0 < \ldots < t_k = \tau$ with $\omega(x,[t_{j-1},t_j)) < \varepsilon$ for all $j\le k$. Then $\tau > 0$ by right-continuity of $x$. Next, observe that $\tau$ is, in face, a maximum. Indeed, we find $\tau' < \tau$ with oscillation at most $\varepsilon$ on $[\tau',\tau)$ (because left-limits exist), and thus obtain a valid partition $0 = t_0 < \ldots < t_k = \tau' < \tau$. Now assume that $\tau < T$. Then we can extend a valid partition of $[0,\tau]$ to $[0,\tau'']$ for some $\tau'' \in (\tau,T]$ by right-continuity of $x$, a contradiction.

    Now assume that $S$ is complete, and $x\colon [0,\infty) \to S$ satisfies $\omega_D(x,\delta,T) \to 0$ as $\delta \to 0$. Fix $t\in [0,T)$ and let $\varepsilon > 0$. Then the existence of a valid partition implies that $x$ oscillates by at most $\varepsilon$ on some interval $[t,t+\delta')$. For left-continuity, take $t\in (0,T]$ any $t_n \uparrow t$. Then for any $\varepsilon > 0$, there exists $\delta'$ such that $x$ oscillates by at most $\varepsilon$ on $(t-\delta,t)$, so $(x(t_n))$ is a Cauchy-sequence.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Corollary.} $x\in D(S)$ is measurable, locally bounded and has at most countably many discontinuities.
\begin{proof}
    Measurability follows because $x$ is uniform limit of step functions. For every $\varepsilon > 0$, there are only finitely many jumps of size $\varepsilon > 0$, so at most countably many positive jumps. Local boundedness follows from $\omega_D(x,\delta,T) < \infty$ for any $\delta > 0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Kolmogorov's criterion for tightness of sequence of $\R^d$-valued \textbf{continuous} stochastic processes (without proof).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} If $(X^{(n)})$ is a sequence of $\R^d$-valued continuous stochastic processes such that $(X^{(n)}(0))_n$ is tight and there exist constants $C > 0$ and $a,b> 0$ with \[
    \E \left[ \left| X^{(n)}_t - X^{(n)}_s \right| ^a \right] \le C \left| t-s \right| ^{1 + b},
\] for all $n\in \N$ and $s,t\ge 0$, then $(X^{(n)})$ is tight.
[/latex]

front:
[latex]Definition of $\Lambda \subset \R_+^{\R_+}$, definition of $\gamma(\lambda)$ for $\lambda\in \Lambda$. Given $\gamma(\lambda)$, what about $\gamma(\lambda^{-1})$, $\gamma(\lambda\circ \lambda')$, $\left\|\lambda-\id\right\|_T$?\\

Definition of Skorokhod topology on $D(S)$ for metric space $S$. What if $S$ is separable or Polish. Generator of Borel $\sigma$-algebra?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} By $\Lambda$ denote the set of bijective, increasing functions $\lambda\colon [0,\infty)\to [0,\infty)$. Such functions are necessarily continuous, strictly increasing, and satisfy $\lambda(0) = 0$ and $\lambda(\infty) = \infty$. Define \[
    \gamma(\lambda) \coloneqq \sup_{0\le s < t} \left| \log \frac{\lambda(t) - \lambda(s)}{t - s} \right| ,\quad \lambda\in \Lambda,
\] and put $\Lambda_0 \coloneqq \left\{ \lambda\in \Lambda\colon \gamma(\lambda) < \infty \right\} $. Then
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] For all $\lambda\in \Lambda$, $\lambda^{-1}\in \Lambda$ exists and $\gamma(\lambda) = \gamma(\lambda^{-1})$,
    \item[(ii)] $\gamma(\lambda_1\circ \lambda_2) \le \gamma(\lambda_1) + \gamma(\lambda_2)$ for all $\lambda_1,\lambda_2\in \Lambda_0$,
    \item[(iii)] $\sup_{t\le T} \left| \lambda(t) - t \right| \le T \left( \e^{\gamma(\lambda)} - 1 \right) $ for all $\lambda\in \Lambda_0$ and $T > 0$.
\end{enumerate}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] \[
                \sup_{s < t} \left| \log \frac{\lambda^{-1}(t) - \lambda^{-1}(s)}{t-s} \right| = \sup_{s < t} \left| \log \frac{\lambda^{-1}(\lambda(t)) - \lambda^{-1}(\lambda(s))}{\lambda(t) - \lambda(s)} \right| .
        \]
    \item[(ii)] Expand by $\frac{\lambda_2(t) - \lambda_2(s)}{t - s}$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\textbf{Definition.} Let $(S,d)$ be a metric space. On $D(S)$ define the \emph{Skorokhod metric} \[
    \rho(x,y) \coloneqq \inf_{\lambda\in \Lambda} \left[ \gamma(\lambda) \vee \int_0^\infty \left( 1 \wedge \left\|d(x^s,y^s\circ \lambda)\right\|_\infty \right)\e^{-s}\dd s  \right] ,\quad x,y\in D(S),
\] where $\left\|d(x,y)\right\|_T\coloneqq \sup_{0\le t\le T} d(x(t),y(t))$ for $x,y\in D(S)$. This defines a metric, and if $S$ is separable or Polish, so is $(D(S),\rho)$. Furthermore, if $S$ is Polish, $\mathcal{B}(D(S)) = \sigma\left( \pi_t\colon t\ge 0 \right)$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisations of convergence w.r.t. Skorokhod topology in $D(S)$ for metric space $(S,d)$ (one local and one global).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} Let $(S,d)$ be a metric space, let $\rho$ denote the Skorokhod topology on $D(S)$, and let $x^{(n)},x\in D(S),\,n\in \N$. Then $\rho(x^{(n)},x) \tendsto{} 0$ if and only if either (both) of the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] There exists $(\lambda_n) \in \Lambda^{\N}$ such that \[
            \gamma(\lambda_n) \tendsto{}  0,\qquad \forall T > 0\colon \left\| d(x^{(n)}, x\circ \lambda_n)\right\|_T\tendsto{}  0.
        \]
    \item[(ii)] For every $T > 0$, there exists $(\lambda_n^T)_n\in \Lambda_0^\N$ such that \[
        \left\|\lambda_n^T - \id\right\|_T \tendsto{} 0,\qquad \left\|d(x^{(n)},x\circ \lambda_n^T)\right\|_T \tendsto{} 0.
        \]
\end{enumerate}
In particular, if this is the case, then $x^{(n)}(t) \tendsto{} x(t)$ for all $t\in \mathcal{C}(x)$, and, if $x$ is continuous, this is equivalent to locally uniform convergence.
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $\rho(x^{(n)},x) \tendsto{} 0$, so (ii) holds. Then, for $t \ge 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        d(x^{(n)}(t),x(t))
        &\le d(x^{(n)}(t),x(\lambda_n^T(t))) + d(x(\lambda_n^T(t)),x(t))\\
        &\le \rho(x^{(n)},x) + d(x(\lambda_n^T(t)),x(t)).
    \end{align*}
    If $t\in \mathcal{C}(x)$, this goes to zero. If $x$ is continuous, the second expression is at most $\omega(x, \left\|\lambda_n^T - \id\right\|, T + 1)$, so the bound is uniform in $t\le T$. On the other hand, locally uniform convergence always implies convergence in $\rho$ (just take $\lambda_n = 0$).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Arzel\`a-Ascoli theorem for $D(S)$ with Skorokhod topology for Polish space $S$, and characterisation of relative compactness of $\mathcal{L}\subset M_1(D(\R^d))$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem (Arz\`ela-Ascoli).} If $(S,d)$ is a Polish space, then a subset $A\subset D(S)$ is relatively compact w.r.t. the Skorokhod topology if and only if
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)]  There exists a dense set $I \subset [0,\infty)$ such that $\left\{ x(t)\colon x\in A \right\} \subset S$ is relatively compact for all $t\in I$,
    \item[(ii)] $\sup_{x\in A} \omega_D(x,\delta,T) \tendsto{} 0$ as $\delta \to 0$ for all $T > 0$.
\end{enumerate}

\textbf{Corollary.} A set $\mathcal{L}\subset M_1(D(\R^d))$ is relatively compact if and only if the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] For all $T > 0$, \[
            \sup_{P\in \mathcal{L}} P\left( x\colon \left\|x\right\|_T \ge L \right) \tendsto{} 0,\quad L \to \infty,
    \]
\item[(ii)] For all $T > 0$ and $\varepsilon > 0$, \[
        \sup_{P\in \mathcal{L}} P\left( x\colon \omega_D(x,\delta,T) \ge \varepsilon \right) \tendsto{} 0,\quad \delta \to 0.
\]
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Lower bound on Ramsey number $R(3,k)$ for large $k\in \N$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} There exists $C > 0$ such that $R(3,k) \ge C \left( \frac{k}{\log k} \right) ^2$ for large $k$.
\begin{proof}
    For fixed $n\in \N$, colour each edge in $K_n$ red with probability $p$, blue otherwise, independently. For $S \in [n]^{(3)}$, let $A_S \coloneqq \left\{ \text{$S$ is red} \right\} $, and for $T \in [n]^{(k)}$, put $B_T \coloneqq \left\{ \text{$T$ is blue} \right\} $. Then \[
        \P(A_S) = p^3,\quad \P(B_T) = (1-p)^{\binom{k}{2} }.
    \] As digraph, join events if they overlap in at least two vertices (i.e. at least one edge). We wish to apply the Local lemma with $x_i = x$ for $A$ events and $x_i = y$ for $B$ events. To estimate degrees, each $A_S$ connects to at most $3n$ other $A$ events and at most $n^k$ $B$ events. $B$ events connect to at most $n\binom{k}{2} $ $A$ and at most $n^k$ $B$ events. We thus have to satisfy the bounds
    \begin{align*}
        p^3 &\le x (1-x)^{3n} (1-y)^{n^k},\\
        (1-p)^{\binom{k}{2} } &\le y (1-x)^{n\binom{k}{2} } (1-y)^{n^k}.
    \end{align*}
    This turns out to work with $k\sim 30 \sqrt{n} \log n$ and suitable choices for $p,x,y$ as functions of $n$, which gives $R(3,k) > n$ in that case. Turning around the formula for $k$ gives $n\sim \left( \frac{k}{60 \log k} \right) ^2$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Chernoff bound on $\P(X\ge nx)$ and $\P(X\le nx)$ for $X\sim \text{Bin}(n,p)$ (raw form).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $n\in \N$, $p\in (0,1)$, and $X\sim \text{Bin}(n,p)$. Then, if $x \ge p$,\[
    \P\left( X\ge nx \right) \le \left[ \left( \frac{p}{x} \right) ^x \left( \frac{1-p}{1-x} \right) ^{1-x} \right] ^n.
\] The same bound holds on $\P(X\le nx)$ if $x\le p$.

\begin{proof}
    Suppose $x\ge p$. Then for $t > 0$ we have  \[
        \P\left( X\ge nx \right) = \P\left( \e^{tX}\ge \e^{tnx} \right) \le \e^{-tnx} \E \left[ \e^{tX} \right] = \left[ \e^{-tx} \left( p\e^t + (1-p) \right)  \right] ^n.
    \] Minimising over $t > 0$ gives the bound. The other bound follows from $n - X \sim \text{Bin}(n,1-p)$ and $\P(X\le nx) = \P(n-X \ge n(1-x))$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Chernoff bounds on $\P(\text{Bin}(n,p) \ge np + t)$ and $\P\left( \text{Bin}(n,p) \ge (1+\varepsilon)np \right) $ for $t > 0$ and $0<\varepsilon \le 1$ (and other way around).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $X\sim \text{Bin}(n,p)$. Then, for $t > 0$, \[
    \P(X\ge np + t) \le \e^{-2t^2 / n},\qquad \P(X \le np -t) \le \e^{-2t^2 / n}.
\] and for $0< \varepsilon\le 1$, \[
\P\left( X \ge (1+\varepsilon) np \right) \le \e^{-\varepsilon^2 np / 4},\qquad \P\left( X \le (1-\varepsilon) np \right) \le \e^{-\varepsilon^2 np / 2}.
\]
\begin{proof}
    We know that, if $x > p$ or $x < p$, then $\P(X \ge (\le) nx) \le \e^{-f(x) n}$, where  \[
        f(x) = x\log \left( \frac{p}{x} \right) + (1-x) \log \left(\frac{1-p}{1-x}\right).
    \] Then $f(p) = f'(p) = 0$, and $f''(x) = \frac{1}{x} + \frac{1}{1-x}$. For the first bound, note that $f''(x) \ge 4$, so $f(p\pm h) \ge 2h^2$. For the second, note that for $p\le x \le (1+\varepsilon)p\le 2p$, $f''(x) \ge \frac{1}{x} \ge \frac{1}{2p} $, so $f((1+\varepsilon)p) \ge \varepsilon^2 p / 4$. for the final bound, note that for $(1-\varepsilon) p \le x \le p$ we have $f''(x) \ge \frac{1}{x}\ge \frac{1}{p}$, so $f((1-\varepsilon)p) \ge \varepsilon^2 p / 2$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Asymptotic bound on maximal degree in $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$ of the form $\P(\Delta \ge ?) \tendsto{} 0$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $\Delta$ is the maximum degree in $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$, and $np \ge 10 \log n$, then \[
    \P\left( \Delta \ge np + 3\sqrt{np \log n}  \right) \tendsto{} 0
\] as $n\to \infty$. That is, no vertex has degree $3\sqrt{\log n} $ standard deviations above its mean.

\begin{proof}
    We have $\P\left( \Delta \ge d \right) \le n \P\left( \text{Bin}(n,p) \ge d \right)$. Put $\varepsilon \coloneqq 3 \sqrt{\frac{\log n}{np}} \le 1$, so that \[
        \P\left( \text{Bin}(n,p) \ge np (1+\varepsilon) \right) \le \exp \left( -9 / 4 \log n \right) = n^{-9 / 4} = o\left(\frac{1}{n}\right).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of convergence $y_n \tendsto{} y$ in Skorokhod topology on $D([0,\infty),S)$ involving limiting behaviour of $y_n(t_n)$ if $t_n \tendsto{} t\in [0,\infty)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $(S,d)$ be a metric space. Then $y_n \tendsto{} y$ in $D(S)$ with respect to the Skorokhod topology if and only if, whenever $t_n \to t$ in $[0,\infty)$, the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $d(y_n(t_n),y(t)) \wedge d(y_n(t_n),y(t-)) \to 0$,
    \item[(ii)] If $d(y_n(t_n),y(t)) \to 0$ and $s_n \ge t_n$, $s_n \to t$, then also $d(y_n(s_n),y(t)) \to 0$,
    \item[(iii)] If $d(y_n(t_n),y(t-)) \to 0$ and $s_n\le t_n$, $s_n \to t$, then also $d(y_n(s_n),y(t-)) \to 0$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of tightness of a sequence of $D([0,\infty),S)$-valued random variables for Polish $S$ (directly from Arzel\`a Ascoli).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $(X^{n})_{n\in \N}$ be a sequence of $D([0,\infty),S)$-valued processes with Polish $S$. Then $(X^{n})$ is tight if and only if the following hold.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] There exists $I\subset [0,\infty)$ dense such that $(X^n(t))_n$ is tight in $S$ for all $t\in I$,
    \item[(ii)] For all $\varepsilon,T > 0$, $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \P\left( \omega_D(X^n,\delta,T) \ge \varepsilon \right) \to 0$ as $\delta \to 0$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Criterion for tightness of sequence of $D([0,\infty),\R)$-valued stochastic processes (Aldous), and in the case of semimartingales (Aldous-Rebolledo).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} A sequence $(Y^n)$ of $D(\R)$-valued stochastic processes is tight if
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $(Y^n(t))_n$ is tight for all $t\ge 0$,
    \item[(ii)] For any bounded sequence $(\tau_n)$ of stopping times and $\varepsilon > 0$,\[
    \limsup_{n\to \infty} \sup_{\theta < \delta} \P\left(\left| Y^n_{\tau_n + \theta} - Y^n_{\tau_n} \right|\ge \varepsilon\right) \tendsto{} 0,\quad \delta \to 0.
    \]
\end{enumerate}
If all $Y^n$ are semimartingales, it suffices if the second condition holds with $Y$ replaced by $A$ and $\left<Y \right> $ (the finite variation part and the quadratic variation).
[/latex]

front: [latex]Large deviations: Definition and basic properties of $M_\mu(\lambda)$ and $I_\mu(x)$ for $\mu\in M_1(\R)$ (with existing exponential moments).[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Proposition.} Suppose $\xi\sim\mu\in M_1(\R)$ integrable with mean $a\in \R$, and existing exponential moments. Then put
\begin{align*}
    M_\mu(\lambda) &\coloneqq \int\e^{\lambda z}\mu(\dd z),\quad \lambda \in \R,\\
    I_\mu(x) &\coloneqq \sup_{\lambda \in \R} \left( \lambda x - \log M_\mu(\lambda) \right) ,\quad x\in \R.
\end{align*}
Then we have
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $M_\mu\colon \R \to (0,\infty)$ is $C^\infty$ and log-convex, and $M_\mu(\lambda)\ge \e^{\lambda a}$,
    \item[(ii)] $I_\mu\colon \R \to [0,\infty)$ is convex, \emph{good} in the sense that $\left\{ I_\mu \le c \right\} \subset \R$ is compact for all $c\in \R$,
    \item[(iii)] $I_\mu(a) = 0$ (attained at $\lambda = 0$), and if $x\ge (\le) a$, we only have to consider $\lambda \ge (\le) 0$ in the supremum.
\end{enumerate}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $M_\mu(\lambda) \ge \e^{\lambda a}$ follows from Jensen's inequality, smoothness is clear, log-convexity follows from H\""older. Indeed, if $\alpha,\beta \in (0,1)$ with $\alpha + \beta = 1$, then
            \begin{align*}
                M_\mu(\alpha \lambda_1 + \beta \lambda_2)
                &= \int \left( \e^{\lambda_1 z} \right) ^\alpha \left( \e^{\lambda_2 z} \right) ^\beta \mu(\dd z) \\
                &\le \left( \int\e^{\lambda_1 z}\mu(\dd z) \right) ^\alpha \left( \int\e^{\lambda_2 z}\mu(\dd z) \right) ^\beta\\
                &= M_\mu(\lambda_1)^\alpha M_\mu(\lambda_2)^\beta.
            \end{align*}
        \item[(ii)] $I$ is a supremum of linear (so convex) functions and thus convex. $I \ge 0$ follows because $\lambda = 0$ yields $0$. $I$ is continuous (because it's convex), so $\left\{ I_\mu\le c \right\} $ is closed. Boundedness follows because whenever $I_\mu(x) \le c$, then (choosing $\lambda = \pm 1$), \[
                \pm x - \log M_\mu(\pm 1) \le I_\mu(x) \le c \implies \left| x \right| \le c + \log M_\mu(1) + \log M_\mu(-1).
        \]
    \item[(iii)] From (i), we know that $\lambda x - \log M_\mu(\lambda) \le \lambda(x-a)$, so we can forget $\lambda < 0$ if $x \ge a$ and vice-versa. This also implies $I_\mu(a) = 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front: [latex]Natural upper bound for $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\log(a_n+b_n)$ for sequences $(a_n),(b_n)\in [0,\infty)^{\N}$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $a_n,b_n\ge 0,\,n\in \N,$ Then \[
    \limsup_{n\to \infty}\frac{1}{n}\log(a_n+b_n) \le \limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\log a_n \vee \limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n} \log b_n.
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have $\log(a_n+b_n) \le \log (a_n\vee b_n) + \log 2$, so LHS is bounded by $\limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\log (a_n\vee b_n)$, which is equal to RHS because $\log(a_n \vee b_n) = \log a_n \vee \log b_n$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cram\'ers theorem on large deviations (proof of upper bound).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Cram\'ers theorem.} If $(\xi_i)_{i=1}^\infty$ are i.i.d. with existing exponential moments, and $\mu_n \coloneqq \P\left( \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n\xi_i \in \cdot  \right) ,\, n\in\N$, then $(\mu_n)$ satisfies the large deviation prinicple (LDP) with rate function $I_\mu$. That is,
\begin{align*}
    \limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\log\mu_n(F) &\le -\inf_{F} I_\mu,\\
    \liminf_{n\to \infty}\frac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(G) &\ge -\inf_G I_\mu,
\end{align*}
whenever $F\subset \R$ is closed and $G\subset \R$ is open.

\begin{proof}[Proof of upper bound]
    If $F = \varnothing$ or $a\in F$, the bound is trivial. If $F \subset (a,\infty)$, so $F \subset [y,\infty)$ with $y = \min F$, then $-\inf_F I = -I(y)$, and for any $\lambda > 0$, we have
    \begin{align*}
        \mu_n(F)
        &\le \mu_n([y,\infty)) \le \e^{-\lambda y} \E \left[ \exp \left( \frac{\lambda}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \xi_i \right) \right]\\
        &= \e^{-\lambda y} \left( \int \e^{\lambda z / n}\mu(\dd z) \right) ^n\\
        &= \e^{-\lambda y} M_\mu\left( \frac{\lambda}{n} \right) ^n.
    \end{align*}
    Rearranging yields \[
        \frac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(F) \le - \left( \frac{\lambda}{n}y - M_\mu\left( \frac{\lambda}{n} \right)  \right) ,\quad \lambda > 0,
    \] where the supremum over $\lambda > 0$ of the RHS is $-I_\mu(y)$. This implies the claim for $F \subset (a,\infty)$, and $F \subset (-\infty,a)$. For general $a\not\in F \neq \varnothing$, we have
    \begin{align*}
    \limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(F)
    &= \limsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(F_1+ F_2) \\
    &\le \left( -\inf_{F_1}I_\mu \right) \vee \left( -\inf_{F_2}I_\mu \right) \\
    &= -\inf_F I_\mu.
\end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cram\'ers theorem on large deviations (proof of lower bound).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
extbf{Cram'ers theorem.} If $(\xi_i)_{i=1}^\infty$ are i.i.d. with existing exponential moments, and $\mu_n \coloneqq \P\left( rac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n\xi_i \in \cdot  ight) ,\, n\in\N$, then $(\mu_n)$ satisfies the large deviation prinicple (LDP) with rate function $I_\mu$. That is,
egin{align*}
    \limsup_{n o \infty} rac{1}{n}\log\mu_n(F) &\le -\inf_{F} I_\mu,\
    \liminf_{n o \infty} rac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(G) &\ge -\inf_G I_\mu,
\end{align*}
whenever $F\subset \R$ is closed and $G\subset \R$ is open.

egin{proof}[Proof of lower bound]
    Let $G\subset \R$ be open. We have to show that $\liminf_{n o \infty} (\ldots ) \ge -I(x)$ for all $x\in G$, so let $x\in G$, WLOG $x \ge a$. Suppose first that the minimum is attained, so $I(x) = \lambda x - \log M(\lambda)$ for some $\lambda \ge 0$. Then \[
        0 \stackrel{!}{=} rac{\dd }{\dd \eta} \left. \left( \eta x - \log M(\eta) ight) ight\vert_{\eta = \lambda} = x - rac{\int z \e^{\lambda z}\mu(\dd z)}{M(\lambda)}.
        \] Thus if we define $ u\in M_1(\R)$ by $ u(\dd z) = rac{\e^{\lambda z}}{M(\lambda)}\mu(\dd z)$, then $ u$ has mean $x$. Now let $\delta > 0$ such that $(x-\delta,x+\delta) \subset G$, so that
        egin{align*}
            \mu_n(G)
            &\ge \mu_n((x-\delta,x+\delta)) = \P\left( \left| rac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \xi_i - x ight| < \delta  ight) \
            &\le \e^{-n\lambda (x+\delta)} \E \left[ \e^{\lambda \sum_{i=1}^n \xi_i} \colon \left| \ldots  ight| < \delta ight] \
            &= \e^{-n\lambda (x+\delta)} M(\lambda)^n \P\left( \left| rac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n Y_i - x ight| < \delta ight) ,
        \end{align*}
        where $Y_i \sim u$ i.i.d. This implies
        egin{align*}
            rac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(G)
            &\ge -\lambda \delta - \lambda x + \log M(\lambda) + o(1)\
            &= -\lambda \delta - I(x) + o(1),
        \end{align*}
        so $\limsup_{n o \infty} rac{1}{n}\log \mu_n(G) \ge -\lambda \delta - I(x)$ for all $\delta > 0$.

        If $I(x)$ is not attained, we find $0\le \lambda_n \uparrow \infty$ such that $\lambda_n x - \log M(\lambda_n) o I(x)$. We have
        egin{align*}
            \lim_{n o \infty}& \int_{(-\infty,x)} \e^{\lambda_n(z-x)}\mu(\dd z) = 0,\
            \lim_{n o \infty}& \int_\R \e^{\lambda_n(z-x)} \mu(\dd z) = \lim_{n o \infty}\e^{ -\lambda_nx + \log M(\lambda_n) } = \e^{-I(x)},
        \end{align*}
        Furthermore, for $\delta > 0$, \[
            \mu([x+\delta,\infty)) \le \e^{-\delta \lambda} \int_{[x+\delta,\infty)} \e^{\lambda_n(z-x)}\mu(\dd z) \le \e^{-\delta \lambda_n} \int_\R (\ldots ) endsto{} 0 \cdot  \e^{-I(x)} = 0,
        \] so $\mu((x,\infty)) = 0$. Hence, $\mu(\left\{ x ight\} ) = \int_\R \e^{\lambda_n(z - x)}\mu(\dd z) o \e^{-I(x)}$, and finally,
        egin{equation*}
            \mu_n(G) \ge \mu_n(\left\{ x ight\} ) \ge \P\left( \xi_1= \ldots =\xi_n = x ight) = \mu(\left\{ x ight\} )^n = \e^{-n I(x)}.
        \end{equation*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]GW branching processes: Connection of $\eta_n = \P(Z_n = 0)$ and $\eta = \P(\text{process dies out})$ with pgf $f$ of $Z$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $(Z_n)$ be the GW branching process with offspring distribution $Z$, and put $\eta_n = \P(Z_n = 0)$, and $\eta = \lim_{n\to \infty} \eta_n = \P\left( \text{process dies} \right) $. Then $\eta_{n+1} = f(\eta_n)$, and $\eta$ is the smallest solution to $f(x) = x$ in $[0,1]$.

\begin{proof}
    We have $\eta_0 = 0$, and \[
        \eta_{n+1} = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \P(Z_1 = k) \P \left(Z_{n+1} = 0 \,\middle\vert\, Z_1 = k\right) = \sum_{k=0}^\infty p_k \eta_n^k = f(\eta_n).
    \] By continuity of $f$, we have $\eta \leftarrow \eta_{n+1} = f(\eta_n) \rightarrow f(\eta)$. Now if $f(x_0) = x_0$, then $\eta_0 = 0 \le x_0$, so $\eta_{n+1} = f(\eta_n) \le f(x_0) = x_0$ for all $n$, so $\eta \le x_0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]When does a GW branching process almost surely die out?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $(Z_n)$ is the GW process with offspring distribution $Z$, $\lambda \coloneqq \E \left[ Z \right] $, and $\eta = \P(\text{process dies})$, then
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] If $\lambda < 1$, then $\eta = 1$,
    \item[(ii)] If $\lambda = 1$ and $\P(Z = 1) < 1$, then $\eta = 1$,
    \item[(iii)] If $\lambda > 1$, then $\eta < 1$.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{proof}
    If $\lambda \coloneqq \E \left[ Z  \right] < 1 $, this follows from $\E \left[ Z_n \right] = \lambda^n \to 0$. Now we know that $\eta < 1$ if and only if $f(x) = x$ has a solution in $[0,1)$. If $f'(1) = \lambda > 1$, then $f(0) \ge 0$ implies the existence of such a solution. If $f'(1) = \lambda = 1$ and $\P(Z\ge 2) > 0$, then $f$ is strictly convex, so $f'(x) < 1$ for all $x\in [0,1)$, and $f(1) = 1$, so $f(x) > x$ for all $x\in (0,1]$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of the GW- and the $G(n,p)$-exploration processes $(Y_t ^{bp})$ and $(Y_t)$, and connection with size of the component of start vertex $v$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} For the branching process, let $(Z_t)_{t\in \N}$ be i.i.d.\ with offspring distribution, and put $Y_0^{bp} = 1$, and \[
Y_{t}^{bp} = \begin{cases}
    Y_{t-1} ^{bp} + Z_t - 1 &, \,Y_{t-1} ^{bp} > 0,\\
    0 &, \, \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}
\] Then $\min \left\{ t\in \N \colon Y^{bp}_t = 0 \right\} $ is the total size of the branching process.\\

\textbf{Definition.} For $G(n,p)$, take $v\in [n]$ fixed start vertex and do DFS. After step $t$, there are $Y_t$ vertices in the buffer ($Y_0 = 1$), $t$ processed vertices, and $U_t \coloneqq n - t - Y_t$ undiscovered vertices. Then pick the buffered vertex with the smallest label, remove it, and denote by $R_t$ the number of new vertices discovered from it, so $R_{t}\sim \text{Bin}(U_{t-1},p)$ (given $Y_{t-1}$), and \[
Y_{t} = \begin{cases}
    Y_{t-1} + R_{t} - 1 &,\, Y_{t-1} > 0,\\
    0 &,\, \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}
\] Then $\left| C_v \right| = \min \left\{ t\in \N\colon Y_t = 0 \right\} $.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Asymptotic probability of the component of a fixed vertex in $G(n,p)$ having size $k\in \N$ if $np \tendsto{} c > 0$. Corollary on expected number of $k$-components.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Denote by $\rho_k(c)$ for $c > 0$ the probability that a $\text{Po}(c)$-GW process has size exactly $k\in \N$. Suppose that $np \tendsto{} c \in (0,\infty)$, and let $v \in \N$. Then \[
    \P \left( \left| C_v \right| = k \right) \tendsto{} \rho_k(c).
\] In particular, if $N_k(G)$ denotes the number of vertices in a component of size $k$, so $k$ times the number of such components, then \[
\E \left[ N_k(G(n,p)) \right] \sim n \rho_k(c).
\]
\begin{proof}
    LHS is the probability that the exploration process $(Y_t)$ hits zero after exactly $k$ steps, RHS is the same for $(Y_t ^{bp})$. Since both RW's can only take steps of size at least $-1$, there is a fixed finite set $S \subset (\Z_{\ge -1})^k$ of possible steps the random walks can take, so have to show that, for fixed $s=(y_1,\ldots ,y_k = 0)\in S$, the probability that $Y$ takes that path converges to the probability that $Y^{bp}$ takes that path. We have, with $r_t \coloneqq y_t - y_{t-1} + 1$, \[
        \P(Y) = \prod_{t=1}^k \underbrace{\P\left( \text{Bin}(n - (t-1) - y_{t-1},p) = r_t \right) }_{\tendsto{} \P (\text{Po}(c) = r_t)} \tendsto{} \P(Y^{bp}).
    \]

    The second statement follows from \[
        \E \left[ N_k(G(n,p)) \right] = \sum_{v\in G(n,p)} \P(\left| C_v \right| = k) = n \P(\left| C_1 \right| = k).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition (good) rate function $I\colon E \to [0,\infty]$ for Polish $E$, and (weak) large deviation principle. In that case, what do we know about $P_\varepsilon(B)$ asymptotically for $B\in \B(E)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} Let $E$ be a Polish space. Then a lower semi-continuous function $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ with $\inf I < \infty$ is called a \emph{rate function}. It is a \emph{good} rate function if $I_c \coloneqq \left\{ I \le  c \right\} \subset E$ is compact for all $c \ge 0$.\\

\textbf{Definition.} If $I$ is a rate function, then a family $(P_\varepsilon \colon \varepsilon > 0)$ of probabilities on $E$ satisfies the \emph{large deviation principle (LDP) with rate $I$} if
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\limsup_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon(F) \le -\inf_F I$ for all $F\subset E$ closed,
    \item[(ii)] $\liminf_{\varepsilon\to o} \varepsilon\log P_\varepsilon(G) \ge -\inf_G I$ for all $G\subset E$ open.
\end{enumerate}
It satisfies the \emph{weak LDP} if (i) holds only for $K\subset E$ compact.\\

If LDP is satisfied, and $B\in \B(E)$ with $\inf_{\overline{B}}I = \inf_{B^\circ} I$, then $\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log P_\varepsilon(B) = -\inf_B I$, so \[
    P_\varepsilon(B) \approx \exp \left( -\frac{\inf_B I}{\varepsilon} \right) ,\quad \varepsilon > 0.
\]
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition (and heuristic meaning) of exponential tightness of a family $(P_\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon > 0)$ on a Polish space $E$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} Let $E$ be a Polish space. Then a family $(P_\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon> 0)$ of probabilities on $E$ is called \emph{exponentially tight} if, for every $c > 0$, there exists a compact set $K_c \subset E$ such that \[
    \limsup_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon \left( E \setminus K_c \right) \le -c,
\] that is, $P_\varepsilon(E\setminus K_c) \lesssim \e^{-c / \varepsilon}$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Under which assumption does weak LDP with a rate function $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ imply that $I$ is good and (strong) LDP holds?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $E$ be a Polish space, and suppose that $(P_\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon > 0)$ satisfies the weak LDP with a rate function $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$, and is exponentially tight. Then
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $I$ is a good rate function,
    \item[(ii)] $(P_\varepsilon)$ satisfies the LDP with rate $I$.
\end{enumerate}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Let $c > 0$ and choose $K_c \subset E$ according to exponential tightness. Then \[
                -c \ge \limsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon(E\setminus K_c) \ge \liminf_{\varepsilon \to 0}\varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon(E\setminus K_c) \ge -\inf_{E\setminus K_c} I,
        \] so $\inf_{E\setminus K_c} \ge c$ and thus $I_c \subset K_{c+1}$ is compact.
    \item[(ii)] Have to prove the upper bound, so let $S\subset E$ be closed. For any $c > 0$, we have
    \begin{align*}
        \limsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon(S)
        &\le \limsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log P_\varepsilon(S\cap K_c) \vee \limsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log P_\varepsilon(E\setminus K_c)\\
        &\le (-\inf_{S\cap K_c} I) \vee (-c)\\
        &\le - (\inf_S I \wedge c),
    \end{align*}
    which implies the claim with $c\to \infty$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ is a good rate function, then it achieves its minimum on closed sets. More generally, $\Phi - I$ achieves its supremum for what kind of $\Phi$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $E$ be Polish and $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ a good rate function. Then, if $\Phi \colon E \to [-\infty,\infty)$ is upper semi-continuous and $S\subset E$ is closed with $\sup_S \Phi < \infty$, then \[
    \Phi(s_0) - I(s_0) = \sup_S (\Phi - I)
\] for some $s_0 \in S$. In particular, $I$ achieves minima on closed sets.

\begin{proof}
    If $\sup_S(\Phi - I) = -\infty$, we are done. Otherwise $\sup_S(\Phi - I) \in (-\infty,\infty)$, so for any $n\in \N$ there exists $s_n \in S$ such that \[
        \sup_S(\Phi - I) - \frac{1}{n} \le \Phi(s_n) - I(s_n) \le \sup_S(\Phi - I),\quad n\in \N.
    \] Then $I(s_n) \le |\sup_S(\Phi - I)| + \sup_S \Phi + 1$ for all $n\in \N$, so WLOG $s_n \to s_0 \in S$ because $I$ is good. Then \[
    \sup_S(\Phi - I) = \limsup_{n\to \infty} \left( \Phi(s_n) - I(s_n) \right) \le \Phi(s_0) - I(s_0),
    \] because $\Phi - I$ is upper semi-contiuous.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ is a good rate function, then $\inf_{S^\delta} I \uparrow \inf_S I$ for any closed $S\subset E$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $E$ be Polish and $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ a good rate function. Then if $S\subset E$ is closed, \[
\inf_{S^\delta} I \uparrow \inf_S I.
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have $\inf_{S^\delta} I \uparrow l \le \inf_S I$. Now take $s_n \in S^{1 / n}$ such that \[
        \inf_n I \coloneqq \inf_{S^{1 / n}}I \le I(s_n) \le \inf_n I + \frac{1}{n},\quad n\in \N.
    \] Then $I(s_n) \le \inf_S I + 1$, so WLOG $s_n \to s_0\in S$, so \[
    \liminf_{n\to \infty} (\inf_n I) \ge \liminf_{n\to \infty} I(s_n) \ge I(s_0) \ge \inf_S I.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Varadhan's theorem on functional integration and LDPs, lower bound.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition (Varadhan, lower bound).} Let $E$ be a Polish space, and suppose $(P_\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ satisfies the weak LDP with rate function $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$. Then, if $\Phi\colon E \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is lower semi-continuous, \[
    \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log \int \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon \ge \sup_{\Phi \wedge I < \infty} (\Phi - I).
\]

\begin{proof}
    Let $s\in E$ such that $\Phi(s) \wedge I(s) < \infty$. Then, for any $\delta > 0$,
    \begin{align*}
       \varliminf_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log \int \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon
       &\ge \varliminf_{\varepsilon \to 0}\varepsilon\log \int_{B(s,\delta)} \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon\\
       &\ge \inf_{B(s,\delta)} \Phi + \varliminf_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon(B(s,\delta))\\
       &\ge \inf_{B(s,\delta)}\Phi - \inf_{B(s,\delta)} I\\
       &\ge \inf_{B(s,\delta)}\Phi - I(s).
    \end{align*}
    Since $\Phi$ is lower semi-continuous, we have $\inf_{B(s,\delta)}\Phi \uparrow \Phi(s)$ as $\delta \to 0$, which finishes the proof. Indeed, we may choose $s_n \to s$ and $\Phi(s_n) \le \inf_{B(s,1 / n)}\Phi + \frac{1}{n}$, and $\varliminf_n \Phi(s_n) \ge \Phi(s)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Varadhan's theorem on functional integration and LDPs, upper bound.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition (Varadhan, upper bound).} Let $ E$ be a Polish space and suppose that $(P_\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon > 0)$ satisfies the LDP with a good rate function $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$, such that \[
\varlimsup_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log \int_{\left\{ \Phi \ge c \right\} } \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon \tendsto{} -\infty,\quad c \to \infty.
\] Then, if $\Phi\colon E\to [-\infty,\infty)$ is upper semi-continuous, \[
\varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \int \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon \le \sup(\Phi- I).
\]
\begin{proof}
    Assume first that $\Phi \le M$ for some $M > 0$. Then, for any $c > 0$, and any $\delta > 0$, we may cover $I_c = \left\{ I \le c \right\} $ with finitely many balls $B_i \coloneqq B(s_i,r_i)$ such that \[
        \sup_{\overline{B_i}} \Phi \le \Phi(s_i) +  \delta,\qquad \inf_{\overline{B_i}}I \ge I(s_i) -  \delta.
    \] Then put $G\coloneqq \bigcup_{i} B_i \supset I_c$, and
    \begin{align*}
        \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \int\e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}}\dd P_\varepsilon
        &= \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log \int_{E\setminus G} \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon \vee \max_i \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \int_{B_i} \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon\\
        &\le \Big(M+ \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log P_\varepsilon(E\setminus G)\Big) \vee \max_i \Big(\sup_{\overline{B_i}} \Phi + \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log P_\varepsilon(\overline{B_i})\Big)\\
        &\le \Big( M - \inf_{E\setminus G} I\Big) \vee \max_i \Big(\Phi(s_i) - I(s_i) + 2\delta\Big)\\
        &\le \big(M - c\Big) \vee \sup(\Phi - I) + 2\delta.
    \end{align*}
    Letting $\delta \to 0$ and $c \to \infty$ finishes the proof in this case.

    Now let $\Phi$ be general. Then, for any $c > 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \int \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon
        &\le \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log \int \e^{\frac{\Phi \wedge c}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon \vee \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon \log \int_{\left\{ \Phi \ge c \right\} }\e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}}\dd P_\varepsilon\\
        &\le \sup(\Phi \wedge c - I) \vee X\\
        &\le \sup(\Phi - I) \vee X,
    \end{align*}
    and $X\to -\infty$ as $c \to \infty$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Varadhan's theorem on functional integration and LDPs, and sufficient criterion for technical assumption.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem (Varadhan).} If $E$ is Polish, and $(P_\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon> 0)$ satisfies LDP with good rate function $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$, and $\Phi\colon E\to \R$ is continuous with
\begin{equation}\label{eq:tech}
\varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon \log \int_{\left\{ \Phi\ge c \right\} } \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon \tendsto{} -\infty,\quad c \to \infty
\end{equation} then \[
\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log \int \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}}\dd P_\varepsilon = \sup(\Phi - I).
\]
\begin{proof}
    Follows from the proofs of upper and lower bound.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Lemma.} If, in the above context, there exists $\gamma > 0$ with \[
    \sup_{0<\varepsilon\le 1} \left( \int \e^{(1+\gamma) \frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}}\dd P_\varepsilon \right) ^\varepsilon < \infty,
\] then the technical assumption (1) holds.
\begin{proof}
    We have $ \ind_{\left\{ \Phi \ge c \right\} } \le \e^{\gamma (\Phi - c) / \varepsilon}$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \varepsilon \log \int_{\left\{ \Phi\ge c \right\} } \e^{\frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \dd P_\varepsilon
        &\le \varepsilon \log \int \e^{(1+\gamma) \frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}} \e^{-\gamma c / \varepsilon} \dd P_\varepsilon\\
        &= -\gamma c + \log \left( \int \e^{(1+\gamma) \frac{\Phi}{\varepsilon}}\dd P_\varepsilon \right) ^{\varepsilon}\\
        &\le -\gamma c + \log M,
    \end{align*}
    which tends to zero as $c\to \infty$, independent of $\varepsilon$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Main theorem on diffusion approximation with discrete-time Markov chains.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose that $a\colon \R ^d\to \R^{d\times d}$, and $b\colon \R^d\to \R^d$ are locally bounded and measurable, and such that the martingale problem $M(a,b)$ is well-posed. Now suppose $(Y^h\colon h>0)$ is a family of discrete-time Markov chains with state space $E_h\subset \R^d$, such that, if
\begin{align*}
    a^h&\colon E_h \to \R ^{d\times d} ;\, x\mapsto \frac{1}{h} \E \left[(Y_1^h - x) (Y_1^h-x)^\top \ind_{\left\{ \left| Y^h_1 - x \right| \le 1 \right\} } \,\middle\vert\, Y^h_0 = x\right],\\
    b^h&\colon E_h\to \R^d ;\, x\mapsto \frac{1}{h} \E \left[\left( Y^h_1 - x \right) \ind_{\left\{ \left| Y^h_1 - x \right| \le 1 \right\} } \,\middle\vert\, Y^h_0 = x\right],\\
    \Delta^h_\varepsilon&\colon E_h \to [0,\infty) ;\, x\mapsto \frac{1}{h} \P\left( \left| Y^h_1 - x \right| \ge \varepsilon \,\middle\vert\, Y^h_0 = x \right) ,
\end{align*}
then $a^h\to a$, $b^h \to b$, and $\Delta^h_\varepsilon \to 0$ ($\forall \varepsilon>0$) locally uniformly, and $Y^h_0 \equiv x^h_0 \to x_0$, then the chains $X^h \coloneqq (Y^h_{\left\lfloor \frac{t}{h} \right\rfloor })_{0\le t \le 1}$ converge in distribution to the unique solution of $M(a,b)$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Main theorem on diffusion approximation with continuous-time Markov processes.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose that $a\colon \R ^d\to \R^{d\times d}$, and $b\colon \R^d\to \R^d$ are locally bounded and measurable, and such that the martingale problem $M(a,b)$ is well-posed. Now suppose $(X^h\colon h>0)$ is a family of continuous-time Markov processes with state space $E_h\subset \R$, such that, putting \[
    K_h(x,\cdot ) \coloneqq \frac{\dd }{\dd t} P^h_t(x,\cdot ) = \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \P^x \left( X^h_t \in \cdot  \right) ,
\] we have $\sup_{x\in E_h \cap K} K_h(x,\R^d\setminus \left\{ x \right\} ) < \infty$ for every compact set $K\subset \R^d$, and
\begin{align*}
    a^h &\colon E_h\to \R ^{d\times d};\, x\mapsto \int_{\left\{ \left| y-x \right| \le 1 \right\} } (y-x) (y-x)^\top K_h(x,\dd y),\\
    b^h &\colon E_h \to \R^d;\, x \mapsto \int_{\left\{ \left| y-x \right| \le 1 \right\} } (y-x) K_h(x,\dd y),\\
    \Delta^h_\varepsilon&\colon E_h \to \R^d;\, x\mapsto K_h(x, B(x,\varepsilon)^{c}),
\end{align*}
then $a^h\to a$, $b^h \to b$, and $\Delta^h_\varepsilon \to 0$ ($\forall \varepsilon>0$) locally uniformly, and $X^h_0 \equiv x^h_0 \to x_0$, then the chains $(X^h_t)_{0\le t \le 1}$ converge in distribution to the unique solution of $M(a,b)$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Asymptotic behaviour of number $N_k$ of vertices in a component of size exactly $k$ in $G(n,p)$, if $np \to c > 0$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $k\in \N$, and $np \tendsto{} c > 0$, and denote by $N_k$ the number of vertices in $G(n,p)$ whose component has size $k$. Then \[
    \frac{N_k}{n} \tendsto{\P} \rho_k(c),
\] which is the probability that a $\text{Poi}(c)$-GW process has size exactly $k$.

\begin{proof}
    We already know that $\E \left[ N_k \right] \sim n \rho_k(c)$, so expectation converges and it suffices to show that $\E \left[ \left( \frac{N_k}{n} \right) ^2 \right] \tendsto{} \rho_k(c)^2$. Putting $I_v \coloneqq \left\{ \left| C_v \right| =k \right\} $, we have \[
    N_k = \sum_{v,w} I_v I_w = \sum_{v,w} I_v I_w \ind_{\left\{ C_v = C_w \right\} } + \sum_{v,w} \ind_{\left\{ C_v \neq C_w \right\} } I_v I_w = A + B.
    \] Then \[
    A = \sum_v I_v \sum_w I_w \ind_{\left\{ C_v = C_w \right\} } = \sum_v I_v k = k N_k \le kn,
    \] and
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[ B \right]
        &= n \E \left[ I_1 \sum_w I_w \ind_{\left\{ C_1 \neq C_w \right\} } \right] \\
        &= n \P\left( \left| C_1 = k \right|  \right) \E \left[N_k(\mathcal{G} - C_1) \,\middle\vert\, \left| C_1 \right| = k\right].
    \end{align*}
    Now if $1 \in C\subset \N$ with $\left| C \right| = k$ is fixed, then \[
        \E \left[ N_k(\mathcal{G}-C) \,\middle\vert\, C_1 = C \right] = \E \left[ N_k(\mathcal{G}-C) \right] = \E \left[ N_k(\mathcal{G}(n-k,p)) \right] \sim n \rho_k(c),
    \] so \[
    \E \left[ B \right] \sim n \rho_k(c) \cdot n \rho_k(c) = n^2\rho_k(c)^2,
\] and so $\E \left[ N_k^2 \right] \sim n^2 \rho_k(c)^2$ as required.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]How does LDP of $(Z^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ on $E$ with good rate $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ transfer to $(f(Z^\varepsilon)\colon \varepsilon>0)$ for $f\colon E\to E'$ continuous?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Suppose $E,E'$ are Polish spaces, $f\colon E\to E'$ is continuous, and $I\colon E\to [0,\infty]$ is a good rate function. Then \[
    I'(s') \coloneqq \inf \left\{ I(s)\colon s\in E, f(s) = s' \right\} = \inf_{f^{-1}(s')} I
\] defines a good rate function. If $(Z^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ are $E$-valued random variables that satisfy LDP with rate $I$, then $(X^\varepsilon\coloneqq f(Z^\varepsilon)\colon \varepsilon > 0)$ satisfy LDP with rate $I'$.
\begin{proof}
