    First observe that the infinmum is always attained because $I$ is good and $f^{-1}(s')$ closed for all $s'\in E'$. If $A\subset E'$, then
   \begin{align*}
       \inf_A I'
       &= \inf_{s\in A} \inf _{f^{-1}(s)}I = \inf_{f^{-1}(A)}I.
   \end{align*}
   Thus, $\inf I' = \inf I < \infty$, $I\ge 0$. Now, if $(s_n') \in {I'_c}^{\N}$ for some $c \ge 0$, take $s_n \in E$ with $f(s_n) = s_n'$ and $I(s_n) = I'(s_n') \le c$, so WLOG $s_n \to s\in E$, so $s_n' = f(s_n) \to f(s) \eqqcolon s'$, and \[
       I'(s') \le I(s) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} I(s_n) \le c,
   \] so $s'\in I'_c$. Thus $I'_c$ is compact, so $I'$ is lower semi-continuous and good. Now, if $F\subset E'$ is closed, so is $f^{-1}(F)$, thus \[
   \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \P\left( X^\varepsilon \in F \right) = \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \P(Z^\varepsilon \in f^{-1}(F) \le -\inf_{f^{-1}(F)}I = -\inf_F I',
   \] and similarly for $G\subset E'$ open.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of exponential convergence $X^\varepsilon_n \tendsto{} X^\varepsilon$ in the context of LDPs. In that case, if $(X^\varepsilon_n\colon \varepsilon>0)$ satisfies LDP with good rate $I_n$, what can you say about $\varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log\P(X^\varepsilon\in S)$ for $S\subset E$ closed, and analogously with $G\subset E$ open?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Lemma.} If $(X^\varepsilon_n\colon \varepsilon>0),\,n\in \N,$ and $(X^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ are families of random variables with values in a Polish space $E$, we say that $X^\varepsilon_n$ goes to $X^\varepsilon$ \emph{exponentially} if, for every $\delta > 0$, \[
    \lim_{n\to \infty} \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \P\left( \rho(X^\varepsilon_n,X^\varepsilon) \ge \delta \right) = -\infty.
\] In that case, if $(X^\varepsilon_n\colon \varepsilon>0)$ satisfies LDP with good rate $I_n$, then \[
\varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log \P(X^\varepsilon\in S) \le -\lim_{\delta \to 0} \varlimsup_{n\to \infty} \inf_{s\in \overline{S^\delta}}I_n(s),
\] for $S\subset E$ closed, and, for $G\subset E$ open, \[
\varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \P(X^\varepsilon\in G) \ge - \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \inf_{B_s(\delta)} I_n,
\] for every $s\in G$ and $\delta > 0$ such that $B_s(2\delta) \subset G$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $S\subset E$ closed. Then, for any $\varepsilon> 0$ and $\delta > 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \P(X^\varepsilon\in S) \le \P(X^\varepsilon_n \in S^\delta) + \P(\rho(X^\varepsilon_n,X^\varepsilon) \ge \delta),
    \end{align*}
    so that
    \begin{align*}
        \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon \log \P(X^\varepsilon\in S)
        &\le (-\inf_{s\in \overline{S^\delta}} I_n(s) )\vee \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log \P(\rho(X^\varepsilon_n,X^\varepsilon) \ge \delta),
    \end{align*}
    which yields the claim by passing to $\varliminf_{n\to \infty}$ on the RHS, and then $\delta \to 0$. Now let $G\subset E$ be open and $B(s,2\delta) \subset G$. Then, \[
        \P(X^\varepsilon_n \in B(s,\delta)) \le \P(X^\varepsilon\in G) + \P(\rho(X^\varepsilon_n,X^\varepsilon) \ge \delta),
    \] and thus \[
    -\inf_{B_s(\delta)} I_n \le \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log\P(X^\varepsilon\in G) \vee \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log\P(\rho(X^\varepsilon_n,X^\varepsilon)\ge \delta),
    \] yielding the claim with $n\to \infty$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of two families $(X^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ and $(Y^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ being exponentially close, and how LDP with good rate transfers in this case.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $(X^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon> 0)$, and $(Y^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ are families of random variables taking values in a Polish space $E$, that are \emph{exponentially close} in the sense that \[
    \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log\P(\rho(X^\varepsilon,Y^\varepsilon)\ge \delta) = -\infty
\] for all $\delta > 0$, then, if $(Y^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ satisfies LDP with a good rate $I$, so does $(X^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$.
\begin{proof}
    We have that $Y^\varepsilon$ goes to $X^\varepsilon$ exponentially. Let $S\subset E$ be closed. Then \[
        \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log \P(X^\varepsilon\in S) \le - \lim_{\delta \to 0} \inf_{\overline{S^\delta}} I = - \inf_S I.
    \] If $G\subset E$ is open, and $B(s,2\delta)\subset G$, then \[
    \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log\P(X^\varepsilon\in G) \ge -\inf_{B(s,\delta)} I \ge -I(s).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]General contraction principle for LDPs.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose $E,E'$ are Polish spaces, $I$ is a good rate on $E$, $f_n\colon E\to E',\,n\in \N,$ are continuous and converge uniformly on sets $\left\{ I\le c \right\} $ to a function $f\colon \left\{ I<\infty \right\} \to E'$. Put
\begin{align*}
    I_n'(s') &\coloneqq \inf \left\{ I(s)\colon s\in E, f_n(s) = s' \right\} \\
    I'(s') &\coloneqq \inf \left\{ I(s)\colon s\in E, I(s)<\infty, f(s) = s' \right\} ,
\end{align*}
which are good rates on $E'$. Suppose that $(X^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon>0)$ satisfy LDP with $I_n'$ for $n\in \N$, and that $X^\varepsilon_n \tendsto{} X^\varepsilon$ exponentially. Then $(X^\varepsilon\colon \varepsilon > 0)$ satisfies LDP with rate $I'$.\\
\begin{proof}
We already know that $I_n'$ are good rates. By a similar argument, $I$ is as well, and both infimums are always attained (For $I'$, note that if $I(s_n) \to I'(s')$ with $s_n \in \left\{ I < \infty \right\} \cap f^{-1}(s')$, then $s_n \in \left\{ I\le I'(s') + 1 \right\} $, so $s_{k(n)}\to s\in \left\{ I<\infty \right\} $ and $f(s) = s'$, and $I(s) = I'(s')$).

Let $G\subset E'$ be open, and $s'\in G$. Choose $\delta > 0$ with $B(s',2\delta) \subset G$, so that \[
    \varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0}\varepsilon\log\P(X^\varepsilon\in G) \ge -\varliminf_{n\to \infty} \inf_{B(s',\delta)} I_n' \stackrel{!}{\ge} -I'(s').
    \] Indeed, this is clear if $I'(s') = \infty$. Otherwise, let $s\in \left\{ I<\infty \right\} $ with $f(s) = s'$ and $I(s) = I'(s')$. Then $f_n(s) \in B(s',\delta)$ for large $n$ because $f_n(s) \to f(s) = s'$, so \[
    \inf_{B(s',\delta)}I_n' = \inf_{f_n^{-1}(B(s',\delta))} I \le I(s) = I'(s')
\] for large $n$.

Now let $S\subset G$ be closed We know that \[
    \varlimsup_{\varepsilon\to 0} \varepsilon\log \P(X^\varepsilon\in S) \le -\lim_{\delta \to 0} \varlimsup_{n\to \infty} \inf_{\overline{S^\delta}}I_n' \eqqcolon -l,
\] so need to show that $l \ge \inf_{S} I'$. For $n\in \N$, choose $s_n' \in S^{1 / n}$ with $I_n'(s_n') \le l + \frac{1}{n}$, and take $s_n \in E$ with $f(s_n) = s_n'$ and $I(s_n) = I'_n(s_n')$. So $s_n \in I_{l+1}$, so $s_n \to s$ in $I_{l+1}$, so $s_n' = f_n(s_n) \to f(s) \eqqcolon s' \in S$. Then, \[
\inf_S I' \le I'(s') \le I(s) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} I(s_n) = l.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Asymptotic behaviour of number of vertices in components of size at most $\omega(n)\uparrow \infty$ in $\mathcal{G}(n,\frac{c}{n})$, if $\omega(n)$ grows sufficiently slowly. (Sketch of proof; coupling of $\text{Po}(c)$ and $\text{Bin}(n,\frac{c}{n})$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $\omega(n) \to \infty$, and $\omega(n) \le n^{1 / 4}$, and $G\sim \mathcal{G}(n,\frac{c}{n})$, then \[
    \frac{N_{\le \omega(n)}(G)}{n} \tendsto{\P} \eta(c).
\]
\begin{proof}
    Firstly, we have \[
        \sum_{k=1}^{\omega(n)}\rho_k(c) \tendsto{} \sum_{k=1}^\infty \rho_k(c) = \P\left( \left| \boldsymbol X_{\text{Po}(c)} \right| < \infty \right) = \eta(c).
    \] The claim then follows similar to how we proved that $N_k(G) / n \tendsto{\P} \rho_k(c)$ for fixed $k\in\N$, by considering error bounds more carefully. For that purpose, the following fact is useful.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Fact.} One can clearly couple $\text{Po}(p)$ and $\text{Bin}(1,p)$ to disagree with probability $O(p^2)$. Thus, one can couple $\text{Po}(np)$ and $\text{Bin}(n,p)$ to disagree with probability $O(np^2)$, and thus $\text{Po}(c)$ and $\text{Bin}(n,\frac{c}{n})$ to disagree with probability $O(\frac{1}{n})$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]What is (whp) the size of the largest component in $\mathcal{G}(n,\frac{c}{n})$ at most, if $c \in (0,1)$ (Phase transition in the subcritical case).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $c \in (0,1)$. Then there exists $A = A(c) > 0$ such that with high probability, \emph{every} vertex in $\mathcal{G}(n,\frac{c}{n})$ has component size at most $A\log n$.
\begin{proof}
    For fixed $v\in \N$, and $k\in \N$, we have $\P\left( \left| C_v \right| \ge k \right) = \P(Y_k > 0)$, where $(Y_t)_{t\ge 0}$ is the component exploration process started at $v$. By a simple coupling, this is at most $\P(Y_k^+ > 0)$, where $(Y_t^+)_{t\ge 0}$ is a random walk started at $1$ with i.i.d.\ increments $\sim \text{Bin}(n,p)-1$. Thus,
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( \left| C_v \right| > k \right)
        &= \P\left( Y_k > 0 \right) \le \P(Y_k^+ > 0)\\
        &= \P\left( 1 - k + \text{Bin}(kn,p) > 0 \right) \\
        &= \P\left( \text{Bin}(kn,p) \ge k\right) \\
        &= \P\left( \text{Bin}(kn,p) \ge kc\left(1 + \frac{1-c}{c}\right) \right) \\
        &\le \exp \left( -\varepsilon^2 kc / 4 \right) ,
    \end{align*}
    where $\varepsilon = \frac{1-c}{c}\wedge 1\in (0,1]$. Putting $A\coloneqq \frac{8}{\varepsilon^2 c}$, this gives $\P\left( \left| C_v \right| > A \log n \right) \le \exp \left( -2 \log n \right) = n^{-2}$, so a union bound yields \[
        \P\left( \exists v \in [n]\colon \left| C_v \right| > A \log n  \right) \le \frac{1}{n} \tendsto{} 0.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Phase transition in $\mathcal{G}(n,\frac{c}{n})$ for $c > 1$ (i.e. number of vertices in large and small components).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $c > 1$, and denote by $L_i(G)$ the size of the $i$'th largest component in $G\sim \mathcal{G}(n,\frac{c}{n})$. Then there exists $A > 0$ such that $L_2(G) \le A\log n$ whp, and \[
    \frac{L_1(G)}{n}\tendsto{\P} 1 - \eta(c).
\] Thus, whp, there are $\sim n\rho_k(c)$ vertices in components of size $k = O(\log n)$, and there is one big component of size $\sim n(1-\eta(c))$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $\delta > 0$, and $(Y_t)$ be the exploration process of $G$. Then the drift (expected jump size) in step $t$ is, given $Y_{t-1}$, exactly $\E \left[ \text{Bin}(U_{t-1},p) \right] -1 = U_{t-1} \frac{c}{n} - 1$, which is larger than $c\delta$ iff \[
        U_{t-1} \ge n \left( \frac{1}{c} + \delta \right) \iff n- U_{t-1} \le n\left( 1 - \frac{1}{c} - \delta \right) \eqqcolon k^+.
    \] We define a random walk $(Y_t^-)$ with i.i.d.\ increments $\sim \text{Bin}(n - k^+,p) - 1$, so that $R_t^- \le R_t$ as long as $U_{t-1} \ge n - k^+$. Then, for $k\le k^+$,
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( \left| C_v \right| = k \right)
        &= \P\left( Y_1,\ldots ,Y_{k-1} > 0, Y_k = 0 \right) \le \P(Y_k^- \le 0),
    \end{align*}
    since, in the event of the LHS, $U_k = n - k \ge n - k^+$. Now we can use Chernoff bounds on $Y_k^- \sim 1 - k + \text{Bin}(k(n-k^+),p)$ to obtain, for $k^- \le k \le k^+$, where $k^- \coloneqq \frac{6}{\varepsilon^2}\log n$, $\P\left( \left| C_v \right| = k \right) \le \frac{1}{n^3}$, so \[
        \P\left( \exists v\in V\colon k^- \le \left| C_v \right| \le k^+  \right) \le \frac{1}{n} \tendsto{} 0.
    \] Thus, whp, all vertices are in small components, or big components, and there are whp $\eta(c)n$ vertices in small components. It only remains to show that there is only one big component, which would follow from the existence of $\delta > 0$ with $2k^+ > (1-\eta(c))n$, i.e. from $1-\frac{1}{c} > \frac{1-\eta}{2}$, i.e. $\eta > \frac{2}{c} - 1 \eqqcolon x$. This is the case iff $\e^{-c(1-x)}>x$, which is true.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]In the context of diffusion approximation by Markov chains, the sequence $(X^h_t = Y^h_{\lfloor t / h \rfloor}))$ in $D([0,1],\R^d)$ is tight.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
by Markov chains, the sequence $(X^h_t = Y^h_{\lfloor t / h \rfloor}))$ in $D([0,1],\R^d)$ is tight.

\begin{proof}
    By localisation, we may assume all locally uniform convergences are globally uniform. Tightness of initial values is clear because they are deterministic. Fix $\varepsilon > 0$, and define entropy times $(\tau_n)$, $\mathcal{N}(X^h,\varepsilon)$, and $\delta(X^h,\varepsilon)$ as usual (where $T = 1$), as well as $\theta \coloneqq \max_{0\le t \le 1} \left| X^h(t) - X^h(t-) \right| $. Then \[
        \forall \delta \le \delta(X^h,\varepsilon)\colon \omega(X^h,\delta) \le 3\varepsilon + \theta.
    \] Thus, \[
    \P\left( \omega(X^h,\delta) > 4\varepsilon \right) \le \P(\theta > \varepsilon) + \P(\delta(X^h,\varepsilon) < \delta)
\] Now the first term is easy, since \[
\P(\theta > \varepsilon) \le \frac{1}{h} \sup_{y\in E^h} \Pi_h(y,B(y,\varepsilon)^{c}) = \sup_y \Delta^h_\varepsilon(y) \tendsto{} 0.
\] For the second term, it suffices to show that there exists $C_\varepsilon > 0$ such that $\P(T_j - T_{j-1} \le \delta) = \P(T_1\le \delta) \le C_\varepsilon \delta$. Then, by standard entropy arguments, there exists $\alpha \in (0,1)$ such that \[
\P\left( \delta(X^h,\varepsilon) \le \delta \right) \le \P\left( \mathcal{N}(X^h,\varepsilon) > k \right) + \P\left( \min_{j\le k}(T_j - T_{j-1}) \le \delta \right) \le \e \alpha^k + kC_\varepsilon\delta,
\] which yields the claim. Putting $\tau \coloneqq \inf \left\{ k\ge 1\colon \left| Y^h_k - x_0^h \right| > \varepsilon \right\} $, we have $T_1 = \tau / h$. Let $f\in C^2(\R^d)$ with $f(0) = 1$, and $f(x) = 0$ if $\left\|x\right\|\ge \varepsilon$, and $\left\|f\right\|\le 1$. Then, with $L^h f(x) \coloneqq \int (f(y) - f(x) ) K_h(x,\dd y)$, we have that $(f(Y^h_n) - \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} h L^hf (Y^h_k))_{n\ge 0}$ is a martingale, and since $\left\|L^h f\right\|\le C_\varepsilon$ independent of $h$(!), \[
(f(Y^h_k) + C_\varepsilon h k)_{k\ge 0}
\] is a submartingale(!), so
\begin{align*}
    \P(T_1 \le \delta) = \P(\tau \le \delta / h) \le \E \left[ 1 - f(Y^h_{\tau \wedge (\delta / h)}) \right] \le hC_\varepsilon \delta / h = C_\varepsilon \delta.
\end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]In the context of diffusion approximation by Markov chains, the weak limit of any subsequence of $(X^h_t = Y^h_{\left\lfloor t / h \right\rfloor })$ in $D([0,1],\R^d)$ is a solution to $M(a,b)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} In the context of diffusion approximation by Markov chains, the weak limit of any subsequence of $(X^h)$ in $D([0,1],\R^d)$ is a solution to $M(a,b)$.

\begin{proof}
    Define \[
        L f(x) \coloneqq \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j=1}^d a_{ij}(x) \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_i \partial x_j}(x) + \sum_{i=1}^d b_i(x) \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i}(x).
    \] Then (!) $L^hf \tendsto{} Lf$ uniformly on $\R^d$ for all $f\in C^2_c(\R^d)$. Now suppose that $h_n \tendsto{} 0$ and $X^{h_n}\tendsto{d} X$ for a $C([0,1],\R^d)$-valued process $X$. STS that $X$ solves $(L,x_0)$. We know that \[
    \left( f(X^{h_n}_{h_n k}) - \sum_{j=0}^{k-1} h_n L^{h_n} f(X^{h_n}_{jh_n}) \right) _{k\ge 0}
    \] is a martingale, so whenever $0\le s \le t \le 1$, put $l_n \coloneqq \left\lfloor \frac{t}{h_n} \right\rfloor $ and $k_n \coloneqq \left\lfloor \frac{s}{h_n} \right\rfloor $, so that, for any bounded, continuous, $\mathcal{F}_s$-measurable $F\colon D\to \R$, \[
    \E \left[ F(X^{h_n}) \left( f(X^{h_n}_{h_n l_n}) - f(X^{h_n}_{h_n k_n}) - \sum_{j=k_n}^{l_n - 1} h_n L^{h_n}f(X^{h_n}_{jh_n}) \right)  \right] = 0.
    \] By Skorokhod, WLOG we have $X^{h_n}\tendsto{\text{a.s.}} X$, so the above converges to \[
    \E \left[ F(X) \left( f(X_t) - f(X_s) - \int_s^t L f(X_r) \dd r \right)  \right] .
\] Thus, $\left( f(X_t) - \int_0^t Lf(X_s)\dd s \right) _{t\ge 0}$ is a martingale, which finishes the proof.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Method of duality. What do the conditions mean in the case of Markov processes, and how can it be generalised (Ethier \& Kurtz).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose $E_1,E_2$ are metric spaces and $\P$ and $\Q$ are probability measures on $D([0,\infty),E_1)$ and $D([0,\infty),E_2)$, respectively. Suppose that there exist bounded functions $f,g\colon E_1\times E_2\to \R$ that are continuous in both arguments, and such that the following holds.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $\left( f(X_t,y) - \int_0^t g(X_s,y)\dd s \right) _{t\ge 0}$ defines a $\P$-martingale for all $y\in E_2$,
    \item[(ii)] $\left( f(x,Y_t) - \int_0^t g(x,Y_s)\dd s \right)_{t\ge 0} $ defines a $\Q$-martingale for all $x\in E_1$.
\end{enumerate}
Then, \[
    \E^{\P\otimes \Q} \left[ f(X_t,Y_0) \right] = \E^{\P\otimes \Q}\left[ f(X_0, Y_t) \right] .
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have
    \begin{align*}
        \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \P \left( f(X_t,y) \right) &= \P \left( g(X_t,y) \right),\quad y\in E_2,\\
        \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \Q\left( f(x,Y_t) \right) &= \Q \left( g(x,Y_t) \right) ,\quad x\in E_1,
    \end{align*}
    so, putting $h(r,s) \coloneqq \E \left[ f(X_r,Y_s) \right] $, $h_r(r,s) = h_s(r,s) = \E \left[ g(X_r,Y_s) \right] \eqqcolon h'(r,s) $, so $h$ is continuously differentiable and \[
        \frac{\dd }{\dd s} \E \left[ f(X_s,Y_{t-s}) \right] = \frac{\dd }{\dd s}h(s,t-s) = (1, -1) \begin{pmatrix} h'(s,t-s) \\ h'(s,t-s) \end{pmatrix} = 0,
    \] for all $0\le s \le t$.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Remark.} If $X$ and $Y$ are Markov processes, the assertion holds if $f$ is such that $f(\cdot,y) \in D(A_X)$ and $f(x,\cdot)\in D(A_Y)$ for all $x,y$ and $A_X f(\cdot ,y)(x)= A_Y f(x,\cdot )(y)$ for $x\in E_1$, $y\in E_2$. More generally, if $\alpha \colon E_1\to \R$ and $\beta \colon E_2\to \R$ are continuous and such that \[
    \int_0^t \left| \alpha(X_s) \right| \dd s < \infty,\quad \int_0^t \left| \beta(Y_s) \right| \dd s < \infty
\] hold almost-surely, and \[
A_X f(\cdot ,y)(x) + \alpha(x) f(x,y) = A_Y f(x,\cdot )(y) + \beta(y) f(x,y),\quad x\in E_1,y\in E_2,
\] then \[
\E \left[ f(X_t,Y_0) \exp \left( \int_0^t \alpha(X_s)\dd s \right)  \right] = \E \left[ f(X_0,Y_t) \exp \left( \int_0^t \beta(Y_s)\dd s \right)  \right] ,
\] given both integrands are integrable.
[/latex]

front: [latex]How uniqueness of one-dimensional distributions to $(A,\mu)$ implies uniqueness. What does this imply for using duality as a means to proving uniqueness in distribution of a martingale problem?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose that $A$ is a Markov pregenerator on a compact and separable space $E$. Then, if, for any $\mu \in M_1(E)$, any two solutions to $(A,\mu)$ have the same one-dimensional distributions, then, for any $\mu\in M_1(E)$, any two solutions to $(A,\mu)$ have the same distributions (i.e.\ fidis).\\

\textbf{Remark.} Thus if we can find a process $(Y_t)$ that is dual to any solution of a martingale problem for a sufficiently large class of functions, then uniqueness of one-dimensional distributions and thus uniqueness in distribution of the martingale problem follows.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Harris's lemma on correlation of up-sets $\mathcal{A},\mathcal{B}\subset \mathcal{P}(X)$. (Careful with $\P^{[n]}$ and $\P^{[n-1]}$!)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $X$ be a finite set, and $X_p \subset X$ the random subset that contains each element independently with probability $p\in [0,1]$. Denote its distribution by $\P_p$.\\

\textbf{Lemma (Harris).} Let $\mathcal{A},\mathcal{B}\subset \mathcal{P}(X)$ be up-sets. Then, \[
    \P_p(\mathcal{A}\cap \mathcal{B}) \ge \P_p(\mathcal{A}) \P_p(\mathcal{B}).
\] It follows that down-sets are also positively correlated, and up- and down-sets are negatively correlated.
\begin{proof}
    Use induction, $n=0$ is trivial. Define
    \begin{align*}
        \mathcal{A}^- &\coloneqq \left\{ A \in \mathcal{A}\colon n \not\in A \right\} \\
        \mathcal{A}^+ &\coloneqq \left\{ A \setminus n \colon A\in \mathcal{A}, n\in A \right\} .
    \end{align*}
    Then $\mathcal{A}^+$ and $\mathcal{A}^-$ are upsets, $\mathcal{A}^- \subset \mathcal{A}^+$, and $\P_p(\mathcal{A}) = p\P_p(\mathcal{A}^+) + (1-p) \P_p(\mathcal{A}^-)$. Put $a^\pm \coloneqq \P_p(\mathcal{A}^\pm)$, same for $\mathcal{B}$. Then $(\mathcal{A}\cap \mathcal{B})^\pm = \mathcal{A}^\pm \cap \mathcal{B}^\pm$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \P_p(\mathcal{A}\cap \mathcal{B})
        &= p \P_p(\mathcal{A}^+ \cap \mathcal{B}^+) + (1-p) \P_p(\mathcal{A}^- \cap \mathcal{A}^+)\\
        &\ge p a^+ b^+ + (1-p) a^- b^- \eqqcolon x,
    \end{align*}
    and $\P_p(\mathcal{A}) \P_p(\mathcal{B}) = (pa^+ + (1-p) a^-) (p b^+ + (1-p) b^-) \eqqcolon y$, and
    \begin{align*}
        x-y
        &= p(1-p) \big( a^+ b^+ - a^+ b^- - a^- b^+ + a^-b^-\big)\\
        &= p(1-p) (a^+ - a^-)(b^+ - b^-)\\
        &\ge 0.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Janson's inequality I.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose that $X\neq \varnothing$, and $X_p$ is the random subset of $X$ that contains each element with probability $p\in [0,1]$, independently. Let $n\in \N$, and $E_1,\ldots ,E_n \subset X$, and put $A_i \coloneqq \left\{ E_i \subset X_p \right\} $ for $i\in [n]$, $Z \coloneqq \sum_{i=1}^n \ind_{A_i}$, $\mu = \E \left[ Z \right] $, and $\Delta = \sum_{i} \sum_{j\sim i} \P(A_i\cap A_j)$.\\

\textbf{Proposition (Janson I).} In the above context, we have \[
    \P(Z = 0) \le \e^{-\mu + \Delta / 2}.
\] Together with Janson II, we have $\P(Z = 0) \le \exp \left( - \frac{\mu}{2}\wedge \frac{\mu^2}{2\Delta} \right) $ (so the worse bound of the two, because either bound is only true in one of the cases $\Delta > (\le) \mu$).
\begin{proof}
    We have, putting $r_i \coloneqq \P \left(A_i \,\middle\vert\, \bigcap_{\substack{j<i \\ j\sim i} } A_j^{c}\right)$, that
    \begin{align*}
        \P(Z = 0)
        &= \prod_{i=1}^n (1-r_i) \le \prod_{i=1}^n \e^{-r_i} = \e^{-\sum_{i} r_i}.
    \end{align*}
    Now let $i\in [n]$, and $D_0 \coloneqq \bigcap_{\substack{j < i \\ j\not\sim i} } A_j^{c}$, $D_1 \coloneqq \bigcap_{\substack{j < i \\ j\sim i} } A_j^{c}$, so that $A_i \indep D_0$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \P \left(A_i \,\middle\vert\, D_0 \cap D_1\right)
        &= \frac{\P(A_i \cap D_0 \cap D_1)}{\P(D_0 \cap D_1)} \ge \frac{\P(A_i \cap D_0\cap D_1)}{\P(D_0)}\\
        &= \P \left(A_i \cap D_1 \,\middle\vert\, D_0\right) = \P(A_i) - \P \left(A_i \cap D_1^{c} \,\middle\vert\, D_0\right)\\
        &\ge \P(A_i) - \P(A_i \cap D_1^{c}),
    \end{align*}
    where we used Harris' inequality and that $A_i$ is an upset, and $D_0,D_1$ are downsets. Now
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( A_i \cap D_1^{c} \right) = \P\left( A_i \cap \bigcup_{\substack{j < i \\ j\sim i} A_j}  \right) \le \sum_{\substack{j < i \\ j\sim i} } \P(A_i \cap A_j),
    \end{align*}
    so that \[
        \sum_{i=1}^n r_i \ge \sum_{i=1}^n \P(A_i) - \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{\substack{j < i \\ j\sim i} }\P(A_i \cap A_j) = \mu - \frac{\Delta}{2}.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Janson's inequality II.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose that $X\neq \varnothing$, and $X_p$ is the random subset of $X$ that contains each element with probability $p\in [0,1]$, independently. Let $n\in \N$, and $E_1,\ldots ,E_n \subset X$, and put $A_i \coloneqq \left\{ E_i \subset X_p \right\} $ for $i\in [n]$, $Z \coloneqq \sum_{i=1}^n \ind_{A_i}$, $\mu = \E \left[ Z \right] $, and $\Delta = \sum_{i} \sum_{j\sim i} \P(A_i\cap A_j)$.\\

\textbf{Proposition (Janson II).} In the above context, if $\Delta \ge \mu$, then \[
    \P(Z = 0) \le \e^{-\frac{\mu^2}{2\Delta}}.
\] Together with Janson I, we have $\P(Z = 0) \le \exp \left( - \frac{\mu}{2}\wedge \frac{\mu^2}{2\Delta} \right) $ (so the worse bound of the two, because either bound is only true in one of the cases $\Delta > (\le) \mu$).
\begin{proof}
    For any $S\subset [n]$, by Janson I, \[
        \P(Z = 0) = \P\left( \bigcap_{i=1} ^n A_i ^{c} \right) \le \P\left( \bigcap_{i\in S} A_i ^{c} \right) \le \e^{-\mu_S + \Delta_S / 2}.
    \] Let $S$ be the random subset of $[n]$ that contains each element with probability $r\in [0,1]$, independently of each other. Then
    \begin{align*}
        \widetilde{\E} \left[ \mu_S \right] &= \sum_{i=1}^n \widetilde{\P}(i\in S) \P(A_i) = r\mu,\\
        \widetilde{\E} \left[ \Delta_S \right] &= \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j\sim i} \widetilde{\P}(i,j\in S) \P(A_i \cap A_j) = r^2\Delta.
    \end{align*}
    Thus, $\widetilde{\P}(\mu_S - \Delta_S / 2 \ge r\mu - r^2\Delta / 2) > 0$, so there exists $S\subset [n]$ with $\mu_S - \Delta_S / 2 \ge r\mu - r^2\Delta / 2$, so \[
        \P(Z = 0) \le \e^{-r\mu + r^2\Delta / 2},\quad 0\le r \le 1.
    \] The choice $r = \frac{\mu}{\Delta}$ is valid if $\Delta \ge \mu$, in which case it gives the proposed bound.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: How does the generator of a diffusion $X$ on $[a,b]$ change under a change of time $\tau(t) = \int_0^t \beta(X_s) \dd s$, or a change of space via $S\colon [a,b]\to [S(a),S(b)]$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] \to \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\\

\textbf{Proposition.} If $\beta\colon \R\to (0,\infty)$ is continuous, $\tau(t) \coloneqq \int_0^t \beta(X_s) \dd s$, and $Z_t \coloneqq X_{\tau(t)}$, then $Z$ is a diffusion with generator  \[
    \mathcal{L}_Z f (x) = \beta(x) \mathcal{L}_X f(x), \quad x \in [a,b].
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have \[
        \E^x \left[ X_t - x \right] = \mu(x) t + o(t),\quad \E^x \left[ \left( X_t - x \right) ^2 \right] = \sigma(x)^2 t + o(t),
    \] so $\E^x\left[ Z_t - x \right] = \E^x \left[ X_{\tau(t)}-x \right] = \mu(x) \beta(x) t + o(t)$, and similarly for infinitesimal variance, so $Z$ is a $(\beta \mu,\beta\sigma)$-diffusion.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Proposition.} If $S\colon [a,b]\to \R$ is continuous and strictly increasing, and $Z_t \coloneqq S(X_t)$, then $Z$ is a diffusion with generator \[
    \mathcal{L}_Z f(z) = \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2(x) S'(x)^2 f''(z) + \mathcal{L}_X S (x) f'(z),
\] where $x \coloneqq S^{-1}(z)$.
\begin{proof}
    We have
    \begin{align*}
        \mathcal{L}_Z f(z)
        &= \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \E \left[ f(Z_t) \,\middle\vert\, Z_0 = z\right] = \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \E \left[f(S(X_t)) \,\middle\vert\, X_0 = x\right]\\
        &= \mathcal{L}_X (f\circ S) (x),
    \end{align*}
    the rest is a straight-forward calculation.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: Definition of scale function, speed density, and speed measure of a diffusion $X$ on $[a,b]$. How can the generator be expressed in terms of those?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] \to \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\\

\textbf{Definition.} The \emph{scale function} of $X$ is given by \[
    S(x) \coloneqq \int_{x_0}^x \exp \left( -\int_\eta^y \frac{2\mu(z)}{\sigma^2(z)}\dd z \right) \dd y,\quad x\in [a,b],
\] where $x_0,\eta \in (a,b)$ are fixed but arbitrary. $X$ is said to be on \emph{natural scale} if $S$ can be taken to be linear. The \emph{speed density} and \emph{speed measure} of $X$ are given by \[
m(x) \coloneqq \frac{1}{\sigma^2(x) S'(x)},\quad M(x) \coloneqq \int_{x_0}^x m(x') \dd x',\quad x\in [a,b].
\] With these definitions, we have $\mathcal{L}_X S = 0$ and \[
\mathcal{L}_X f = \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{\dd M / \dd S} \frac{\dd ^2 f}{\dd S^2} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{\dd }{\dd M} \left( \frac{\dd f}{\dd S}  \right) .
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have $\mathcal{L}_X S = 0$ by definition of $S$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \frac{1}{2} \frac{\dd }{\dd M} \left( \frac{\dd f}{\dd S} \right)
        &= \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m(x)} \frac{\dd }{\dd x} \left( \frac{1}{S'(x)} \frac{\dd  f }{\dd x} \right) \\
        &= \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2(x) S'(x) \left( \frac{1}{S'(x)} \frac{\dd ^2f}{\dd x^2} - \frac{S''(x)}{S'(x)^2} \frac{\dd f}{\dd x} \right) \\
        &= \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2(x) \frac{\dd ^2 f}{\dd x^2} + \mu(x) \frac{\dd f}{\dd x}.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: Probabilities $\P \left(T_x < T_y \,\middle\vert\, T_x \wedge T_y < \infty\right)$ (in terms of scale function).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] \to \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\\

\textbf{Proposition.} If $a < x < y < b$, and $x_0 \in [x,y]$, then \[
    \P \left(T_x < T_y \,\middle\vert\, T_x \wedge T_y < \infty\right) = \frac{S(y) - S(x_0)}{S(y) - S(x)}.
\]
\begin{proof}
    $S(X_t)$ has no drift, so it is a time-changed Brownian motion, so \[
        \P^{x_0} \left(T_x < T_y \,\middle\vert\, T_x \wedge T_y < \infty\right) = \P_B^{S(x_0)} \left( T_{S(x)} < T_{S(y)}\right) = \frac{S(y) - S(x_0)}{S(y) - S(x)}.
    \] Note that the choice of $x_0$ cancels in the difference, and the choice of $\eta$ in the ratio.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: Feller boundary classification.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] \to \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\\

\textbf{Definition.} If $M$ and $S$ are the speed measure and the scale function, then define \[
    u(x) = \int_{x_0}^x M \dd S,\quad v(x) = \int_{x_0}^x S \dd M.
\] The boundary at $b$ is said to be
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] \emph{regular} if $u(b) <  \infty$, $v(b) < \infty$,
    \item[(ii)] \emph{exit} if $u(b) < \infty$, $v(b) = \infty$,
    \item[(iii)] \emph{entrance} if $u(b) = \infty$, $v(b) < \infty$,
    \item[(iv)] \emph{natural} if $u(b) = \infty$, $v(b) = \infty$.
\end{enumerate}
The former two are called \emph{accessible}, the latter two \emph{inaccessible}.\\

\textbf{Theorem.} $\mathcal{L}\coloneqq \frac 12 \sigma(\cdot)^2 f''(\cdot) + \mu(\cdot) f'(\cdot)$ defines a Markov generator with domain all $f\in C([a,b]) \cap C^2((a,b))$ with the following additional conditions (for $b$ analogously).
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] If $a$ is inaccessible, no further restrictions,
    \item[(ii)] If $ a$ is exit, then $\mathcal{L}f(x) \tendsto{!} 0$ as $x \to a$,
    \item[(iii)] If $a$ is regular, then for every $q\in [0,1]$ there is a Feller semigroup associated with $\mathcal{L}_q$ for the domain on which the additional assumption \[
            q\lim_{x\to a}\mathcal{L}f(x) = (1-q) \lim_{x\to a}\frac{1}{S'(x)}f'(x)
        \] is satisfied (for $b$ a minus on RHS).
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: Green's function of $(X_t)$ and how it can be used to calculate $\E^x \left[ \int_0^T g(X_s) \dd s \right] $ with exit time $T = T_a \wedge T_b$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] \to \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\\

\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose $T\coloneqq T_a\wedge T_b$, and $g\colon [a,b]\to \R$ is continuous. Then, \[
    \E^x \left[ \int_0^T g(X_s)\dd s \right] = \int_a^b G(x,\xi) g(\xi) \dd \xi,
    \] where the \emph{Green's function} $G\colon (a,b)\times (a,b) \to \R$ is defined by \[
    G(x,\xi) \coloneqq \frac{2m(\xi)}{S(b) - S(a)} \begin{cases}
        (S(b) - S(x)) (S(\xi) - S(a)) &, a < \xi \le x\\
        (S(b) - S(\xi)) (S(x) - S(a)) &, x < \xi < b
    \end{cases}.
\]
\begin{proof}
    Note first that, for $h > 0$, \[
        w(x) = \E^x \left[ \int_0^h g(X_s) \dd s \right] + \E^x \left[ \int_h^T g(X_s) \dd s \right] .
    \] Now,
    \begin{align*}
        \E^x \left[ \int_h^T g(X_s) \dd s \ind_{\left\{ T > h \right\} } \right]
        &= \E^x \left[ \E^x \left[ \int_h^T g(X_s) \dd s \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_h \right] \ind_{\left\{ T > h \right\} } \right] \\
        &= \E^x \left[ \E^{X_h} \left[ \int_0^T g(X_s) \dd s \right] \ind_{\left\{ T > h \right\} } \right] \\
        &= \E^x \left[ w(X_h) \ind_{\left\{ T > h \right\} } \right] ,
    \end{align*}
    where we used that $ \ind_{\left\{ T > h \right\} }T = \ind_{\left\{ T > h \right\} } (h + \inf \left\{ t \ge 0\colon X_{h+t} \in \left\{ a,b \right\}  \right\} )$. Now note that, putting $c \coloneqq (b-x) \wedge (x - a) > 0$, \[
        \P^x(T < h) \le \P^x \left( \left| X_t - x \right| \ge c \right) \le c^{-3} \E \left[ \left| X_t - x \right| ^3 \right] = o(h),
    \] so, since $\E^x \left[ w(X_h) \right] = T_h w (x)$,
    \begin{align*}
        \lim_{h\to 0}\frac{1}{h} \left( \E \left[ \int_h^t g(X_s)\dd s \right] - w(x) \right)
        &= \lim_{h\to 0} \frac{T_h w(x) - w(x)}{h}= \mathcal{L} w (x).
    \end{align*}
    The limit exists and $w\in D(\mathcal{L})$ because \[
        \E^x \left[ \frac{1}{h}\int_0^h g(X_s) \dd s \right] \tendsto{} g(x) \quad (h\to 0),
    \] so we conclude \[
    \begin{cases}
        \mathcal{L} w = -g &,\\
        w(a) = w(b) = 0.
    \end{cases}
\] Now use that $\mathcal{L}w(x) = \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m(x)} \frac{\dd }{\dd x} \left( \frac{w'(x)}{S'(x)} \right)  $ and integrate twice.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: Definition of stationary distribution and reversible stationary distribution for the diffusion $X$, and motivation for the definition of the latter.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] o \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\

extbf{Definition.} $ u \in M_1([a,b])$ is called a \emph{stationary distribution for $(X_t)$} if $X_0 \sim u$ implies $X_t \sim u$ for all $t > 0$. It is called \emph{reversible}, or $X$ is called \emph{reversible w.r.t.\ $ u$} if, for all $f,g\in D(\mathcal{L})$, \[
\int f \mathcal{L}g \dd u = \int g \mathcal{L}f \dd u.
\]
extbf{Motivation.} Suppose $ u(\dd x) = u(x) \dd x$, and $P_t(x,\dd y) = p_t(x,y) \dd y$. Then we might want to define reversability by requiring $ u(x) p_t(x,y) = u(y) p_t(y,x)$. Multiplying by $f(x)g(y)$ and integrating on both sides gives
egin{align*}
    \int \dd x\, u(x) f(x) T_t g(x) = \int \dd y\, u(y) g(y) T_t f (y),
\end{align*}
and differentiating after $t$ (heuristically) gives the equation we required.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Theory of speed and scale: Definition of regularity of $X$, and under what circumstances $\nu(\dd x) \sim m(x) \dd x$ defines a (reversible?) stationary distribution, and when the stationary distribution is unique.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $a < b$, and $\mu,\sigma \colon [a,b] o \R$ are locally Lipschitz, bounded, and $\sigma^2 > 0$ on $(a,b)$, and $X$ is a $(\mu,\sigma)$-diffusion.\

extbf{Definition.} $X$ is called \emph{regular} if $\P^x(T_y < \infty) > 0$ for all $x\in (a,b)$ and $y\in [a,b]$.\

extbf{Theorem.} If $\int_a^b m(x) \dd x \eqqcolon I  < \infty$, then \[
    u(\dd x) \coloneqq rac{m(x)\dd x}{I}
\] defines a reversible stationary distribution for $(X_t)$. If $X$ is regular, on natural scale, and without absorbing boundaries, then a stationary distribution exists iff $I < \infty$, in which case the above is the unique stationary distribution.
egin{proof}
    Clearly, $ u(x)$ as defined above is non-negative and integrates to $1$, so defines a $ u \in M_1([a,b])$. We have
    egin{align*}
        0
        &= rac{1}{2} rac{\dd }{\dd x} (S'(x) \sigma^2(x) u(x))\
        &= rac{1}{2} S''(x) \sigma^2(x) u(x) + rac{1}{2} S'(x) rac{\dd }{\dd x} \left( \sigma^2(x) u(x) ight) \
        &= -S'(x) \mu(x) u(x) + rac{1}{2} S'(x) rac{\dd }{\dd x} \left( \sigma^2(x) u(x) ight), \
    \end{align*}
    so $ rac{1}{2} rac{\dd ^2}{\dd x^2} \left( \sigma^2(x) u(x) ight) - rac{\dd }{\dd x} \left( \mu(x) u(x) ight) = 0$, so, if $f\in D(\mathcal{L})$ with $f,f'$ vanishing on the boundary,
    egin{align*}
        rac{\dd }{\dd t} \E^ u \left[ f(X_t) ight]
        &= \int \mathcal{L}f(x) u(\dd x)\
        &= \int \left( rac{1}{2} \sigma^2(x) u(x) f''(x) + \mu(x) u(x) f'(x) ight) \dd x\
        &= \int f(x) \left( rac{1}{2} rac{\dd^2}{\dd x^2}\left(\sigma^2(x) u(x) ight) - rac{\dd }{\dd x} \left( \mu(x) u(x) ight)  ight) \dd x\
        &= 0.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Clique number of $G(n,p)$: Definition of $X_k$, $\mu_k$, thus $\mu_{k+1}/\mu_k$. Definition and asymptotic behaviour of $k_0$. What are $(1 / p)^k$ and $\mu_{k+1}/\mu_k$ if $k\sim k_0$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Lemma.} Let $0 < p < 1$ fixed, and $G \sim \mathcal{G}(n,p)$. Let $X_k$ be the number of copies of $K_k$ in $G$, and put \[
\mu_k \coloneqq \E \left[ X_k \right] = \binom{n}{k} p^{\binom{k}{2} },\quad \frac{\mu_{k+1}}{\mu_k} = \frac{n-k}{k+1} p^k.
\] Then the ratio is decreasing in $k$, so $\mu_k$ first increases ($\mu_0 = 1,\mu_1 = n,\ldots $), then decreases ($\mu_n = p^{\binom{n}{2} } \ll 1$). Define \[
k_0 \coloneqq \min \left\{ k\ge 1\colon \mu_k < 1 \right\} .
\] Then, $k_0 \sim 2 \frac{\log n}{\log (1 / p)}$. In particular, if $k\sim k_0$, then \[
\left( \frac{1}{p} \right) ^k = n^{2 + o(1)},\quad \frac{\mu_{k+1}}{\mu_k} = n^{-1 + o(1)}.
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have \[
        \left( \frac{n}{k} \right) ^k p^{\binom{k}{2} }\le \mu_k \le \left( \frac{\e n}{k} \right) ^k p^{\binom{k}{2} },
    \] so $\mu_k^{1 / k}= \Theta \left( \frac{n}{k} p^{k / 2} \right) $. Now, if $k \le (1-\varepsilon) 2 \log_{1 / p}(n)$, then $(1 / p)^{k / 2} \le n^{1-\varepsilon}$, so \[
    \frac{n}{k} p^{k / 2} \ge n^{\varepsilon} / k \gg 1,
\] so $k_0 \ge (1-\varepsilon) 2\log_{1 / p} (n)$ for large $n$. Other direction similarly.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Clique number of $G(n,p)$: Asymptotic bound on $\Delta_k / \mu_k^2$ (if $k\sim k_0$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $k\sim k_0$, then  \[
    \frac{\Delta_k}{\mu_k^2} \le \max \left\{ n^{-2 + o(1)}, \frac{n^{-1 + o(1)}}{\mu_k} \right\} .
\]
\begin{proof}
    By definition, if $A_S = \left\{ \text{all edges in $S$ are present} \right\} $ for $S\in [n]^{(k)}$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \Delta_k
        &= \sum_{S} \sum_{T\sim S} \P\left( A_S \cap A_T \right) = \sum_{s=2}^{k-1} \binom{n}{k} \binom{k}{s} \binom{n-k}{k-s} p^{2 \binom{k}{2} - \binom{s}{2}},
    \end{align*}
    so \[
        \frac{\Delta_k}{\mu_k^2} = \sum_{s=2}^{k-1}\alpha_s,\qquad \alpha_s = \frac{\binom{k}{s} \binom{n-k}{k-s}  }{\binom{n}{k} } p^{\binom{s}{2} }\, (0\le s \le k).
    \] By examining ratios, one can show that $\alpha_s$ first decreases, then increases, so
    \begin{align*}
    \frac{\Delta_k}{\mu_k^2}
    &\le k \max_{2\le s \le k-1}\alpha_s\\
    &\le n^{o(1)} \max \left\{ \alpha_2,\alpha_{k-1} \right\} \\
    &\le \max \left\{ n^{-2 + o(1)}, \frac{n^{-1 + o(1)}}{\mu_k} \right\} .
\end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]What is whp the clique number of $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$ for $0 < p < 1$ fixed? (Using the asymptotic bound on $\Delta_k / \mu_k^2$ for the lower bound).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $0 < p < 1$ be fixed. Then, \[
    \P \left( k_0-2 \le \omega(G) \le k_0 \right) \tendsto{} 1.
\]
\begin{proof}
    For the upper bound, just note that
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( \omega(G) > k_0 \right)
        &= \P\left( X_{k_0 + 1} \ge 1 \right) \le \mu_{k_0 + 1} = \mu_{k_0} \frac{\mu_{k_0+1}}{\mu_{k_0}}\le n^{-1 + o(1)} \tendsto{} 0.
    \end{align*}
    For the lower bound, it suffices to show that $\P\left( X_k \ge 1 \right) \to 1$ if $k = k_0 - 2$. Indeed, we have \[
        \mu_k = \frac{\mu_k}{\mu_{k+1}} \mu_{k+1} \ge n^{1 + o(1)}\tendsto{} \infty,
    \] since $k\sim k_0$ and $k+1 = k_0 - 1$, so $\mu_{k+1} \ge 1$. Finally, \[
    \frac{\Delta_k}{\mu_k^2} \le \max \left\{ n^{-2 + o(1)}, \frac{n^{-1 + o(1)}}{\mu_k} \right\} \le n^{-2 + o(1)} \tendsto{} 0.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Clique number of $G(n,p)$: Strong upper bound on $\P\left( \omega(G) < k_0 - 3 \right) $ (by Janson's inequality).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $0 < p < 1$ be fixed. Then, \[
    \P \left( \omega(G) < k_0 - 3 \right) \le \e^{-n ^{2 - o(1)}}.
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have, putting $k \coloneqq k_0 - 3$ \[
        \mu_k = \mu_{k_0 - 1} \frac{\mu_{k_0 - 2}}{\mu_{k_0-1}} \frac{\mu_{k_0 - 3}}{\mu_{k_0 - 2}} \ge n^{2 + o(1)},
    \] and \[
    \frac{\Delta_k}{\mu_k^2} \le \max \left\{ n^{-2 + o(1)}, \frac{n^{-1 + o(1)}}{\mu_k} \right\} \le n^{-2 + o(1)},
    \] so Janson's inequality yields the claim.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Asymptotic chromatic number of $\mathcal{G}(n,p)$, for fixed $0 < p < 1$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $0 < p < 1$ fixed, and $G \sim \mathcal{G}(n,p)$. Then, for every $\varepsilon > 0$, \[
    (1-\varepsilon) \frac{n}{2\log_b n} \le \chi(G) \le (1+\varepsilon) \frac{n}{2\log_b n}
\] whp, where $b = 1 / (1 - p)$.
\begin{proof}
    We know that $\chi(G) \ge n / \alpha(G)$, and $\alpha(G) = \omega(G^{c}) \le k_0(n,1-p)$ whp, where $k_0(n,1-p) \sim 2 \log_b n$.

    For the upper bound, let $m = \left\lfloor n / (\log n)^2 \right\rfloor $ (so that $m =n^{1 + o(1)}$, but $m = o(\text{proposed bound})$). For $W \subset \N$, $\left| W \right| = m$, let $E_W$ be the event that $G[W] \sim \mathcal{G}(m,p)$ contains an independent set of size at least \[
        k \coloneqq k_0(m,1-p) - 3 \sim 2 \log_b m \sim 2 \log_b n.
    \] Then, \[
        \P(E_W^{c}) = \P\left( \alpha(G[W]) < k \right) \le \e^{-m^{2 - o(1)}} = \e^{-n ^{2 - o(1)}},
    \] so, putting $E \coloneqq \bigcap_{W} E_W$, $\P(E^{c}) \le 2^n \e^{-n^{2 - o(1)}} \tendsto{} 0$. Now suppose that $G$ is a fixed graph on $n$ vertices for which $E$ holds. Then pick independent sets of size $k$ and give them some colour each, until $<m$ vertices are left, give them all their own colours, so \[
    \chi(G) \le \frac{n}{k} + m \sim \frac{n}{2\log_b n}.
\] In particular, $\chi(G) \le (1+\varepsilon) n / (2\log_b n)$ for large $n$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Suppose $U\subset \R^d$ is open and bounded. Then all moments of the exit time $T\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon B_t \not\in U \right\} $ are finite.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} Let $U\subset \R^d$ be open and bounded, and put $T\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon B_t\not\in U \right\} $. Then, \[
\sup_{x\in U} \E^x \left[ T^p \right] < \infty, \quad p > 0.
\]
\begin{proof}
    We have \[
        \E^x \left[ T^p \right] = \int_0^\infty \P^x \left( T^p \ge x \right) \dd s = \int_0^\infty p s^{p-1} \P^x \left( T \ge s \right) \dd s,
    \] so it suffices to show that $\sup_x \P^x \left( T \ge k \right) \le q^k$ for all $k\in \N$ for some $q \in (0,1)$. We have \[
    \P^x(T \ge 1) \le \P^x( B_1 \in \overline{U} ) \le \P^x \left( \left| B_1-x \right| \le K \right) = \P^0 \left( \left| B_1 \right| \le K \right)  \eqqcolon q \in (0,1),
    \] where $K \coloneqq \text{diam}\, U$. For $k \ge 2$, we have
    \begin{align*}
        \P^x \left( T \ge k \right)
        &= \P^x \left( T \ge k, B_1 \in U \right) = \E^x \left[ \ind_{\left\{ B_1 \in U \right\} } \P^{B_1}\left( T\ge k-1 \right)   \right] \\
        &\le q^{k-1} \P^x \left( B_1 \in U \right) \le q^k.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of harmonic function $u\colon \overline{U}\to \R$. In that case, what do you know about $(u(B_t))_{0\le t\le T}$, and how can $u(x),x\in \overline{U}$, be expressed in terms of Brownian motion?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Theorem.} Let $U\subset \R^d$ be open and bounded. Then a function $u\in C(\overline{U},\R) \cap C^2(U,\R)$ is called \emph{harmonic} if $\Delta u = 0$ on $U$, in which case it is said to solve the \emph{Dirichlet problem} with boundary $\phi \coloneqq u \!\!\restriction_{\partial U} \in C(\partial U,\R)$. Then, $(u(B_t))_{t\ge 0}$ is a local martingale, and \[
    u(x) = \E^x \left[ u(B_T) \right] = \E^x \left[ \phi(B_T) \right] ,\quad x\in \overline{U},
\] where $T = \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon B_t \not\in U \right\} $. In particular, a solution to the Dirichlet problem with fixed boundary value is, if it exists, unique and given by the above formula.
\begin{proof}
    By Ito's formula, we have \[
        u(B_t) = u(x) + \sum_{i=1}^d \int_0^t D_i u(B_s) \dd B^j_s,\quad 0\le t\le T,
    \] so there exists a random time-change $\gamma \colon [0,\infty) \to [0,T]$ such that $X_t \coloneqq u(B_{\gamma(t)}),\,t\ge 0,$ defines a bounded martingale (take $\gamma(t) \coloneqq \inf \left\{ s\ge 0\colon \left<M \right> _s > t \right\} \wedge T\uparrow T$). We thus have $X_t \tendsto{} X_\infty = u(B_T)$ a.s.\ and in $L^2$ ($T < \infty$ a.s., and $u$ is continuous), so, for any $x\in \overline{U}$,
    \begin{align*}
        u(x) = u(B_0) = X_0 = \E \left[ X_0 \right] = \E \left[ X_\infty \right] = \E^x \left[ u(B_T) \right] .
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition recurrence, neighbourhood recurrence, and transience for an $\R^d$-valued Markov process.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} An $\R^d$-valued Markov process is said to be
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] \emph{recurrent} if it visits every point $x\in \R^d$ infinitely often,
    \item[(ii)] \emph{neighbourhood recurrent} if it visits every open set infinitely often,
    \item[(iii)] \emph{transient} if it goes to $\infty$ almost-surely,
\end{enumerate}
where doing something infinitely often means doing it for arbitrarily large times almost-surely.
[/latex]

front: [latex]$\P^x \left( T_r < T_R \right) $ for $0 < r < \left| x \right| < R$ for Brownian motion, and connection with Bessel process.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Let $0 < r < \left| x \right| <R$. Then, \[
    \P^x \left( T_r < T_R \right) = \frac{\psi(R) - \psi(\left| x \right| )}{\psi(R) - \psi(r)},
\] where $\psi$ is a non-vanishing solution to $\psi''(\rho) + \frac{d-1}{\rho}\psi'(\rho) = 0$, so \[
\psi(\rho) = \begin{cases}
    c_1 \rho + c_2 &, d = 1,\\
    c_2 \log \rho + c_2 &, d=2,\\
    c_1 \rho ^{2 - d} +c_2 &, d\ge 3.
\end{cases}
\] In particular, those are the 1d-exit times of a diffusion with generator $\frac{1}{2} \frac{\dd ^2}{\dd x^2} + \frac{d-1}{2x}\frac{\dd }{\dd x}$, so the Bessel process of dimension $d$, i.e.\ the modulus of $d$-dimensional Brownian motion.
\begin{proof}
    Let $A \coloneqq \left\{ x\in \R^d\colon r < \left| x \right| < R \right\} $, open and bounded. Then the Ansatz $u(x) = \psi(\left| x \right| )$ gives a harmonic function (in fact, every harmonic function on $A$ has to be radially symmetric) iff $\psi$ solves the above equation, to which the general solution is as given above. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        \psi(\left| x \right| )
        &= u(x) = \E^x \left[ u(B_T) \right] = \P^x\left( T_r < T_R \right) \psi(r) + \P^x \left( T_R < T_r \right) \psi(R),
    \end{align*}
    which implies the claim.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Brownian motion is neighbourhood recurrent in $d = 2$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]\textbf{Proposition.} In $d=2$, Brownian motion is neighbourhood recurrent.
\begin{proof}
    Because BM is a strong Markov process, it suffices to show that it hits every ball with probability one. Let  $\varepsilon > 0$. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        \P^x \left( T_\varepsilon < \infty \right)
        &= \P^x \left( \bigcup_{R \in \N} \left\{ T_\varepsilon < T_R \right\}  \right) = \lim_{R\to \infty} \P^x \left( T_\varepsilon < T_R \right) \\
        &= \lim_{R\to \infty} \frac{\log R - \log \left| x \right| }{\log R - \log \varepsilon} = 1.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of polar sets, singletons are polar in $d\ge 2$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition.} A compact set $K\subset \R^d$ is called \emph{polar} if $\P^x \left( B_t \in K \text{ for some $t > 0$} \right) = 0$ for all $x\in \R^d$.\\

\textbf{Proposition.} Singletons are polar if $d\ge 2$. In particular, Brownian motion is not recurrent if $d\ge 2$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $T \coloneqq \inf \left\{ t > 0\colon B_t = 0 \right\} $. Then, for $x\neq 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \P^x\left( T < \infty \right)
        &= \lim_{R \to \infty} \P^x\left( T < T_R \right) \le \lim_{R\to \infty}\varliminf_{\varepsilon\to 0} \P^x \left( T_\varepsilon < T_R \right) \\
        &= \lim_{R\to \infty} 0 = 0.
    \end{align*}
    Now, if $x = 0$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \P^0 \left( \text{$B_t = 0$ for some $t\ge \varepsilon$} \right)
        &= \P^0\left( \P^{B_\varepsilon} \left( T < \infty \right)  \right) = 0
    \end{align*}
    for all $\varepsilon > 0$, and LHS converges to $\P^0(T < \infty)$ as $\varepsilon \to 0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Brownian motion is transient in $d \ge 3$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Brownian motion is transient in $d\ge 3$. That is, $\lim_{t\to \infty}\left| B_t \right| = \infty$ almost-surely.
\begin{proof}
    For $n\in \N$, put \[
    A_n \coloneqq \left\{ \text{$\left| B_t \right| \le \sqrt{n} $ for some $t\ge T_n$} \right\} .
    \] Then, \[
    \P^x(A_n) = \E^x \left[ \P^{B_{T_n}}\left( T_{\sqrt{n} }<\infty \right)  \right] = \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{n} } \right) ^{d-2},
    \] where we used that $\P^x \left( T_r < \infty \right) = \lim_{R\to \infty}\frac{R^{2-d}-\left| x \right| ^{2-d}}{R^{2-d} - r^{2-d}}$, so \[
    \P^x\left( \varlimsup_{n\to \infty}A_n^{c} \right) = \lim_{n\to \infty} \P^x \left( \bigcup_{k\ge n} A_k^{c} \right) \ge \lim_{n\to \infty} \P^x \left( A_n^{c} \right) = 1,
\] so $(B_t)$ almost-surely eventually leaves $B(0,\sqrt{n}) $ for infinitely many $n\in \N$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition harmonic measure on $\partial U$ for $U\subset \R^d$ open and bounded, and Poisson formula for harmonic measure on unit sphere.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Proposition.} Let $U\subset \R^d$ be open and bounded, and $T\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon B_t\not\in U \right\} $. Then $\mu(x,\cdot )\coloneqq \P^x \left( B_T \in \cdot  \right) $ for $x\in U$ is called the \emph{harmonic measure} on $\partial U$. If $U$ is the unit sphere, then \[
    \mu(x,A) = \P^x \left( B_T \in A \right) = \int_A \frac{1 - \left| x \right| ^2}{\left| x-y \right| ^d} \pi(\dd y),\quad A\in \B(\partial U),
\] for $x\in U$, where $\pi$ is the uniform measure on $\partial U$.
\begin{proof}
    It suffices to show that, for any $\phi\in C( \partial U)$, we have \[
        \E^x \left[ \phi(B_T) \right] = \int_{\partial U} \frac{1-\left| x \right| ^2}{\left| x-y \right| ^d}\phi(y) \pi(\dd y) \eqqcolon u(x),\quad x\in U.
    \] Thus it is sufficient to show that $u$ is harmonic and can be continuously extended to $\overline{U}$ such that $u\!\!\restriction_{\partial U} = \phi$. It is a straight-forward calculation that $\Delta u \equiv 0$. Now consider $\phi\equiv 1$. In that case, $u$ is rotationally symmetric and $u(0) = 1$, so for any $x\in U$, $\left| x \right| \in (0,1)$, \[
    1 = u(0) = \E^0 \left[ u(B_{T_{\left| x \right| }}) \right] = \E^0 \left[ u(x) \right] = u(x),
\] so $u\equiv 1$. Now, let $z\in \partial U$, $\delta > 0$, $D_0 \coloneqq \partial U \cap B(y,\delta)$, and $D_1 = \partial U \setminus D_0$. Then, for $x\in U$, $\left| x-z \right| < \delta$,
\begin{align*}
    \left| \phi(z) - u(x) \right|
    &\le \int_{\partial U} \frac{1-\left| x \right| ^2}{\left| x-y \right| ^d} \left| \phi(z) - \phi(y) \right| \pi(\dd y)\\
    &\le 2 \left\|\phi\right\| \underbrace{\int_{D_1} \frac{1-\left| x \right| ^2}{\left| x-y \right| ^d}\pi(\dd y)}_{\tendsto{} 0 \, (x\to z)} + \sup_{y\in D_0} \left| \phi(z) - \phi(y) \right|
\end{align*}
Thus, for any $\delta > 0$, \[
    \varlimsup_{\substack{x\to z \\ x\in U} } \left| \phi(z) - u(x) \right| \le \sup_{\substack{\left| y-z \right| < \delta \\ y\in \partial U} } \left| \phi(z) - \phi(y) \right| \tendsto{} 0,\quad \delta \to 0.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of Poisson problem for $g\in C(U)$ for $U\subset \R^d$ bounded and open, and connection with expected occupation time measure of Brownian motion and $G_U$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Proposition.} Let $U\subset \R^d$ be open and bounded, and $g\in C(U)$. Then $u\in C(\overline{U}) \cap C^2(U)$ is called a solution to the \emph{Poisson problem for $g$} if \[
\begin{cases}
    \frac{1}{2}\Delta u = -g & \text{on $U$},\\
    u = 0 & \text{on $\partial U$}.
\end{cases}
\] In that case, if $T\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon B_t\not\in U \right\} $, then \[
u(x) = \E^x \left[ \int_0^T g(B_s) \dd s \right] = \int_U G_U(x,y) g(y) \dd y ,\quad x\in U,
\] if $G_U$ is Green's function of Brownian motion on $U$. In particular, solutions to the Poisson problem are unique (if they exist).
\begin{proof}
    By Ito's formula,
    \begin{align*}
        u(B_{t\wedge \tau}) = u(x) + \text{(clm)} - \int_0^{t\wedge \tau} g(B_s) \dd s,\quad 0\le t < T,
    \end{align*}
    so $M_t \coloneqq u(B_{t\wedge \tau}) + \int_0^{t\wedge \tau} g(B_s) \dd s$ defines a local martingale which is uniformly bounded by $\left\|u\right\| + T \left\|g\right\|$, so $L^2$-bounded, so \[
        u(x)= \E^x \left[ M_0 \right] = \E^x \left[ M_{\infty} \right]  = \E^x \left[ \int_0^T g(B_s) \dd s \right] .
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex](In-)Finiteness of occupation time $\int_0^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s) \dd s$ of Brownian motion for open, bounded $U\subset \R^d$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $U\subset \R^d$ be open and bounded. Then, for any $x\in \R^d$, \[
    \int_0^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s) \dd s = \infty,\quad \text{$\P^x$-a.s.},
\] if $d = 2$, and \[
\E^x \left[ \int_0^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s)\dd s \right] < \infty,
\] if $d \ge 3$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $d = 2$ and assume $U = B(0,r)$. Then put $T_0 \coloneqq 0$ and, for $n\in \N$,
    \begin{align*}
        S_k &\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t > T_{k-1} \colon \left| B_t \right| < r \right\} ,\\
        T_k &\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t > S_k\colon \left| B_t \right| > 2r \right\} .
    \end{align*}
    Since $B$ is neighbourhood-recurrent, this defines a sequence of finite stopping times. Now, if $k\in \N$ and $z \ge 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \P^x \left(\int_{S_k}^{T_k} \ind_U(B_s) \dd s \ge z \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_{S_k}\right)
        &= \P ^{B_{S_k}} \left( \int_0^{T_1} \ind_U(B_s) \dd s \ge z \right) \\
    \end{align*}
    is constant (because the RHS only depends on $\left| B_{S_k} \right| = r$) and does not depend on $k$, so $\int_{S_k}^{T_k} \ind_U(B_s) \dd s$ is independent of $\mathcal{F}_{S_k}$ and its non-zero distribution does not depend on $k$. Thus, \[
        \int_0^\infty \ind_U(B_s) \dd s = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \int_{S_k}^{T_k} \ind_U(B_s) \dd s = \infty
    \] $\P^x$-a.s.\ by the strong law of large numbers.

    Now, if $d\ge 3$, and $x = 0$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \E^0 \left[ \int_0^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s) \dd s \right]
        &= \int_{U} G(0,y) \dd y = c(d) \int_0^r s^{d-1} s^{2-d} \dd s = c(d) \frac{r^2}{2}< \infty,
    \end{align*}
    and, if $x \neq 0$, and $T \coloneqq T_{\left| x \right| }$,
    \begin{align*}
        \E^x \left[ \int_0^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s) \dd s \right]
        &= \E^0 \left[ \int_T^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s) \dd s \right]\\
        &\le \E^0 \left[ \int_0^\infty \ind_{U}(B_s) \dd s \right] < \infty.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Green's function of Brownian motion in $\R^d$ for $d\ge 3$ and connection with expected occupation time measure.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Proposition.} Let $d\ge 3$ and put \[
    G(x,y) \coloneqq \int_0^\infty p_t(x,y) \dd t = \frac{\Gamma \left( d / 2 - 1 \right) }{2 \pi^{d / 2}} \left| x-y \right| ^{2-d}.
\] Then, for $f\colon \R^d\to \R$ measurable and bounded or non-negative, \[
\E^x \left[ \int_0^\infty f(B_s) \dd s \right] = \int_{\R^d} G(x,y) f(y) \dd y,\quad x\in \R^d.
\]
\begin{proof}
    If $f$ is bounded, then, by Fubini,
    \begin{align*}
        \E^x \left[ \int_0^\infty f(B_s) \dd s \right]
        &= \int_0^\infty \E^x \left[ f(B_s) \right] \dd s = \int_0^\infty \int_{\R^d} p_t(x,y) f(y) \dd y \dd s\\
        &= \int_{\R^d} G(x,y) f(y)\dd y,
    \end{align*}
    for any $x\in \R^d$. If $f$ is non-negative, the claim thus follows with monotone convergence.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Green's function $G_U$ of a bounded domain $U\subset \R^d$ of Brownian motion in $d\ge 3$, and connection with expected occupation time measure.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Proposition.} Let $U\subset \R^d$ be open and bounded, and put \[
    G_U(x,y) \coloneqq G(x,y) - \int_{\partial U} G(z,y) \mu(x,\dd z),\quad x,y\in U,\, x\neq y,
\] where $\mu(x,\cdot ) = \P^x \left( B_T \in \cdot  \right) $ is the harmonic measure on $\partial U$. Then, for $x\in U$ and $f\colon U \to \R$ measurable and bounded or non-negative, \[
\E^x \left[ \int_0^T f(B_s) \dd s \right] = \int_U G_U(x,y) f(y) \dd y,
\] so $G_U(x,\cdot )$ is the density of the expected occupation time measure.
\begin{proof}
    Let $f\colon U\to \R$ be measurable and bounded, and $x\in U$. Put $f\equiv 0$ on $U^{c}$. Then, \[
        w(x) \coloneqq \E^x \left[ \int_0^\infty f(B_s) \dd s \right] = \int_{U} G(x,y) f(y) \dd y,
    \] but also \[
    w(x) = \E^x \left[ \int_0^T f(B_s)\dd s \right] + \E^x \left[ w(B_T) \right] .
    \] Thus,
    \begin{align*}
        \E^x \left[ \int_0^T f(B_s) \dd s \right]
        &= \int_U G(x,y) f(y) \dd y - \E^x \left[ \int_U G(B_T,y) f(y) \dd y \right] \\
        &= \int_U G(x,y) f(y) \dd y - \int_U \left( \int_{\partial U} G(z,y) \mu(x,\dd z) \right) f(y) \dd y\\
        &= \int_U G_U(x,y) f(y) \dd y.
    \end{align*}
    It follows from this equation that $G_U$ must be non-negative, so the statement for non-negative $f$ follows by monotone convergence.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Feynman-Kac formula for heat equation with dissipation rate in $\R^d$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Definition/Proposition.} A continuous function $u\colon [0,\infty) \times \R^d\to \R$ that is $C^2$ on $(0,\infty)\times \R^d$ is said to satisfy the \emph{heat equation with heat dissipation rate $c\colon (0,\infty)\times \R^d\to \R$ and initial condition $f\colon \R^d\to \R$} if \[
    \begin{cases}
        \frac{\partial u}{\partial t}(t,x) = \frac{1}{2}\Delta u(t,x) - c(t,x)u(t,x) & \text{on $(0,\infty)\times \R^d$},\\
        u(0,\cdot ) = f(\cdot ).
    \end{cases}
\] In that case, and if $u$ is bounded on $[0,t]\times \R^d$ for all $t > 0$ and $c$ is bounded, then \[
u(t,x) = \E^x \left[ f(B_t) \exp \left( - \int_0^t c(t-r,B_r)\dd r \right)  \right] ,\quad t\ge 0,x\in \R^d.
\] In particular, the heat equation has a unique (locally bounded) solution in this case.
\begin{proof}
    Define, for fixed $t\ge 0$ and $s\in [0,t)$, \[
        M_s \coloneqq u(t-s,B_s) \exp \left( -\int_0^s c(t-r,B_r)\dd r \right) .
    \] Then applying Ito's formula to the csm $(t-s,B^1_s,\ldots ,B^d_s,\int_0^s c(t-r,B_r)\dd r)_{s\ge 0}$ gives that $M$ is a local martingale. It is bounded by assumption, so a uniformly integrable martingale, and $M_s \tendsto{\text{a.s.}} f(B_t) \exp \left( -\int_0^t c(t-r,B_r)\dd r \right) \eqqcolon M_t$, so convergence holds in $L^1$ and \[
    u(t,x) = M_0 = \E^x\left[ M_0 \right] = \E^x \left[ M_t \right]
    \] for $x\in\R^d$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Feynman-Kac formula for one-dimensional parabolic equation (and generalisation without proof).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} Suppose that $F$ solves \[
\begin{cases}
    \frac{\partial F}{\partial t}(t,x) +\mu(t,x) \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}(t,x) + \frac{1}{2}\sigma^2(t,x) \frac{\partial^2 F}{\partial x^2} = 0 &, 0\le t \le T,\\
    F(T,\cdot ) = \Phi(\cdot ).
\end{cases}
\] Then, if $(X_t)_{0\le t \le T}$ solves $\dd X_t = \mu(t,X_t)\dd t + \sigma(t,X_t) \dd B_t$, and \[
\int_0^T \E \left[ \left( \sigma(s,X_s) \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}(s,X_s) \right) ^2  \right] \dd s < \infty,
\] then $F(t,x) = \E \left[\Phi(X_T) \,\middle\vert\, X_t = x\right]$.\\

\textbf{Remark.} There is also a formula in the case where there are additional terms $V(t,x) F(t,x) + f(t,x)$.
\begin{proof}
    Applying Ito's formula to $(F(s,X_s))_{t\le s \le T}$ for some fixed $t$ gives
    \begin{align*}
        \Phi(X_T)
        &= F(T,X_T) \\
        &= F(t,X_t) + \int_t^T \left( \frac{\partial F}{\partial s}(s,X_s) \mu(s,X_s) \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}(s,X_s) + \frac{1}{2}\sigma(s,X_s)^2 \frac{\partial^2 F}{\partial x^2}(s,X_s)  \right) \dd s \\
        &\phantom{=} + \int_t^T \sigma(s,X_s) \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}(s,X_s) \dd B_s\\
        &= F(t,X_t) + \int_t^T \sigma(s,X_s) \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}(s,X_s) \dd B_s.
    \end{align*}
    By assumption, this local martingale is a true martingale, so \[
        \E \left[\Phi(X_T) \,\middle\vert\, X_t = x\right] = F(t,x).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Schilder's theorem on LDP of Brownian motion and sketch of proof.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} The family $(\sqrt{\varepsilon} B\colon 0<\varepsilon<1)$ of $E=C_0([0,1])$-valued random variables satisfies LDP with good rate function \[
    I\colon E\to [0,\infty]; \, w\mapsto \begin{cases}
        \frac{1}{2} \int_0^1 \left| \dot{w}(t) \right| ^2 \dd t &, w\in H^{1,2},\\
        \infty &, \text{else}.
    \end{cases}
\]
\begin{proof}
    Uses the generalised contraction principle. Let $E_n = \R ^{2^n}$, $\pi_n\colon E\to E_n$ the evaluation at the $n$-th dyadics, $g_n\colon E_n \to E$ the natural linearly interpolating map, and $f_n \coloneqq g_n \circ \pi_n\colon E\to E$, which is continuous. Put $X^\varepsilon \coloneqq \sqrt{\varepsilon} B$ and $X^\varepsilon_n \coloneqq f_n(X^\varepsilon) = g_n(\pi_n(X^\varepsilon))$, where $\pi_n(X^\varepsilon)$ is just Gaussian and has LDP with strong rate \[
        I_n\colon E_n \to E_n; a \mapsto \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k=1}^{2^n} 2^n \left( a_k - a_{k-1} \right) ^2,
    \] so $X_n^\varepsilon$ has good rate
    \begin{align*}
        I_n'(w)
        &= \inf \left\{ I_n(a)\colon g_n(a) = w \right\} = \begin{cases}
            I(w) &, w \in g_n(E_n),\\
            \infty &, \text{else}
        \end{cases}\\
        &= \inf \left\{ I(x)\colon x\in E, f_n(x) = w \right\} .
    \end{align*}
    It thus suffices to show that $I$ is a good rate, that $X_n^\varepsilon \tendsto{} X^\varepsilon$ exponentially, and that $f_n \tendsto{} \id_E$ uniformly on $\left\{ I \le c \right\} $ for $c > 0$.

    Let $c > 0$ and $w\in I_c$. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| w_t - w_s \right|
        &= \left| \int_s^t \dot{w}_r \dd r \right| \le \sqrt{t-s} \sqrt{\int_0^t \left| \dot{w}_r \right| ^2 \dd r} \\
        &\le \sqrt{2c(t-s)} ,
    \end{align*}
    so $I_c$ is equicontinuous and thus relatively compact. It remains to show closedness, which is not too hard.

    Exponential convergence is quite straight-forward as well, and if $w\in I_c$ for $c > 0$, then, for $n\in \N$ and $t\in [t^n_{k-1},t^n_k]$,
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|w - f_n(w)\right\|
        &= \max_{1\le k \le 2^n} \sup_{t\in J_k} \left| w_t - f_n(w)_t \right| \\
        &\le 2 \max_k \sup_{s\le 2^{-n}} \left| w_{t_k^n + s} - w_{t_k^n} \right| \\
        &\le 2 \max_k \int_{t_k^n}^{t_{k+1}^n} \left| \dot{w}_s \right| \dd s\\
        &\le 2 \sqrt{2^{-n}} \sqrt{2c} .
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: Exponential distribution (pdf, cdf, expectation, variance, mgf, cf).
back:
[latex]
Let $X\sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)$, $\lambda > 0$.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $f(x) = \lambda \e ^{-\lambda x}$,
    \item[(ii)] $\P(X\le x) = 1 - \e^{-\lambda x}$,
    \item[(iii)] $\E \left[ X \right] = \frac{1}{\lambda}$,
    \item[(iv)]  $\V(X) = \frac{1}{\lambda^2}$,
    \item[(v)] $\E \left[ \e ^{aX} \right] = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda - a}$,
    \item[(vi)] $\E \left[ \e ^{\i t X} \right] = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda - \i t}$.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: Poisson distribution (expectation, variance, pgf, mgf, cf)
back:
[latex]
Let $X\sim \text{Poi}(\lambda)$, $\lambda > 0$.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $p_k = \e^{-\lambda} \frac{\lambda^k}{k!}, k\in  \N_0$,
    \item[(ii)] $\E \left[ X \right] = \lambda$,
    \item[(iii)]  $\V(X) = \lambda$,
    \item[(iv)] $\E \left[ z^X \right] = \exp \left( \lambda(z-1) \right) $,
    \item[(v)] $\E \left[ \e ^{aX} \right] = \exp \left( \lambda (\e^a - 1) \right) $,
    \item[(vi)] $\E \left[ \e^{i t X} \right] = \exp \left( \lambda (\e^{\i t}-1) \right) $.

\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

Let $X\sim \text{Geo}(p)$ (including first success), $Y = X-1$ (only failures), $p\in (0,1]$.

front: Probability generating function and how to obtain (factorial) moments and [$]p_k[/$] from it.
back:
[latex]
For $\N_0$-valued random variable $X$, $g(s) \coloneqq g_X(s) \coloneqq \sum_{k=0}^\infty p_k s^k$. Then,
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $p_k = \frac{1}{k!} g^{(k)}(0)$,
    \item[(ii)] $g ^{(k)}(1-)$ is $k$-th factorial moment, in particular $\E \left[ Z \right] = g'(1-)$,
    \item[(iii)] $\V(X) = g''(1-) + g'(1-) - g'(1-)^2$.
\end{enumerate}
All proofs are trivial.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Solution to recurrence $p_n = a_n p_{n-1} + b_n$ started at $p_s, \, s\in \Z$ (and simplification if $p_s = b_s$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $p_n = a_n p_{n-1} + b_n$, started at $p_s$ for some $s\in \Z$, then \[
p_n = \sum_{l=s+1}^n \left[ b_l \prod_{m=l+1}^n a_m \right] + p_s \prod_{m=s+1}^n a_m.
\]
If $p_s = b_s$, this simplifies to $p_n = \sum_{l=s}^n \left[ b_l \prod_{m = l+1}^n a_m \right] $.
[/latex]

front: Lagrange Multipliers.
back:
[latex]
Let $f,g_1, \ldots ,g_s \in C^1(U)$ and $U\subset \R^d$ open, such that $\left\{ \nabla g_i(x)\colon i\in [s] \right\} \subset \R^d$ is linearly independent for all $x\in U$. Put \[
    \Lambda\colon U \times \R^s \to \R; \, (x,\lambda) \mapsto f(x) - \sum_{k=1}^s \lambda_k g_k(x).
\] Then, if $x_\star \in U$ is a local extremum of $f$ under the condition $g_i(x_\star) = 0\forall i\in [s]$, then $\frac{\partial \Lambda}{\partial x_i} (x_\star)= 0$ for all $i\in [d] $. (Together with the constraints, this gives $d + s$ equations for $x$ and $\lambda$, and the solutions are all possible \emph{candidates} for local extrema).
[/latex]

front: [latex]Stirling formula, standard bounds for binomial coefficients (with proof), and sum formula for $\sum_{m=k}^n \binom{m}{k}$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Stirling formula is $n! \sim \sqrt{2\pi n} \left( \frac{n}{\e} \right) ^n$ (and $\ge$). \[
    \left( \frac{n}{k} \right) ^k \le \binom{n}{k} \le \frac{n^k}{k!}\le \left( \frac{\e n}{k} \right) ^k.
\] The upper bound follows from $k! \ge (k/\e)^k$, which follows directly from series expansion of $\e^k$.  \[
\sum_{m=k}^n \binom{m}{k}  = \binom{n+1}{k+1} .
\]
[/latex]

front: [latex]A continuous local martingale $M$ with $M_0 = 0$ converges a.s.\ on $\left\{ \left<M \right> _\infty < \infty \right\} $.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $M$ be a clm with $M_0 = 0$. Then  there exists $M_\infty$ such that $M_t \tendsto{} M_\infty$ a.s.\ on $\left\{ \left<M \right> _\infty<\infty \right\} $.

\begin{proof}
    For $n\in \N$, put $\tau_n \coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon \left<M \right> _t >n \right\} $. Then $M^{\tau_n}$ is an $L^2$-bounded martingale, so \[
    M^{\tau_n}_t \tendsto{} M^{n}_\infty
    \] a.s. Let $N$ be a $\P$-null-set such that $M^{\tau_n}(\omega) \tendsto{} M^n_\infty(\omega)$ for all $n\in \N$ and $\omega\not\in N$. Then, if $\omega\in \left\{ \left<M \right> _\infty\le n \right\}\setminus N $ and $n\le m$, $\tau_n(\omega) = \tau_m(\omega) = \infty$ and \[
    M^n_\infty(\omega) \longleftarrow M^{\tau_n}_t(\omega) = M_t(\omega) = M^{\tau_m}_t(\omega) \tendsto{} M^m_\infty(\omega).
\] Thus, \[
M_\infty(\omega) \coloneqq \begin{cases}
    M^n_\infty(\omega) &, \left<M \right> _\infty(\omega) \le n,\\
    0 &, \left<M \right> _\infty(\omega) = \infty,
\end{cases}
\] is well-defined, and $M_t(\omega) \tendsto{} M_\infty(\omega)$ for all $\omega\in \left\{ \left<M \right> _\infty<\infty \right\}\setminus N $.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Distribution of $\int_0^t A(s) \dd B_s$ for $A\in C([0,\infty),\R ^{n\times m})$ and $m$-dimensional Brownian motion $B$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $A\colon [0,\infty) \to \R ^{n\times m}$ has continuous, and $B$ is an $m$-dimensional Brownian motion, then  \[
    \int_0^t A(s) \dd B_s \sim \mathcal{N}_n \left( 0, \int_0^t A(s) A(s)^\top \dd s \right) .
\]
\begin{proof}
    Fix $t\ge 0$, and take $\Delta_n$ with $\left| \Delta_n \right| \to 0$ and \[
        \sum_{t_i \in \Delta_n} A(t_i) (B_{t_{i+1}}- B_{t_i}) \tendsto{\text{a.s.}} \int_0^t A(s) \dd B_s.
    \] The LHS has distribution
    \begin{align*}
        \sum_{t_i\in \Delta_n} A(t_i) \mathcal{N}_m\left( 0, (t_{i+1}-t_i) I_m \right)
        &\stackrel{d}{=} \sum_{t_i\in \Delta_n} \mathcal{N}_n \left( 0, (t_{i+1}-t_i) A(t_i)A(t_i)^\top \right) \\
        &\stackrel{d}{=} \mathcal{N}_n\left( 0, \sum_{t_i\in \Delta_n} (t_{i+1}-t_i) A(t_i)A(t_i)^\top \right) \\
        &\tendsto{d} \mathcal{N}_n\left( 0, \int_0^t A(s)A(s)^\top \dd s \right) .
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Transformation formula for densities.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $U,V\subset \R^d$ open, $\phi$ a $C^1$-diffeomorphism from $U$ to $V$ with non-singular Jacobian on $U$. If $X$ is a $U$-valued random vector with density $f_X\colon U\to [0,\infty)$, then $Y$ has density \[
    f_Y(y) = f_X(\phi^{-1}(y)) \left| \det J_{\phi^{-1}}(y) \right| ,\quad y\in V.
\] Alternatively, $\left|\det J_{\phi^{-1}}(y) \right|= \left| \det J_\phi \left( \phi^{-1}(y) \right)  \right| ^{-1}$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Version of Ito's formula for $f\in C^2(U,\R)$ with $U\subset \R^d$ open.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $f\in C^2(U,\R)$ with $U\subset \R$ open, and $X$ an $\R$-valued csm, then for any stopping time $\tau$ such that $X^\tau$ is $A$-valued for some closed $A\subset U$, \[
    f(X_{t\wedge \tau}) = f(X_0) + \int_0 ^{t\wedge \tau} f'(X_s)\dd X_s + \frac{1}{2} \int_0 ^{t\wedge \tau} f''(X_s) \dd \left<X \right> _s,\quad t\ge 0,
\] a.s. Analogously for $d > 1$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $g\in C^2(\R)$ with $g = f$ on $A$. Then Ito applied to $g$ and $X^\tau$ gives
    \begin{align*}
        f(X_{t\wedge \tau})
        &= g(X^\tau_t) = g(X_0) + \int_0^t g'(X_{s\wedge \tau}) \dd \left( X^\tau \right) _s + \frac{1}{2} \int_0^t g''(X_{s\wedge \tau}) \dd \left<X^\tau \right> _s\\
        &= f(X_0) + \int_0 ^{t\wedge \tau} g'(X_{s\wedge \tau}) \dd X_s + \frac{1}{2}\int_0^{t\wedge \tau} g''(X_{s\wedge \tau}) \dd \left<X \right> _s\\
        &= f(X_0) + \int_0^{t\wedge \tau} f'(X_s) \dd X_s + \frac{1}{2}\int_0^{t\wedge \tau}f''(X_s) \dd \left<X \right> _s.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $M$ is a clm, $M_0 = x$, $a < x < b$, and $\tau_a\wedge \tau_b < \infty$ a.s., what is $\P(\tau_a < \tau_b)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} $\P(\tau_a < \tau_b) = \frac{b-x}{b-a}$.
\begin{proof}
    Set $\tau \coloneqq \tau_a\wedge \tau_b$. Then $M^\tau$ is a bounded martingale, and $\tau < \infty$ a.s., so by OST for finite stopping times, $p \coloneqq \P(\tau_a < \tau_b)$, \[
        x = \E \left[ M^\tau_0 \right] = \E \left[ M^\tau_\tau \right] = \E \left[ M_\tau \right] = pa + (1-p)b.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Skorokhod's lemma ($z = y + a$, without proof)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $y\colon [0,\infty) \to \R$ is continuous with $y(0) \ge 0$, then there exist unique continuous functions $a,z\colon [0,\infty)\to \R$ such that
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] $z = y+a$,
    \item[(ii)] $z \ge 0$,
    \item[(iii)] $a$ is increasing, $a(0) = 0$, and $\dd a$ is supported on $\left\{ z = 0 \right\} $.
\end{enumerate}
In that case, \[
    a(t) = 0\vee \left[ \sup_{s\le t}(-y(s)) \right] .
\]
[/latex]

front: [latex]Let $M$ be a clm, $M_0 = 0$, $S_t \coloneqq \sup_{s\le t}M_s$. Connection between processes $(L^0_t)$, $(S_t)$, and $(\left| M_t \right|) $, and also $(L^x_t)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} As processes, \[
    (S_t-M_t,S_t) \stackrel{d}{=} (\left| M_t \right| ,L^0_t),\qquad (L^x_t) \stackrel{d}{=} \big((S_t-\left| x \right| )\vee 0\big).
\]
\begin{proof}
    $X_t \coloneqq -\int_0^t \sgn(M_s)\dd M_s $ defines a clm, $X_0 = 0$, and $\left<X \right> = \left<M \right> $, so $(X_t = B_{\left<X \right> _t}= B_{\left<M \right> _t}) \stackrel{d}{=} (\widetilde{B}_{\left<M \right> _t} = M_t)$. Then, $\left| M_t \right|  = -X_t + L_t$, so $L_t = \sup_{s\le t} X_s$, so \[
        \left( \left| M_t \right| ,L_t \right) = \left( L_t - X_t,L_t \right) \stackrel{d}{=} \left( S_t - M_t,S_t \right) .
    \] Finally, $\left| M_t - x \right| = \left| x \right|  - X_s + L^x_t$, so  \[
    L^x_t = \sup_{s\le t} \left( X_s - \left| x \right|  \right) \vee 0 = \left( \sup_{s\le t }X_s - \left| x \right|  \right) \vee 0.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]For a clm $X$, under what assumption on $\left<X \right> $ can you conclude $\frac{X_t}{t^\alpha} \tendsto{} 0$ a.s.\ as $t\to \infty$ for $\alpha > 0$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $X$ is a clm and $\left<X \right> _t \le C t^\beta$ a.s.\ for all $t> 0$ for some $c,\beta > 0$, then \[
    \frac{X_t}{t^\alpha}\tendsto{} 0,\quad t\to \infty,
\] a.s.\ for all $\alpha > \beta / 2$.
\begin{proof}
    By BDG, $\E \left[ (X_t^\star)^p \right] \le c_p \E \left[ \left<X \right>_t ^{p / 2}  \right] \le c t ^{\beta p / 2} $ for any $p > 0$, so, for $\varepsilon > 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( X_n^\star \ge \varepsilon n^\alpha \right) \le (\varepsilon n^\alpha)^{-p} c n ^{\beta p / 2} = c n ^{p \left( \beta / 2 - \alpha \right) }.
    \end{align*}
    This is summable for large $p$, so $X_n^\star / n^\alpha \le \varepsilon$ eventually a.s., so
    \begin{align*}
        \varlimsup_{t\to \infty} \frac{|X_t|}{t^\alpha} \le \varlimsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{X_n^\star}{(n-1)^\alpha} = \varlimsup_{n\to \infty} \frac{X_n^\star}{n^\alpha} \le \varepsilon,
    \end{align*}
    a.s.\ for any $\varepsilon > 0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $f\in C^2([s,\infty),\R)$ and $X$ is a csm, what is $\dd (f(\cdot )X)_t$ and $\left<f(\cdot )X \right> _t$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} $\dd (f(\cdot )X)_t = f'(t) X_t \dd t + f(t) \dd X_t$ and \[
    \left<f(\cdot )X \right> _t = \int_s^t f(s)^2 \dd \left<X \right> _s,
\] for $t\ge s$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $\tilde{f}\in C^2(\R,\R)$ such that $\tilde{f} = f$ on $[s,\infty)$, and put $g(t,x) = \tilde{f}(t) x$ for $x,t\in \R$, so Ito applied to $g$ and $(t,X_t)_{t\ge s}$ gives
    \begin{align*}
        f(t) X_t = g(t,X_t) = f(s) X_s + \int_s^t f'(r) X_r \dd r + \int_s^t f(r) \dd X_r,\quad t\ge s.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Local time of a clm in terms of Brownian local time. More specifically, local time of $(g(t) B_{f(t)})$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $B$ is a BM, $f,g$ continuous, $f(0) = 0$ increasing, $g > 0$ of finite variation, and $Y_t \coloneqq g(t) B_{f(t)}$, $t\ge 0$, then \[
    L^0_t(Y) = \int_0^t g(s) \dd L^0_{f(s)}(B) = \int_0 ^{f(t) } g (f^{-1}(s)) \dd L_s^0(B),
\] where the second equality holds if $f$ is strictly increasing. In particular, if $M$ is a clm, \[
L^0_t(M) = L^0_{\left<M \right> _t}(W)
\] for a BM $W$.
\begin{proof}
    Write $L_t^Y \coloneqq L_t^0(Y), L_t = L_t^0(B)$. Recall that $\dd \left| B_f(s) \right| = \sgn (B_{f(s)}) \dd B_{f(s)} + \dd L_{f(s)}$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \left| Y_t \right|
        &= g(t) \left| B_{f(t)} \right| = \int_0^tg(s) \dd \left| B_f(s) \right| + \int_0^t \left| B_{f(s)} \right| \dd g(s)\\
        &= \int_0^t g(s) \sgn(B_{f(s)}) \dd B_{f(s)} + \int_0^t g(s) \dd L_{f(s)} + \int_0^t \left| B_{f(s)} \right| \dd g(s),
    \end{align*}
    but also, since $\dd Y_s = B_{f(s)}\dd g(s) + g(s) \dd B_{f(s)}$,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| Y_t \right|
        &= \int_0^t \sgn(Y_s) \dd Y_s + L^Y_t\\
        &= \int_0^t \sgn(B_{f(s)}) B_{f(s)}\dd g(s) + \int_0^t \sgn(B_{f(s)}) g(s) \dd B_{f(s)} + L^Y_t
    \end{align*},
    so \[
        L^Y_t = \int_0^t g(s) \dd L_{f(s)} .
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Local time of a csm as an almost-sure limit.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $X$ is a csm, $x\in \R$, $t\ge 0$, then a.s. \[
    L^a_t(X) = \lim_{\varepsilon\to 0} \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\int_0^t \ind_{[a,a+\varepsilon)}(X_s) \dd \left<X \right> _s.
\]
\begin{proof}
    By the occupation time formula, \[
        \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\int_0^t \ind_{[a,a+\varepsilon)}(X_s) \dd \left<X \right> _s = \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \int_a^{a + \varepsilon} L^x_t \dd x ,
    \] and the claim follows from right-continuity of $L$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Dubins-Schwarz for general clm's (with idea of proof).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Theorem.} If $M$ is a clm, $M_0 = 0$, then there is an enlarged probability space with a BM $\beta \indep M$ such that \[
B_t = \begin{cases}
    M_{\tau_t} &, t < \left<M \right> _\infty,\\
    M_\infty + \beta_{t - \left<M \right> _\infty} &, t\ge \left<M \right> _\infty
\end{cases}
\] is a BM.
\begin{proof}
    Let $(\Omega',(\mathcal{F}_t'),\P')$ host a BM $\beta$ and consider $(\Omega\times \Omega', (\mathcal{F}_{\tau_t}\otimes \mathcal{F}_t),\P\otimes \P')$, and put \[
    B_t = M_{\tau_t} + \int_0^t \ind_{\left\{s > \left<M \right> _\infty\right\}} \dd \beta'_s,\quad t\ge 0.
\] Then $(B_t)$ is adapted, a clm, and a BM by Levy.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of pseudo-Poisson process, semigroup and generator.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $E$ be a measurable space, $\alpha > 0$ and $\mu\colon E\times \mathcal{E}\to [0,1]$ a stochastic kernel. Then the associated \emph{pseudo-Poisson process} on $E$ is $X = Y \circ N$, where $N$, $Y$ are independent, respectively a Poisson process with rate $\alpha$ on $\N_0$ and a discrete-time Markov chain on $E$ with transition kernel $\mu$. Then $T_t = \e^{t A}$ (defined on the Banach space $B_b(E)$) where $A = \alpha(G-I)$, that is, \[
    (Af)(x) = \alpha \int_E (f(y) - f(x)) \mu(x,\dd y),\quad f\in C(E), x\in E.
\]
\begin{proof}
    \begin{align*}
        T_t f(x)
        &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \P(N_t = n) \E^x \left[ Y_n \right] \\
        &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \e^{-\alpha t} \frac{(\alpha t)^n}{n!} G^n f(x)\\
        &= \e^{\alpha (G-I) t} f (x).
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]
