front: [latex]Characterisation of $A <_\text{colex} B$ for $A,B\subset [n]$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Claim.} $A <_\text{colex} B$ iff $\left\|A\right\| \coloneqq \sum_{i\in A} 2^i < \sum_{i\in B} 2^i$.

\begin{proof}
    Clear if $A\subset B$ or $B\subset A$, so suppose not. By definition, $A <_\text{colex}B$ iff $\max (A\setminus B) < \max(B\setminus A)$, so HTS that $\max U < \max V$ iff $\left\|U\right\|< \left\|V\right\|$ for disjoint sets $\varnothing \neq U,V\subset [n]$. Suppose the former holds. Then
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|U\right\| \le \sum_{i=1}^{\max U}2^i = 2^{\max U+1} - 1 \le 2^{\max V}-1 < 2^{\max V} \le \left\|V\right\|.
    \end{align*}
    By the same argument, if $\max V < \max U$, then $\left\|V\right\|< \left\|U\right\|$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Exponential bound on $\P\left( \sup_{s\le t}\left| X_s \right|\ge x  \right) $ for a clm $X$ with $X_0 = 0$ and deterministic bound on $\left<X \right> _t$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $X$ is a continuous local martingale with a deterministic bound $\left<X \right> _t \le S_t$ for all $t > 0$, then \[
    \P\left( \sup_{s\le t} \left| X_t \right| \ge x \right) \le 2 \exp \left( -\frac{x^2}{2S_t} \right) ,\quad t > 0.
\]
\begin{proof}
    By Novikov, the stochastic exponential is a true martingale. For any $\lambda > 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( \sup_{s\le t} X_s \ge x \right)
        &= \P\left( \e^{\lambda \sup_{s\le t}X_s -\lambda^2 \frac{\left<X \right> _t}{2} } \ge \e^{\lambda x - \lambda^2 \frac{\left<X \right> _t}{2} }  \right) \\
        &\le \P\left( \sup_{s\le t} \e^{\lambda X_s - \lambda ^2\frac{\left<X \right> _s}{2}} \ge \e^{\lambda x - \lambda^2 \frac{S _t}{2}} \right)\\
        &\le \e^{\lambda^2 S_t / 2 - \lambda x} \\
        &= \exp \left(-\frac{x^2}{2 S_t}\right),
    \end{align*}
    where we chose $\lambda = x / S_t$. Finally, $\left<-X \right> = \left<X \right>  $, so
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( \sup_{s\le t} \left| X_s \right| \ge x \right)
        &\le \P\left( \sup_{s\le t}X_s \ge x \right) + \P\left( \sup_{s\le t}(-X_s) \ge x \right) \\
        &\le 2 \exp \left( -\frac{x^2}{2 S_t} \right) .
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Regularity of local times.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $X$ be a continuous semimartingale with local times $(\widetilde{L}^a_t)$. Then there exists a $\B([0,\infty))\otimes \mathcal{P}$-measurable map $(a,t,\omega) \mapsto L^a_t(\omega)$ such that $(\widetilde{L}^a_t)_{t\ge 0}$ and $(L^a_t)_{t\ge 0}$ are indistinguishable for all $a\in \R$ and such that $L$ is continuous in $t$ and cadlag in $a$, and, a.s., \[
L^a_t - L^{a-}_t = 2\int_0^t \ind_{\left\{ X_s = a \right\} }\dd X_s = 2\int_0^t \ind_{\left\{ X_s = a \right\} }\dd A_s,
\] for $t\ge 0$ and $a\in \R$. In particular, $L$ is continuous in $a$ if $X$ is a local martingale.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Connection between a process $(M_t)$ on $(\Omega,\mathcal{F},(\mathcal{F}_t),\P)$ and its law on the canonical path space being *martingales.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $M = (M_t)$ is a *martingale on a filtered probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, (\mathcal{F}_t),\P)$, then the canonical process $X$ on $(\R ^{[0,\infty)}, \mathcal{F},\P^M)$ is a *martingale w.r.t.\ the natural filtration $\mathcal{F}^X_t = \sigma(X_s\colon s\le t)$. The converse holds if $(\mathcal{F}_t) = (\mathcal{F}^M_t)$.
\begin{proof}
    Let $0\le s \le t$. Then the set \[
        \mathcal{D}\coloneqq \left\{ A\in \mathcal{F}^X_s\colon \P^M(X_t \ind_{A}) \stareq \P^M(X_s \ind_{A}) \right\}
    \] is a Dynkin system and contains cylinders, since, if $A = \left\{ X_{t_i}\in B_i\forall i\in [n] \right\} $, then \[
    \P^M(X_t \ind_{A}) = \P\left( M_t \ind_{\left\{ M_{t_i} \in B_i \forall i\in [n] \right\} } \right) \stareq \P(M_s \ind) = \P^M(X_s \ind_{A}).
\] The same argument shows that, assuming the latter, that $M$ is a *martingale w.r.t.\ $(\mathcal{F}^M_t)$
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Is a martingale $M$ on $(\Omega,(\mathcal{F}_t),\P)$ also a martingale w.r.t.\ the right-continuous completion of $(\mathcal{F}_t)$?[/latex]

\textbf{Proposition.} If $E_j$ is expected number when $j$ lineages remain, then \[
\begin{cases}
    E_j = \frac{j-1}{\rho + j-1} E_{j-1} + \frac{\rho}{\rho + j-1} E_{j+1} + \frac{\rho}{\rho + j-1}&,j\ge 2,\\

        &= (1-x)^{j-1} \e^{\rho x} \Big\vert_{x=0}^1 + (j-1) \int_0^t (1-x)^{j-2} \e^{\rho x} \dd x\\

[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.}
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] For every $c \in (1,\infty)$ exists a unique $d \in (0,1)$ with $c\e^{-c} = d\e^{-d}$,
    \item[(ii)] If $c > 1$ and $\eta < 1$ is the extinction probability of $\boldsymbol X_{\text{Po}(c)}$, then $d = \eta c$,
    \item[(iii)] $\boldsymbol X_{\text{Po}(c)}$ conditioned on extinction is $\boldsymbol X_{\text{Po}(d)}$.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $x \mapsto x \e^{-x}$ is a bijection $(0,1) \to (0,\e)$ and $(1,\infty) \mapsto (0,\e)$.
        \item[(ii)] We know that $\eta = f_{\text{Po}(c)}(\eta) = \e^{-c(1-\eta)}$, so \[
        \eta c = c\e^{-c} \e^{\eta c}.
        \]
    \item[(iii)]
        \begin{align*}
            \P \left(Z_1 = k \,\middle\vert\, \text{extinction}\right)
            &= \frac{\eta^k \P(Z_1 = k)}{\eta} = \e^{c(1-\eta)} \eta^k \e^{-c} \frac{c^k}{k!}\\
            &= \e^{-\eta c} \frac{(\eta c)^k}{k!},
        \end{align*}
        and the conditioning applies also to subsequent generations.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Two upsets $A,B \subset \mathcal{P}(X) $ ($\varnothing \neq X$ finite) are independent w.r.t.\ $\P_p \in \mathcal{M}_1(\mathcal{P}(X))$ iff they depend on disjoint sets, that is, iff there are disjoint $I,J\subset X$ such that \[
    \forall \omega\in \mathcal{P}(X)\colon \omega\in A \iff \omega\cap I \in A,
\] and the same for $B$ and $J$. That is, $A \in \sigma \left( x \colon x\in I \right) $ in the obvious sense.
\begin{proof}
    Let $x\in X$. Define
    \begin{align*}
        A^+ &\coloneqq \left\{ \omega \setminus \left\{ x \right\} \colon \omega\in A \right\} ,\\
        A^- &\coloneqq \left\{ \omega\subset X\setminus \left\{ x \right\} \colon \omega \in A \right\} ,
    \end{align*} the upper and lower face of $A$ w.r.t.\ $x$. Then as in the proof of Harris' inequality we see that, putting $a^+ \coloneqq \P_p^{(X\setminus \left\{ x \right\} )}(A^+)$, $a^-$ and $b^{\pm}$ similarly, \[
    0 = \P_p(A\cap B) - \P_p(A)\P_p(B) \ge p(1-p) (a^+ - a^-) (b^+ - b^-) \ge 0,
    \] so in fact equality holds everywhere, say $a^+ = a^-$. This means that $A^- = A^+$ and hence that $\omega\in A \iff \omega \cup \left\{ x \right\} \in A$ for all $\omega\subset X$, so $A$ does not depend on $x$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Density of first hitting time $T_a$ of BM (in $d = 1$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Lemma.} If $B$ is a BM and $T_a \coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon B_t \ge a \right\} $, then $\P(T_a \le t) = 2 \P(B_t \ge a)$ and $T_a$ has density \[
    f_a(t) = \frac{a}{\sqrt{2\pi t^3} } \e^{- \frac{a^2}{2t}}.
\]
\begin{proof}
    By reflection principle,
    \begin{align*}
        \P(T_a \le t)
        &= \P(B_t^\star \ge a) = \P(B_t \ge a) + \P(B_t^\star \ge a, B_t < a)\\
        &= \P(B_t\ge a) + \P(B_t > a) \\
        &= 2\P(B_t\ge a).
    \end{align*}
    Hence,
    \begin{align*}
        f_a(t)
        &= \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \P(T_a \le t) = 2 \frac{\dd }{\dd t} \int_a^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi t} } \e^{-x^2 / (2t)}\dd x\\
        &= \ldots = \frac{a}{\sqrt{2\pi t^3} } \e^{-\frac{a^2}{2t}}
    \end{align*}
    which can be confirmed directly or obtained via IBP.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

\textbf{Proposition.} $\left<X \right> _t = A_t$ and $X$ is a martingale iff $\E \left[ \sqrt{A_t}  \right] < \infty$ for all $t\ge 0$.

\begin{proof}
    Put $\tau_n \coloneqq \inf \left\{ t\ge 0\colon A_t \ge n \right\} \uparrow \infty$, and note $A_{t \wedge \tau_n}= A_t \wedge n$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] First of all, $X$ is adapted, and for $t\ge 0$ and $n\in \N$, \[
        \E \left[ |X_{\tau_n \wedge t}| \right] = \E \left[ |B_{A_t\wedge n}| \right] = \E \left[ \sqrt{A_t \wedge n}  \right] \E \left[ \left| \mathcal{N} \right|  \right] < \infty.
        \] Let $0\le s \le t$, $0\le s_1\le\ldots \le s_k \le s$, $C\in \B(\R)$, and \[
                A\coloneqq \left\{ (B_{A_{s_1}}, \ldots ,B_{A_{s_k}}) \in C \right\} .
            \] HTS $\E \left[ (X_{\tau_n \wedge t} - X_{\tau_n \wedge s}) \ind_{A} \right] = 0$. Indeed, by independence of $A $ and $B$,
            \begin{align*}
                \text{LHS}
                &= \int\limits_{C[0,\infty)} \underbrace{\E \left[ (B_{a(t) \wedge n}- B_{a(s) \wedge n}) \ind_{\left\{ \left(B_{a(s_1)}, \ldots ,B_{a(s_k)}\right) \in C \right\} } \right] }_{= 0} \P^A(\dd a) = 0.
            \end{align*}
        \item[(ii)] Let $t > 0$ and $(\pi_n)$ a sequence of partitions with $\left| \pi_n \right| \to 0$. Then, for $\varepsilon > 0$,
            \begin{align*}
                \P&\left( \left| QV^{\pi_n}_t(X) - A_t \right| \ge \varepsilon  \right) \\
                  &= \int\limits_{C[0,\infty)} \underbrace{\P \left( \left| \sum_{t_i\in \pi_n} \left( B_{a(t_{i+1})}- B_{a(t_i)} \right) ^2 - a(t) \right| \ge \varepsilon \right)}_{= \P\left( \left| QV^{a(\pi_n)}_{a(t)}(B) - a(t) \right| \ge \varepsilon \right) \to 0} \P^A(\dd a) \tendsto{} 0
            \end{align*}
            by dominated convergence. In particular, $QV_t ^{\pi_n}(X) \tendsto{\text{a.s.}} A_t$ for some subsequence, so $(A_t)$ is $\mathcal{F}^X_t$-measurable and $\left<X \right> _t = A_t$.
        \item[(iii)] For $t\ge 0$, \[
        \E \left[ |X_t| \right] = \E \left[ \left| B_{A_t} \right|  \right] = \E \left[ \sqrt{A_t}  \right] \E \left[ \left| \mathcal{N} \right|  \right] ,
        \] so $X$ is integrable iff $\E \left[ \sqrt{A_t}  \right] <\infty$ for all $t\ge 0$. In that case, $X$ is a true martingale by the same argument as before.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $\sigma, b \colon \R\to \R$ be bounded and measurable, $\sigma \ge \varepsilon$ for some $\varepsilon > 0$. Then uniqueness in law of $\dd X_t = \sigma(X_t) \dd B_t$ implies uniqueness in law of $\dd X_t = \sigma(X_t)\dd B_t + b(X_t) \dd t$ and vice versa.

\begin{proof}
    Suppose that $\dd X_t = \sigma(X_t) \dd \overline{B}_t + b(X_t) \dd t$ and $X_0 = x\in \R$ w.r.t.\ $\P$. Put \[
        \overline{L}_t \coloneqq - \int_0^t b(X_s) \sigma(X_s)^{-1} \dd \overline{B}_s,\quad t\ge 0.

Hence if $F\colon C[0,\infty)\to \R$ is measurable and $t\ge 0$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \P \left( F(X^t) \right)
        &= \Q\left( \mathcal{E}(\overline{L})^{-1} F(X^t) \right) \\
        &= \Q \left( \mathcal{E}(-L) F(X^t) \right) ,
    \end{align*}
    where $L_t = \overline{L}_t - \left<\overline{L}_t \right> =- \int_0^t b(X_s) \sigma(X_s)^{-1} \dd B_s $, so the RHS depends only on $\Q^{(X,B)}$, which is unique. The other way works the same way.

[latex]Rate function of $\mathcal{N}(a,\Sigma)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} The rate function of $\mathcal{N}(a,\Sigma) \in \mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$ is \[
    I(x) = \frac{1}{2} (x-a)^\top \Sigma ^{-1} (x-a),\quad x\in \R^d.
\]
\begin{proof}
    First consider $a = 0$ and $\Sigma = I_d$. Then \[
        M(\lambda) = \E \left[ \e^{\lambda X} \right] = \e^{\lambda^\top \lambda / 2},\quad \lambda \in \R,
    \] so, for $x\in \R^d$, \[
    I(x) = \sup_{\lambda \in \R} \left[ \lambda^\top \left( x - \frac{\lambda}{2} \right)  \right] = \frac{x^\top x}{2},
\] because the supremum must be attained locally, and $\nabla_\lambda \left[ \cdot  \right] = x - \lambda$. Now let $\Sigma = A A^\top$, so that $Z\coloneqq f(X) \sim \mathcal{N}(a,\Sigma)$, where $f(x) \coloneqq Ax + b$. Then $f$ is bijective, so by the contraction principle and because $X_n \coloneqq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X^{(i)}$ satisfies LDP with good rate $I$, it follows that $f(X_n) \sim Z_n$ satisfies LDP with good rate \[
I'(x) = \inf_{f^{-1}(x)} I = I(f^{-1}(x)) = I(A^{-1}(x-a)) = \frac{1}{2} (x-a)^\top \Sigma^{-1}(x-a).
\] Since good rates are unique, $I'$ must be \emph{the} rate function of $\mathcal{N}(a,\Sigma)$ (in particular the one we would obtain from Cramer's definition).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Single $P\in \mathcal{M}_1(E)$ with $S \coloneqq \supp(P)$ has rate function $I(x) = \infty \ind_{S}$, and if $\Phi\colon E\to \R$ is continuous, then \[
\lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log \int \e^{\Phi / \varepsilon} \dd P = \sup_S \Phi.
\]

\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] For any $A\in \B(E)$, \[
                \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log P(A) = \begin{cases}
                    -\infty &, P(A) = 0,\\
                    0 &, P(A) > 0.
                \end{cases}
            \] If $F\subset E$ is closed, then $\inf_F I = \infty \ind_{\left\{ F\subset S^{c} \right\} }$. Hence if $F\cap S \neq \varnothing$, there is nothing to show, otherwise $P(F) = 0$ and we are also done. If $G\subset E$ is open, then $\inf_G I = \infty \ind_{\left\{ G \subset S^{c} \right\} } = \infty \ind_{\left\{ P(G) = 0 \right\} }$, and we are also done.
        \item[(ii)] First note that $\sup (\Phi - I) = \sup_S \Phi$. If $\sup_S \Phi = \infty$, then by lower bound of Varadhan \[
        \varliminf_{\varepsilon \to 0} \varepsilon \log \int \e^{\Phi / \varepsilon}\dd P \ge \sup_S \Phi = \infty.
        \] Otherwise, \[
        \sup_{\varepsilon \le 1} \left( \int \e^{2\Phi / \varepsilon} \dd P \right) ^\varepsilon \le \e^{2 \sup_S \Phi} < \infty,
        \] so Varadhan's full theorem gives the claim.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} Let $G$ be a locally finite, connected graph. Then $\theta\colon [0,1] \to [0,1]$ is right-continuous on $[0,1)$ and left-continuous on $(p_c,1]$.

\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] We have \[
                \theta(p) = \P_p(x \leftrightarrow \infty) = \P_p(\forall n\in \N\colon \text{SAW}_n) = \lim_{n\to \infty} f_n(p),
        \] where \[
        f_n(p) = \P_p(\text{SAW}_n) = \P_p(\text{$\exists$ self-avoiding walk of length $n$ starting at $x$})
    \] is a polynomial (it only depends on edges with distance at most $n$ from $x$). This is a decreasing limit, and $f_n$ is increasing in $p$, so we may exchange two decreasing limits in \[
    \lim_{q \downarrow p} \theta(q) = \lim_{q\downarrow p} \lim_{n\to \infty} f_n(q) = \lim_{n\to \infty} \lim_{q\downarrow p} f_n(q) = \lim_{n\to \infty} f_n(p) = \theta(p).
    \]
\item[(ii)] Let $p\in (p_c,1)$, and $p_c < p_n \uparrow p$.  We may host $(\P_q)_{q\in [0,1]}$ on one probability space by taking i.i.d.\ $U(0,1)$-variables $(U_e)_{e\in E}$ and opening $e$ w.r.t.\ $\P_p$ iff $U_e < p$. Then
    \begin{align*}
        \lim_{n\to \infty} \theta(p_n)
        &= \lim_{n\to \infty} \P \left( x \stackrel{p_n}{\longleftrightarrow } \infty \right) \\
        &= \P\left( \exists n \in \N\colon x \stackrel{p_n}{\longleftrightarrow} \infty \right) \\
        &\le \P(x \stackrel{p}{\longleftrightarrow} \infty) = \theta(p).
    \end{align*}
    Now a.s.\ there exists a unique infinite component $C_n$ for every $p_n$ and $C$ for $p$, so $C_1 \subset C_2 \subset \ldots \subset C$. Then $ x \stackrel{p}{\longleftrightarrow} \infty $ implies that there is a finite path from $x$ to $C_1$ consisting of edges with $U_e < p$, so all of these edges have weight $< p_n$ for some $n\in \N$, so $x \stackrel{p_n}{\longleftrightarrow} \infty $ for some $n\in \N$ already, so we actually have equality above.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $(\Omega,\A,\mu)$ is a measure space and $p\in [1,\infty]$, then $L^p(\Omega,\A,\mu)$ is a Banach space.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proof}
Only have to show completeness, so let $(f_k) \subset L^p$ be Cauchy. If $p = \infty$, then $f_n(x)$ is Cauchy, so $f_n \to f$ pointwise, and $f\in L^\infty$, and
\begin{align*}
    \left| f_n(x) - f(x) \right| = \lim_{m\to \infty} \left| f_n(x) - f_m(x) \right| \le \sup_{m\ge n} \left\|f_n - f_m\right\|_\infty \tendsto{n\to \infty} 0.
\end{align*}
If $p \in [1,\infty)$, then we can pass to a subsequence $(g_j \coloneqq f_{k_j})$ with $\mu(x\colon \left| g_j - g_{j+1} \right| \ge 2^{-j}) \le 2^{-j} $, so that $g_j$ is pointwise Cauchy $\mu$-a.e., with measurable limit $f\coloneqq g\coloneqq \varliminf_j g_j$. Then $f\in L^p$ by Fatou and
\begin{align*}
    \left\|f_n - f\right\|_p^p
    &= \int_E \lim_{j\to \infty} \left| f_n(x) - f_{k_j}(x) \right|^p \mu(\dd x) \le \varliminf_{j\to \infty} \left\|f_n - f_{k_j}\right\|_p^p\\
    &\le \sup_{m\ge n} \left\|f_n - f_m\right\|_p^p \tendsto{} 0.
\end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Dual of Hölder's inequality and dual space of $L^p(\Omega,\A,\mu)$[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Proposition.} If $(\Omega,\A,\mu)$ is a measure space, and $p\in [1,\infty]$, then \[
    \left\|f\right\|_p = \sup \left\{ \int fg \dd \mu\colon \left\|g\right\|_{q} \le (=) 1 \right\} .
\] (If $p = \infty$ then $\nu$ must be $\sigma$-finite). If $p\in [1,\infty)$, then the dual space of $L^p$ is $L^q$. The dual of $L^\infty$ is \emph{not} $L^1$.\\

\begin{proof}
Clear if $\left\|f\right\|_p = 0$, assume $\in (0,\infty)$. If $p\in [1,\infty)$, put $g\coloneqq (\sgn f) \left| f \right| ^{p-1} / \left\|f\right\|_p^{p-1}$. If $p = \infty$, choose for $\varepsilon > 0$ a set $\Omega_\varepsilon$ with $\mu(\Omega_\varepsilon) \in (0,\infty)$ and $f\ge \left\|f\right\|_\infty - \varepsilon$ on $\Omega_\varepsilon$, and put $g \coloneqq (\sgn f) \ind_{\Omega_\varepsilon} / \mu(\Omega_\varepsilon)$. Then $\mu(fg) \ge \left\|f\right\|_\infty - \varepsilon$.

If $\left\|f\right\|_p = \infty$, WLOG $f \ge 0$, take $f_k \coloneqq f \wedge k$ and $\left\|g_k\right\|= 1$ with $\mu( f_k g_k) \ge \left\|f_k\right\|_p - 1$ Then $\text{RHS} \ge \mu(f g_k) \ge \left\|f_k\right\|_p - 1\uparrow \infty$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Dense subsets of $L^p(\Omega,\A,\mu)$, in particular when is it separable.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $p\in [1,\infty)$, then the set of $p$-integrable simple functions is dense in $L^p(\Omega,\A,\mu)$. If
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\Omega$ is topological space, $\mu$ $\sigma$-finite Borel measure and $\mathcal{N}\subset \A_\nu$ is countable and produce open sets through unions, or
        \item[(ii)] $\mu$ is finite and $\mathcal{N}\subset \A$ is countable and produces a good generator through unions,
    \end{enumerate}
    then the set of rational linear combinations of indicators of $\mathcal{N}$ is dense. In particular $L^p$ is separable if $\mu$ is $\sigma$-finite Borel measure on second-countable space, or if $\mu$ is finite and $\A$ countably generated.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $f\in L^p$, WLOG $f\ge 0$. Then there is a sequence $0\le f_n \uparrow f$ of simple functions (hence also integrable), and $\left\|f_n - f\right\|_p \to 0$ by DCT (dominated by $2f$).

    In (i) we may assume that $\mu$ is finite (for general $f$ take open set $O$ of finite measure such that $f$ has small mass outside $O$ and approximate $f$ on $O$, where we replace $\mathcal{N}$ by those members that lie in $O$), so that we are in the case of (i). Denote by $\mathcal{F}$ the $\left\|\cdot \right\|_p$-closure of (rational=real) linear combinations of indicators of $\mathcal{N}$. Then $\mathcal{F}$ is a vector space, and \[
    \mathcal{D} \coloneqq \left\{ A\in \A\colon \ind_{A}\in \mathcal{F} \right\}
\] contains $\mathcal{M}$ and is a Dynkin-system ($1 = \ind_{\Omega}$ because $\mathcal{M}$ is good, $1 - \ind_{A}$ because $\mathcal{F}$ vector space, rest because of MCT), so $\mathcal{D} = \A$, so we are done.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Approximation of identity (version for $f\in C(\R^d)$ and $f\in L^p(\R^d)$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
For $\rho \colon \R^d\to \R$, put $\rho_\varepsilon(\cdot ) \coloneqq \frac{1}{\varepsilon^d} \rho\left( \frac{\cdot}{\varepsilon} \right) $ for $\varepsilon > 0$.

\begin{proposition}
    Let $\rho \ge 0$ measurable, $\int \rho \dd x = 1$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $\rho$ has compact support and $f\in C(\R^d)$, $f \star \rho_\varepsilon \tendsto{} f$ uniformly on compacts.
        \item[(ii)] If $f\in L^p(\R^d)$, $p\in [1,\infty)$, then $\left\|f\star \rho_\varepsilon - f\right\|_p \tendsto{} 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Let $K\subset \R^d$ be compact, $K'$ its $1$-fattening. WLOG $\supp(\rho) \subset B(0,1)$, so $\supp(\rho_\varepsilon) = \varepsilon\supp(\rho)  \subset B(0,\varepsilon)$. Then
            \begin{align*}
                \sup_{x\in K} \left| (f\star \rho_\varepsilon)(x) - f(x) \right|
                &\le \int \sup_{x\in K}\underbrace{ \left| f(x-y) - f(x) \right|}_{\text{here $x,x-y \in K'$}}  \rho_\varepsilon(y) \dd y\le \omega\left( f\!\!\restriction_{K'} ,\varepsilon \right) \tendsto{} 0,
            \end{align*}
            because $f$ is uniformly continuous on $K'$.
        \item[(ii)] For $x\in \R^d$,
            \begin{align*}
                \left| (f\star \rho_\varepsilon)(x) - f(x) \right|
                &\le \int \left| f(x-y) - f(x) \right| \rho_\varepsilon(y)^{1 / p} \rho_\varepsilon(y)^{1 / q} \dd y\\
                &\le \left(\int \left| f(x-y) - f(x) \right|^p \rho_\varepsilon(y) \dd y\right)^{1 / p} \underbrace{\left(\int \rho_\varepsilon(y) \dd y\right)^{1 / q}}_{ = 1},
            \end{align*}
            so, taking $r > 0$ with $\left\|f^y - f\right\|\le \delta$ for $\left| y \right| \le r$,
            \begin{align*}\left\|f\star \rho_\varepsilon - f\right\|_p^p
                &\le \int \left\|f^y - f\right\|_p^p \rho_\varepsilon(y)\dd y \le \delta + (2\left\|f\right\|_p)^p \int_{\left| y \right| \ge r} \rho_\varepsilon(y)\dd y \tendsto{\varepsilon \to 0} \delta,
            \end{align*}
            and this holds for every $\delta> 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

\begin{proposition}
    Let $p\in [1,\infty)$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $C_c^\infty(\R^d)$ is dense in $L^p(\R^d)$.
        \item[(ii)] If $\Omega \in \B(\R^d)$ satisfies $\lambda(\Omega\setminus \Omega^o) = 0$, then $C_c^\infty(\Omega) \coloneqq \left\{ f\in C^\infty(\Omega)\colon \supp(f) \subset \Omega^o \right\} $ is dense in $L^p(\Omega)$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Take $\rho\in C_c^\infty(\R^d)$ with $\int \rho\dd x = 1$ and $\supp(\rho)\subset B(0,1)$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Take $f\in L^p$. Since $\left\|f \ind_{\R^d \setminus B(0,N)}\right\| \to 0$ as $N\to \infty$, we may assume that $f$ has compact support. Then, $f_\varepsilon \coloneqq f\star \rho_\varepsilon \tendsto{L^p} f$ and $f_\varepsilon$ is in $C^\infty$ and compactly supported (because $\rho_\varepsilon$ and $f$ are).
        \item[(ii)] Let $f\in L^p(\Omega)$, we may assume it has compact (i.e.\ bounded) support. For $k\in \N$, put $\Omega_k \coloneqq \left\{ x\in \Omega\colon B(x, 1/ k) \subset \Omega \right\} $ and $f_k \coloneqq f \ind_{\Omega_k}$. Then $f_k \star \rho_\varepsilon \in C^\infty_c(\Omega)$ for $\varepsilon < 1 / k$ and  approximates $f_k$ as $\varepsilon \to 0$. Finally, $f - f_k \downarrow f \ind_{\Omega\setminus \Omega^o}$, which is $\lambda$-a.e.\ zero, so $\left\|f - f_k\right\|_p \to 0$ by DCT.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]A function $f\colon X\to [0,\infty]$ on a metric space $X$ is lower semi-continuous iff it is the increasing limit (or supremum) of non-negative continuous functions.[/latex]

[latex]
\begin{proof}
    \textbf{``$\impliedby$'':} Suppose $f_n \uparrow f$ and $x_m \to x$. Then, \[
        f_n(x) = \lim_{m\to \infty} f_n(x_m) \le \varliminf_{m\to \infty} f(x_m),
    \] and the LHS goes to $f(x)$.

    \textbf{``$\implies $'':} If $f\equiv \infty$ it is clear, assume otherwise. Put \[
        f_n(\cdot ) \coloneqq \inf_{y\in X} \left( f(y) + n \rho(\cdot ,y) \right),\quad n\in \N.
        \] Then, $f_n\colon X\to [0,\infty)$ is increasing and bounded above by $f$ (and everywhere finite because $\inf f < \infty$). Then $f_n$ is $n$-Lipschitz. Indeed, WLOG $n = 1$, and if $x,x'\in X$, choose $y'\in X$ with $f_1(x') \le f(y') + \rho(x',y') \le f_1(x') + \varepsilon$, so \[
        f_1(x) \le f(y') + \rho(x, y') \le f(y) + \varepsilon + \rho(x,y).
        \] Now let $x\in X$, then $\varlimsup f_n(x) \le f(x)$, and if $y_n\in X$ with $f(y_n) + n\rho(x,y_n) \le f_n(x) + \varepsilon(\le f(x) + \varepsilon)$, then either $\rho(x,y_n) \to 0$ and hence \[
f(x) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} f(y_n) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \left( f(y_n) + n\rho(x,y_n) \right) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} f_n(x) + \varepsilon,

front: [latex](DDSDE) Krylov and Kasminskii estimates.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Assume $(A^{1.1})$ holds and $X$ solves the SDE, and $(2p,2q)\in \mathcal{K}$. Then there exist $c,k > 1$ such that for any $f\in L^p_q(s,t)$,
    \begin{align*}
        \text{\bf (Krylov)} &\qquad \E \left[\int_{s}^t \left| f_r(X_r) \right| \dd r \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_s\right] \le c \left\|f\right\|_{L^p_q(s,t)},\\[8pt]
        \text{\bf (Kasminskii)} & \qquad \E \left[\e^{\int_s^t \left| f_r(X_r) \right| \dd r} \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_s\right] \le \e^{c + c \left\|f\right\|^k_{L^p_q(s,t)}}.
    \end{align*}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    WLOG $f\ge 0$. Let $u\in H^{2,p}_q(s,t)$ be the solution to $(\partial_r + L_r) u_r = \lambda u_r + f_r$ and $u_t = 0$, so that $\dd u_t(X_t) = (\lambda u_t + f_t)(X_t) \dd t + \dd M_t$ for a martingale $M$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[ \int_s^t  f_r(X_r) \dd r\,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_s \right]
        &= \E \left[u_t(X_t) - u_s(X_s) - \lambda \int_s^t u_r(X_r)\dd r \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_s \right] \\
        &\le (2 + \lambda T) \left\|u\right\|_\infty \le (2 + \lambda T) c \left\|f\right\|_{L^p_q}.
    \end{align*}

    Say we go from $t_0$ to $t_1$ instead of $s$ to $t$. Since $\mathcal{K}$ is open, (Krylov) also holds for $(p,q')$ with $q'< q$, so for $\delta > 0$, \[
        \E \left[ \int_t^{t+\delta} f_s(X_s) \dd s \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_t \right] \le c \left\|f\right\|_{L^p_{q'}} \le c \delta^{1/k} \left\|f\right\|_{L^p_{q}},
    \] where $k = (qq')/(q-q')$. Let $n\in \N$ so that the above is no larger than $1 / 2$ for $\delta \le 1 / n$, which can be chosen such that $n\le c + c \left\|f\right\|_{L^p_q}^k$. Then, for $m\in \N$,
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[ \left( \int_t ^{t+\delta} f_s(X_s)\dd s \right) ^m \,\middle\vert\,  \mathcal{F}_t \right]
        &= m! \E \left[\int_{s_1<\ldots <s_m} \prod_{i=1}^m f_{s_j}(X_{s_j}) \dd s_j \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_t\right]\\
        &\le \ldots \le m! 2^{-m},
    \end{align*}
    and hence $\E \left[ \exp \left( \int_t ^{t+\delta} f_s(X_s)\dd s \right) \,\middle\vert\, \mathcal{F}_s \right] \le \sum_{m=0}^\infty 2^{-m} = 2$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[ \e^{\int_{t_0}^{t_1} f_s(X_s) \dd s} \right] \le 2^n \le \e^{c' + c' \left\|f\right\|_{L^p_q}}.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex](DDSDE) Well-posedness of (SDE) under assumptions $(A^{1.1})$.[/latex]

[latex]
egin{theorem}
    Suppose $(A^{1.1})$ holds. Then (SDE) is well-posed. In fact, for any $k\in \N$ there is $c = c(k) > 0$ such that \[
        \E \left[ \sup_{t\in [0,T]} \left| X^x_t- X^y_t ight|^k  ight] \le c \left| x-y ight| ^k,\quad x,y\in \R^d.
    \]
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    Weak existence follows by Girsanov transform and standard theory. If we show the remaining claim we have pathwise uniqueness and hence well-posedness by Yamada-Watanabe.

    Applying Zvonkin's transform with $\lambda$ so large that $\left\| abla u ight\|_\infty < 1$ gets rid of the singular drift through a diffeomorphism, so it STS the claim for the transformed SDE. Let $Y^1$ and $Y^2$ be two solutions and put $\xi_t \coloneqq \left| Y^1_t - Y^2_t ight| $. Then, by Ito,
    egin{align*}
        \dd \xi_t ^{2k} \le c_k \xi_t ^{2k} \left( 1 + rac{\left| u_t(Y^1_t) - u_t(Y^2_t) ight| }{\xi_t} + rac{\left\|\widetilde{\sigma}_t(Y^1_t) - \widetilde{\sigma}_t(Y^2_t) ight\|^2}{\xi_t^2} ight) + \dd M_t
    \end{align*}
    for a clm $M$. By maximal functional lemma, the two fractions are at most
    egin{align*}
        c \sum_{i = 1,2}\left[ \left( M(\left| abla u_t ight| + \left\| abla \widetilde{\sigma}_t ight\|^2 ight) (Y_t^i) + \left\|u ight\|_\infty + \left\|\widetilde{\sigma} ight\|_\infty^2 ight] = \sum_{i=1,2} f(Y^i_t) \eqqcolon B_s,
    \end{align*}
    where by $(A^{1.1})$, $f\in L^{p / 2}_{q / 2}$ for some $(p,q)\in \mathcal{K}$, so putting $A_t \coloneqq c_k \int_0^t B_s \dd s$, we have $\E \left[ \e^{\lambda A_T} ight] < \infty$ for all $\lambda > 0$ by Kasminskii, and \[
    \xi_t ^{2k} \le \left| Y_0^1 - Y_0^2 ight| ^{2k} + \int_0^t \xi_s ^{2k} \dd A_s + M_t.
\] Stochastic Grönwall finishes the proof.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

egin{theorem}

front: [latex](DDSDE) Harnack inequality for $P_t$ with power.[/latex]

\begin{theorem}

\begin{proof}
    The idea is to look at a coupling of the form \[
    \begin{cases}
        \dd X_s = b_s(X_s) \dd s + \sigma_s(X_s) \dd W_s, & X_0 = x,\\
        \dd Y_s = (b_s(Y_s) + \xi_s \sigma(Y_s))\dd s + \sigma_s(Y_s)\dd W_s, & Y_0 = y,
    \end{cases}
\] where $\xi = \xi_s(x,y)\uparrow \infty$ as $ s\to t$ except if $x\to y$. Then $X_t = Y_t$ almost surely and there is a martingale $(R_s)_{s\in [0,t]}$ such that under $\dd \Q\coloneqq R \dd \P$, $Y$ satisfies the SDE of $X$, and for some $q > 1$, $c > 0$, \[

front: [latex]Definition of Radon measures, their role as a dual space, and (strongly) Radon spaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A Borel measure $\mu$ on a locally compact Hausdorff topological space $X$ is called \emph{Radon measure} if it is locally finite and inner regular on open sets.

\begin{theorem}
    Denote $C_0(X) \coloneqq \overline{C_c(X,\R)}^{\left\|\cdot \right\|_\infty}$, which is a Banach space with the supremum norm. Then the positive continuous linear functionals on $C_0(X)$ are exactly the maps $f \mapsto \int f \dd \mu$ for finite Radon measures $\mu$ on $X$. The set of all continuous linear functionals (i.e.\ the elements of the topological dual) are exactly the differences of these.
\end{theorem}

$X$ is called \emph{(strongly) Radon} if every (locally) finite Borel measure is Radon. If $X$ is Suslin (image of a Polish space under continuous map), then $X$ is strongly Radon and every Radon measure is outer regular (i.e.\ every locally finite Borel measure is regular).
[/latex]

front: [latex]Finite signed measures on $\R^d$ as Banach space and role as dual.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    A finite signed measure $\mu$ on $\R^d$ is a set function on the Borel sets such that, for every disjoint collection $(A_i)_{i\in \N}$, \[
        \sum_{i=1}^\infty \left| \mu(A_i) \right| <\infty,\qquad \mu \left( \bigcup_{i=1} ^\infty A_i  \right) = \sum_{i=1}^\infty\mu(A_i).
    \] This becomes a Banach space with \[
    \left\|\mu\right\| \coloneqq \sup \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^\infty \left| \mu(A_i) \right| \colon \sum_{i=1}^\infty A_i = \R^d \right\} = \mu_+(\R^d) + \mu_-(\R^d).
    \]
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\mu$ can be uniquely decomposed into the difference of two finite Borel measures $\mu_+$ and $\mu_-$,
        \item[(ii)] The space of finite signed measures is the dual of $C_0(\R^d)$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Hahn-Jordan decomposition.
        \item[(ii)] $\R^d$ is locally compact Suslin, so finite Borel measures are exactly finite Radon measures are exactly positive continuous linear funcitonals.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Kantorovich formulation of optimal transport, and criterion for existence of optimal transference plan.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{definition}
    Let $E$ be Polish and $\mu, u\in \mathcal{M}_1(E)$, and $c\colon E imes E o [0,\infty]$ measurable. Denote by $\Gamma(\mu, u)\subset \mathcal{M}_1(E imes E)$ the couplings of $\mu$ and $ u$. Then the Kantorovich optimal transport problem (KOT) is to find a minimizer of \[
        I_K \coloneqq \inf \left\{ \Pi(c)\colon \Pi \in \Gamma(\mu, u) ight\} .
    \]
\end{definition}

egin{theorem}
    If $c$ is lower semi-continuous, then KOT has a solution.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    First note that it is clear that $\Gamma(\mu, u)$ is compact in the weak topology (tight because $\mu$ and $ u$ are, and easy to confirm that closed). Furthermore, there are continuous bounded functions $0\le c_n \uparrow c$ because $c$ is lower semicontinuous, so $I_n \coloneqq \left[ \gamma \mapsto \gamma(c_n) ight] $ are continuous and $I \coloneqq \left[ \gamma \mapsto \gamma(c) ight] = \sup_n I_n$ by MCT, so $I$ is lower semicontinuous. Finally, a lower semicontinuous function on a compact set achieves a minimum.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Dual problem to Kantorovich optimal transport and idea of proof.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $\mu, u\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$, $c\colon \R^d imes \R^d o [0,\infty)$ measurable, and $I_\star = \inf \left\{ \Pi(c)\colon \Pi\in \Gamma(\mu, u) ight\} $. The \emph{dual problem} is \[
    J_\star \coloneqq \sup_{(\phi,\psi)\in \Phi} \left( \mu(\phi) + u(\psi) ight) ,
\] where $\Phi = \left\{(\phi,\psi)\colon  \phi\in L^1(\mu),\psi \in L^1( u), \phi(x) + \psi(y) \le c(x,y) ext{ $\mu imes u$-a.e.} ight\}$.

egin{theorem}
    If $c$ is lower semicontinuous, then $I_\star = J_\star$.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}[Sketch of Proof]
    First note that $\sup_{\phi,\psi\in C_b} \left( \mu(\phi) + u(\psi) - \Pi(\phi + \psi) ight) = \infty \ind_{\Pi \in \Gamma(\mu, u)}$ for any $\Pi\in \mathcal{M}_F(\R^d imes \R^d)$, so \[
        I_\star = \inf_\Pi \sup_{\phi,\psi\in C_b} \left( \mu(\phi) + u(\psi) + \Pi(c - \phi - \psi) ight) .
    \] Now it is true(!) that we can exchange inf and sup, so this is
    egin{align*}
        \sup_{\phi,\psi} \Big( \mu(\phi) + u(\psi) + \underbrace{\inf_\Pi \Pi(c - \phi - \psi)}_{=-\infty \ind_{\left\{\phi + \psi ot\le c ight\}}} \Big) = \sup_{\phi + \psi \le c} \left( \mu(\phi) + u(\psi) ight) .
    \end{align*}
    The last step is to see that we can relax $\phi$ and $\psi$ to the set $\Phi$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition and Characterisation of Cameron-Martin space $\mathbb{H}\subset C([0,T],\R^d)$, and Malliavin derivative $D\colon D^{1,2}\subset L^2(\mu_W) \to L^2(\mu_W)$. Is this well-defined on $L^2$?[/latex]

[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $\tau_h$ for $h\in C([0,T],\R^m)$ is the shift operator, then $\mu_W$ and $\mu_W \circ \tau_h^{-1}$ are absolutely continuous iff $h$ is in the Hilbert space \[
        \mathbb{H}\coloneqq \left\{ h\in C([0,T],\R^m)\colon \int_0^T \left|h'(s)\right|^2\dd s < \infty \right\} ,
    \] (where the derivative is weak.) The converse is easy to see if $h$ is absolutely continuous by Girsanov transform.
\end{proposition}

\begin{definition}
    Let $F \colon C([0,T],\R^m) \to \R$ be continuous and in $L^2(\mu_W)$, such that for $\mu_W$-a.e.\ $\gamma\in C$, \[
    \mathbb{H} \to \R;\, h \mapsto D_h F(\gamma) \coloneqq \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \frac{F(\gamma + \varepsilon h) - F(\gamma) }{\varepsilon},
\] exists and defines a bounded linear operator. In that case, for such $\gamma$ there is $DF(\gamma) \in \mathbb{H}$ such that $D_h F(\gamma) = \left<DF(\gamma),h \right>_{\mathbb{H}} $. Suppose furter that $DF\colon C \to \mathbb{H}$ satisfies $\left\|DF\right\|_{\mathbb{H}} \in L^2(\mu_W)$, then $F$ is called \emph{Malliavin differentiable}, write $F\in D^{1,2}$. This can be extended to $\R^d$-valued $F$ by doing it component-wise (in that case $DF\colon C\to \mathbb{H}^d$).
\end{definition}

Note that by definition of $\mathbb{H}$, if $F = G$ $\mu_W$-a.s., then $DF = DG$ $\mu_W$-a.s., so $D\colon D^{1,2} \subset L^2(\mu_W) \to L^2(\mu_W)$ is well-defined.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Malliavin calculus: Definition of $D_h F$ for $F = f(W)$ for a Brownian motion $W$ on $(\Omega, \A, \P)$ and random $h$. If $h$ is adapted, what is $\E \left[ D_h F \right] $?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    If $f\in D^{1,2}$ and $F = f(W)$ for a Brownian motion $W$ on $(\Omega, \A, \P)$, and $h\in L^2(\Omega\to \mathbb{H}, \P)$ (resp.\ $L^\infty$), then \[
        (D_h F)(\omega) \coloneqq (D_{h(\omega)}f)(W(\omega)),\quad \omega\in \Omega,
    \] is an element of $L^1(\Omega,\A,\P)$ (resp.\ $L^2$).
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    We have \[
        \left| D_h F \right| = \left| D_h f (W) \right|  = \left| \left<Df(W), h \right>_\mathbb{H}  \right|  \le \left\|h\right\|_\mathbb{H} \left\|Df(W)\right\|_\mathbb{H},
    \] and both of these factors are in $L^2(\P)$, so $D_h F \in L^1(\P)$.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}
    If $f\in D^{1,2}$, $F = f(W)$ for a BM $(\Omega,\mathcal{F},(\mathcal{F}_t),\P)$, and $h\in L^2(\Omega\to \mathbb{H},\P)$ is adapted, then \[
        \E \left[ D_h F \right] = \E \left[ F \int_0^T h'(s) \dd W_s \right] .
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    By some approximation, assume $\E \left[ \exp \left( \frac{1}{2} \left\|h\right\|_\mathbb{H} \right)  \right] < \infty$. For $\varepsilon > 0$, put $L^\varepsilon_t \coloneqq - \varepsilon \int_0^t h'(s) \dd W_s$, so $\mathcal{E}(L^\varepsilon)$ is a martingale by Novikov, and under $\dd \Q \coloneqq \mathcal{E}(L) \dd \P$, $\widetilde{W} = W + \varepsilon h$ is a Brownian motion, so
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[ D_h F \right]
        &= \E \left[ \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \frac{f(W+\varepsilon h) - f(W)}{\varepsilon} \right] = \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \E \left[ \ldots  \right] \\
        &= \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \left( \Q \left[ \mathcal{E}(-\widetilde{L^\varepsilon})_T f(\widetilde{W}) \right] - \E \left[ f(W) \right]   \right) \\
        &= \lim_{\varepsilon \to 0} \E \left[ f(W) \frac{\mathcal{E}(-L^\varepsilon)_T - 1}{\varepsilon} \right] \\
        &= \E \left[ f(W) \int_0^T h'(s)\dd W_s \right] .
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Malliaving calculus: Bismut formula for $\nabla _v P_t f(x)$.[/latex]

egin{theorem}
    Suppose $(A^{1.1})$ holds, let $v\in \R^d$, and put $\zeta_s \coloneqq \sigma_s^ op (\sigma_s \sigma_s^ op)^{-1}$. Then, for every $f\in B_b(\R^d)$ and $t\in (0,T]$, \[
abla _v P_tf(x) = rac{1}{t} \E \left[ f(X^x_t) \int_0^t \zeta_s(X^x_s) abla _v X^x_s \dd W_s ight] .
\]
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}[Sketch of Proof.]
    By Zvonkin transform, we may(!) assume $b^{(0)}= 0$. We further assume that that $f\colon \R^d o \R$ is bounded Lipschitz. Fix $t\in (0,T]$, and put $h(s) \coloneqq rac{1}{t} \int_0^s \zeta_s(X_s^x) abla _v X^x_s \dd s$. Then we start by showing that \[
    v_t \coloneqq abla_v X^x_t \coloneqq \lim_{\varepsilon o 0} rac{X^{x+\varepsilon v}_t -X^x_t}{\varepsilon}= D_h X^x_t,
\] (where $X^x_t = f(W) \colon C([0,T],\R^m) o \R^d$). Then $f(W+\varepsilon h) = X^{x,\varepsilon}_t$, where $\dd X^{x,\varepsilon}_s = b_s(.)\dd s + \sigma_s(.) (\dd W_s + \varepsilon \dd h_s)$, $X^{x,\varepsilon}_0 = X^x_0 = x$. Hence \[
w_s \coloneqq D_h X^x_s = \lim_{\varepsilon o 0} rac{X^{x,\varepsilon}_s - X^x_s}{\varepsilon}
\] solves the SDE
egin{align*}
    \dd w_s &= \left( abla _{w_s} b_s(X^x_s) + \sigma_s(X^x_s) h'(s) ight) \dd s + abla _{w_s}\sigma_s(X^x_s) \dd W_s,\
    w_0 &= 0.
\end{align*}
    Differentiating the SDE of $X$ in direction $v$ gives
    egin{align*}
        \dd v_s &= ( abla _{v_s} b_s)(X_s^x) \dd s + ( abla_{v_s} \sigma_s)(X^x_s)\dd W_s,\
        v_0 &= 0,
        \end{align*} and since $\sigma_s h'(s) = rac{1}{t} v_s$, $( rac{s}{t} v_s)_{s\in [0,t]}$ solves the SDE of $w$, so by uniqueness, \[
D_h X^x_t = w_t = rac{t}{t} v_t = v_t = abla _v X^x_t.
\] From here we conclude
egin{align*}
    abla _v P_t f(x)
    &= abla _v \E \left[ f(X^x_t) ight] = \E \left[ abla _v f(X^ x_t) ight]  = \E \left[ ( abla f)(X^x_t) \cdot abla _v X^x_t ight] \
    &= \E \left[ ( abla f)(X^x_t) \cdot D_h X^x_t ight] = \E \left[ D_h (f(X^x_t)) ight] \
    &= \E \left[ f(X^x_t) \int_0^t h'(s)\dd W_s ight] .
\end{align*}

front: [latex]Definition of Legendre-Fenchel transform $f^\star$ and $c$-transform $f^c$ and connection. Characterisation of functions of the form $g^\star$, and of functions with $f^{cc} = f$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $f\colon \R^d\to (-\infty,\infty]$ is \emph{proper} (i.e.\ $f\not\equiv \infty$), \[
                f^\star(y) \coloneqq \sup_{x\in \R^d} \left( x\cdot y - f(x) \right) \in (-\infty,\infty] ,\quad y\in \R^d.
        \]
    \item[(ii)] If $f\colon \R^d\to [-\infty,\infty)$ is proper, then \[
            f^c(y) = \inf_{x\in \R^d} \left( \frac{1}{2} \left| x-y \right| ^2 - f(x) \right)\in [-\infty,\infty) ,\quad y\in \R^d,
    \] is called \emph{$c$-concave}.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}
    If $f\colon \R^d\to [-\infty,\infty)$ is proper, then $\frac{1}{2} \left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - f^c = \left( \frac{1}{2} \left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - f \right) ^\star$, in particular is convex. Furthermore,
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] A proper function $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is of the form $f = g^\star$ iff it is convex and lower semicontinuous, in which case $f^{\star\star}=f$,
        \item[(ii)] A proper function $f\colon \R^d \to [-\infty,\infty)$ is $c$-concave iff $f^{cc} = f$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    First part is straight-forward, for (i) it is clear that $f=g^\star$ is lsc and convex. For (ii), suppose that $f$ is $c$-concave and continuous, then $\frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - f$ is convex by the above and lower semicontinuous, so
    \begin{align*}
        f^{c c}
        &= \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - f \right) ^\star \right) ^c\\
        &= \frac{1}{2} \left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - f \right) ^\star \right)  \right)^\star \\
        &= \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| \cdot  \right| ^2 - f \right) ^{\star\star}\\
        &= f.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Kolmogorov-Riesz-Fr\'echet theorem (anaolgue of Arzela-Ascoli in $L^p(\R^d)$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $p\in [1,\infty)$ and $\Omega\subset \R^d$ bounded, and suppose $\mathcal{F}\subset L^p(\Omega)$ satisfies
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\sup_{f\in \mathcal{F}} \left\|f\right\|_{L^p} < \infty$,
        \item[(ii)] $\sup_{f\in \mathcal{F}, \left| y \right| \le \delta} \left\|\widetilde{f}^y - \widetilde{f}\right\|_{L^p} \tendsto{} 0$ as $\delta\to 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
    Then $\mathcal{F}$ is relatively compact. Here $\widetilde{f}$ is the trivial extension of $f$ to $\R^d$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    $\Omega$ bounded, so $\mathcal{F}$ is also $L^1$-bounded. Let $\rho\in C(\R^d)$ with $\rho \ge 0$, $\int \rho = 1$, and $\supp(\rho) \subset B(0,1)$. Then,
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\sup_{f\in \mathcal{F}} \left\|\widetilde{f}_\varepsilon - \widetilde{f}\right\|_p \tendsto{} 0$ as $\varepsilon \to 0$,
        \item[(ii)] $\widetilde{\mathcal{F}}_\varepsilon \subset C(\Omega)$ is relatively compact for all $\varepsilon > 0$.

    \end{enumerate}
    Indeed, the first is just because \[
        \left\|\widetilde{f}_\varepsilon - \widetilde{f}\right\|_p^p \le \int \left\|\widetilde{f}^y - \widetilde{f}\right\|_p^p \rho_\varepsilon(y) \dd y \le \sup_{\left| y \right| \le \varepsilon} \left\|\widetilde{f}^y - \widetilde{f}\right\|_p^p.
    \] For the second, $\left\|\widetilde{f}_\varepsilon\right\|_\infty \le \left\|\rho_\varepsilon\right\|_\infty \left\|\widetilde{f}\right\|_1 \le C_\varepsilon$, and
    \begin{align*}
        \left|\widetilde{f}_\varepsilon(x) - \widetilde{f}_\varepsilon(y)\right|
        &\le \int \left| \rho_\varepsilon(x-z) - \rho_\varepsilon(y-z) \right| \left| \widetilde{f}(z) \right| \dd z \le C_\varepsilon \left| x-y \right| \left\|\widetilde{f}\right\|_1,
    \end{align*}
    then apply Arzela-Ascoli on $\overline{\Omega}$ (which is compact). Now let $\eta > 0$ and take $\varepsilon>0$ such that $(\textrm{i})_\varepsilon \le \eta$, and then $A\subset \mathcal{F}$ finite such that $\widetilde{A}_\varepsilon  $ is an $\eta$-net of $\widetilde{\mathcal{F}}_\varepsilon \subset C(\Omega)$. Then for any $f\in \mathcal{F}$ there is $g\in A$ such that
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|f - g\right\|_{L^p(\Omega)}
        &= \left\|\widetilde{f} - \widetilde{g}\right\|_{L^p(\Omega)} \le \left\|\widetilde{f} - \widetilde{f}_\varepsilon\right\|_{L^p(\R^d)} + \left\|\widetilde{f}_\varepsilon -\widetilde{g}_\varepsilon\right\|_{L^\infty(\Omega)} + \left\|\widetilde{g}_\varepsilon - \widetilde{g}\right\|_{L^p(\R^d)}\le 3\eta.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition weak derivative and conformance with weak convergence in $L^p$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $\Omega\subset \R^d$ open.
\begin{definition}
    Let $f\in L^1_\text{loc}(\Omega)$, and $\alpha \in \N_0^d$ a multi-index. Then $g\in L^1_\text{loc}(\Omega)$ is called weak $\alpha$-derivative of $f$ if \[
        \lambda(f \partial^\alpha \varphi) = (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \lambda (g \varphi),\quad \varphi\in C_c^\infty(\Omega).
    \] In that case we write $g = \partial^\alpha f$, which is unique $\lambda$-a.e.\ if it exists. Furthermore, the definition doesn't change if the test function space is $C^{\left| \alpha \right| }_c(\Omega)$.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    If $\varphi\in C^{\left| \alpha \right| }_c(\Omega)$, then $\varphi_\varepsilon\coloneqq \rho_\varepsilon\star \varphi \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$ and $\varphi_\varepsilon\tendsto{L^\infty} \phi$ and $\partial^\alpha (\varphi_\varepsilon) = \rho_\varepsilon \star (\partial^\alpha \varphi) = (\partial^\alpha \varphi)_\varepsilon \tendsto{L^\infty} \partial^\alpha \varphi$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \lambda(f \partial^\alpha \varphi) \longleftarrow\lambda(f (\partial^\alpha \varphi)_\varepsilon) = \lambda(f \partial^\alpha (\varphi_\varepsilon)) = (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \lambda(g \varphi_\varepsilon) \tendsto{} (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \lambda(g\varphi)
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}
    If $\Omega\subset \R^d$ open, $(u_n) \subset L^p(\Omega)$ converges to $u$ (weakly is enough) in $L^p(\Omega)$, and $\partial^\alpha u_n \to v$ in $L^p$, then $u$ has weak $\alpha$-derivative and $\partial^\alpha u = v$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    We have \[
        \lambda(u \partial^\alpha \varphi) \longleftarrow \lambda(u_n \partial^\alpha \varphi) = \lambda(v_n \varphi) \tendsto{} \lambda(v \varphi),
    \] so $v$ is a weak $\alpha$-derivative of $u$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of $W^{k,p}$ and $W_0^{k,p}$ (and proof of completeness).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Let $k\in \N$ and $p \in [1,\infty]$. Then the set of $f\in L^p(\Omega)$ with weak derivatives up to order $k$ which are all in $L^p(\Omega)$ is denoted $W^{k,p}(\Omega)$, which is a Banach space with \[
        \left\|f\right\|_{W^{k,p}} \coloneqq \left( \sum_{\left| \alpha \right| \le k} \left\|\partial^\alpha f\right\|_{L^p(\Omega)}^p \right) ^{1 / p}.
    \] If $p = 2$, this is called $H^k(\Omega)$ which is a Hilbert space with \[
    \left<f,g \right> _{H^k(\Omega)} \coloneqq \sum_{\left| \alpha \right| \le k} \left<\partial^\alpha f, \partial^\alpha g \right> _{L^2(\Omega)}.
    \]
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    HTS completeness. If $(u_m)$ is a $W^{k,p}$ Cauchy sequence, then $(\partial^\alpha u_m)$ is $L^p$-Cauchy for all $\alpha$, so converges to $v_\alpha$ in $L^p$. Put $u\coloneqq v_0$. Then $u\in W^{k,p}$ and $v_\alpha = \partial^\alpha u$ for all $\alpha$, in particular $u_m \to u$ in $W^{k,p}$.
\end{proof}

\begin{definition}
    If $p\in[1,\infty)$, then $W_0^{k,p}(\Omega) \coloneqq \overline{C_c^\infty(\Omega)}^{\left\|\cdot \right\|_{W^{k,p}}}$. This is still a Banach space because it is a closed subspace of $W^{k,p}(\Omega)$. Write $H^{k}_0(\Omega) \coloneqq W^{k,2}_0(\Omega)$.
\end{definition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $g\in L^1_\text{loc}$ and $\lambda(g\varphi) = 0$ for all $\varphi\in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$, then $g= 0$ a.e.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\Omega\subset \R^d$ open and $g\in L^1_\text{loc}(\Omega)$ and $\lambda(g\varphi) = 0$ for all $\varphi\in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$, then $g = 0$ a.e.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    WLOG $\Omega$ bounded and $g\in L^1(\Omega)$. Let $\varepsilon > 0$ and take $h\in C_c(\Omega)$ with $\left\|g - h\right\|_{L^1}< \varepsilon$, and $\varphi \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$ with $\varphi = 1 (-1)$ on $\left\{ h\ge \varepsilon (\le -\varepsilon) \right\} $, so $\left| \left\|h\right\|_{L^1} - \lambda(h\varphi) \right| \le \lambda (h \left| \text{sgn}(h)-\varphi \right|)\le \varepsilon$, so \[
    \left\|g\right\|_{L^1} \le \left\|h\right\|_{L^1} + \varepsilon \le 2\varepsilon.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Integration by parts for $W^{k,p}(\Omega)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $\Omega\subset \R^d$ be open, $p\in (1,\infty]$, $k\in \N_0$, $u\in W^{k,p}(\Omega)$, $v\in W_0^{k,p'}(\Omega)$, and $\left| \alpha \right| \le k$. Then \[
        \int_\Omega u (\partial^\alpha v) \dd x = (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \int_\Omega (\partial^\alpha u) v \dd x.
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $v_n \in C_c^\infty(\Omega)$ with $v_n \tendsto{W^{k,p'}} v$, so that \[
        \lambda(u(\partial^\alpha v))\longleftarrow\lambda(u (\partial^\alpha v_n)) = (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \lambda((\partial^\alpha u) v_n) \tendsto{} (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \lambda((\partial^\alpha u) v).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Weak derivative and convolution (what is $\partial^\alpha (\rho \star f)$?)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $\rho \in C^\infty_c(\R^d)$.

\begin{proposition}
    Let $p\in [1,\infty)$ and $k\in \N_0$. If $f\in W^{k,p}(\R^d)$, then $\rho \star f\in C^\infty(\R^d) \cap W^{k,p}(\R^d)$ and for every $\left| \alpha \right| \le k$, \[
        \partial^\alpha (\rho \star f) = \rho \star (\partial^\alpha f).
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    We already know that $\rho\star f \in C^\infty(\R^d) \cap L^p(\R^d)$. Furthermore, for every $\left| \alpha \right| \le k$,
    \begin{align*}
        \partial^\alpha (\rho\star f)(x)
        &= (\partial^\alpha \rho) \star f (x)= \int \partial^\alpha_x \rho(x - y) f(y)\dd y = (-1)^{\left| \alpha \right| } \int \partial^\alpha_y \rho(x-y) f(y) \dd y \\
        &= \int \rho(x-y) \partial^\alpha f(y) \dd y = \rho\star (\partial^\alpha f )(x).
    \end{align*}
    Since $\partial^\alpha f \in L^p(\R^d)$, we know that $\partial^\alpha (\rho \star f) = \rho \star (\partial^\alpha f) \in L^p$, so $\rho\star f \in W^{k,p}(\R^d)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Meyers-Serrin (and proof if $\Omega=\R^d$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Meyers-Serrin]
    If $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is open and $p\in [1,\infty)$ and $k\in \N_0$, then $C^\infty(\Omega) \cap W^{k,p}(\Omega)$ is dense in $W^{k,p}(\Omega)$ (w.r.t.\ $\left\|\cdot \right\|_{W^{k,p}}$).
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    If $\Omega = \R^d$, take $\rho \ge 0$, $\int \rho \dd x = 1$, $\rho\in C^\infty_c(\R^d)$. Then if $f\in W^{k,p}(\R^d)$, $f_\varepsilon \in C^\infty(\R^d) \cap W^{k,p}(\R^d)$, and for every $\left| \alpha \right| \le k$, \[
        \partial^\alpha f_\varepsilon = (\partial^\alpha f)_\varepsilon \tendsto{L^p} \partial^\alpha f,
    \] that is $f_\varepsilon \tendsto{W^{k,p}} f$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of Lipschitz and $C^m$ domain and segment condition (and their relation), and condition under which $C^\infty_c(\R^d)\!\!\restriction_{\Omega}$ is dense in $W^{k,p}(\Omega)$. In particular, do we have $W_0^{k,p}(\R^d) = W^{k,p}(\R^d)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Let $\Omega\subset \R^d$ be open.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\Omega$ is said to be \emph{Lipschitz} ($C^m$) if for every $x_0\in \partial\Omega$ there is $r > 0$ and a Lipschitz ($C^m$) function $\gamma$ such that (potentially after relabelling axes), \[
                \Omega \cap B(x_0,r) = \left\{ x\colon x_d > \gamma(x_1, \ldots ,x_{d-1}) \right\} \cap B(x_0,r).
        \]
    \item[(ii)] $\Omega$ is said to satisfy the \emph{segment condition} if for every $x_0\in \partial\Omega$ there is $r > 0$ and $y\in \R^d\setminus\{0\}$ such that for every $x\in \overline{\Omega}\cap B(x_0,r)$, the line segment \[
            (z,z+y) \coloneqq z + (0,1)\cdot y \subset \Omega.
    \]
    \end{enumerate}
    Clearly, (i) implies (ii).
\end{definition}

\begin{theorem}
    If $p\in [1,\infty)$, $k\in \N_0$, and $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is open and satisfies the segment condition, then $C_c^\infty(\R^d)\!\!\restriction_{\Omega} $ is dense in $W^{k,p}(\Omega)$. In particular, $W_0^{k,p}(\R^d) = W^{k,p}(\R^d)$.
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Stein's extension theorem (for Sobolev functions).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $\Omega\subset \R^d$ be bounded, open, and with Lipschitz boundary, $p\in [1,\infty)$. Then there is a map $E\colon \left\{ f\colon \Omega\to \R \right\} / \sim \,\,\to \left\{ f\colon \R^d\to \R \right\} / \sim $ (where $\sim$ denotes equality a.e.) such that $Eu = u$ a.e.\ on $\Omega$ and for $u\in W^{k,p}(\Omega)$, \[
        \left\|Eu\right\|_{W^{k,p}(\R^d)}\le C_{k,p,\Omega} \left\|u\right\|_{W^{k,p}(\Omega)}.
    \]
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Trace operator for Sobolev spaces and characterisation of $W^{1,p}_0(\Omega)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $p\in [1,\infty)$, $k\in \N$, $\Omega \subset \R^d$ open, bounded, with $C^{k-1}_\text{Lip}$ boundary. Then there exists a unique linear bounded operator $T\colon W^{k,p}(\Omega) \to L^p(\partial \Omega)$ such that \[
        T u = u\!\!\restriction_{\partial \Omega} \text{ for all $u\in C(\overline{\Omega}) \cap W^{k,p}(\Omega)$}.
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Uniqueness is clear because $Tu$ is fixed for all $u\in C^\infty_c(\R^d)\!\!\restriction_{\Omega} $, which is dense. For existence it suffices (by denseness) to define $Tu = u\!\!\restriction_{\partial \Omega}$ on the same set and show that it is bounded there. For an idea we consider the case where $d = 2$ and $(-2,2)\times \left\{ 0 \right\} $ is part of the boundary, and $(-2,2) \times (0,1) \subset \Omega$, and we only consider the trace on $(-1,1)\times \left\{ 0 \right\} $. Let $u \in C_c^\infty(\R^d)$, and $\rho \in C^\infty_c((-2,2)\times (-1,1))$ with $\rho \equiv 1$ on $(-1,1)\times \left\{ 0 \right\} $, so with $B\coloneqq (-2,2)\times (0,1)$,
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|u\right\|_{L^p((-1,1)\times \left\{ 0 \right\}) }^p
        &= \int_{-1}^1 \left| u(x,0) \right| ^p \dd x \le \int_{-2}^2 \rho(x,0) \left| u(x,0) \right| ^p \dd x \\
        &=- \int_{-2}^2 \int_0^1 \partial_y\Big( \rho(x,y) \left| u(x,y) \right| ^p \Big) \dd y \dd x\\
        &\le C \int_B \left( \left| u \right| ^p + \left| \nabla u \right| \left| u \right| ^{p-1} \right) \dd x \\
        &\le C' \int_B \left( \left| u \right| ^p + \left| \nabla u \right| ^p \right) \dd x\\
        &\le C' \left\|u\right\|_{W^{1,p}(\Omega)}.
    \end{align*}
    where we used Young's inequality.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}

front: [latex]Definition (strong and weak solution to) DDSDE and definition of well-posedness.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $b\colon [0,T]\times \R^d\times \mathcal{P} \to \R^d$ and $\sigma\colon [0,T]\times \R ^d \times \mathcal{P} \to \R ^{d\times m}$ be measurable, where $\mathcal{P} = \mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$. Given an $m$-dim.\ BM $(W_t)$ on a complete filtered probability space, a continuous adapted process $(X_t)_{t\in [0,T]}$ is called a \emph{strong solution} to (DDSDE) if \[
    X_t = X_0 + \int_0^t b_s(X_s,\mathcal{L}_{X_s}) \dd s + \int_0^t \sigma_s(X_s, \mathcal{L}_{X_s})\dd W_s.
\] A \emph{weak solution} is a tuple $(\widetilde{X},\widetilde{W})$ that solves this on some filtered probability space. Let $\widehat{\mathcal{P}}\subset \mathcal{P}$. We say that (DDSDE) is
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] \emph{strong $\widehat{\mathcal{P}}$-well posed} if for every $\mathcal{F}_0$-measurable $X_0$ with $\mathcal{L}_{X_0}\in \widehat{\mathcal{P}}$, there is a unique (up to indistinguishability) strong solution $(X_t)_{t\in [0,T]}$ starting at $X_0$ with $\mathcal{L}_{X_t} \in \widehat{\mathcal{P}}$ for all $t\in [0,T]$,
    \item[(ii)] \emph{weak $\widehat{\mathcal{P}}$-well posed} if for every $\nu\in \mathcal{\widehat{P}}$, there is a unique (in distribution) weak solution $(\widetilde{X},\widetilde{W})$ with $\mathcal{L}_{\widetilde{X}_0} = \nu$ and $\mathcal{L}_{\widetilde{X}_t}\in \mathcal{\widehat{P}}$ for all $t\in [0,T]$.
    \item[(iii)] \emph{well-posed} if it is both strong and weak well-posed.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Modified Yamada-Watanabe for DDSDE.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $\widehat{\mathcal{P}}\subset \mathcal{P} \coloneqq \mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$
\begin{proposition}
    Suppose that for every $\mu \in C([0,T],\widehat{\mathcal{P}})$, the classical SDE \[
        \text{(SDE)}_\mu\qquad \dd X_t = b_t(X_t,\mu_t) \dd t + \sigma_t(X_t,\mu_t) \dd W_t
    \] satisfies pathwise uniqueness. Then YW holds for DDSDE, that is, pathwise uniqueness and weak existence imply strong existence and uniqueness in law (thus strong and weak well-posedness).
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    We apply YW to the classical SDE above: Take a weak solution $(\widetilde{X},\widetilde{W})$ of (DDSDE) on some probability space, and put $\mu_t \coloneqq \mathcal{L}_{\widetilde{X}_t}$. Then $(\widetilde{X},\widetilde{W})$ is a weak solution of $(\text{SDE})_\mu$, so by classical YW, there is a strong solution $(X_t)$ to $(\text{SDE})_\mu$ and $(\text{SDE})_\mu$ has uniqueness in law, so $\mathcal{L}_{X_t}= \mathcal{L}_{\widetilde{X}_t}=\mu_t$, so $X$ is a strong solution to DDSDE. Weak well-posedness similarly.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Correspondence between weak solutions to (DDSDE) and fixed points of a map. How can one infer weak/strong well-posedness of (DDSDE)?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $\gamma \in \widehat{\mathcal{P}}$ and $C_\gamma \coloneqq \left\{ \mu \in C([0,T],\widehat{\mathcal{P}})\colon \mu_0 = \gamma \right\} $.

\begin{lemma}
    Suppose that for any $\mu\in C_\gamma$, $(\text{SDE})_\mu$ has a unique weak solution $X^\mu$ with $\mathcal{L}_{X^\mu_0} = \gamma$, and define \[
        \Phi\colon C_\gamma \to C_\gamma; \, (\mu_t) \mapsto (\mathcal{L}_{X_t^\mu}).
    \] Then fixed points of $\Phi$ are exactly laws of weak solutions to (DDSDE). In particular, if $\Phi$ has a unique fixed point, (DDSDE) is weak well-posed. If additionally $\text{(SDE)}_\mu$ is strong well-posed, then so is (DDSDE).
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    If $(X_t)$ is a weak solution to (DDSDE) and $\mu \coloneqq \mathcal{L}_X$, then $X$ is a weak solution to $(\text{SDE})_\mu$ and $\Phi \mu = \mathcal{L}_X = \mu$, so the law of $X$ is a fixed point. On the other hand, if $\mu$ is a fixed point and $X$ the corresponding weak solution of $(\text{SDE})_\mu$, then $X$ is a weak solution to (DDSDE).

    Suppose that $(\text{SDE})_\mu$ is also strong-well posed. Then if $\mu$ is a fixed point and $X$ a strong solution to $(\text{SDE})_\mu$, $X$ is a strong solution to (DDSDE), and if $Y$ is another one, then by weak well-posedness it has the same law as $X$ so is also another strong solution to $(\text{SDE})_\mu$, so $X = Y$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Optimal transport with $c(x,y) = \frac{1}{2}\left| x-y \right| ^2$: If $(\varphi,\psi)\in \Phi_c$, what do you know about $(\varphi^{c c},\varphi^c)$, and how can you replace $(\varphi,\psi)$ by a nice pair $(\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi}) \in \Phi_c$ that is at least as good?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $c(x,y) = \frac{1}{2}\left| x-y \right| ^2$ and $\mu,\nu\in \mathcal{P}_2(\R^d)$.
\begin{lemma}
    Suppose that $(\varphi,\psi)\in \Phi_c$ satisfy $\varphi + \psi \le c$ everywhere.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\varphi^{cc} \ge \varphi$ and $\varphi^c \ge \psi$ and $\varphi^{c c} + \varphi^{c} \le c$.
        \item[(ii)] There is $(\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi})\in \Phi_c$ with $J[\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi}] \ge J[\varphi,\psi]$ and $\widetilde{\varphi}\vee \widetilde{\psi}\le \left| \cdot  \right| ^2$. In fact,  $(\widetilde{\varphi}, \widetilde{\psi}) = (\eta, \eta^{c})$ for a $c$-concave function $\eta$.

    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] We have $\varphi^c(x) = \inf_y \left( c(x,y) - \phi(y) \right) \ge \psi(x)$ and
    \begin{align*}
        \varphi^{c c}(x)
        &= \inf_y \left( c(x,y) - \varphi^{c}(y) \right) = \inf_y \sup_z \left( c(x,y) - c(y,z) + \varphi(z) \right) \\
        &\ge \inf_y \varphi(x) = \varphi(x).
    \end{align*}
    Furthermore,
    \begin{align*}
        \varphi^{c c}(x) + \varphi^{c}(y)
        &= \inf_z \left( c(x,z) - \varphi^{c}(z) + \varphi^{c}(y) \right) \le c(x,y).
    \end{align*}
    Since $\varphi^{c c}$ and $\varphi^{c}$ are already bounded below by integrable functions, upper bounds suffice to get $(\varphi^{c c}, \varphi^{c}) \in L^1(\mu) \times L^1(\nu)$ and thus $ \in \Phi_c$.
        \item[(ii)] Define \[
        a  \coloneqq \inf_y \left( \left| y \right| ^2 - \varphi ^c(y) \right) .
    \] We show later that $a  \in \R$, but assuming this $(\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi}) \coloneqq  (\varphi ^{c c} - a , \varphi ^{c} + a )$, so the claimed bounds hold by definition of $a $. Indeed,
    \begin{align*}
    \varphi ^{c c}(x) - a 
    &= \sup_y \inf_z \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| x-z \right| ^2 - \varphi ^c(z) - \left| y \right|^2 + \varphi ^c(y) \right) \le \sup_y \left( \frac{1}{2}\left| x-y \right| ^2 - \left| y \right| ^2 \right) \\
    &\le \left| x \right| ^2,
    \end{align*} and the other one is obvious. Thus $(\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi})\in \Phi_c$ and $J[\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi}] = J[\varphi^{c c},\varphi^{c}] \ge J[\varphi,\psi]$ by the previous lemma. Now note that $(\widetilde{\varphi},\widetilde{\psi}) = ((\varphi - a)^{cc}, (\varphi - a)^c)$, so put $\eta \coloneqq (\varphi - a)^{c c}$.

    It remains to show $a \in \R$. We have $\varphi ^c(y) = \inf_z (c(y,z) - \varphi (z)) \ge \psi (y)$, so $a  \le \left| y_0 \right| ^2 - \psi (y_0) < \infty$. Furthermore,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| y \right| ^2 - \varphi ^{c}(y)
        &= \sup_z \left( \left| y \right| ^2 -  \frac{1}{2}\left| y-z \right| ^2 + \varphi (z) \right) \ge \sup_z \left( \varphi (z) - \left| z \right| ^2 \right) \\
        &\ge \varphi (x_0) - \left| x_0 \right| ^2,
    \end{align*}
    so $a  \ge \varphi (x_0) - \left| x_0 \right| ^2 > -\infty$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex] Convergence in Wasserstein distance on bounded subsets of a Polish space is equivalent to weak convergence.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $E$ is Polish with metric $\rho$.
\begin{lemma}
    Suppose $p\ge 1$, $\mu_n ,\mu \in \mathcal{P}_p(E)$ are supported on a common bounded set. Then $\mu_n \to \mu$ weakly iff $d_p(\mu_n,\mu) \to 0$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $d_p(\mu_n,\mu) \to 0$, then for any Lipschitz function  $f\colon E\to \R$ and any coupling $\gamma_n \in \Gamma(\mu_n,\mu)$,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| \mu_n(f) - \mu(f) \right|
        &= \left| \int f(x) \Pi_n(\dd x,\dd y) - \int f(y) \Pi_n(\dd x,\dd y) \right| \le \int \left| f(x) - f(y) \right| \Pi_n(\dd x,\dd y)\\
        &\le L \Pi_n(d),
    \end{align*}
    so upper bounded by $L d_1(\mu_n,\mu) \le L d_p(\mu_n,\mu) \to 0$.

    For the other direction, suppose that $\mu_n \to \mu $ weakly and let $\varepsilon > 0$. By the dual representation of $d_1$, we find $\varphi_n\in \text{Lip}_1(E)$ such that $d_1(\mu_n,\mu) \le \left| \mu_n(\varphi_n) - \mu(\varphi_n) \right| + \varepsilon$. By replacing $\varphi_n \to \varphi_n - \varphi_n(x_0)$ and by our assumption we can assume that $\left\{ \varphi_n \right\} $ is uniformly bounded, say by $M > 0$ (in fact $M$ is the radius of the smallest common support ball). Let $K\subset E$ be compact such that all of $\mu_n$ and $\mu$ put all but $\varepsilon$ of their mass on $K$, then $\left\{ \varphi_n \!\!\restriction_{K} \colon n\in \N \right\} \subset C(K,\R)$ is relatively compact by Arzela-Ascoli and so every subsequence has a subsequence (call it the same) that converges uniformly on $K$ to some $\varphi\in \text{Lip}_1(K)$, which can be extended to $\varphi \in \text{Lip}_1(E)$ bounded. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        \varlimsup_{n\to \infty}d_1(\mu_n,\mu)
        &\le \varepsilon + \varlimsup_{n\to \infty} \left| \mu_n(\varphi_n) - \mu(\varphi_n) \right| \\
        &\le \varepsilon + \varlimsup_{n\to \infty}\big( \left| \mu_n(\varphi_n - \varphi) \right| + \underbrace{\left| \mu_n(\varphi) - \mu(\varphi) \right|}_{\to 0} + \underbrace{\left| \mu(\varphi - \varphi_n) \right|}_{\le M\varepsilon + \mu(K) \left\|\varphi - \varphi_n\right\|_K} \big)\\
        &\le \varepsilon + 2M\varepsilon.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convergence in Wasserstein distance on Polish space is equivalent to weak convergence plus convergence of $p$'th moments.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $\mu_n,\mu\in \mathcal{P}_p(E)$, then for every $x_0\in E$, $d_p(\mu_n,\mu) \to 0$ iff $\mu_n \to \mu$ weakly and $\mu_n(\rho(\cdot ,x_0)^p) \to \mu(\rho(\cdot ,x_0)^p)$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    $d_p$-convergence implies $d_1$-convergence implies weak convergence (by the obvious direction of the dual representation), and \[
        \left| \mu_n(\rho(x_0,\cdot)^p) - \mu(\rho(x_0,\cdot )^p) \right| = \left| d_p(\mu_n,\delta_{x_0}) - d_p(\mu,\delta_{x_0}) \right| \le d_p(\mu_n,\mu) \to 0.
    \]

    For the other direction, define by $P_R\colon E\to B(x_0,R)$ to be the identity on $B(x_0,R)$ and constant $x_0$ everywhere else. Since $\mu \circ \rho(x_0,\cdot )^{-1}$ can only have countably many point masses, $P_R$ is $\mu$-a.e.\ continuous for all but countably many $R > 0$, so $P_R(\mu_n) \to P_R(\mu)$ as $n\to \infty$ weakly for all such $R > 0$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \varlimsup_{n\to \infty} d_p(\mu_n,\mu) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \big( d_p(\mu_n,P_R(\mu_n) ) + \underbrace{d_p(P_R(\mu_n), P_R(\mu))}_{\to 0} + d_p(P_R(\mu), \mu)\big)
    \end{align*}
    for every $R > 0$. Finally,
    \begin{align*}
        d_p(\mu_n, P_R(\mu_n))
        &\le \int \rho(x,P_R(x))^p \mu_n(\dd x) = \int\limits_{\left\{x\colon \rho(x_0,x) \ge R \right\}} \rho(x_0,x)^p \mu_n(\dd x)
    \end{align*}
    goes to zero as $R\to \infty$ uniformly in $n$(!).
\end{proof}
[/latex]
