    If $p\ge 1$ and $f_1,g_1,f_2,g_2\in \mathcal{P}_p(\R^d)$, then
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $d_p(f_1\star f_2, g_1\star g_2) \le d_p(f_1, g_1) + d_p(f_2,g_2)$,
        \item[(ii)] If $\E \left[ f_i \right] = \E \left[ g_i \right] $, then $d_2(f_1\star f_2, g_1\star g_2)^2 \le d_2(f_1,g_1)^2 + d_2(f_2,g_2)^2$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $(X_1,Y_1)$ and $(X_2,Y_2)$ be optimal couplings of $(f_1,g_1)$ and $(f_2,g_2)$, independent on the same probability space. Then for (i), \[
        \text{LHS} \le \left\|(X_1+X_2) - (Y_1+Y_2)\right\|_{L^p} \le \left\|X_1-Y_1\right\|_{L^p} + \left\|X_2-Y_2\right\|_{L^p} = \text{RHS}.
    \] For (ii),
    \begin{align*}
        \text{LHS}
        &\le \E \left[ \left( X_1+X_2 - (Y_1+Y_2) \right) ^2 \right] \\
        &= \E \left[ (X_1-Y_1)^2 \right] + \E \left[ (X_2-Y_2)^2 \right] + 2 \underbrace{\E \left[ (X_1-Y_1)(X_2-Y_2) \right] }_{=0}\\
        &= \text{RHS}.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $\mu,\nu\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$ with $\mu$ diffusive, what is the unique increasing $T\colon \R \to \R$ with $T(\mu) = \nu$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{proposition}
    Suppose $\mu, u\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$ and $\mu$ is diffusive. Then there is a ($\mu$-a.e.\ unique) increasing map $T\colon \R o \R$ with $T(\mu) = u$, which is given by $T = G^{-1}\circ F$.
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    Clearly, if $T$ is like that, it is increasing and $T(\mu) = G^{-1}(F(\mu)) = G^{-1}(\lambda) = u$. Now suppose $T$ is increasing and $T(\mu) = u$. Then, \[
        F(x) = \mu ((-\infty,x]) \le \mu\left( T ^{-1}(T(-\infty,x]) ight) = u((-\infty,T(x)]) = G(T(x)),
    \] so $G^{-1}(F(x)) \le T(x)$. Now suppose the inequality is strict at some $x\in \R$, which means that $G \ge F(x)$ on some interval $(x',T(x))$. Now for any $y < x$, $G(T(y)) = \mu(T^{-1}(-\infty,T(y)]) \le \mu((-\infty,x]) = F(x)$, so in fact $F(x) = G(y)$ for all $y\in (x',T(x))$, so if $\Lambda$ denotes the set of values of $G$ on plateaus (which is countable), then $F(x) \in \Lambda$, and the set of such $x$ is $\mu$-negligible (otherwise $F(\mu) = \lambda$ had point masses), so the inequality is strict only on a $\mu$-negligible set.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front:
[latex]Solution to Kantorovich problem in one dimension. In particular, what is $d_p(\mu,
u)$ and $d_1(\mu,
u)$ for $\mu,
u\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$.[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
egin{theorem}
    If $\mu, u\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$, then for cost function $c(x,y) = h(x-y)$ with (strictly) convex $h$, then \[
        I_\star = \int_0^1 h(F^{-1}(\eta) - G^{-1}(\eta)) \dd \eta.
    \] If $I_\star < \infty$, then the (unique) optimal transport plan $\Pi\in \Gamma(\mu, u)$ is given by $(F^{-1},G^{-1}) \# \lambda$, which is induced by the map $T = G^{-1}\circ F$ if $\mu$ is diffusive.
\end{theorem}

In particular, for any $\mu, u\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$ and $p \in [1,\infty)$, $d_p(\mu, u) = \left\|F^{-1} - G^{-1} ight\|_{L^p((0,1))}$, and \[
    d_1(\mu, u) = \int_0^1 \left| F^{-1}(\eta) - G^{-1}(\eta) ight| \dd \eta = \int_{\R} \left| F(x) - G(x) ight| \dd x.
\]

egin{proof}
    That $(F^{-1},G^{-1}) \# \lambda \in \Gamma(\mu, u)$ is obvious, and
    egin{align*}
        \int_0^1 \left| F^{-1}(\eta) - G^{-1}(\eta) ight| \dd \eta
        &= \int_0^1 \int_\R \ind_{F(x) \wedge G(x) \le \eta \le F(x) \vee G(x)}\dd x\dd \eta\
        &= \int_\R \left| F(x) - G(x) ight| \dd x.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front: [latex]Definition of flow map $\Phi_{s,t}\colon \R^d\to \R^d$ associated with a velocity field $u\colon [0,T] \times \R^d\to \R^d$. What regularity does the flow map have?[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
Suppose $u\colon [0,T] \times  \R^d\to \R^d$ (the \emph{velocity field}) is globally Lipschitz in space with constant $L$, and continuous in time. Then the associated flow map $\Phi_{s,t}\colon \R^d\to \R^d$ is defined by $\Phi_{s,t} (x) = v_t$ where \[
\begin{cases}
    \dot{v} &= u(v), \text{ on $(s,t)$,}\\
    v_s &= x.
\end{cases}
\] This has a unique solution because $u$ is globally Lipschitz, and Gr\""onwall implies that $\Phi_{s,t}$ is globally Lipschitz with constant $\e^{L(t-s)}$. It also follows from standard theory that $\Phi_{s,t}$ is a diffeomorphism.

\begin{proof}
    Proof of Lipschitzness. Suppose $v$ and $w$ are solutions starting respectively at $x,y\in \R^d$, and say $s = 0$. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| v_s - w_s \right|
        &\le \left| x-y \right| + \int_0^s \left| u_r(v_r) - u_r(w_r) \right| \dd r\\
        &\le \left| x-y \right| + L \int_0^s \left| v_r - w_r \right| \dd r,
    \end{align*}
    so Gr\""onwall implies \[
        \left| \Phi_t(x) - \Phi_t(y) \right| = \left| v_t - w_t \right| \le \left| x-y \right| \e^{Lt}.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front:
[latex]Weak form and unique weak solution (as paths in $\mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$ or $\mathcal{P}_p(\R^d)$) of \[
    \partial_t \rho = \nabla (\rho\nabla V),
\] where $V\in C^2(\R^d,\R)$ uniformly convex with bounded second derivatives.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Consider the PDE $\partial_t ho = abla ( ho abla V)$, where $V\in C^2(\R^d,\R)$ has bounded second derivatives and $D^2 V \ge \lambda I_d$ for $\lambda > 0$ (uniformly convex). Then the weak form of this for a path $( ho_t)$ in $\mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$ starting at $\mu\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$ is that for all $T>0$ and $\psi \in C^\infty_0([0,T] imes \R^d)$,
egin{align}\label{eq:weakpde}
    \int_0^T ho_t( \partial_t \psi_t) \dd t = ho_T(\psi_T) - \mu(\psi_0) + \int_0^T ho_t( abla \psi abla V) \dd t.
\end{align}
egin{proposition}
    Given $\mu\in \mathcal{M}_1(\R^d)$, there is a unique solution $( ho_t)$ of ( ef{eq:weakpde}) given by $ ho_t = \Phi_t(\mu)$, where $\Phi_t\colon \R^d o \R^d$ is the flow map associated with $- abla V$. If $\mu\in \mathcal{P}_p(\R^d)$, then $ ho\in C([0,\infty), \mathcal{P}_p(\R^d))$.
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    It is straight-forward to check that the PDE is equivalent to ( ef{eq:weakpde}) if $ ho$ has a smooth density, so it is the correct weak form.

    To check that $ ho_t$ is a solution, it suffices to consider $\mu = \delta_x$ (otherwise integrate all of the following against $\mu$). We will use that $\partial_t(\psi_t(\Phi_t(x))) = \dot{\psi_t}(\Phi_t x) + ( abla \psi_t)(\Phi_t x) \partial_t \Phi_t x$, and $\partial_t \Phi_t x = - abla V(\Phi_t x)$ by definition, so
    egin{align*}
        \int_0^T ho_t(\partial_t \psi_t) \dd t
        &= \int_0^T \dot{\psi_t}(\Phi_t x) \dd t \
        &= \psi_T(\Phi_T x) - \psi_0(x) + \int_0^T \dd t\, ( abla \psi_t) (\Phi_t x) ( abla V)(\Phi_t x)\
        &= \ldots + \int_0^T ho_t( abla \psi_t abla V) \dd t.
    \end{align*}

    To prove uniqueness of the solution, let $\varphi \in C_c^\infty(\R^d)$ and put $\psi_t(\cdot ) \coloneqq \varphi(\Phi_{t,T}(\cdot )) \in C^\infty_0([0,T] imes \R^d)$. By the method of characteristics, this is the unique solution to $\dot{\psi_t} = abla \psi abla V$ with $\psi_T = \varphi$, so any solution to ( ef{eq:weakpde}) satisfies \[
        ho_T(\varphi) = ho_T(\psi_T) = ho_0(\psi_0) = \mu(\Phi_T(\varphi)),
    \] so the solution is unique.
   
    Finally, if $\mu\in \mathcal{P}_p(\R^d)$, we use that $t \mapsto \left| \Phi_t(x) ight| $ for $x\in \R^d$ is decreasing by convexity of $V$ (assuming that the unique global minimum is in zero, otherwise shift), so  $ ho_t(\left| x ight|^p) = \mu (\left| \Phi_t(x) ight| ^p) \le \mu (\left| x ight| ^p)< \infty $ and continuous in $t$ by monotone or dominated convergence.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Measures in convex potential (Weak form of PDE $\partial \rho = \nabla (\rho \nabla V)$): Exponential convergence to stationary solution $\delta_0$.[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
egin{theorem}
    If $\mu, u\in \mathcal{P}_2(\R^d)$, then \[
        d_2(\Phi_t(\mu), \Phi_t( u)) \le \e^{-\lambda t} d_2(\mu, u).
    \] In particular, $d_2( ho_t,\delta_0) \le \e^{-\lambda t } d_2(\mu,\delta_0)$.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    Given a $d_2$-optimal coupling $\gamma\in \Gamma(\mu, u)$, we have $(\Phi_t,\Phi_t) \# \gamma \in \Gamma(\Phi_t(\mu),\Phi_t( u))$, so \[
        ext{LHS}^2 \le \int \left| \Phi_t(x) - \Phi_t(y) ight|^2 \gamma(\dd x,\dd y).
    \] Now use that
    egin{align*}
        rac{\dd }{\dd t} \left| \Phi_t(x) - \Phi_t(y) ight| ^2
        &= -2 (\Phi_t(x) - \Phi_t(y)) \left( abla V(\Phi_t(x)) - abla V(\Phi_t(y)) ight) \
        &\le -2\lambda \left| \Phi_t(x) - \Phi_t(y) ight| ^2.
    \end{align*}
    We can pull in the derivative because the modulus of the derivative is (because flow and $ abla V$ are Lipschitz) bounded by $C\left| x-y ight| ^2 \le C \left( \left| x ight| ^2 + \left| y ight| ^2 ight) $, which is $\gamma$-integrable because $\mu, u\in \mathcal{P}_2(\R^d)$. Hence we can pull in the derivative and \[
        rac{\dd }{\dd t} d_2(\Phi_t(\mu),\Phi_t( u))^2\!\! estriction_{t = 0}  \le -2\lambda \int \left| x-y ight| ^2 \gamma(\dd x,\dd y) = -2\lambda d_2(\mu, u)^2.
    \] We could repeat this at any $t > 0$ (by starting with an optimal coupling of $\Phi_t(\mu)$ and $\Phi_t( u)$), so the claim follows.
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front: [latex]If $\Phi \colon E\to E$ is $L$-Lipschitz and $p \ge 1$, then $ \mathcal{P}_p(E) \to \mathcal{P}_p(E); \, \mu \mapsto  \Phi(\mu)$ is $L$-Lipschitz w.r.t.\ $d_p$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\Phi \colon E\to E$ is $L$-Lipschitz and $p \ge 1$, then $ \mathcal{P}_p(E) \to \mathcal{P}_p(E); \, \mu \mapsto  \Phi(\mu)$ is $L$-Lipschitz w.r.t.\ $d_p$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $\gamma\in \Gamma(\mu,\nu)$. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        d_p(\Phi(\mu),\Phi(\nu))^p \le \int \rho(\Phi(x),\Phi(y))^p \gamma(\dd x,\dd y)
        &\le L^p \int \rho(x,y)^p \gamma(\dd x,\dd y).
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front:
[latex]
Aggregation equation: If $W\in C^2(\R^d)$ with bounded second derivatives:
egin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)]Definition and niceness of flow map associated with velocity field $u( ho) = - abla W\star ho$,
    \item[(ii)] Bound on $\left| \Phi_t^1(x) - \Phi_t^2(x) ight| $ for two paths $ ho_{1,2}$ in $\mathcal{P}_1(\R^d)$,
    \item[(iii)] Existence and uniqueness of (weak) solution to $\dot{ ho} = abla ( ho( abla W\star ho)) $.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
Define the velocity field associated with a path $ ho\in C([0,T],\mathcal{P}_1(\R^d))$ by $u( ho) \coloneqq - abla W \star ho$. Then $u$ is globally Lipschitz in space and continuous in time, so the flow-map is globally Lipschitz and smooth.

Denote by $\left\|\cdot ight\|$ the supremum norm in $C([0,T],\mathcal{P}_1(\R^d))$.
egin{lemma}
    If $ ho_1, ho_2 \in C([0,T],\mathcal{P}_1(\R^d))$, and the flow maps associated with $u( ho_i)$ are denoted $\Phi^i$, then for $x\in \R^d$, $t\in [0,T]$, \[
        \left| \Phi_t^1(x) - \Phi_t^2(x) ight| \le L \int_0^t \e^{L(t-s)} d_1( ho_1(s), ho_2(s))\dd s.
        \] In particular, for $\mu\in \mathcal{P}_1(\R^d)$, if $\mathcal{F}\colon C_\mu o C_\mu; ho \mapsto (\Phi_t( ho)\# \mu)_{t\in [0,T]}$, \[
    \left\|\mathcal{F} ho_1 - \mathcal{F} ho_2 ight\| \le \left( \e^{LT}-1 ight) \left\| ho_1- ho_2 ight\|.
    \] In particular, there is a unique weak solution.
\end{lemma}

egin{proof}
    $u$ is well-defined because $W$ has linear growth and $ ho\in \mathcal{P}_1(\R^d)$. Fix $ ho$, then, since $ abla W$ is Lipschitz (say with constant $L > 0$),
    egin{align*}
        \left| u(t,x) - u(t,y) ight| \le \int \left| abla W(x-z) - abla W(y-z) ight| ho_t(\dd z) \le L \left| x-y ight| ,
    \end{align*}
    and
    egin{align*}
        \left| u(t,x) - u(s,x) ight|
        &= \left| ho_t( abla W(x-\cdot )) - ho_s( abla W(x - \cdot )) ight| \le L d_1( ho_t, ho_s).
    \end{align*}
    We have $\Phi^i_t(x) = x + \int_0^t u^i(s,\Phi^i_s(x)) \dd s$, so
    egin{align*}
        \left| \Phi^1_t(x) - \Phi^2_t(x) ight|
        &\le \underbrace{\int_0^t \left| u^1(s,\Phi^1_s(x)) - u^1(s,\Phi^2_s(x)) ight| \dd s}_{\le L \int_0^t \left| \Phi^1_s(x) - \Phi^2_s(x) ight|\dd s} + \int_0^t \left| u^1(s,\Phi^2_s(x)) - u^2(s,\Phi^2_s(x)) ight| \dd s.
    \end{align*}
    Then use that
    egin{align*}
        \left| u^1(s,z) - u^2(s,z) ight|
        &\le \left| \int abla W(z-x) \left( ho_1(s,\dd x) ight) - ho_2(s,\dd x) ight| \le L d_1( ho_1(s), ho_2(s)).
    \end{align*}
    A variation of Gr""onwall's lemma implies the first claim. Now if $\mu\in \mathcal{P}_1(\R^d)$, and $t\in [0,T]$, then
    egin{align*}
        d_1(\Phi^1_t(\mu),\Phi^2_t(\mu))
        &\le \int \left| \Phi^1_t(x) - \Phi^2_t(x) ight| \mu(\dd x) \le \mu(1) \left( \e^{Lt}-1 ight) \left\| ho_1- ho_2 ight\|.
    \end{align*}
    Finally, since $C$ is a Banach space, if $T$ is small enough there is a unique fixed point, i.e.\ a unique weak solution on a small time interval. By gluing together we get a unique global weak solution.
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front: [latex]Stability in $d_1$ for (weak) solutions to $\dot{\rho} = \nabla (\rho (\nabla W\star \rho))$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Assume that $W\in C^2(\R^d)$ with second derivatives bounded by say $L > 0$.
egin{proposition}
    If $ ho_1, ho_2 \in C([0,\infty),\mathcal{P}_1(\R^d))$ are two (weak) solutions, then \[
        d_1( ho_1(t), ho_2(t)) \le \e^{2Lt} d_1( ho_1(0), ho_2(0)).
    \]
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    Let $\mu = ho_1(0), u = ho_2(0)$. Denote the flow map associated with $ ho_i$ by $\Phi^i$. Then take an optimal $d_1$-coupling $\gamma\in \Gamma(\mu, u)$, so
    egin{align*}
        d_1( ho_1(t), ho_2(t))
        &= d_1(\Phi^1_t(\mu), \Phi^2_t( u)) \le \int \left| \Phi^1_t(x) - \Phi^2_t(y) ight| \gamma(\dd x,\dd y)\
        &\le \int \left| \Phi^1_t(x) - \Phi^2_t(x) ight| \mu(\dd x) + \int \left| \Phi^2_t(x) - \Phi^2_t(y) ight| \gamma(\dd x,\dd y)\
        &\le L \int \e^{L(t-s)} d_1( ho_1(s), ho_2(s))\dd s + \e^{Lt} d_1(\mu, u).
    \end{align*}
    Put $x(s) \coloneqq \e^{-Ls} d_1( ho_1(s), ho_2(s))$, then $x(t) \le d_1(\mu, u) + L \int_0^t x(s) \dd s$, so $x(t) \le \e^{Lt}d_1(\mu, u)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]GNS inequality (Sobolev inequality).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{theorem}[GNS inequality] If $p\in [1,d)$, then there is $C_{d,p}> 0$ such that \[
    \left\|u ight\|_{L^{p^\star}(\R^d)} \le C_{d,p} \left\| abla u ight\|_{L^p(\R^d)},\quad u\in W^{1,p}(\R^d).
\] If $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is bounded Lipschitz, then for every $q\in [1,p^\star]$, there is $C_{d,p,q,\Omega}$ such that \[
\left\|u ight\|_{L^q(\Omega)} \le C_{d,p,q,\Omega} \left\|u ight\|_{W^{1,p}(\Omega)},\quad u\in W^{1,p}(\Omega).
\]
\end{theorem}
It is easy to see by looking at $u_\lambda(\cdot ) = u(\lambda \cdot )$ that the above can only possibly hold for this specific $p^\star$.
egin{proof}
    By denseness suffices to consider $u\in C_c^\infty(\R^d)$, by looking at $\left| u ight| ^{\gamma}$ it suffices to consider $p = 1$, and WLOG $d = 2$ (general case just more notation). Then, \[
        \left| u(x) ight| \le \int_\infty^{x_1} \left| \partial_{x_1} u(y_1,x_2) ight| \dd y_1 \le \int_\R \left| abla u(y_1,x_2) ight| \dd y_1.
    \] Multiply this estimate with the one for the second coordinate to get \[
    u(x)^2 \le \int_\R \left| abla u(y_1,x_2) ight| \dd y_1 \int_\R \left| abla u(x_1,y_2) ight| \dd y_2.
    \] Integrate against $\dd x_1\dd x_2$ to obtain $\left\|u ight\|_{L^2}^2 \le \left\| abla u ight\|_{L^1}^2$. The claim for domains follows with extension and Hölder.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Friedrich's inequality (Sobolev inequality for $W^{1,p}_0$ functions).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Friedrich's inequality]
    If $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is open and bounded and $p\in [1,\infty)$, and \[
    \begin{cases}
        q\in [1,p^\star] &, p < d,\\
        q\in [1,\infty) &, p = d,\\
        q\in [1,\infty] &, p > d.
    \end{cases}
    \] (In particular $q = p$ is allowed.) Then there is $C_{d,p,q,\Omega} > 0$ such that  \[
        \left\|u\right\|_{L^q(\Omega)} \le C_{d,p,q,\Omega} \left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L^p(\Omega)},\quad u\in W^{1,p}_0(\Omega).
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    If $q = p$, this is simple analysis, if $p < d$ it is GNS, the rest uses Morrey's inequality as well.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Poincar\'e's inequality (Sobolev inequality for $\left\|u - \overline{u}\right\|$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Poincar\'e's inequality]
    Suppose $p\in [1,\infty]$ and $\Omega$ a bounded Lipschitz domain. Then, \[
        \left\|u - \overline{u}\right\|_{L^p(\Omega)}\le C_{d,p,\Omega} \left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L^p(\Omega)},\quad u\in W^{1,p}(\Omega),
    \] where $\overline{u} = \frac{1}{\left| \Omega \right| }\int_\Omega u$.
\end{theorem}
This is essentially Friedrich's inequality, but since we subtract the average we do not need $u\in W^{1,p}_0$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Morrey's inequality (Embedding of Sobolev space into Hölder space). In particular, what is $W^{1,\infty}(\Omega)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
For $\alpha\in (0,1]$, put $[u]_{C^{0,\alpha}(\Omega)}\coloneqq \sup_{x\neq y\in \Omega} \frac{\left| u(x) - u(y) \right| }{\left| x-y \right| ^{\alpha}}$, and $\left\|u\right\|_{C^{0,\alpha}(\Omega)} \coloneqq \left\|u\right\|_\infty + [u]_{C^{0,\alpha}(\Omega)}$, which makes $C^{0,\alpha}(\Omega)$ a Banach space.

\begin{theorem}[Morrey's inequality]
    Suppose $d < p \le \infty$ and $\Omega$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain or $\Omega = \R^d$. Then every $u\in W^{1,p}(\Omega)$ has a $(1-d / p)$-Hölder continuous representative, and there is $C_{d,p,\Omega}> 0$ such that \[
        \left\|u\right\|_{C^{0,1 - d / p}(\Omega)}\le C_{d,p,\Omega} \left\|u\right\|_{W^{1,p}(\Omega)}.
    \] In particular, if $\Omega$ bounded: The embedding $W^{1,p}(\Omega) \hookrightarrow C^{0,\beta}(\Omega)$ is compact for every $0 < \beta < 1 - d / p$. Furthermore, in fact $W^{1,\infty}(\Omega) = C^{0,1}(\Omega)$ (Lipschitz functions).
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Rellic-Kondrachov's compactness theorem (compact Sobolev embeddings).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Rellic-Kondrachov's compactness theorem]
    Let $\Omega$ be a bounded Lipschitz domain and $p\in [1,\infty]$. Let \[
    \begin{cases}
        q\in [1,p^\star) &, p < d,\\
        q \in [1,\infty) &, p = d,\\
        q \in [1,\infty] &, p > d.
    \end{cases}
\] Then the embedding $W^{1,p}(\Omega) \hookrightarrow L^{q}(\Omega)$ is compact. (The critical embedding $W^{1,p}(\Omega) \hookrightarrow L^{p^\star}(\Omega)$ is in fact not compact.)
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    When $p = q \in [1,\infty)$, it is (up to some extension and truncation), just the lemma (and the AA version for $L^q$).
\end{proof}

\begin{lemma}
    Let $p\in [1,\infty)$, $u\in W^{1,p}(\R^d)$, and $y\in \R^d$, then \[
        \left\|u^y - u\right\|_{L^p(\R^d)} \le \left| y \right| \left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L^p(\R^d)}.
    \]
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    $C^\infty(\R^d)\cap W^{1,p}(\R^d)$ is dense, and for such functions it is easy.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Elliptic PDEs: How injectivity/surjectivity of $L\!\!\restriction_{H^1_0} $ correspond to uniqueness/existence of solutions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Assume that $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain (if not otherwise specified, then $H^1 = H^1(\Omega)$, $L^2 = L^2(\Omega)$ etc.), $a_{ij},b_i,c\colon \Omega\to \R$ are measurable, bounded, and $a$ symmetric and uniformly elliptic (with bounds from above and below). Define $L$ by $Lu \coloneqq -\partial_i(a_{ij}\partial_j u) + b_i \partial_i u + cu$.

\begin{lemma}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Weak solutions exist for all $u_0 \in H^1, g\in L^2,f\in H^{-1}$ iff $L\!\!\restriction_{H^1_0} \colon H^1_0 \to H^{-1}$ is surjective,
        \item[(ii)] Weak solutions are unique for all $u_0\in H^1, g\in L^2, f\in H^{-1}$ iff $L\!\!\restriction_{H^1_0} $ is injective.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    For (i), if it is surjective, take $v\in H^1_0$ with $Lv = -Lu_0 + f + \partial_ig_i$ and put $u \coloneqq u_0 + v$. Conversely, if $T\in H^{-1}$, take a solution $u$ with $u_0 = g = 0$, $f = T$, so that $u \in H^1_0$ and $Lu = f = T$.

    If it is injective, and $u$ and $\widetilde{u}$ are solutions, then $u-\widetilde{u}\in H^1_0$ and $L(u-\widetilde{u}) = 0$. If solutions are unique, and $u,\widetilde{u}\in H^1_0$ with $Lu = L\widetilde{u}$, then $u,\widetilde{u}$ solve (BVP) with $g = u_0 = 0$ and $f = Lu = L\widetilde{u}$, so $u = \widetilde{u}$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Elliptic PDEs: If $B$ is coercive (in particular if $b = 0$ and $c\ge 0$), then $L\!\!\restriction_{H_0^1} $ is bijective, so there are unique weak solutions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Assume that $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain (if not otherwise specified, then $H^1 = H^1(\Omega)$, $L^2 = L^2(\Omega)$ etc.), $a_{ij},b_i,c\colon \Omega\to \R$ are measurable, bounded, and $a$ symmetric and uniformly elliptic (with bounds from above and below). Define $L$ by $Lu \coloneqq -\partial_i(a_{ij}\partial_j u) + b_i \partial_i u + cu$.

\begin{theorem}
    If $b = 0$ and $c\ge 0$ a.e. (or, more generally, if $B$ is coercive), then $L\!\!\restriction_{H^1_0}\colon H^1_0 \to H^{-1} $ is bijective. In particular, for all $f,g_i\in L^2$ and $u_0\in H^1$, (BVP) has a unique weak solution.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    In this case, for $u\in H^1_0$,
    \begin{align*}
        B(u,u)
        &= \int_\Omega \big(a_{ij}\partial_i u \partial_j u + c u^2\big) \ge \lambda \left\|\nabla u\right\|_{L^2} \ge c\left\|u\right\|_{H^1}^2,
    \end{align*}
    where we used Friedrich's inequality, so $B(\cdot ,\cdot )$ is a scalar product on $H^1_0$ whose norm is equivalent to $\left<\cdot ,\cdot  \right> _{H^1_0}$, which means we can apply Riesz representation theorem to get that for every $T\in H^{-1}$, there is a unique $u\in H^1_0$ such that \[
        Tv = B(u,v) = (Lu)(v),\quad v\in H^1,
    \] that is, that $T = Lu$.
\end{proof}

front: [latex]Elliptic PDEs: Fredholm alternative. How can (iii) be motivated, and what is the meaning of $N$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Assume that $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain (if not otherwise specified, then $H^1 = H^1(\Omega)$, $L^2 = L^2(\Omega)$ etc.), $a_{ij},b_i,c\colon \Omega\to \R$ are measurable, bounded, and $a$ symmetric and uniformly elliptic (with bounds from above and below). Define $L$ by $Lu \coloneqq -\partial_i(a_{ij}\partial_j u) + b_i \partial_i u + cu$.\\

Define the adjoint $L^\star \in\mathcal{L}( H^1 ,H^{-1})$ by \[
    (Lu)(v) = B(u,v) = (L^\star v)(u),\quad u,v\in H^1,
\] which in the notation of $L$ is $L^\star v = -\partial_i (a_{ij} \partial_j v) - \partial_i(b_iv) + cv$. Note then that if there is a $v_0$ such that $L^\star v_0 = 0$, then $(Lu)(v_0) = (L^\star v_0)(u) = 0$ for all $u\in H^1$, so $L$ cannot be surjective. There may still be solutions for particular $u_0,f,g$, and if $u$ is such a solution, then, since $u - u_0 \in H_0^1$,
\begin{align*}
    (f + \partial_ig_i)v_0
    &= (Lu)(v_0) = B(u,v_0) = B(u_0,v_0) + \underbrace{B(u-u_0,v_0)}_{=(L^\star v_0)(u-u_0) = 0} = B(u_0,v_0).
\end{align*}

\begin{theorem}[Fredholm Alternative]
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $L\!\!\restriction_{H^1_0}$ is bijective iff it is injective (i.e.\ iff the only solution to the homogeneous problem is trivial),
        \item[(ii)] The kernels $N$ of $L\!\!\restriction_{H^1_0} $ and $N^\star$ of $L^\star \!\!\restriction_{H_0^1} $ are of equal, finite dimension,
        \item[(iii)] If $N$ is not trivial, then (BVP) has a solution for given $u_0,f,g$ iff $B(u_0,v) = \left<f,v \right> - \left<g_i,\partial_i v \right> $ for all $v\in N^\star$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}

Note that (i) implies that either there is a unique weak solution for all $u_0,f,g$, or there is a non-trivial weak solution to the homogeneous problem. Indeed, if the former is not true then $L\!\!\restriction_{H_0^1} $ is not injective, so there is $u\in H^1_0$ with $Lu = 0$. In fact $N\subset H_0^1$ is the space of homogenuous solutions.
[/latex]
