front: [latex]Elliptic PDEs: Regularity of solutions for differentiable $a$ (interior $H^2$, global $H^2$, and $C^\infty$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Assume that $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain (if not otherwise specified, then $H^1 = H^1(\Omega)$, $L^2 = L^2(\Omega)$ etc.), $a_{ij},b_i,c\colon \Omega\to \R$ are measurable, bounded, and $a$ symmetric and uniformly elliptic (with bounds from above and below). Define $L$ by $Lu \coloneqq -\partial_i(a_{ij}\partial_j u) + b_i \partial_i u + cu$.

\begin{theorem}
    Suppose that $f\in L^2$, and $u\in H^1$ satisfies $Lu = f$ in $\Omega$ in the weak sense.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $a\in C^1(\Omega)$, then $u\in H^2_{\text{loc}}$, in fact for any open $\omega$ with $\overline{\omega}\subset \Omega$, there is $C = C(d,\Omega,\omega,a,b,c) > 0$ with \[
                \left\|u\right\|_{H^2(\omega)} \le C \left( \left\|f\right\|_{L^2(\Omega)} + \left\|u\right\|_{H^1(\Omega)} \right) .
        \]
    \item[(ii)] If $a\in C^1(\overline{\Omega})$, $\Omega$ bounded with $C^2$-boundary, $u\in H^1_0(\Omega)$, then $u\in H^2(\Omega)$ and there is $C = C(d,\Omega,a,b,c) > 0$ with \[
            \left\|u\right\|_{H^2(\Omega)} \le C \left\|f\right\|_{L^2(\Omega)}.
    \]
\item[(iii)] If $a,b,c \in C^\infty(\overline{\Omega})$, $\Omega$ is bounded with $C^\infty$-boundary, $f\in C^\infty(\Omega)$, and $u\in H_0^1(\Omega)$, then $u\in C^\infty(\Omega)$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}

We sketch the idea of the proof of (i) in the remaining chapter. Note that to get a global statement, one (1.) needs regularity of the boundary of the domain, and (2.) regularity of $a$ at the boundary. These are precisely the additional assumptions needed in (ii). We assume $b \equiv c \equiv 0$ to illustrate the methods.

\begin{proofsketch}
    First use a cutoff to be able to assume that $u$ vanishes near the boundary, then use that to reduce to the case $\Omega = \R^d$. If $a$ is constant, then by a change of variables we can assume it is the identity, so $L = -\Delta$. Looking at the statement, it suffices to bound $\left\|D^2 u\right\|_{L^2}$ by $\left\|f\right\|_{L^2}$, and the idea is to use the fact that for $v\in C^\infty$, $\left\|D^2v\right\|_{L^2} = \left\|\Delta v\right\|_{L^2}$ by IBP, and we can control $\Delta u = -f$. Now take mollifiers $(\rho_\varepsilon)$ and put $u_\varepsilon \coloneqq \rho_\varepsilon\star u$, $f_\varepsilon\coloneqq \rho_\varepsilon\star f$. Some Fubini confirms that $-\Delta u_\varepsilon = f_\varepsilon$ weakly, thus strongly because they are smooth. Hence,  \[
    \left\|D^2 u_\varepsilon\right\|_{L^2} = \left\|\Delta u_\varepsilon\right\|_{L^2} = \left\|f_\varepsilon\right\|_{L^2} \le \left\|f\right\|_{L^2} \left\|\rho_\varepsilon\right\|_{L^1} = \left\|f\right\|_{L^2},
\] where we used Young's convolution inequality towards the end. By reflexivity of $L^2(\R^d)$, $(D^2u_\varepsilon)$ converges weakly in $L^2$ along a subsequence, say to $A\in L^2(\R^d,\R ^{d\times d})$ with $\left\|A\right\|_{L^2}\le \left\|f\right\|_{L^2}$. Now if $\varphi\in C^\infty_c(\R^d)$, then \[
\int \partial_i\partial_j u_\varepsilon \varphi = \int u_\varepsilon \partial_i \partial_j \varphi.
\] The LHS converges to $\int A_{ij} \varphi$, the RHS to $\int u \partial_i\partial_j \varphi$, which by definition implies $u\in H^2$ and $D^2u = A$ weakly. Hence $\left\|D^2u\right\|_{L^2}\le \left\|f\right\|_{L^2}$.

One possible way to extend to non-constant $a$ is the method of freezing the coefficients. Suppose $\left| a_{ij} - \delta_{ij} \right| < \delta_0$ in $\Omega$, then \[
    -\Delta u = (a_{ij} - \delta_{ij}) \partial_i\partial_j u + \partial_i a_{ij} \partial_j u + f,
\] so by the result we already have, \[
\left\|u\right\|_{H^2(\omega)} \le C \left( \left\|f\right\|_{L^2} + \left\|u\right\|_{H^1} + \sup_{\omega,i,j}\left| a_{ij}- \delta_{ij} \right| \left\|D^2u\right\|_{L^2(\omega)}  \right) .
\] If $\delta_0$ is small enough, we can absorb the annoying factor on the right to the LHS. The full result is then obtained by covering in small balls (since $a$ is continuous).
\end{proofsketch}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Elliptic PDEs: Continuity of solutions for general coefficients. Why is this theorem easy if one assumes continuity of $a$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Assume that $\Omega\subset \R^d$ is a bounded Lipschitz domain (if not otherwise specified, then $H^1 = H^1(\Omega)$, $L^2 = L^2(\Omega)$ etc.), $a_{ij},b_i,c\colon \Omega\to \R$ are measurable, bounded, and $a$ symmetric and uniformly elliptic (with bounds from above and below). Define $L$ by $Lu \coloneqq -\partial_i(a_{ij}\partial_j u) + b_i \partial_i u + cu$.

\begin{theorem}[De Giorgi-Moser-Nash]
    If $f\in L^q(\Omega)$ for some $q > \frac{d}{2}$, and $u\in H^1(\Omega)$ satisfies $Lu = f$ in $\Omega$ weakly, then $u$ is locally Hölder continuous, in fact for any open $\omega$ with $\overline{\omega}\subset \Omega$, there are $C = C(d,\Omega,\omega,a,b,c) > 0$ and $\alpha = \alpha(d,\Omega,\omega,a) > 0$ with \[
        \left\|u\right\|_{C^{0,\alpha}(\omega)}\le C \left( \left\|f\right\|_{L^q(\Omega)} + \left\|u\right\|_{H^1(\Omega)} \right) .
    \]
\end{theorem}

\begin{remark}
    The main point here is that $a$ is not assumed to be continuous. If we did assume that, we could use the method of freezing coefficients and hence assume that $a$ is constant, so we only need to consider $-\Delta u = f$. This already implies that $u\in W^{2,q}_\text{loc}$ (this is obvious in 1d, where $u'' = -f\in L^q$, but true in any dimension). Then if $d / 2 < q < d$, we have $q^\star > d$ and so \[
    W^{2,q}_\text{loc} \hookrightarrow W^{1,q^\star}_\text{loc} \hookrightarrow C^{0,2 - \frac{d}{q}}_\text{loc},
    \] where we used GNS and Morrey's inequalities and that $1 - d / q^\star = 2 - d / q$.
\end{remark}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of well-order and principle of induction.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A totally ordered $(X,\le)$ is called a \emph{well-order} if every non-empty subset has a minimum, that is, if \[
\forall S\subset X\colon S\neq \emptyset \implies \left[ \exists y\in S\, \forall x\in S\colon y\le x \right] .
\]
\begin{proposition}[Induction]
    If $S\subset X$ such that \[
    \forall x\colon \left[ \forall y\colon y < x \Rightarrow y\in S \right] \Rightarrow x\in S,
    \] then $S = X$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $S \neq X$, and let $x$ be the minimal element of $X\setminus S$. Then $y\in S$ for all $y < x$, so $x\in S$ by assumption, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Isomorphisms between well-ordered sets are unique.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $X$ and $Y$ are isomorphic well-ordered sets, then there is a unique isomorphism.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $f,g\colon X\to Y$ are two different isomorphisms, and let $x\in X$ be the minimum of $\left\{ f\neq g \right\} \subset X$. Let $a\in Y$ be the minimum of $Y\setminus S$ where $S \coloneqq \left\{ f(y)\colon y<x \right\} $. Since $f$ is injective, $f(x)\not\in S$ is in this set, so $f(x) \ge a$. If $f(x) > a$, then $x > f^{-1}(a)$, so $a \in S$, a contradiction. Hence $f(x) = a$, and $g(x) = a$ by the same argument, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition initial segment of a well-order, and characterisation.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A subset $S\subset X$ is called an \emph{initial segment} if \[
\forall x\in S\, \forall y\colon y < x \Rightarrow y\in S.
\]
\begin{lemma}
    A set $S\subset X$ is an initial segment iff it is of the form $I_x = \left\{ y\in X\colon y < x \right\} $ for some $x\in X$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Clearly, $I_x$ is an initial segment for all $x\in X$. Suppose $S\subset X$ is an initial segment, and let $x$ be the minimum of $X\setminus S$. Then $I_x \subset S$. Conversely, if $y\in S$, then certainly $y\neq x$, and if $y > x$, we had $x\in S$ which is not true, so $y < x$, i.e.\ $y\in I_x$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Recursion on well-ordered sets.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
In the following, we identify a function $f\colon X\to Y$ with the set $\left\{ (x,f(x))\colon x\in X \right\} $.

\begin{theorem}[Recursion]
    Suppose $X$ is a well-ordered set and $G\colon \mathcal{P}(X\times Y)\to Y$ is a function for a set $Y$. Then there is a unique function $f\colon X\to Y$ with \[
        \forall x\colon f(x) = G(f\!\!\restriction_{I_x} ).
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    For an initial segment $I\subset X$ we say that $h\colon I\to Y$ is an \emph{attempt (on $I$)} if $h(x) = G(h\!\!\restriction_{I_x} )$ for all $x \in I$. We first show that two attempts $h$ and $h'$ on $I$ must be the same, using induction: Suppose $h(y) = h'(y)$ for all $y < x$ for some $x \in I$. Then $h(x) = G(h\!\!\restriction_{I_x} ) = G(h'\!\!\restriction_{I_x} ) = h'(x)$. Next, we show by induction that for every $x\in X$ there is an attempt $h\colon I\to Y$ such that $x\in I$. For every $y < x$ there is an attempt $h_y$ defined on $I_y$, put $h' \coloneqq \bigcup_{y<x} h_y$. This is well-defined(!) and an attempt on $I_x$(!), and we put $h\coloneqq h' \cup \left\{ (x,G(h')) \right\} $. Then $h$ is an attempt on the initial segment $I_x \cup \left\{ x \right\} $, which contains $x$.

    Finally, we define $f(x)$ for $x\in X$ by $h(x)$ for any attempt defined at $x$. By the above, this is well-defined and satisfies what we want. It is also unique: If $f$ and $f'$ both work, then if they agree on $I_x$, $f(x) = G(f\!\!\restriction_{I_x} ) = G(f'\!\!\restriction_{I_x} ) = f'(x)$, so $f=f'$ by induction.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark}
    Obviously $G$ only needs to be defined on functions $f\colon I\to Y$ for initial segments $I$ (just define the value of $G$ on other sets as some fixed arbitrary value), and to make a recursion equation of the form \[
        f(x) = G(f\!\!\restriction_{I_x} )
    \] work it suffices to show that for any $x\in X$ the RHS is well-defined under the assumption that $f\!\!\restriction_{I_x} $ is an attempt.
\end{remark}
\begin{proof}
    Define $G$ to be some arbitrary value $\perp$ when the RHS is ill-defined, which yields a completely defined $G$ and thus a function $f$. Now it STS by induction that $G(f\!\!\restriction_{I_x} ) \neq \perp$ for all $x\in X$, which follows from the assumption.

    Also, if $f'$ is another function which satisfies the original equation, then $G(f'\!\!\restriction_{I_x} )$ must be well-defined for all $x\in X$, so $f'$ also satisfies the recursion equation with the new $G$, so $f = f'$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]A subset of a well-order $X$ is isomorphic to a unique initial segment. What does this tell us about $X$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}[Subset collapse]
    If $Y\subset X$, then $Y$ is isomorphic to a unique initial segment of $X$. In particular, a well-order can never be isomorphic to a proper initial segment of itself.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    First note that we have to prove that there is a uniqe order-preserving injection $f\colon Y\to X$ whose image is an initial segment. Next, note that a function $f\colon Y\to X$ has this property iff it satisfies \[
        \forall x\in Y\colon f(x) = \min \left( X\setminus \left\{ f(y)\colon y<x \right\}  \right) .
    \] We thus have to show that there is a unique such function, so we only need to prove that, for $x\in X$, if $f\colon I_x\to Y $ satisfies the recursion equation on $I_x$, then $\left\{ f(y)\colon y < x \right\} \neq X$. For this it STS by induction that $f(y)\le y$ for all $y < x$, which is clear (if $f(z) \le z$ for all $z < y$, then $f(z) \le z < y$, so $y\in S\coloneqq  X\setminus \left\{ f(z)\colon z < y \right\} $, so $f(y) = \min S \le y $).
   
    The unique initial segment of $X$ to which $X$ is isomorphic is obviously $X$ itself.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition ordinal, order type, and a total order on ordinals.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
An ordinal is a well-ordered set, with isomorphic sets considered equal. The order type of a WOS is its ``equivalence class''.

\begin{definition}
    We write $\alpha \le \beta$ if $\alpha$ is an initial segment of $\beta$ (that is, if $X$ is isomorphic to an initial segment of $Y$ for two arbitrarily chosen representatives). This is well-defined and a total order on the ordinals.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    Clearly well-defined, reflexive, and transitive. Suppose $X\le Y$ and $Y\le X$ via injections $f$ and $g$. Then $g\circ f\colon X\to X$ is an isomorphism from $X$ to an initial segment of itself, which must be $X$, so $g$ is surjective, so an isomorphism from $Y$ to $X$. Finally, for $X$ and $Y$ two given WOs, define a function $f\colon X\to Y \sqcup \left\{ \perp \right\} $ via recursion, \[
        f(x) = \begin{cases}
            \min (Y\setminus f(I_x)) &, f(I_x) \neq Y,\\
            \perp &, \text{else}.
        \end{cases}
    \] If $f(x) \neq \perp$ for all $x\in X$, then $f$ is an isomorphism between $X$ and an initial segment of $Y$. Otherwise let $x\in X$ be minimal with $f(x) = \perp$. Then $f\!\!\restriction_{I_x} \colon I_x \to Y$ is an order-preserving injection to an initial segment of $Y$ and $f(I_x) = Y$, so an isomorphism.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of $\alpha^+$ and $\sup_i \alpha_i$. Why is the latter well-defined and indeed a least upper bound?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
For ordinals $\alpha, \alpha_i, i\in I, $ define $\alpha^+$ as the order type of $X^+$ for an arbitrary representative, and $\sup_{i\in I} \alpha_i$ as the order type of the union of $I_{\alpha_i}, i\in I$. This is the least upper bound of all $\alpha_i$.
\begin{proof}
    $\sup_i \alpha_i$ is well-defined because $(I_{\alpha_i})_{i\in I}$ are all genuine initial segments of each other, and obviously an upper bound. If $\beta \ge \alpha_i$ for all $i\in I$, then on the level of representatives, $I_{\alpha_i}\le I_\beta$ for all $i\in I$, so $\bigcup_{i\in I} I_{\alpha_i}\le I_\beta$, so $\sup_i \alpha_i \le \beta$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Ordinals are well-ordered. In particular, ordinals do not form a set.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Ordinals are well-ordered.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $S$ be a non-empty set of ordinals, take $\alpha \in S$. If $\alpha$ is minimal, we are done, otherwise consider $I_\alpha = \left\{ \beta\colon \beta < \alpha \right\} $, which is a well-ordered set (it is isomorphic to any $X$ with order type $\alpha$), and $S\cap I_\alpha$ is non-empty, so has a least element, which is a least element of $S$.
\end{proof}

\begin{theorem}
    Ordinals are not a set.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose they were, $O$, call its order type $\alpha\in O$. Then $O$ is isomorphic to $I_\alpha$, which is a proper initial segment of $O$ (as it does not contain $\alpha$).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Hartog's lemma and $\omega_1$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}[Hartog]
    For every set $X$, there is a well-order which does not inject into $X$. The least is called $\gamma(X)$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $L$ be the set of order types of well-ordered subsets $(Y,\le)$ of $X$. Then $L$ is an initial segment of ordinals, and any $(Y,\le) \simeq I_{(Y,\le)}$, which is a proper initial segment of $L$, so $\text{otp} (Y,\le) < \text{otp} L$. Now if $L \hookrightarrow X$, then its order type is that of a well-ordered subset of $X$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}

In particular, $\omega_1 \coloneqq \gamma(\omega)$ is an uncountable ordinal (the least one). It has the properties that every initial segment is countable, and every sequence in it is bounded (because a countable supremum of countable ordinals is countable).
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of successor and limit ordinals.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    An ordinal is a \emph{successor} if it is of the form $\beta^+$ iff there is a greatest element $\beta$ below it. Otherwise, it is called a \emph{limit}.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    There is a greatest element below it iff $I_\alpha$ has a maximal element, say $\beta$, in which case $I_\alpha = I_\beta \cup \left\{ \beta \right\} $, so $\alpha = \beta^+$.

    Conversely, if $\alpha = \beta^+$, then $I_\alpha = I_{\beta^+} = I_\beta \cup \left\{ \beta \right\} $ (since $\beta^+$ is the least ordinal greater than $\beta$), so $\beta$ is a greatest element of $I_\alpha$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Synthetic and inductive definitions of ordinal arithmetic. Proof they are equal for $+$, and associativity of addition.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}[Ordinal Arithmetic, Synthetic]
    For ordinals $\alpha$ and $\beta$, $\alpha + \beta$ is defined as the order type of writing two representatives after each other. $\alpha \cdot \beta$ is defined on $\alpha \times \beta$ by sorting w.r.t.\ the second argument first.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Ordinal Arithmetic, Inductive]
    For fixed $\alpha$, we define $\alpha^+$ recursively for all ordinals $\beta$ (to justify this we do recursion on $I_\gamma$ for all ordinals $\gamma$).
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $\alpha + 0 =  \alpha$,
        \item $\alpha + \beta^+ = (\alpha + \beta)^+$,
        \item $\alpha + \lambda = \sup \left\{ \alpha + \gamma\colon \gamma < \lambda \right\} $.
    \end{enumerate}
    (This is a case distinction between successor and limit, where the latter is distinguished between $0$ and not $0$).
    Multiplication is defined via
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $\alpha \cdot 0 = 0$,
        \item $\alpha \cdot \beta^+ = \alpha \cdot \beta + \alpha$,
        \item $\alpha \cdot \lambda = \sup \left\{ \alpha\cdot \gamma\colon \gamma < \lambda \right\} $.
    \end{enumerate}
    Exponentiation is defined via $\alpha^0 = 1$, $\alpha ^{\beta^+} = \alpha^\beta \cdot \alpha$, and $\alpha^\lambda = \sup_{\alpha^\gamma\colon \gamma < \lambda}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{lemma}
    Inductive and synthetic definitions of addition coincide. In particular addition is associative.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Write $+'$ for synthetic definition, we use induction on $\beta$ for fixed $\alpha$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $\alpha + 0 = \alpha = \alpha +' 0$,
        \item $\alpha + \beta^+ = (\alpha +\beta)^+ = (\alpha+'\beta)^+ = \alpha +' \beta+$,
        \item $\alpha + \lambda = \sup \left\{ \alpha + \gamma\colon \gamma < \lambda \right\} = \sup \left\{ \alpha +' \gamma\colon \gamma < \lambda \right\} $. The latter is
            \begin{align*}
                \bigcup_{\gamma \in I_\lambda} (\alpha +' \gamma)
                &= \alpha +' \bigcup_{\gamma \in I_\lambda}  \gamma,
                = \alpha +' \lambda,
            \end{align*}
            where we used in the last step that $\lambda = \sup_{\gamma\colon \gamma < \lambda}$ for a limit ordinal $\lambda$ (certainly $\ge$, and if $>$, then the RHS would be a greatest element smaller than $\lambda$).
    \end{enumerate}
    Associativity is obvious with the synthetic definition.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition outer measure, and associated $\sigma$-algebra and (complete) measure.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
An \emph{outer measure} on $X\neq \emptyset$ is a map $\mu\colon \mathcal{P}(X)\to [0,\infty]$ which is monotone and $\sigma$-subadditive and such that $\mu(\emptyset) = 0$. In that case, \[
    \mathcal{A}_\mu \coloneqq \left\{ A\subset X\colon \forall E\subset X\colon \mu(E) = \mu(E\cap A) + \mu(E\setminus A)  \right\}
\] is a $\sigma$-algebra (the \emph{$\mu$-measurable sets}) and $\mu\colon \mathcal{A}_\mu \to [0,\infty]$ is a complete measure.

\begin{proof}
    First observe that if $A\in \mathcal{A}_\mu$ and $B\subset X$, then \[
        \mu(A\sqcup B) = \mu((A \sqcup B) \cap A) + \mu((A \sqcup B)\setminus A) = \mu(A) + \mu(B).
    \] This implies finite additivity and hence $\sigma$-additivity. Indeed, if $A_i \in \mathcal{A}_\mu$ are disjoint, then for every $n\in \N$, \[
    \sum_{k=1}^n \mu(A_k) = \mu\left( \bigcup_{k=1} ^n A_k\right) \le \mu \left( \bigcup_{k=1} ^\infty A_k \right) ,
    \] hence the same holds if we replace the LHS by its limit $n\to \infty$.

    $\mathcal{A}_\mu$ is obviously closed under complements, and contains $\emptyset$. It is also closed under finite intersections. Indeed if $A,B\in \mathcal{A}_\mu$, and $E\subset X$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \mu(E\setminus (A\cap B))
        &= \mu(E \cap A^{c} \cup E \cap B^{c}) = \mu(E\cap B^{c}\cap A) + \mu(E\cap A^{c})\\
        &= \mu(E\cap A) - \mu(E\cap B\cap A) + \mu(E) - \mu(E\cap A)\\
        &= \mu(E) - \mu(E\cap A\cap B).
    \end{align*}
    It suffices to show that it is closed under countable disjoint unions (then it is a $\cap$-stable Dynkin system). Let $A_i\in \mathcal{A}_\mu, i\in \N, $ and $E\subset X$, $A\coloneqq \bigcup_{i\ge 1} A_i$. Then, similarly how we proved finite additivity, \[
        \sum_{i=1}^n \mu(E\cap A_i) = \mu(E\cap \bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i) \le \mu(E\cap A) \le \sum_{i= 1 }^\infty\mu(E\cap A_i) ,
    \] where the last step is $\sigma$-subadditivity. This implies that $\mu(E \cap \bigcup_{i=1} ^n A_i) \to \mu(E\cap A)$ as $n\to \infty$ and thus
    \begin{align*}
        \mu(E\setminus A) + \mu(E\cap A) \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \big( \underbrace{\mu( E\setminus \bigcup_{i=1} ^n A_i ) + \mu( E\cap \bigcup_{i=1} ^n A_i )}_{= \mu(E)} \big) = \mu(E).
    \end{align*}
    Here the $\le$ comes from the first term (the inequality is just monotonicity of $\mu$), the second equality comes from the fact that finite unions are in $\mathcal{A}_\mu$.
   
    If $A\subset X$ and $\mu(A) = 0$, then $\mu(E) \le \mu(E\cap A) + \mu(E \setminus A) = \mu(E\setminus A) \le \mu(E)$, where we first used subadditivity and then monotonicity.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]$\B(\R) \neq \mathcal{P}(\R)$[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    \[
        \B(\R) \neq \mathcal{P}(\R).
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $A\subset [0,1]$ contain exactly one representative of $\R / \sim$, where $x\sim y$ iff $x-y\in \Q$. Suppose $B \coloneqq \bigcup_{q\in [-1,1]\cap \Q} (A-q)\in \B(\R)$. This is a disjoint union (if $x\in (A-q) \cap (A-q'),$ then $x + q, x+q'\in A$ but they have rational difference), and contains $[0,1]$ (if $x\in [0,1]$, then some other representative of the same equivalence class is in $A$, and their difference is at most $1$), and is contained in $[-1,2]$. If $B\in \B(\R)$, then \[
        3 \ge \lambda(B) = \sum_{q} \lambda(A - q) = \sum_q \lambda(A),
    \] which is impossible (this is either $0$ or $\infty$).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of Lebesgue outer measure, value on intervals, and Borel sets are $\lambda^\star$-measurable.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
It is defined by \[
    \lambda^\star(A) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^\infty \left| I_i \right| \colon A\subset \bigcup_{i=1} ^\infty I_i \text{ is a covering with intervals} \right\} .
\] This is an outer measure, and $\lambda^\star(I) = \left| I \right| $ for intervals, and $\mathcal{A}_\mu$ contains $\B(\R)$.

\begin{proof}
    Write $\mu \coloneqq \lambda^\star$ here. Clearly $\mu(\emptyset) = 0$ and $\mu$ is monotone. Now let $A_k\subset \R,k\in \N,$ be disjoint, and $I_{nk}$ an $\varepsilon 2^{-n}$-good covering of $A_k$. Then $(I_{nk})_{n,k\in \N}$ is an interval covering of $A \coloneqq \bigcup_{k=1}^\infty A_k$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \mu(A) \le \sum_{n,k} \left| I_{nk} \right| \le \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left( \mu(A_n) + \varepsilon 2^{-n} \right) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \mu(A_n) + \varepsilon.
    \end{align*}

    If $I\subset \R$ is an interval, then $m(I) \le \left| I \right| $. If $(I_i)$ is an interval covering, then by making them all slightly bigger we may assume $I_i$ are open and cover $\overline{I}$, so we can reduce to a finite covering, for which $\sum_i \left| I_i \right| \ge \left| I \right| $ obviously holds.

    It STS that open intervals are $\lambda^\star$-measurable. Let $I\subset \R$ be an interval, $E\subset \R$, and $I_i$ an interval covering of $E$. Then $(I\cap I_i)$ is an interval covering of $E\cap I$, and $(I_i\setminus I)$ is an interval covering of $E\setminus I$ (possibly after replacing some of those by two intervals), so, \[
        \mu(E\cap I) + \mu(E\setminus I) \le \sum_{i}|I_i \cap I| + \sum_i |I_i \setminus I| = \sum_i |I_i|.
    \] Now take the infimum on the RHS.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Knaster-Tarski fixed point theorem (functions on posets).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Knaster-Tarski]
    Any order-preserving function on a complete poset has a fixed point.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $s \coloneqq \sup S$ were $ S \coloneqq \left\{ x\in X\colon x \le f(x) \right\} $. This is well-defined because $\min X \in S$. First, any $x\in S$ satisfies $x\le f(x) \le f(s)$, so $f(s)$ is also an upper bound, so $s \le f(s)$. This implies that $f(s) \le f(f(s))$, so $f(s) \in S$, so $f(s) \le s$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cantor-Schröder-Bernstein theorem on bijections between sets.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Cantor-Schröder-Bernstein]
    If $f\colon A\to B$ and $g\colon B\to A$ are injections, then there is a bijection $h\colon A\to B$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    If we show that there are $P \sqcup Q = A$ and $R \sqcup S = B$ with $f(P) = R$ and $g(S) = Q$, then we can put $h = f$ on $P$ and $h = g^{-1}$ on $Q$. This works iff $g(B\setminus f(P)) = A\setminus P$, so iff the map \[
        \mathcal{P}(A) \to \mathcal{P}(A); \, P \mapsto A\setminus g(B\setminus f(A))
    \] has a fixed point. But the map is order-preserving and $\mathcal{P}(S)$ is complete.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Proof of Zorn's lemma from Choice.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Zorn]
    If $X$ is a poset in which every chain has an upper bound, then it has a maximal element.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    For any chain $T\subset X$ let $u(T) \in X$ be an upper bound (here we use Choice). Suppose for contradiction that every $x\in X$ has a larger element $x'> x$. We show that we can construct ``arbitrarily large'' elements in $X$ in the sense that for every ordinal $\gamma$ we find an injection $\gamma \hookrightarrow X$, which cannot be true by Hartog. We define a map $\alpha \mapsto  x_\alpha$ such that $\alpha < \beta$ implies $x_\alpha < x_\beta$ by recursion (on a fixed initial segment $I_\gamma$ of well-orders) by
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[-] $x_0 = x$,
        \item[-] $x_{\alpha^+ } = {x_\alpha}'$,
        \item[-] $x_\lambda = u(\left\{ x_\alpha\colon \alpha < \lambda \right\} )'$.
    \end{enumerate}
    For this to be well-defined, it suffices to show that under the assumption that $x_\alpha$ has been defined on some initial segment $I_\lambda$, it is true that for any $\alpha < \beta (<\lambda)$, $x_\alpha < x_\beta$. We do this for fixed $\alpha$. Then
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[-] If $\beta = 0$ then $\beta \not> \alpha$, so there is nothing to show,
        \item[-] If $\beta = \zeta^+ > \alpha$, then $x_\beta = x_{\zeta}' > x_\zeta \ge x_\alpha$,
        \item[-] If $\beta = \sup \left\{ \zeta\colon \zeta < \beta \right\} $, then $x_\beta > u(\ldots ) \ge x_\alpha$.
    \end{enumerate}
    The recursion is thus well-defined and the above also proves that it is an injection, so we can inject $\gamma \simeq I_\gamma \hookrightarrow X$ for every ordinal $\gamma$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Zorn's lemma $\implies$ AC.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proof}
    Let $(A_i)_{i\in I}$ be a non-empty family of non-empty sets. We call a tuple $(J,f)$ with $J\subset I$ and $f\colon J\to A \coloneqq \bigcup_{i\in I} A_i$ a partial choice if $f(j) \in A_j$ for all $j\in J$, and consider the poset of all partial choices, where $(J,f) \le (J',f')$ if $J\subset J'$ and $f$ and $ f'$ aggree on $J'$. It is not empty (pick $J = \left\{ i \right\} $ for some $i\in I$), and if $(J_k,f_k), k\in \N,$ is a chain, then $(\cup J_k, \cup f_k)$ is well-defined and an upper bound. Hence by Zorn's lemma we find a maximal element $(J,f)$. If $J\neq I$, then we could pick $i\in I\setminus J$ and $x\in A_i$ so that $(J \cup \left\{ i \right\} , f \cup \left\{ (i,x) \right\} ) > (J,f)$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Well-ordering theorem $\iff$ AC.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proof}
    ``$\implies$'': Take a well-ordering on $A \coloneqq \bigcup_{i\in I} A_i$, and define $f\colon I\to A$ by $f(i) \coloneqq \min A_i$.

    ``$\impliedby$'': Let $X$ be a non-empty set and $\gamma$ an ordinal larger than $X$ (Hartog's lemma). We define $x_\alpha$ for $\alpha \in I_\gamma$ by recursion on the set $I_\gamma$: $x_0 = x_0$ for some arbitrary $x_0\in X$, and if $x$ is defined on $I_\alpha$, then choose  \[
        \begin{cases}
            x_\alpha \in X \setminus \left\{ x_\beta\colon \beta < \alpha \right\} &, \left\{ x_\beta\colon \beta < \alpha \right\} \subsetneq X,\\
            x_\alpha \coloneqq \perp &, \text{else}.
        \end{cases}
    \] (Here we need AC.) Then $x\colon I_\gamma \to X \cup \left\{ \perp \right\} $, and if $x_\alpha \neq \perp$ for all $\alpha \in I_\gamma$, then $x\colon I_\gamma \hookrightarrow X$, a contradiction. So if $\beta$ is the smallest ordinal with $x_\beta = \perp$, then $x\colon I_\beta \to X$ is a bijection, through which we can push the well-order of $I_\beta$ to $X$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Bourbaki-Witt theorem (``AC free'' part of Zorn).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a chain-complete poset and $f\colon X\to X$ an inflationary function ($f(x) \ge x$ for all $x\in X$), then $f$ has a fixed point.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    It suffices to show that $X$ has a maximal element. This follows from Zorn, but we can prove it without AC because we can make the choices in the proof of Zorn explicit: Assuming $f$ has no fixed point, we can make the explicit choice $x'\coloneqq f(x) > x$ for $x\in X$, and instead of having to choose an upper bound for each chain we can take its supremum.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definitions of $P$, $L(P)$, valuation, semantic entailment, model, tautology.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{enumerate}
    \item $P$ is just a set of atoms, $L(P)$ is the smallest superset that contains $\perp$ and $p\Rightarrow q$ whenever $p,q\in L(P)$.
    \item A \emph{valuation} is a map $v\colon L\to \left\{ 0,1 \right\} $ such that $v(\perp) = 0$ and $v(p\Rightarrow q) = 1 - \ind_{\left\{ p = 0, q = 1 \right\} }$. It is clearly defined by its values on $P$.
    \item If $S\subset L$, we say that a valuation $v$ is a \emph{model} for $S$ if $v(s) = 1$ for all $s\in S$.
    \item If $t\in L$, then we write $S \vDash t$ if $t$ is true in any model for $S$, and say that $S$ \emph{entails/semantically implies} $t$. If $\vDash t$, we say $t$ is a \emph{tautology}.
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of syntactic entailment and the three axioms.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    If $S\subset L$ and $t\in L$, then a \emph{proof} of $t$ from $S$ is a finite sequence $t_1, \ldots ,t_n$ such that $t_n = t$ and every $t_i$ is either an axiom, a member of $S$, or was deduced from previous propositions with modus ponens.

    In that case, we say that $S$ \emph{proves} or \emph{syntactically entails} $t$ and write $S \vdash t$. If $\vdash t$, then $t$ is called a \emph{theorem}.
\end{definition}

The axioms are
\begin{enumerate}
    \item $p \Rightarrow (q \Rightarrow p)$
    \item $(p \Rightarrow (q\Rightarrow r)) \Rightarrow ((p\Rightarrow q) \Rightarrow (q\Rightarrow r))$
    \item $\neg \neg p \Rightarrow p$
\end{enumerate}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Deduction theorem.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Deduction theorem]
    If $S\subset L$ and $p,q\in L$, then \[
        S \vdash (p\Rightarrow q) \quad \iff \quad S\cup \left\{ p \right\} \vdash q.
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    ``$\implies$'': Take a proof and append the lines $p$ and then $q$.

    ``$\impliedby$'': Take a proof $t_1, \ldots ,t_n$ from $S\cup \left\{ p \right\} $ to $q$. We show inductively that $S \vdash (p\Rightarrow t_i)$ for all $i\in [n]$. If $t_i$ is an atom or in $S$, we can write
    \begin{align*}
        & t_i \Rightarrow (p\Rightarrow t_i)\\
        & t_i\\
        \cline{1-2}
        & p\Rightarrow t_i.
    \end{align*}
    If $t_i = p$, we can prove $\vdash (p\Rightarrow p)$. If it is the result of two previous lines $t_j$ and $t_j \Rightarrow t_i$, then we by induction we can prove
    \begin{align*}
        & p \Rightarrow (t_j \Rightarrow t_i)\\
        & p \Rightarrow t_j\\
        & (p \Rightarrow (t_j \Rightarrow t_i)) \Rightarrow ((p\Rightarrow t_j) \Rightarrow (p\Rightarrow t_i))\\
        \cline{1-2}
        & (p\Rightarrow t_j) \Rightarrow (p \Rightarrow t_i)\\
        \cline{1-2}
        & p \Rightarrow t_i.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definitions of completeness, soundness, and adequacy, and soundness theorem.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Our theory is called \emph{sound} if $S\vdash t$ implies $S\vDash t$, \emph{adequate} if $S\vDash t$ implies $S\vdash t$, and \emph{complete} if it is sound and adequate.

\begin{theorem}[Soundness theorem]
    If $S\vdash t$, then $S\vDash t$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $t_1, \ldots ,t_n$ be a proof of $t$ from $S$, and $v$ a model for $S$. We inductively prove that $v(t_i) = 1$ for all $i\in [n]$. This is clear if $t_i$ is an axiom or member of $S$, and if it was derived with MP from $t_j \Rightarrow t_i$ and $t_j$, both of which are true in $v$ by induction hypothesis, then $v(t_i) = 1$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of (in-)consistence, the model existence theorem, and why it implies adequacy.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{definition}
    $S\subset L$ is called \emph{inconsistent} if $S\vdash \perp$, otherwise \emph{consistent}.
\end{definition}

egin{theorem}[Model existence theorem]
    If $S$ is consistent, then it has a model. (The converse holds by soundness.)
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    First note that for every $p\in L$, either of $S\cup\left\{ p ight\} $ or $S\cup \left\{ eg p ight\} $ must be consistent. Otherwise we could prove $S \vdash p$ and $S\vdash eg p$ (deduction theorem) and thus $S\vdash \perp$, a contradiction. With AC we may now choose either $t$ or $ eg t$ according to this rule for all $t\in L$ and add them to obtain $S$. This is still consistent (proofs are finite) and deductively closed (if $S \vdash t$ but $t ot\in S$, then $ eg t\in S$, so $S\vdash \perp$). Now check that \[
        v(t) \coloneqq egin{cases}
            1 &, t \in S,\
            0 &, t ot\in S,
        \end{cases}
    \] is a valuation.
\end{proof}

egin{corollary}[Adequacy]
    If $S\vDash t$, then $S\vdash t$.
\end{corollary}
egin{proof}
    Suppose $S\vDash t$, so $S \cup \left\{ eg t ight\} \vDash \perp$, so $S \cup \left\{ eg t ight\} \vdash \perp$ (model existence), so $S \vdash eg eg t$, so by the third axiom and MP $S\vdash t$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Compactness and decidability theorems (as corollaries to completeness).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Compactness]
    If $S\vDash t$, then there is a finite subset $S'\subset S$ with $S' \vDash t$. In particular, if every finite subset of $S$ has a model, then so does $S$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Trivial if $\vDash$ is replaced by $\vdash$ because proofs are finite. For the second statement, suppose that $S$ does not have a model, so $S\vdash \perp$, so $S'\vdash \perp$ for a finite subset, a contradiction.
\end{proof}

\begin{theorem}[Decidability]
    For every finite $S\subset L$ and $t\in L$, there is an algorithm which determines whether $S\vdash t$ in finite and bounded time.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Trivial for $\vDash$ by writing out truth tables.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $f\colon [a,b]\to \R$ is Riemann-integrable, then it is Lebesgue measurable and the integrals coincide.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proof}
    By definition of Riemann-integrability, $f$ is bounded, and there are sequences of step functions $\psi_n \downarrow$ and $\phi_n \uparrow$ with $\phi_n \le f \le \psi_n$. Then their pointwise limits satisfy $\phi \le f \le \psi$, and (by MCT) and definition of Riemann integral \[
    \int^L \psi \dd x \longleftarrow \int^L \psi_n \dd x\tendsto{} \int^R f \dd x,
\] same for $\psi$, so $\psi = \phi = f$ a.e.\ (so $f$ is Lebesgue measurable) and $\int^L f = \int^L \psi = \int^R f$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]The \emph{Devil's staircase:} A function which is continuous and a.e.\ differentiable on $[0,1]$, but $\int_0^1 f'(x)\dd x \neq f(1) - f(0)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Define $f$ by  \[
    f \left( \sum_{k=0}^\infty a_k 3^{-k} \right)  \coloneqq \sum_{k=0}^\infty \ind_{\left\{ a_k > 0 \right\} } 2^{-k}
\] That is, $1 / 2$ on $[1 / 3, 2 / 3]$, $3 / 4$ on $[7 / 9, 8 / 9] $ etc. Then $f$ is continuous, a.e.\ differentiable, in fact constant on $[0,1] \setminus C$, so \[
\int_0^1 f'(x) \dd x = 0 \neq f(1) - f(0).
\]
[/latex]

front: [latex]A sum of exponential RV's is (in-)finite iff their mean is.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $\lambda_i > 0,i\in \N$, and $E_i \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda_i)$ independent, then $S \coloneqq \sum_{i=1}^\infty E_i$ is a.s.\ (in-)finite iff $\E \left[ S \right] = \sum_{i=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda_i} $ is (in-)finite.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Only have to show that infinite mean implies infinite a.s., for which it STS that $\E \left[ \e^{-S} \right] = 0$, where \[
    \E \left[ \e^{-S} \right] = \lim_{n\to \infty} \prod_{i=1}^n \E \left[ \e^{-E_i} \right] = \lim_{n\to \infty} \prod_{i=1}^n \frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_i + 1},
    \] which is zero iff the following is infinite, \[
    -\sum_{i=1}^\infty \log \left( \frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_i + 1} \right) = \sum_{i=1}^\infty \log \left( 1 + \frac{1}{\lambda_i} \right)
    \] If $1 / \lambda_i \ge 1$ infinitely often, then this is infinite, otherwise this is at least $c\sum_{i = i_0}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda_i} = \infty$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Forward- and backward equations for continuous-time Markov chain.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    The transition matrices $(P(t))_{t\ge 0}$ of a minimal continuous-time Markov chain with $Q$-matrix $Q$ are the minimal solution to either of the equations \[
        P'(t) = Q P(t) \quad \text{ or }\quad P'(t) = P(t)Q,
    \] with $P(0) = \ind$. If the chain is non-explosive, the solution is unique.
\end{proposition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]How to find entries of $P(t)$ for $M(\cdot ,Q)$ with finite state space?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    $p_{ij}(t) =  \sum_{k\in S} a_k \e^{\lambda_k t}$, where $(\lambda_k)$ are the eigenvalues of $Q$, and the coefficients can be determined via $P^{(i)}(0) = Q^{i}$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    $Q = U \Lambda U^{-1}$ for some matrix $U$, so \[
        P(t) = \e^{tQ} = U \e^{t\Lambda} U^{-1} = U \text{diag}(\e^{t\lambda_k}) U^{-1},
    \] so $p_{ij}(t)$ is a linear combination of $\e^{\lambda_k t}$ terms.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of transience/recurrence of states for $M(\nu,Q)$. This coincides with the notion for the corresponding jump chain and $i\in S$ is recurrent iff $\int_0^\infty p_{ii}(t) \dd t = \infty$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    $i\in S$ is transient/recurrent if $X_t$, started from $i$, a.s.\ eventually leaves $i$ for every/is at $i$ for arbitrarily large times.

    Then a state is transient/recurrent iff it is transient/recurrent for the corresponding jump chain, and $i\in S$ is recurrent iff \[
        \int_0^\infty p_{ii}(s) \dd s = \infty.
    \]
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    If $i\in S$ is recurrent/transient for $X$, then it clearly is for $Y$. If $i\in S$ is transient for $Y$, say it leaves forever at $n$, then $X_t \neq i$ for all $t \ge T_n$, and $T_n < \infty$ a.s. If $i\in S$ is recurrent for $Y$, say $Y_{n_j} = i$ for $j\in \N$, then $X$ spends time at least $\sum_{j=1}^\infty (T_{n_j} - T_{n_j - 1})$ at state $i$, and this is a sum of i.i.d.\ RV's, so a.s.\ infinite.

    Finally, if $q_i = 0$ then then $i$ is recurrent and $p_{ii}(t) = 1$ for all $t > 0$, so suppose $q_i > 0$. Then
    \begin{align*}
        \int_0^\infty p_{ii}(t) \dd t
        &= \E^i \left[\int_0^\infty \ind_{\left\{ X_t = i \right\} } \dd t\right]\\
        &= \E^i \left[ \sum_{n=0}^\infty Z_n \ind_{\left\{ Y_n = i \right\} } \right] \\
        &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \P^i(Y_n = i) \E^i \left[Z_n \,\middle\vert\, Y_n = i\right]\\
        &= \frac{1}{q_i} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \pi^{(n)}_{ii}.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]First order logic: Language, closed term, bound/free variables, sentences, substitution, $L$-structure, interpretation of a sentence (in a structure)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Let $\Omega$ (function symbols) and $\Pi$ (relation symbols) be disjoint sets and $\alpha\colon \Omega\cup \Pi \to \N_0$ (arity), then the \emph{language} $L = L(\Omega,\Pi,\alpha)$ is the set of formulae, where
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(Terms)] Variables ($x,x_1,x_2,y,z, \ldots $) are terms, and for terms $t_i$ and $f\in \Omega$, $f(t_1, \ldots ,t_n)$ is a term,
        \item[(Atomic formulae)] $\perp$ is an AF, $(s=t)$ for terms $s,t$ is an AF, and $\phi(t_1, \ldots ,t_n)$ for $\phi\in \Pi$ and terms $t_i$ is an AF,
        \item[(Formulae)] Atomic Formulae are formulae, and if $p,q$ are formulae, then so are $(p\Rightarrow q)$ and $(\forall x)p$.
    \end{enumerate}
    We make the following definitions.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] A \emph{closed} term is one without variables,
        \item[(ii)] An occurrence of a variable $x$ in a formula is \emph{bound} if it is within the range of $(\forall x)$, otherwise \emph{free},
        \item[(iii)] A \emph{sentence} is a formula with no free variables,
        \item[(iv)] If $p$ is a formula, $t$ a term, $x$ a variable, then $p[t / x]$ is obtained from $p$ by replacing each \emph{free} occurrence of $x$ in $p$ by $t$,
        \item[(v)] A \emph{structure} for $L$ is a set $A\neq\varnothing$ together with functions and relations of the appropriate arities,
        \item[(vi)] If $A$ is a structure for $L$ and $p$ is a sentence, then $p_A\in \left\{ 0,1 \right\} $ is the statement obtained by plugging in the appropriate functions and relations, and replacing $\forall x$ by $\forall x\in A$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]First order logic: Theory, model, semantic entailment, tautology[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose a language is given.

\begin{definition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] A \emph{theory} $S$ is a set of sentences. An $L$-structure $A$ is called a \emph{model} for a sentence $p$ if $p_A = 1$, and a model for $S$ if $p_A = 1$ for all $p\in S$.
        \item[(ii)] We say that $S$ \emph{entails} a sentence $p$, written $S\vDash p$, if every model for $S$ is a model for $p$. A \emph{tautology} is a sentence with $\vDash p$, for example $(\forall x)(x=x)$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]First order logic: Syntactic entailment (proofs), deduction theorem[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Axioms of predicate logic are the three axioms from propositional logic (on formulas), and additionally
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $(\forall x)(x=x)$ for any variable $x$,
        \item[(ii)] $(\forall x)(\forall y) \big( (x=y)\Rightarrow (p\Rightarrow p[y / x])\big)$ for any variables $x,y$, and formula $p$, with $y$ not occurring bound in $p$,
        \item[(iii)] $[(\forall x)p] \Rightarrow p[t / x]$ for formula $p$, variable $x$, and no free variable of $t$ occuring bound in $p$,
        \item[(iv)] $[(\forall x)(p\Rightarrow q)] \Rightarrow [p\Rightarrow (\forall x)q]$ for formulas $p,q$ and variables $x$ not occurring free in $p$.
    \end{enumerate}
    Deduction rules are moduls ponens, and generalisation: from $r$ can deduce $(\forall x)r$ if $x$ has not occurred as a free variable in a premise so far in the proof.

    A proof of a formula $p$ from a set of formulae $S$ is a sequence of statements, where each statement is an axiom, an element of $S$, or deduced from previous lines using MP or Gen. In that case write $S\vdash p$ and call $p$ a \emph{theorem} of $S$.
\end{definition}

\begin{theorem}[Deduction theorem]
    For $S\subset L$ and $p,q\in L$, \[
    S \vdash p\Rightarrow q \quad \text{if and only if}\quad S \cup \left\{ p \right\} \vdash q.
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Just like with propositional logic, but for ``$\impliedby$'' have to check Gen. Hence suppose that a proof of $q$ from $S\cup \left\{ p \right\} $ contains a use of Gen to obtain $(\forall x)r$ from $r$, and that we can prove $p\Rightarrow r$ from $S$. $x$ is not free in a premise used so far in either proof, so we get $(\forall x)(p\Rightarrow r)$. If $x$ is not free in $p$, then we get $p \Rightarrow (\forall x)r$ by an axiom, otherwise $p$ has not been used in the proof of $r$ yet, so $S\vdash r$, so $S\vdash (\forall x)r$, so $S\vdash p\Rightarrow (\forall x)r$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]First order logic: Model existence, completeness[/latex]
back:
[latex]
The model existence lemma states that if $S\subset L$ is consistent, then it has a model. As with propositional logic, soundness is clear and we deduce completeness of first order logic.

\begin{theorem}[Completeness of first order logic]
    If $S$ is a theory, and $p$ a sentence, then $S\vdash p$ iff $S\vDash p$.
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]First order logic: Compactness, Löwenheim-Skolem[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{theorem}[Compactness]
    If $S$ is a theory such that every finite subset has a model, then $S$ has a model.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    Having a model is equivalent to being consistent, and then it is clear because proofs are finite.
\end{proof}

egin{corollary}[Löwenheim-Skolem]
    Let $S$ be a theory.
    egin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $S$ has arbitrarily large (finite) models, then it has an infinite model,
        \item[(ii)] If $S$ has an infinite model, then it has an uncountable model (in fact as large as any set),
        \item[(iii)] If $L$ is countable and $S$ has a model, then it has a countable model.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{corollary}
egin{proof}
    egin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Let $S' = S \cup igcup_{n\in \N} \left\{ \left| A ight| \ge n ight\} $, where $\left| A ight|\ge 2 $ stands for the sentence $(\exists x)(\exists y)(x eq y)$, for example. Then every finite subset of $S'$ has a model by assumption, so $S'$ has a model. This must be a model of $S$ and infinite,
        \item[(ii)] Let $I$ be uncountable (or as large as desired), add constants $\left\{ c_i\colon i\in I ight\} $ to $L$, and let \[
        S' = S \cup igcup_{i,j\in I, i eq j} \left\{ c_i eq c_j ight\} .
    \] Then every finite subset of $S'$ only has finitely many new constants, so has a model, so $S'$ has a model,
        \item[(iii)] The model constructed in the model existence theorem is countable.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]ZF: Axioms of extension, separation, and empty set.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{axiom}[Axiom of extension]
    If two sets have the same elements, they are the same set. (The converse holds automatically by axioms.)
\end{axiom}

\begin{axiom}[Axiom of separation]
    If $x$ is a set and $p$ a formula (with free variables $t_1, \ldots ,t_n,z'$), then the set $\left\{ z\in x\colon p(z) \right\} $ exists (where $p(z)$ is short for $p[z / z']$).
\end{axiom}

\begin{axiom}[Axiom of empty set]
    The empty set exists.
\end{axiom}
[/latex]

front: [latex]ZF: Axiom of pair set, ordered pairs, functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{axiom}[Axiom of pair set]
    Can form $\left\{ x,y \right\} $. More precisely, for $x,y$ there exists a set whose elements are exactly $x$ and $y$.
\end{axiom}

\begin{definition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] \textbf{Ordered pairs.} Write $(x,y)$ for $\left\{ \left\{ x \right\} ,\left\{ x,y \right\}  \right\} $.
        \item[(ii)] \textbf{Functions.} A function is a set that contains only ordered pairs and such that $(x,y)\in f \wedge (x,z)\in f \Rightarrow y=z$. We can build $\text{dom} f$ as subset of $\bigcup \bigcup f $ using separation, and write $f\colon x\to y$ if $x = \text{dom} f$ and $(u,v)\in f \Rightarrow v\in y$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]ZF: Axioms of union and power set, how to build $\bigcap x$, $x \times y$, and the set of functions $x\to y$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{axiom}[Axiom of union]
    Can build the union $\bigcup x$ of a set $x$, that is $(\forall x) (\exists y)(\forall z)(z\subset  y \Leftrightarrow  z\in x)$, where $z\subset y$ stands for $(\forall v)(v\in z \Rightarrow v\in y)$. Write $x\cup y$ for $\bigcup \left\{ x,y \right\}  $.
\end{axiom}

Note that we do not need an axiom for $\bigcap x$, we can build it by taking $x_1\in x$ and $\left\{ y\in x_1\colon  (\forall x')(x'\in x \Rightarrow y\in x')  \right\} $.

\begin{axiom}[Axiom of power set]
    We can build power sets.
\end{axiom}

We can also build $x\times y$ as subset of $\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{P}(x \cup y ))$, and the set of functions $x \to y$ as subset of $\mathcal{P}(x \times y)$.
[/latex]

front: [latex]ZF: Axiom of infinity, successor sets, $\omega$, and induction.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
We would like to define $\N$. For $x$ put $x^+ \coloneqq x \cup \left\{ x \right\} $, then we have $0 \coloneqq \emptyset$, $1\coloneqq 0^+ = \left\{ 0 \right\} $, $2\coloneqq 1^+ = \left\{ 0,1 \right\} $ etc. We need an axiom to make sure there is a set which contains all these.

\begin{axiom}[Axiom of infinity]
    $(\exists x) (\emptyset \in x \wedge (\forall y)(y\in x \Rightarrow y^+ \in x))$.
\end{axiom}

A set is called a \emph{successor set} if it has this property. We can define the intersection of all successor sets by taking any successor set $x$ and defining the set $S$ of all successor subsets of $x$ as subset of $\mathcal{P}(x)$, and put $\omega \coloneqq \bigcap S$. Then by definition \[
    (\forall x) [(x\subset \omega \wedge x \text{ is a successor set}) \Rightarrow x = \omega].
\] This is genuine induction!
[/latex]

front: [latex]ZF: Axiom of foundation/regularity.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
We say $y\in x$ is \emph{$\in$-minimal in $x$} if $z\in x \Rightarrow z\not\in y$.
\begin{axiom}[Axiom of foundation]
    Every set has an $\in$-minimal member.
\end{axiom}
[/latex]

front: [latex]ZF: Classes, function classes, and axiom of replacement.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A \emph{class} is a formula with a single free variable, we think of it as $\left\{ x\colon p(x) \right\} $ (where $p(x) = p[x/*]$ where $*$ is the free variable). This is a \emph{function class} if $p$ is of the form \[
p(x) = (\exists y)(\exists z)(x = (y,z) \wedge q(y,z)],
\] where $q$ is a formula with two free variables satisfying $q(y,z)\wedge q(y,z') \Rightarrow z = z'$.

\begin{axiom}[Axiom of replacement]
    If $p$ is a function class (equivalently if $q$ has the above property) and $x$ a set, then the image of $x$ under $p$ is a set, i.e. \[
        (\exists y)(\forall z)[z\in y \Leftrightarrow (\exists t)(t\in x \wedge q(t,z))].
    \]
\end{axiom}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Three easy criteria for a continuous-time Markov chain to be non-explosive.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $X \sim M(\nu,Q)$ be a continuous-time Markov chain with state space $S$. If any of the following hold, $X$ is non-explosive.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $S$ is finite,
        \item[(ii)] $\sup_i q_i < \infty$,
        \item[(iii)] $X_0 = i$ and $i$ is recurrent (for $X$ or the jump chain).
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    (i) implies (ii). One way to obtain $X$ is to take $E_i \sim \text{Exp}(1)$ i.i.d.\ and let $X$ follow the jumps of $Y$ with waiting times $T_i = E_i / q_{Y_i}$. Then \[
    T_\infty \ge \frac{1}{\sup q_i} \sum_{i=1}^\infty E_i = \infty.
\] If (iii) holds, then $T_\infty$ is lower bounded by an infinite sum of i.i.d.\ exponentials (the holding times in state $i$), which is infinite.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of invariant measure for a continuous-time MC and characterisation with $Q$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    A measure $\xi = (\xi_i)_{i\in S}$ on $S$ is called \emph{invariant} for $Q$ if $\xi P(t) = \xi$ for all $t\ge 0$, equivalently if $\xi Q = 0$.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    We have \[
        \frac{\dd }{\dd t} (\xi P(t)) = \xi Q P(t) = \xi P(t) Q.
    \] If $\xi$ is invariant, then $\text{LHS} = 0$ and $\text{RHS} = \xi Q$, and if $\xi Q = 0$ then $\text{RHS} = 0$, so $\xi P(t) = \xi P(0) = \xi$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Positive recurrence is a class property for continuous-time MC's, and connection with invariant measures. (No proof.)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Positive recurrence is a class property. If $Q$ is irreducible, then it is positive recurrent iff it has an invariant distribution, in which case \[
    \xi_i = \frac{1}{m_i q_i},\quad i\in S,
    \] and every invariant measure is a multiple of this. In partiuclar, invariant distributions are unique if they exist.
\end{proposition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convergence to equilibrium and ergodic theorem for continuous-time Markov chains.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{theorem}
    Let $Q$ be irreducible and positive recurrent, and $\xi$ the unique invariant distribution. Then, for $X \sim M( u,Q)$, \[
        u P(t) endsto{} \xi,
        \] (entry-wise), and \[
    rac{1}{t} \int_0^t \ind_{\left\{ X_s = i ight\} }\dd s endsto{} \xi_i
    \] a.s.\ as $t o \infty$.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    Let $X' \sim M(\xi,Q)$, and $Y \coloneqq (X,X')$. Then $Y$ is a continuous-time Markov chain on $S imes S$ with stationary distribution $\xi \otimes \xi$, in particular recurrent, so $T\coloneqq \inf \left\{ t \ge 0\colon X_t = X_t' ight\} \le T_{(s,s)} < \infty$ a.s.\ (for any fixed $s\in S$). Put \[
    Z_t \coloneqq egin{cases}
        X_t &, t \le T,\
        X_t'&, t > T.
    \end{cases}
\] By the strong Markov property, $Z\sim M( u,Q) \sim X$, so \[
\P(X_t = j) = \P(Z_t = j) = \underbrace{\P(T\le t)}_{ o 1}  \underbrace{\P(X_t' = j)}_{= \xi_j} + \underbrace{\P(T>t)}_{ o 0} \P(X_t = j) endsto{} \xi_j.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition and transition probabilities of time-reversal of an irreducible pos.\ recurrent Markov chain. Reversability and detailed balance equations.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $(Y_m)_{0\le m \le n}$ is an irreducible Markov chain with (and started at) stationary distribution $\mu$, then $\widehat{Y}\coloneqq (Y_{n-m})_{0\le m\le n}$ is also an irreducible Markov chain with stationary distribution $\mu$ and transition probabilities \[
    \widehat{\pi}_{ij} = \xi_j \pi_{ji} / \xi_i,\quad i,j\in S.
\]
\end{proposition}

$Y$ is said to be \emph{reversible} if $\widehat{Y} \stackrel{d}{=} Y$, that is if it satisfies the \emph{detailed balance equations} \[
\mu_j \pi_{ji} = \mu_i \pi_{ij},\quad i,j\in S.
\] If $\mu$ satisfies these, then it is automatically a stationary measure. If it has infinite mass, then $Y$ is null-recurrent.

\begin{proof}
    We have
    \begin{align*}
        \P \left( \widehat{Y}_{0} = i_0, \ldots ,\widehat{Y}_n = i_n \right)
        &= \P \left( Y_0 = i_n, \ldots ,Y_n = i_0 \right) \\
        &= \mu_{i_n} \pi_{i_n i_{n-1}}\cdot \ldots\cdot  \pi_{i_1i_0}\\
        &= \mu_{i_0} \widehat{\pi}_{i_0i_1}\cdot \ldots \cdot \widehat{\pi}_{i_{n-1}i_n}.
    \end{align*}
    If $\mu$ satisfies the balance equations, then summing over $i$ gives $\mu_j = \sum_i \mu_i \pi_{ij}$. If $\mu$ has infinite mass, it cannot be positive recurrent (because then every stationary measure is a constant multiple of the invariant distribution).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition, $Q$-matrix and transition probabilities of time-reversal of an irreducible pos.\ recurrent continuous-time Markov chain. Reversability and detailed balance equations.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $Q$ is irreducible with stationary distribution $\xi$, and $X \sim M(\xi,Q)$, fix $t > 0$ and define $\widehat{X} \coloneqq (X_{(t-s)-})_{0\le s \le t}$ (so that $\widehat{X}$ is right-continuous).

\begin{proposition}
    $\widehat{X}$ is also an irreducible positive recurrent continuous-time Markov chain with stationary distribution $\xi$ and \[
        \widehat{q}_{ij} = \xi_j q_{ji} / \xi_i,\qquad \widehat{p}_{ij}(t) = \xi_j p_{ji}(t) / \xi_i,\quad i,j\in S.
    \]
\end{proposition}

$X$ is said to be \emph{reversible} if $X \stackrel{d}{=} \widehat{X}$, i.e.\ if the \emph{detailed balance equations} \[
\xi_j q_{ji} = \xi_i q_{ij},\quad i,j\in S,
\] are satisfied. Conversely, if they are, then $\xi$ is an invariant measure. If it has infinite mass, $X$ is null-recurrent.

\begin{proof}
    First confirm that $\widehat{Q}$ is a $Q$-matrix with transition probabilities $\widehat{P}$. Off-diagonal elements are non-negative, and $\sum_{j\in S} \widehat{q}_{ij} = \frac{1}{\xi_i} \sum_{j\in S} \xi_j q_{ji} = 0$. Furthermore,
    \begin{align*}
        \widehat{p}_{ij}\,'(t)
        &= \xi_j p_{ji}'(t) / \xi_i = \xi_j \sum_{k\in S} q_{jk} p_{ki}(t) / \xi_i = \sum_{k\in S} \widehat{q}_{kj} \widehat{p}_{ik}(t),
    \end{align*}
    i.e.\ $\widehat{P}\, '(t) = \widehat{P}(t) \widehat{Q}$. Now we confirm that $\widehat{X} \sim M(\xi,\widehat{Q})$ by finding its fidis.
    \begin{align*}
        \P\left( \widehat{X}_{t_1} = i_1, \ldots ,\widehat{X}_{t_n} =i_n \right)
        &= \P\left( X_{(t-t_n)-}=i_n, \ldots ,X_{(t-t_1)-} = i_1 \right) \\
        &= \xi_{i_n} p_{i_n i_{n-1}}(t-t_n) \cdot \ldots \cdot p_{i_2 i_1}(t_2-t_1)\\
        &= \xi_{i_1} \widehat{p}_{i_1i_2}(t_2-t_1)\cdot \ldots \cdot \widehat{p}_{i_{n-1}i_n}(t-t_n).
    \end{align*}

    Finally, if $\xi$ satisfies the balance equations, then summing $i$ gives $0 = \sum_{i\in S} \xi_i q_{ij}$, so $\xi$ is invariant. If $\xi$ has infinite mass then $X$ must be null-recurrent because otherwise every invariant measure is multiple of the unique stationary distribution (and so has finite mass).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of omega ordinals (and proof that they are exactly the initial ordinals).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Define $\omega_\alpha$ for ordinals $\alpha$ by
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\omega_0 = \omega$,
        \item[(ii)] $\omega_{\alpha + 1} = \gamma(\omega_\alpha)$,
        \item[(iii)] $\omega_\lambda = \sup \left\{ \omega_\alpha\colon \alpha < \lambda \right\} $.
    \end{enumerate}
    Call an ordinal \emph{initial} if it does not biject with any smaller ordinal. Then the omega ordinals are \emph{exactly} the infinite initial ordinals.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    All are initial by induction: $\omega_0$ does not biject with finite sets, $\gamma(\omega_\alpha)$ is initial by definition of $\gamma(\cdot )$, and if $\lambda$ is a limit ordinal and $\omega_\lambda \sim \beta$ for some $\beta < \omega_\lambda$, then there is $\alpha < \lambda$ with $\beta < \omega_\alpha < \omega_\lambda$, so $\beta \sim \omega_\alpha$, contradiction.

    Now let $\delta$ be an infinite initial ordinal, and $\alpha$ the smallest ordinal for which $\omega_\alpha \ge \delta$ (exists bc the omega ordinals are unbounded). Done if $\alpha = 0$. If $\alpha = \beta^+$, then $\delta < \omega_\alpha = \gamma(\omega_\beta)$ would imply $\delta \le \omega_\beta$, a contradiction. If $\alpha$ is a limit and $\delta < \omega_\alpha$, then there is $\beta < \alpha$ with $\delta < \omega_\beta$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of cardinals and cardinal arithmetic.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    For a set $x$, $\text{card}(x)$ is the smallest ordinal which bijects with $x$. This is always an initial ordinal, so every set has cardinality $\aleph_\alpha = \text{card}(\omega_\alpha)$ for some ordinal $\alpha$. Define sum, product, and exponentiation of ordinals in the obvious way, then $m + n = n + m$, $mn = nm$, and $(m^n)^p = m^{np}$.
\end{definition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]What are $\aleph_\alpha \aleph_\alpha$, $\aleph_\alpha + \aleph_\beta$, and $\aleph_\alpha \aleph_\beta$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    For every ordinal $\alpha$, \[
    \aleph_\alpha \aleph_\alpha= \aleph_\alpha.
    \] In particular, if $\alpha \le \beta$, then $\aleph_\alpha + \aleph_\beta = \aleph_\alpha \aleph_\beta = \aleph_\beta$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Assume that $\alpha \neq 0$. Obviously $\omega_\alpha$ injects into $\omega_\alpha \times \omega_\alpha$. To show the opposite, it suffices to define a well-order on the latter set of order type at most $\omega_\alpha$. Define an order of the form $(x,y) < (x',y')$ if $\max(x,y) < \max(x',y')$, and if they are equal we order by $y$ first (say). This is a well-order because we can first choose a smallest $\max$, so we are left with the edge of a square, which looks like (an initial segment of) $\alpha$. Now it STS that every proper initial segment has order type $< \omega_\alpha$. For any $x,y\in \omega_\alpha$ we have $I_{(x,y)}\subset \beta\times \beta$ for $\beta \coloneqq I_{\max(x,y)^+} < \omega_\alpha$ (because $\omega_\alpha$ is a limit), and by induction hypothesis (we may assume $\beta$ is infinite because $\alpha \neq 0$), $\beta\times \beta \sim \beta$,so $I_{(x,y)}$ has order type smaller than $\omega_\alpha$ (otherwise its cardinality was at least $\aleph_\alpha$).

    Finally, if $\alpha \le \beta$, then \[
    \aleph_\beta \le \aleph_\beta + \aleph_\alpha \le \aleph_\beta + \aleph_\beta \le \aleph_\beta\aleph_\beta = \aleph_\beta.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cardinality of $\R^{\N}$ and continuum hypothesis.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
We have \[
    \text{card}(\R ^{\N}) = (2^{\aleph_0})^{\aleph_0} = 2^{\aleph_0 \aleph_0}= 2^{\aleph_0} = \text{card}(\R).
\] The continuum hypothesis is $2^{\aleph_0} = \aleph_1$. It is independent of ZFC.
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition renewal process, $m(t)$ (with representation and local boundedness), and renewal equation.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A \emph{renewal process} with i.i.d.\ inter-arrival times $Z_k$ is \[
X_t = \left| \left\{ k\in \N\colon T_k \le t \right\}  \right| = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \ind_{\left\{ T_k \le t \right\} },
\] where $T_k = \sum_{i=1}^k Z_k$.

\begin{proposition}
    $m(t) = \sum_{k=1}^\infty F_k(t)\lesssim \e^t$, where $F_k = F_{k-1} \star f$, and $m$ is the unique locally bounded solution to the \emph{renewal equation} \[
        m = F + m\star f.
    \] (Here $f$ must not be a pdf but just a probability measure on $(0,\infty)$.)
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    We have $X_t = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \ind_{\left\{ T_k \le t \right\} }$, so the first equality is clear. Also, $T_k\sim f^{\star(k)}$, integrating gives cdf $F_k$. Now,
    \begin{align*}
        F_k(t)
        &= \P\left( T_k \le t \right) \le \e^t \E \left[ \e^{-T_k} \right] = \e^t \E \left[ \e^{-Z_1} \right]^k,
    \end{align*}
    so putting $\theta \coloneqq \E \left[ \e^{-Z_1} \right] \in (0,1)$, $m(t) \le \e^t \frac{\theta}{1 - \theta}$.

    To prove the renewal equation,
    \begin{align*}
        m(t)
        &= \int_0^t \E \left[X_t \,\middle\vert\, T_1 = s\right] \dd f(s) = \int_0^t \left( 1 + \E \left[ X_{t-s} \right] \right) \dd f(s)\\
        &= F(t) + \int_0^t m(t-s) \dd f(s).
    \end{align*}
    If $\widetilde{m}$ is another locally bounded solution, then $\alpha \coloneqq m - \widetilde{m}$ satisfies $\alpha = \alpha \star f$, so
     \begin{align*}
         \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left| \alpha(t) \right| =\sum_{k=1}^\infty\left|\int_0^t \alpha(t-s) \dd f^{\star(k)}(s)\right| \le m(t) \sup_{s\le t} \left| \alpha(s) \right| < \infty
    \end{align*}
    so $\alpha(t) = 0$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Strong law and CLT of renewal theory, and elementary renewal theorem.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $X$ be a renewal process with $\mu \coloneqq \E \left[ Z_1 \right] \in (0,\infty)$.
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item[(SLLN)] $\displaystyle\frac{X_t}{t} \tendsto{a.s.} \frac{1}{\mu},\quad t \to \infty.$
        \item[(E)] $\displaystyle \frac{m(t)}{t} \tendsto{} \frac{1}{\mu},\quad t\to \infty.$
        \item[(CLT)] If $Z_1$ is square-integrable and $\sigma^2 \coloneqq \V(Z_1) \in (0,\infty)$, then \[
            \widetilde{X_t}\tendsto{d} \mathcal{N}(0,1),\quad t\to \infty.
    \]
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    (SLLN) essentially follows from $\frac{T_n}{n} \tendsto{a.s.} \mu$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Renewal theory: Age and excess lifetime processes, Renewal property (vanilla and for delayed processes).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A renewal process where $Z_1$ is allowed to have a different distribution then $X_2,X_3, \ldots$ is called a \emph{delayed} renewal process. For $t\ge 0$, define
\begin{align*}
    A_t &\coloneqq t -T_{X_t} \text{ (time since last arrival)},\\
    E_t &\coloneqq T_{X_t + 1} - t \text{ (time until next arrival)}.
\end{align*}
$(A_t)$ is called the \emph{age process} and $(E_t)$ the \emph{excess lifetime process}. Note that $(E_t)$ is a Markov process which decreases linearly and jumps up by $Z_1$ whenever it hits zero.

\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is a renewal process, and $T$ a jump-time-valued stopping time (f.ex.\ just $T_k$), then $(X_{T+s}-X_T)$ has the same distribution as $X$ and is independent of $(X_s)_{s\le T}$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is a (delayed) renewal process and $t \ge 0$, then $(X_{t+s}-X_t)_{s\ge 0}$ is a delayed renewal process with $\widetilde{Z}_1 = E_t$ (but not necessarily independent of $\mathcal{F}_t$). In particular, if the distribution of $E_t$ is independent of $t$, then $X$ has stationary increments.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Obvious.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Renewal theory: Size-biased distributions, and limit of $(A_t,E_t)$ as $t\to \infty$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    The \emph{size-biased} distribution associated with a probability $f$ on $(0,\infty)$ with finite mean $\mu$ is $\dd \widehat{f}(t) \coloneqq \frac{1}{\mu} t \dd f(t)$. If $L\sim \widehat{f}, $$U\sim \mathcal{U}(0,1)$, $U\indep L$, then \[
        \P(LU > x) = \frac{1}{\mu} \int_x^\infty (y-x)\dd f(y).
    \]
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Condition on $L$.
\end{proof}
\begin{proposition}
    For every $x \ge 0$, \[
        \P(E_t \ge x) \tendsto{} \frac{1}{\mu}\int_x^\infty (y-x) \dd f(y).
    \] That is, $E_t \tendsto{d} LU$, where $L$ is the size-biased distribution corresponding to $Z_1$, and $U\sim \mathcal{U}(0,1),\,U \indep L$. In fact, \[
    (A_t,E_t) \tendsto{d} (L(1-U),LU).
    \]
\end{proposition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Associated stationary process of a renewal process and convergence to it (renewal theorem).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a renewal process with finite inter-arrival mean, and $\widetilde{X}$ is a delayed version with $Z_1 \stackrel{d}{=} LU$, then $E_t \stackrel{d}{=} LU$ for all $t\ge 0$, in particular $\widetilde{X}$ has stationary increments. Furthermore, if $X$ also has a continuous inter-arrival distribution, then for any fixed $s \ge 0$, \[
    X_{t+s} - X_t \tendsto{d} \widetilde{X}_s,\quad t\to \infty,
    \] and \[
    m(t+s) - m(t) \tendsto{} \frac{s}{\mu},\quad t \to \infty.
    \]
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Key renewal theorem.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $X$ be a renewal process with continuous inter-arrival distribution of finite mean $\mu$. If $h\colon [0,\infty)\to [0,\infty)$ is integrable and decreasing, then \[
        (h\star m')(t) \tendsto{} \frac{1}{\mu} \left\|h\right\|_{L^1},\quad t\to \infty.
    \]
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition convex hull of a set and characterisation.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
The \emph{convex hull} $\conv A$ of $A\subset \R^d$ is the intersection of all convex supersets.
\begin{lemma}
    $\conv A = \left\{ \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i x_i\colon k\in \N, \lambda_i \ge 0, \sum_i \lambda_i = 1, x_i \in A \right\} $.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    The RHS is a convex superset of $A$, so $\subset $. On the other hand, if $C\supset A$ is convex, then it must contain all convex combinations of elements of $A$, so it must contain the RHS.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Minkowski combinations of sets. How do they interact with convexity, and how do $(\alpha+\beta)A$, $\alpha A+\beta A$ and convexity of $A$ relate?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $A,B\subset \R^d$, and $\alpha,\beta\in \R$, then \[
\alpha A + \beta B \coloneqq \left\{ \alpha x + \beta y\colon x\in A,y\in B \right\} .
\]
\begin{proposition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $A$ and $B$ are convex, then so is $\alpha A + \beta B$.
        \item[(ii)] $(\alpha + \beta) A \subset \alpha A + \beta A$. The converse is true for all $\alpha,\beta \in \R$ iff $A$ is convex.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Let $\mu+\lambda = 1$, then
            \begin{align*}
                \mu (\alpha x_1+\beta y_1) + \lambda (\alpha x_2 + \beta y_2) = \alpha \underbrace{(\mu x_1 + \lambda x_2)}_{\in A} + \beta \underbrace{(\mu y_1 + \lambda y_2)}_{\in B} \in \alpha A + \beta b.
            \end{align*}
        \item[(ii)] $\subset $ is clear. Now suppose $A$ is convex, $x,y\in A$. Then
            \begin{align*}
            \alpha x + \beta y = (\alpha + \beta) \underbrace{\left(\frac{\alpha}{\alpha + \beta}x + \frac{\beta}{\alpha + \beta}y\right)}_{\in A}  \in (\alpha+\beta) A.
            \end{align*}
            On the other hand if $\supset$ holds and $x,y\in A$, $\mu + \lambda = 1$, then \[
                \mu x + \lambda y \in \mu A + \lambda A = (\mu+\lambda)A = A.
            \]
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex](Pre-)images of convex sets under affine maps are convex.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $f\colon \R^n \to \R^m$ is affine and $A\subset \R^n$ and $B\subset \R^m$ are convex, then so are $f(A)$ and $f^{-1}(B)$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If $\mu + \lambda = 1$ and $x,y\in A$, then \[
        \mu f(x) + \lambda f(y) = f(\mu x + \lambda y) \in f(A).
    \] If $x,y\in f^{-1}(B)$, then \[
    f(\mu x + \lambda y) = \mu f(x) + \lambda f(y) \in B,
\] so $\mu x + \lambda y \in f^{-1}(B)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of polyhedral sets, polytopes, simplices. Why are polytopes closed (hence compact)?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A \emph{polyhedral set} is the intersection of finitely many closed half spaces.

A \emph{polytope} is the convex hull of finitely many points. It is called an \emph{$r$-simplex} if it is the convex hull of $r + 1$ affinely independent points.

\begin{lemma}
    Polytopes are compact.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    STS that $P$ is closed. Let $P = \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $ and $p_n = \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda^{(n)}_i x_i \in P$ for $n\in \N$ and suppose $p_n \to p\in \R^d$. We find a subsequence along which $\lambda_i^{(n)} \to \lambda_i \in [0,1]$ for each $i\in [k]$, so along that subsequence $p_n \to \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i x_i \in P$, so $p\in P$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition and characterisation of vertices of a polytope, and $P = \conv (\cvert P)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $P$ is a polytope then $x\in P$ is called a \emph{vertex} of $P$ is $P\setminus \left\{ x ight\} $ is convex.
egin{lemma}
    If $P = \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $ for distinct $x_i\in \R^d$, then $x_1\in \cvert P$ iff $x_1 ot\in \conv\left\{ x_2, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $.
\end{lemma}
egin{proof}
    extbf{``$\implies$'':} If $x_1\in \cvert P$ then $P\setminus \left\{ x_1 ight\} $ is convex, so it contains $\conv \left\{ x_2, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $.

    extbf{``$\impliedby$'':} Suppose $x_1 ot\in \cvert P$, so there are $y,z \in P\setminus \left\{ x_1 ight\} $ and $\mu + \lambda = 1$ such that $\mu y + \lambda z = x_1$. Now $y$ and $z$ are convex combinations of $x_1, \ldots ,x_k$ with less than full weight on $x_1$ (otherwise $y = z = x_1$, a contradiction), so the LHS above is $(1-a)x_1 + X$ where $X$ is a combination of $x_2, \ldots ,x_k$ with total weight $a \in (0,1)$, rearranging gives $x_1 = X / a$, where the RHS is now a convex combination of $x_2, \ldots ,x_k$.
\end{proof}

egin{proposition}
    If $P$ is a polytope, then $P = \conv (\cvert P)$.
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    $P$ is convex and contains $\cvert P$, so $\supset $ is clear. For the other direction let $x_1, \ldots ,x_k$ be distinct points such that $P = \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $.  If $x_1 ot\in \cvert P$, then $x_1 \in \conv \left\{ x_2, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $, so $P = \conv \left\{ x_2, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $. This way we can successively remove points that are not vertices until we are left with a subset which still produces all of $P$ but consists only of vertices.

    (In fact those are all vertices. Indeed, if we had not $\cvert P \subset  \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $, then $P = \conv \left\{ x,x_1, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $, so $x ot\in \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k ight\} = P$.)
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Characterisation of a simplex.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    A convex set $A\subset \R^d$ is a ($k$-)simplex iff there are $x_0, \ldots ,x_k\in A$ such that every $x\in A$ is a unique convex combination of $x_0, \ldots ,x_k$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If $A = \conv \left\{ x_0, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $ is a simplex, then $x_i$ are affinely independent so convex combinations are unique. Conversely if the statement holds, then clearly $A = \conv \left\{ x_0, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $, and since all convex combinations are unique, $x_i$ must be affinely independent.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Radon's and Helly's theorems[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Radon]
    If $x_1, \ldots ,x_n$ are affinely independent, then there is a partition $I \dot J = [n]$ such that \[
    \conv x_I \cap \conv x_J \neq \emptyset
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    There are $\alpha_i \in \R$ such that \[
    \sum_i \alpha_i = 0,\qquad \sum_i \alpha_i x_i = 0.
\] Now let $I = \left\{ i\colon \alpha_i \ge 0 \right\} $ and $J = [n] \setminus I$.
\end{proof}
\begin{theorem}[Helly]
    If $(A_i)$ is a family of convex sets in $\R^d$ (if they are compact it may be infinite) such that every $d+1$ of them have non-empty intersection, then \[
    \bigcap_i A_i \neq \emptyset
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    For compact sets, finite intersections being non-empty implies full intersection being non-empty, so suppose there are $\infty>m > d + 1$ sets (if $m \le d+1$ there is nothing to show), and assume the claim is already true for smaller $m$. Then choose points \[
        x_i \in A_1 \cap \ldots \cap \check{A_i} \cap\ldots \cap A_m,
    \] which exist by hypothesis. Since $m \ge d+2$ these are affinely dependent, so take $I \dot J = [m]$ according to Radon's theorem, and let $x_0 \in \conv x_I \cap \conv x_J$. If $i\in I$ then $x_J \subset A_i$ and vice versa, so $x_0\in A_k$ for all $k\in [m]$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Carathéodory's theorem (characterisation of convex hull with simplices)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $x\in \R^d$ is a convex combination of $x_1, \ldots ,x_n$, then there is an affinely independent subset of which $x$ is also a convex combination.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose they are not yet affinely independent, we show that we can remove one of them. Suppose $x = \sum_i \alpha_i x_i$ with $\alpha_i \in (0,1]$ and $\sum_i \alpha_i = 1$, and that $\beta_i \in \R$ with $\sum_i \beta_i x_i = 0$ and $\sum_i \beta_i = 0$. Then choose $c > 0$ such that $\alpha_i + c \beta_i \ge 0$ for all $i$ and $\alpha_{i_0} + c \beta_{i_0} = 0$ for some index (among those with $\beta_i < 0$, the one for which $\left| \alpha_i / \beta_i \right| $ is smallest), so that $x = \sum_i (\alpha_i + c\beta_i) x_i$ is a convex combination using one less vertex.
\end{proof}

\begin{theorem}[Carathéodory]
    If $A\subset \R^d$ and $x\in \R^d$, then $x\in \conv A$ iff there is a simplex with vertices in $A$ containing $x$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    ``$\impliedby$'' is obvious. If $x\in \conv A$ then it is a convex combination of vertices in $A$, which we can choose affinely independent by the lemma. Then the polytope spanned by those is the desired simplex.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Definitions of $\dim A$, $\aff A$, $\cl A$, $\relint A$ for $A\subset \R^d$. Characterisation of $\relint A$ for a simplex $A$. In particular, $\relint A \neq \emptyset$ for a convex set $A\neq \emptyset$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{definition}
    egin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\aff(A)$ is the intersection of all affine spaces containing $A$,
        \item[(ii)] $\dim A = \dim (\aff A) $ is the largest $k\in \N_0$ for which there are affinely independent $x_0, \ldots ,x_k\in A$,
        \item[(iii)] $\cl A$ is the closure,
        \item[(iv)] $ elint A$ is the interior w.r.t.\ $\aff A$ as ambient space.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

egin{lemma}
    If $A = \conv \left\{ x_0, \ldots ,x_k ight\} $ is a simplex, then \[
        elint A = \left\{ \sum_{i=0}^k \alpha_i x_i\colon \alpha_i\in (0,1), \sum_i \alpha_i = 1 ight\} .
    \] In particular, if $B eq \emptyset$ is convex, then $ elint B eq \emptyset$.
\end{lemma}
egin{proof}
    The map \[
        \Phi\colon \R ^{k} o ext{lin} (x_1-x_0, \ldots ,x_k-x_0);\, eta \mapsto \sum_{i=1}^k eta_i (x_i-x_0)
    \] is a homeomorphism, and $\Phi^{-1}(A) = \left\{ eta \in [0,1]^{k}\colon \sum_i eta_i = 1 ight\}$, which has interior $\left\{ eta \in (0,1)^k\colon \sum_i eta_i = 1 ight\} $.

    If $B eq\emptyset$ is convex then it contains a simplex so we are done.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: If $A\subset \R^d$ is convex then when is $[y,x)\subset \relint A$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $A\subset \R^d$ is convex, $x\in \cl A$ and $y\in \relint A$ then $[y,x) \subset \relint A$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    WLOG $\dim A = d$. Let $y\in V \subset A$ be open, and $A\ni x_k \to x$, and $z = \alpha y + (1-\alpha) x$. Then if $y_k$ is such that $z = \alpha y_k + (1-\alpha) x_k$ then  $y_k \in V$ for large $k$, so $z \in \alpha V + (1-\alpha)x_k \subset A$ which is an open set.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Characterisation of $\cl A$ and $\relint A$ using rays $[x,y)$ for a convex set $A$.[/latex]
