front:
[latex]Convex geometry: \emph{Metric projection} $p(A,\cdot )\colon \R^d \to A$ for non-empty convex closed set $A$.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] How it can be used to separate $x\in \R^d\setminus A$ from $A$ with a hyperplane,
    \item[(ii)] $p(A,\cdot )$ is a contraction.
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $A\neq \emptyset$ is closed and convex, then for every $x\in \R^d$ there is a unique $p(A,x)\in A$ such that \[
        \left\|p(A,x) - x\right\| = \inf_{y\in A} \left\|y-x\right\|.
    \] Then $p(A,\cdot )$ is contractive, and the hyperplane through $x$ orthogonal to $x-p(A,x)$ supports $A$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If $y_k \in A$ approaches the infimum then $(y_k) \subset A \cap B(0,N)$ for some large $N$ so WLOG converges to some $y\in A$. Uniqueness follows because if $y_1,y_2\in A$ achieve the minimum then by Pythagoras, $y \coloneqq \frac{1}{2} (y_1+y_2)$ would be even better.

    If $x\in \R^d\setminus A$ and $a\in A$, then  $F(t)\coloneqq  \left\|(1-t)p(x) + ta - x\right\|^2$ for $t\in [0,1]$ has a global minimum at $t = 0$, so $F'(0) \ge 0$ which implies
    \begin{equation}\label{eq1}
        \forall x\in \R^d, a\in A\colon \left<a-p(x), x-p(x) \right> \le 0,
    \end{equation} (trivially true if $x\in A$) and thus implies that \[
    A \subset \left\{ z\in \R^d\colon \left<z-p(x),x-p(x) \right> \le 0 \right\}.
    \] Now let $x,y\in \R^d$. Then by Eq.\~(\ref{eq1}), $\left<p(y) - p(x),x-p(x) \right> \le 0$ and vice versa, adding those and rearranging gives \[
\left\|p(y)-p(x)\right\|^2 \le \left<p(y)-p(x),y-x \right> \le \left\|p(y)-p(x)\right\|\left\|y-x\right\|.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Definition of supporting hyperplanes/halfspace/point, and (proper) separation of sets. Characterisation of a closed convex set through its supporting halfspaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{definition}
    A hyperplane $E = \left\{ f = \alpha ight\} $ is a \emph{supporting hyperplane} of a closed and convex set if $E\cap A eq \emptyset $ and $A\subset \left\{ f\le \alpha ight\} $ or $A\subset \left\{ f \ge \alpha ight\} $. The halfspace containing $A$ is a \emph{supporting halfspace}, points in $A\cap E$ are \emph{supporting points}.

    We say that $E$ \emph{separates} two sets $A,B\subset \R^d$ if $A\subset \left\{ f\le \alpha ight\} $ and $B\subset \left\{ f\ge \alpha ight\} $ (or vice versa). It separates them \emph{properly} if not both $A$ and $B$ are subsets of $E$.
\end{definition}

egin{proposition}
    A closed convex set $A eq \emptyset $ is the intersection of its supporting halfspaces.
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    It is obviously a subset, and if $x ot\in A$ then it can be separated from $A$ (using the metric projection).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Separation theorem (characterisation of proper separability of two convex sets).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $A,B\subset \R^d$ are non-empty and convex, then they can be properly separated iff $\relint A\cap \relint B = \emptyset $.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    ``$\implies $'' is clear. For the converse, note that $0 \not\in  \relint A - \relint B = \relint (A-B)$. Hence (whether $0\in \cl(A-B)$ or not), there is a hyperplane $\left\{ f = 0 \right\} $ separating $0$ from $\cl(A-B) \subset \left\{ f\le 0 \right\} $. Then, $f(a) \le f(b)$ for $a\in A$ and $b\in B$, so $\alpha \coloneqq \sup_{a\in A} f(a) \le \inf_{b\in B}f(b)$, so \[
    A\subset \left\{ f\le \alpha \right\} ,\qquad B\subset \left\{ f \ge \alpha \right\} .
\] If we first do this in the ambient space of $A \cup B $, then this must be properly separating (otherwise $A\cup B$ had not full dimension in its ambient space), and we can extend it by adding orthogonal dimensions to the hyperplane.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]A subset of a metric space is sequentially compact iff it is compact.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $M$ is a metric space, then $K\subset M$ is compact iff it is sequentially compact.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    \textbf{``$\implies$'':} Suppose it was not, so that there was a sequence $(x_n)$ without accumulation points. Then for every $x\in K$ there is a ball $B_x \ni x$ such that $x_n \in B_x$ for at most finitely many $n$. Then $K\subset \bigcup_{x\in K} B_x$ can be reduced to a finite subcover, but then $x_n \in K$ for only finitely many $n$, a contradiction.

    \textbf{``$\impliedby$'':} Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a family of open sets covering $K$ and assume there is no finite subcover. Since $K$ is sequentially compact it is totally bounded, so for every $n\in \N$ there is a ball $B_n = B(x_n, 1 / n)$ such that $B_n \cap K$ cannot be covered by a finite subset of $\mathcal{C}$. Then $x_n$ has an accumulation point $\widehat{x}\in K$, and there must be $\widehat{x}\in O \in \mathcal{C}$, but then $B_n \subset O$ for sufficiently large $n$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]A finite-dimensional subspace of a normed space is closed.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $Y$ is a finite-dimensional subspace of a normed space $X$, then $Y$ is closed.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $b_1, \ldots ,b_n \in Y$ be a basis of $Y$, and let $\widetilde{y} \in \R^n$ for $y\in Y$ be the unique coefficient vector of $y$ (i.e.\ $y = \sum_i \widetilde{y}_i b_i$), and put $\left\|\widetilde{y}\right\|\coloneqq \left\|y\right\|$, so that $(\R^n,\left\|\cdot \right\|)$ is a normed space, which must be complete. Then if $Y \in y_n \to x\in X$, then $(y_n)$ is Cauchy, hence so is $(\widetilde{y}_n)$, so $\widetilde{y_n} \to \widetilde{y}\in \R^n$, and if $y\coloneqq \sum_i \widetilde{y}_i b_i\in Y$ then \[
    \left\|y - y_n\right\| = \left\|\widetilde{y} - \widetilde{y}_n\right\| \to 0,
    \] so $x = y\in Y$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $Y$ is a proper closed linear subspace of a normed space $X$, then $\overline{B}(0,1) \not\subset Y^\delta$ for any $\delta < 1$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $X$ is a normed space and $Y\subsetneq  X$ a closed linear subspace, then for every $\delta \in (0,1)$, \[
        \overline{B}(0,1) \not\subset Y^\delta,
    \] where $Y^\delta = \left\{ x\in X\colon \left\|x - Y\right\|< \delta \right\} $.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $x\in X\setminus Y$, then $d\coloneqq \left\|x-Y\right\|> 0$ (because $X\setminus Y$ is open). Let $y\in Y$ and put $\overline{x}\coloneqq \frac{x-y}{\left\|x-y\right\|}$. Then $\left\|\overline{x}\right\|=1$ and for any $\overline{y}\in Y$,
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|\overline{x}-\overline{y}\right\|
        &= \frac{1}{\left\|x-y\right\|} \left\|x-(y+\left\|x-y\right\|\overline{y})\right\| \ge \frac{d}{\left\|x-y\right\|},
    \end{align*}
    which we can make $\ge \delta$ for any $\delta \in (0,1)$ by choosing $y$ appropriately.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $X$ is a metric space, then $\overline{B}(0,1)$ is compact iff $\dim X < \infty$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a metric space, then $\overline{B}(0,1)$ is compact iff $\dim X < \infty$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    ``$\implies$'' is clear. Choose $x_1 \in \partial B(0,1)$. Now suppose $x_1,\ldots,x_n$ have been chosen, then $Y_n\coloneqq \left<x_1,\ldots,x_n\right>$ is a finite dimensional (hence proper and closed) linear subspace of $X$, so we can choose $x_{n+1} \in \partial B(0,1)$ with $\left\|x_{n+1}-Y_n\right\| \ge 1 / 2$. Then we inductively obtain a sequence $(x_n) \subset \partial B(0,1)$ with $\left\|x_n - x_m\right\|\ge 1 / 2$ for all $n\neq  m$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Characterisation of $0$-support sets and representation of all support sets of a polytope.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $P\subset \R^d$ be a polytope.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] The $0$-support sets of $P$ are exactly $\left\{ x \right\} $ for $x\in \cvert P$,
        \item[(ii)] If $F$ is a support set of $P$, then $F = \conv (F \cap \cvert P)$.
    \end{enumerate}
    In particular, every support set is a polytope and there are only finitely many.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $\left\{ x \right\} $ is a support set with half space $\left\{ f\le \beta \right\} $, then $x\in P$ and $P\setminus \left\{ x \right\} = P \cap \left\{ f < \beta \right\} $ is convex. Conversely, if $x$ is a vertex (and $x_1, \ldots ,x_k$ are the others), then let $Q \coloneqq \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $, and $y \in (x,p(Q,x)) $, and $\left\{ f\le \beta \right\} $ the half space separating $\left\{ y \right\} $ and $Q$ going through $y$ orthogonal to $y-p(y)$. Then $\alpha \coloneqq f(x) > \beta$, and we claim that $ \left\{ f \le \alpha \right\} $ is a support plane going through $x$. It clearly contains $x$, now suppose $z \in P $, then \[
                f(z) = \sum_{i=1}^k \mu_i \underbrace{f(x_i)}_{<\alpha} + \mu \underbrace{f(x)}_{=\alpha} \le \alpha,
        \] and equality holds iff $z = x$.
    \item[(ii)] Suppose $\cvert P = \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $ and exactly the first $1\le m \le k$ lie in a support set $F = P \cap \left\{ f\le \alpha \right\} $ of $P$. Then for any $z = \sum_{i=1}^k \mu_i x_i \in P$, \[
            f(z) = \sum_{i\le m} \mu_i \underbrace{f(x_i)}_{=\alpha} + \sum_{i > m} \mu_i \underbrace{f(x_i)}_{< \alpha},
        \] so $z\in F$ iff $f(z) = \alpha$ iff $z \in \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_m \right\} $.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Polytopes are polyhedral sets.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Every polytope is a polyhedral set.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Assume $\dim P = d$. Let $F_1, \ldots ,F_m$ be the support sets of $P$ and $H_1, \ldots ,H_m$ the corresponding half spaces. Then, \[
    P \subset \bigcup_{i=1} ^m H_i \eqqcolon P',
\] and it suffices to show the opposite inclusion. Suppose there was $x\in P'\setminus P$, take $y\in \relint P$, so that there is a unique $z\in (y,x) \cap \bd P$. By the support theorem there is an $i\in [m]$ such that $z\in \bd H_i$, but also $y,x \in \text{int} H_i$, so $z\in \text{int} H_i$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Extremal and exposed points of a convex set $A$, their relation, and the case where $A$ is a polytope.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Let $A\subset \R^d$ be closed and convex. Then $x\in A$ is called
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] an \emph{extremal point} of $A$, written $x\in \ext A$, if $A\setminus \left\{ x \right\} $ is convex, i.e.\ if $x$ cannot be written as non-trivial convex combination of points in $A$,
        \item[(ii)] an \emph{exposed point} of $A$, written $x\in \exp A$, if $\left\{ x \right\} $ is a support set of $A$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
\begin{proposition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $\exp A \subset \ext A$,
        \item[(ii)] If $A$ is a polytope, then $\exp A = \ext A = \cvert A$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $\left\{ x \right\}  = A \cap \left\{ f = \alpha \right\} $ and $A \subset \left\{ f\le \alpha \right\} $, then $A\setminus \left\{ x \right\} = A \cap \left\{ f < \alpha \right\} $ is convex.
        \item[(ii)] $\ext A = \cvert A$ by definition, and $\cvert A \subset \exp A$ by the support theorem.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Minkowski's theorem (on $\ext K$ for compact convex $K$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Minkowski]
    If $K\subset \R^d$ is compact and convex, and $A\subset K$, then $K = \conv A$ iff $\ext K \subset A$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Clearly it is necessary that $\ext K \subset A$ (otherwise $\conv A \subset K \setminus \left\{ x \right\} $), so it STS that $K = \conv \ext K$, which we prove by induction on $d$. If $d = 1$ then $K = [a,b]$ and $\ext K = \left\{ a,b \right\} $. Now suppose $d \ge 2$. Let $x\in K$, take an arbitrary line $g$ through $K$, then $g\cap K = [y,z]$ and $y,z\in \bd K$. Then there are supporting hyperplanes $E_y,E_z$ of $K$, and $K_y \coloneqq K \cap E_y = \conv \ext K_y$ by induction hypothesis, same for $z$. It is easy to see that $\ext K_y \subset \ext K$, so
    \begin{align*}
        x \in [y,z]
        &\subset \conv \left(K_y \cup K_z  \right) = \conv \left( \conv \ext K_y \cup \conv \ext K_z \right) \\
        &\subset \conv \ext K.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Characterisation of polytopes via $\ext P$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    A compact convex set $P\subset \R^d$ is a polytope iff $\ext P $ is finite.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If $P$ is a polytope, then $\ext P = \cvert P$ is finite. If $\ext P = \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $ is finite, then $P = \conv \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_k \right\} $ is a polytope.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of compact sets in $\ell^p$ for $p \in [1,\infty)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    $A\subset \ell^p$ is relatively compact iff it is bounded and \[
    \sup_{x\in A} \sum_{k=n}^\infty \left| x_k \right| ^p \tendsto{} 0,\quad n\to \infty.
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Clearly this is necessary (otherwise there was a sequence without a converging subsequence). Now suppose this is satisfied, then it STS that $A$ is totally bounded. Let $\varepsilon > 0$ and choose $N\in \N$ such that $\sup_{x\in A} \left(\sum_{k > N} \left| x_k \right| ^p\right)^{1 / p} < \varepsilon$. Then $A \subset (\left\{ (x_1, \ldots ,x_N,0, \ldots )\colon x\in A \right\})^\varepsilon $, so it STS that $\pi_N(A) \subset \R^N$ is totally bounded, which is clear because it is bounded.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Arzela-Ascoli. In particular, compact embeddings of Hölder spaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $K$ is a compact metric space, then $A\subset C(K)$ is relatively compact iff it is bounded and \emph{equicontinuous}, i.e.\ \[
        \sup_{x\in A} \omega(x,\delta) \tendsto{} 0,\quad \delta \to 0.
    \] In particular, $C^{0,\alpha(K)} \hookrightarrow C(K)$ is compact for all $\alpha \in (0,1]$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    \textbf{``$\implies$'':} If $A$ is relatively compact then it is totally bounded, hence bounded. Now since $\sup_A \le \sup_{\overline{A}}$, we may assume $A$ is compact. Then since $\omega(\cdot ,\delta)\colon C(K) \to \R$ is continuous we can for every $\varepsilon > 0$ cover $A$ in finitely many balls $B_i$ such that $\sup_{x\in B_i} \omega(x,\delta_i) < \varepsilon$, so if $\delta \coloneqq \min_i \delta_i$ then \[
        \sup_{x\in A} \omega(x,\delta) < \varepsilon.
    \]

    \textbf{``$\impliedby$'':} For $N\in \N$ let $\delta_N$ be according to equicontinuity of $A$ and cover $K$ in finitely many balls with radius $\delta_N$ and let $S_N$ be their centres. Now if $(x_n) \subset A$ is a sequence, then $(x_n(s))_{n\in \N}$ is bounded for every $s \in \bigcup_{N\in \N} S_N$ so has a convergent subsequence, so we find a subsequence (denoted the same) such that $x_n(s)$ converges as $n\to \infty$ for all such $s$. Now if $\varepsilon > 0$ take $N > 1 / \delta$, and then take $n_0\in \N$ so large that $\left| x_n(s) - x_m(s) \right| < \varepsilon$ for all $n,m\ge n_0$ and $s\in S_N$. Then if $t\in K$ it is in $B(s,\delta_N)$ for some $s\in S_N$ so
    \begin{align*}
        \left| x_n(t) - x_m(t) \right|
        &\le \left| x_n(t) - x_n(s) \right| + \left| x_n(s) - x_m(s) \right| + \left| x_m(s) - x_m(t) \right| < 3\varepsilon
    \end{align*}
    for all $n,m\ge n_0$ independent of $t$, so this is a Cauchy sequence so $A$ is totally bounded hence relatively compact because $C(K)$ is complete.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $k\in C([0,1]^2)$, then $T\colon C([0,1]) \to C([0,1]);\, f \mapsto  \int_0^1 k(\cdot ,s) f(s)\dd s$ is compact.[/latex]

\begin{proof}

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Bounded polyhedral sets are polytopes.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proof}
    K is convex and compact, so it STS that $\ext K$ is finite. Let $H_1, \ldots ,H_m$ be the half spaces with boundary planes $E_1, \ldots ,E_m$. Let $x\in \ext K$ and put \[

\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: How to obtain (compact convex) $K\subset \R^d$ from $\exp K$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $K\subset \R^d$ is compact and convex, then \[
    K = \cl \conv \exp K.
    \] In particular, \[
    \exp K \subset \ext K \subset \cl \exp K.
    \]
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}[Proof of Proposition]
    For $z\in \R^d$ let $y_z \in K$ be the furthest point from $z$ in $K$, then the hyperplane $E$ through $y_z$ orthogonal to $z-y_z$ supports $K$ and $E\cap K = \left\{ y_z \right\} $, so $y_z \in \exp K$. It thus STS that if \[
    \widehat{K}\coloneqq \cl \conv \left\{ y_z\colon z\in \R^d \right\}
\] then $K\subset \widehat{K}$. Suppose for contradiction that there is $x \in K\setminus \widehat{K}$. Then along the line $s = x + [0,\infty)\cdot (\overline{x}-x)$ where $\overline{x} = p(x,\widehat{K})$ (exists because $\widehat{K}$ is closed) we find a point $z\in \R^d$ for which $\sup_{y\in \widehat{K}}\left| z-y \right| < \left| z-x \right| $, but this is a contradiction because $\left| z-x \right| < \left| z-y_z \right| $ and $y_z \in \widehat{K}$.

    In particular, \[
    K = \cl \conv \exp K \subset \cl \conv \cl \exp K = \conv \cl \exp K,
    \] so $\ext K \subset \cl \exp K$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Definition of convex and quasi-convex functions and characterisation. Characterisation of convexity for a positively homogenous function.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    A function $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is called
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] \emph{convex} if \[
                \epi f \coloneqq \bigcup_{x\in \R^d} \left\{ x \right\} \times [f(x),\infty) \subset \R ^{d+1}
            \] is convex, iff $f(\alpha x + (1-\alpha) y) \le \alpha f(x) + (1-\alpha) f(y)$ for all $\alpha \in [0,1]$ and $x,y\in \R^d$.
        \item[(ii)] \emph{quasi-convex} if $\left\{ f\le \alpha \right\} $ is convex for all $\alpha \in \R$ iff $f(\alpha x + (1-\alpha) y) \le f(x) \vee f(y)$ for all $\alpha \in [0,1]$ and $x,y\in \R^d$.
        \item[(iii)] \emph{positively homogenous} if $f(\alpha x) = \alpha f(x)$ for all $x\in \R^d$ and $\alpha \ge 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{definition}

Then convex functions are quasi-convex, and a positively homogenous function is convex iff it is sub-additive.

\begin{proof}
    Everything is sort of clear except maybe the claim with the homogenous functions. Suppose it is sub-additive, then \[
        f(\alpha x + (1-\alpha) y) \le f(\alpha x) + f((1-\alpha)y) = \alpha f(x) + (1-\alpha) f(y).
    \] Suppose it is convex, then \[
    f(x+y) = 2 f( \frac{1}{2} (x+y)) \le 2 (\frac{1}{2} f(x) + \frac{1}{2} f(y)) = f(x) + f(y).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]How to obtain a convex function $f_A \colon \R^d \to \R$ from a convex set $A \subset \R \times \R ^{d+1}$. How does $A$ relate to $\epi f_A$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    If $A$ is convex and $A_x \coloneqq \left\{ \alpha \colon (x,\alpha) \in A \right\} $ is bounded from below for all $x\in \R^d$, then \[
    f_A\colon \R^d \to \R; \, x \mapsto \inf A_x
\] is convex. Then $A \subset \epi f_A$ and equality holds iff $A_x = [\inf A_x,\infty)$ for all $x\in \R^d$.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $x,y\in \R^d$ and $\alpha \in (0,1)$, may assume that $f_A(x) , f_A(y) < \infty$, and $\inf A_x \in A_x$, same for $y$ (otherwise use $\varepsilon$'s). Then, \[
        A \ni \alpha (x,f_A(x)) + (1-\alpha) (y,f_A(y)) = (\alpha x + (1-\alpha) y, \alpha f_A(x) + (1-\alpha) f_A(y)),
    \] so $f_A(\alpha x + (1-\alpha) y) \le \alpha f_A(x) + (1-\alpha) f_A(y)$.

    By definition, $\epi f_A = \bigcup_{x\in \R^d} \left\{ x \right\} \times [f_A(x),\infty) \supset A$, and the final claim follows.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Closure of a convex function.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is convex, then there is a unique convex function $\cl f$ with $\epi \cl f = \cl \epi f$. Then $\cl f \le f$ and for any closed convex $g \le f$ we have $g \le \cl f$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $A \coloneqq \cl \epi f$ and consider the convex function $f_A \colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ (we have $f_A \ge h > -\infty$ for any affine function $h \le f$ so this is well-defined). If we can show that $A_x = [f_A(x),\infty)$ for all $x \in \R^d$ then $\epi f_A = A$ and so the first claim holds. Indeed, if $x\in \R^d$ and $b \in [f_A(x),\infty)$ (assume $f_A(x) < \infty$, otherwise $A_x = \emptyset =[f_A(x),\infty)$), then there are $\epi f \ni (x_n,b_n) \to (x,f_A(x))$, so \[
        \epi f \ni (x_n,b_n \vee b) \to (x, b),
    \] so $(x,b) \in A$, so $b \in A_x$.

    Finally, $\cl \epi f \supset \epi f$ implies $\cl f \le f$, and if $g\le f$ is closed and convex, then $\epi g \supset \epi f$ is closed, so $\epi g \supset \cl \epi f = \epi \cl f$, so $g \le \cl f$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: $\cl f = \sup \left\{ h\colon h\le f \text{ affine} \right\} $ for any convex $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is convex, then $\cl f = \sup \left\{ h\colon h \le f \text{ affine} \right\} $.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Note that $h\le f$ iff $h\le \cl f$ for any affine $h$, so we may assume that $f$ is closed. It suffices to show that any $(x,b) \not\in \epi f$ can be separated from $\epi f$ with a \emph{non-vertical} hyperplane. We know that any such $(x_0,b_0)$ can be strongly separated using some hyperplane $\left\{ I_0 \le 0 \right\} $, say, so suppose it is a vertical one then we must have $x_0\not\in \dom f$ and we can wish for $I_0(x_0) > 0$ and $I_0(x) \le 0$ for all $x\in \dom f$. Now take any affine function $I_1 \le f$ (f.ex.\ by separating $(x,f(x)-1)$ from $\epi f$ for any $x\in \dom f$), so that \[
    h_a \coloneqq a I_0 + I_1 \le f \quad \forall a > 0.
\] Furthermore, $h_a(x_0) = aI_0(x_0) + I_1(x_0) > b_0$ for sufficiently large $a$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Definition and properties of complex conjugate $f^\star$, and what is $f^{\star\star}$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ be proper and convex. Then the \emph{convex conjugate} of $f$ is \[
        f^\star(y) = \sup_{x\in \R^d} \left( \left<x,y \right> -f(x) \right) ,\quad y\in \R^d.
        \] Then $f^\star\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is closed, proper, and convex, and  \[
    f^{\star \star} = \cl f.
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    $f^\star >-\infty$ because $f$ is proper, and $f^\star$ is closed and convex as supremum of affine (hence closed and convex) functions. To see that $f^\star$ is proper, note that for any affine function $h = \left<y,\cdot  \right> -\alpha \le f$, we have \[
        f^\star(y) \le \sup_{x\in \R^d} \left( \left<y,x \right>  - (\left<y,x \right> -\alpha) \right) = \alpha.
    \] Now let $x\in \R^d$, then
    \begin{align*}
        f^{\star \star}(x)
        &= \sup_{y\in \R^d} \left( \left<y,x \right> - \sup_{z\in \R^d} \left( \left<z,y \right> - f(z) \right)  \right) \\
        &\le \sup_{y\in \R^d} \left( \left<y,x \right> - (\left<x,y \right> -f(x)) \right) \\
        &= f(x).
    \end{align*}
    Now let $h = \left<y,\cdot  \right> -\alpha \le f$, then $f^\star(y) \le \alpha$, so \[
        f^{\star\star}(x) = \sup_{y\in \R^d} \left( \left<z,x \right> -f^\star(z) \right) \ge \left<y,x \right> -\alpha = h,
    \] so $f^{\star\star} \ge \sup \left\{ h\colon h\le f \text{ affine} \right\} = \cl f$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Lipschitz continuity of convex functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is convex, then it is uniformly Lipschitz on compact subsets of $\interior \dom f$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    First note that $f$ is locally bounded in $D \coloneqq \interior \dom f$: If $x\in D$ then there is a simplex $P = \left<x_0, \ldots ,x_n \right> \subset D$ such that $x\in \interior P$, and $\sup_{x\in P}\left| f(x) \right|  \le \max_{i = 0, \ldots ,n} \left| f(x_i) \right| $ by convexity.

    Let $A \subset \interior\dom f$ be compact. Then there is an $\varepsilon > 0$ such that $A^\varepsilon \subset \interior \dom f$ (take $\varepsilon = d(A,(\interior \dom f)^{c}) / 2$), and $C \coloneqq \sup_{x\in A} \left| f(x) \right| < \infty$. Let $x,y \in A$ with $\left| x-y \right| \le \varepsilon$. Then there is $z \in \partial B(x,\varepsilon)$ such that $y = (1-\alpha) x + \alpha z$ where $ \left| x-y \right| = \alpha \varepsilon$ (go along $x \to y$ until distance $\varepsilon$), so \[
        f(y) \le (1-\alpha) f(x) + \alpha f(z) \iff f(y) - f(x) \le \alpha (f(z) - f(x)) \le \frac{2C}{\varepsilon} \left| x-y \right| .
    \] By symmetry, we obtain \[
    \left| f(x) - f(y) \right| \le \frac{2C}{\varepsilon} \left| x-y \right| ,
    \] for all $x,y\in A$ with $\left| x-y \right| < \varepsilon$. If $\left| x-y \right| \ge \varepsilon$, this holds automatically.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Elementary characterisation of boundedness for linear operator between normed spaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ and $Y$ are normed spaces, and $T\colon X \to Y$ is linear, then TFAE:
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $T$ is Lipschitz continuous,
        \item[(ii)] $T$ is continuous,
        \item[(iii)] $T$ is continuous at zero,
        \item[(iv)] $T$ is bounded.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    (i) $\implies$ (ii) $\implies$ (iii) and (iv) $\implies$ (i) are clear. Assume $T$ is continuous at zero, so since $T0 = 0$ there is $\delta > 0$ with $T \overline{B}(0,\delta) \subset B(0,1)$. Then if $x\in X $, \[
        \left\|T x\right\| = \frac{\left\|x\right\|}{\delta} \left\|T \left( \delta \frac{x}{\left\|x\right\|} \right) \right\| \le \frac{\left\|x\right\|}{\delta}.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]When is $\mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ a Banach space.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $X$ is a normed space and $Y$ is a Banach space, then $\mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ is a Banach space. In particular, $X^\star$ is a Banach space.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $(T_n)\subset \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ is a Cauchy sequence. Then for any $x\in X$, \[
    \left\|T_n x - T_m x\right\|\le \left\|T_n - T_m\right\| \left\|x\right\|,
\] so $(T_n x) \subset Y$ is Cauchy, so $Tx \coloneqq \lim_{n\to \infty} T_n x$ exists. Clearly $T$ is linear, and $\left\|T x\right\| \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_n x\right\| \le (\sup_{n\in \N} \left\|T_n\right\|) \left\|x\right\|$, so $T\in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$. Finally, for any $x\in X$ with $\left\|x\right\| = 1$, \[
\left\| T_n x - T x\right\| \le \varliminf_{m\to \infty} \left\|T_n x - T_m x\right\|\le \varliminf_{m\to \infty} \left\|T_n - T_m\right\| \tendsto{} 0,\quad n \to \infty,
\] and the upper bound does not depend on $x$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Sufficient condition for the range of $T \in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ to be closed.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $X$ is a Banach space and $Y$ normed, and $T \in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ satisfies $\left\|Tx\right\|\ge c \left\|x\right\|$ for some $c > 0$, then $R(T)$ is closed.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $x_n \in X$ such that $T x_n \to y$ in $Y$. Then, \[
    \left\|x_n - x_m\right\| \le \frac{1}{c} \left\|T_n - T_m\right\|,\quad n,m\in \N,
\] so $(x_n)$ is Cauchy, so $x_n \to x$, so \[
y = \lim_{n\to \infty} T x_n = T x \in R(T).
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $\mu \in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$ and $f \in C^1(\R)$ with $f(-\infty) = 0$, how can you express $\mu(f)$ in terms of $\mu(\cdot  \ge t)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\mu \in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$ and $f\in C^1(\R)$ is increasing, then \[
        \mu(f) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f'(t) \mu( (t,\infty)) \dd t.
    \]
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    We have
    \begin{align*}
        \mu(f)
        &= \int f(x) \mu(\dd x) = \int \int_{-\infty}^\infty f'(s) \ind_{\left\{ s \le x \right\} } \dd s\, \mu(\dd x) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f'(s) \mu(\cdot \ge s) \dd s.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]In a separable normed space, the Borel sigma algebra is generated by cylindrical sets.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is a normed vector space, then its Borel $\sigma$-algebra is generated by the \emph{cylindrical} sets \[
        \mathcal{M} \coloneqq \left\{\bigcap_{i=1} ^k \ell_i^{-1}(B_i) \colon  k\in \N, \ell_1, \ldots ,\ell_k \in X^\star, B_1, \ldots ,B_k \in \B(\R)\right\}.
    \] Furthermore, $\mathcal{M}$ is a $\pi$-system that contains $B$, and is invariant under dilations and translations.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    $\mathcal{M}$ is clearly a $\pi$-system, and $\ell^{-1}(\R) = B$ for any $\ell\in B^\star$. Now if $\ell_i \in B^\star$, $B_i \in \B(\R)$, and $\alpha > 0$, $x_0\in B$, then
    \begin{align*}
        x \in \alpha \left( \bigcap_{i=1} ^k \ell_i^{-1}(B_i) \right) + x_0
        &\iff \forall i \in [k]\colon \frac{x}{\alpha} - x_0 \in \ell_i^{-1}(B_i)\\
        &\iff \forall i\in [k]\colon  \frac{1}{\alpha} \ell_i(x) - \ell(x_0) \in B_i\\
        &\iff x \in \bigcap_{i=1} ^k \ell_i^{-1} \big( \alpha(B_i + \ell(x_0))\big) \in \mathcal{M}.
    \end{align*}
    Then if $\varphi$ is an affine map, $\varphi^{-1} (\sigma(\mathcal{M})) = \sigma (\varphi^{-1}(\mathcal{M})) = \sigma(\mathcal{M})$, so both $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{E}\coloneqq \sigma(\mathcal{M})$ are invariant under tranlsations and dilations.

    Since $X$ is separable, every open set is a countable union of closed balls, so it suffices to show that $\mathcal{E}$ contains closed balls. Since $\mathcal{M}$ and hence $\mathcal{E}$ are invariant under translations and dilations, it suffices to show that $B(0,1) \in \mathcal{E}$. For that purpose let $D $ be a dense subset of $\partial B(0,1)$, and let $\ell_x \in B^\star$ with $\left\|\ell_x\right\| = 1$ and $\ell_x(x) = 1$ (Hahn-Banach) for $x\in D$. Then put \[
        E \coloneqq \left\{ x\in B\colon \left|\ell_y(x)\right| \le 1 \forall y\in D \right\} = \bigcap_{y\in D} \ell_y^{-1} ([-1,1]) \in \mathcal{E}.
    \] Clearly, $\overline{B}(0,1) \subset E$, so need to show that if $\left\|x\right\| > 1$ then $x\not\in E$. In that case, let $\widehat{x} \coloneqq x / \left\|x\right\|$ and $D\ni x_{n}\to x$. Then, putting $\ell_n \coloneqq \ell_{x_n}$, \[
    \left| \ell_n(\widehat{x}) - 1 \right| =\left| \ell_n(\widehat{x}) - \ell_n(x_n) \right| \le \left\|\widehat{x} - x_n\right\| \to 0,
\] so $\ell_n(x) = \left\|x\right\| \ell_n(\widehat{x}) > 1$ for large $n$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of probability measure on separable normed space by one-dimensional distributions and its Fourier transform.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{proposition}
    If $\mu, u$ are probability measures on a separable normed space such that $\ell^\star \mu = \ell^\star u$ for all $\ell\in B^\star$, then $\mu = u$. In particular, $\mu$ is uniquely determined by its \emph{Fourier transform} \[
        \widehat{\mu}\colon X^\star o \R;\, \ell\mapsto \int_X \e^{\i \ell(x)}\mu(\dd x).
    \]
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    First note that if $k\in \N$ and $\ell_1, \ldots ,\ell_k \in B^\star$, then for any $\alpha \in \R^k$, \[
        \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha_i \ell_i^\star \mu = \left( \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha_i \ell_i ight) ^\star \mu = \sum_{i=1}^k \alpha_i \ell_i^\star u,
    \] so that $(\ell_1, \ldots ,\ell_k)^\star \mu = (\ell_1, \ldots ,\ell_k)^\star u$ as measures in $\R^k$. Thus $\mu$ and $ u$ coincide on cylindrical sets $ igcap_{i=1} ^k \ell_i^{-1}(B_i)$ for $B_i \in \B(\R)$, which are a $\pi$-generator of $\B(B)$ that contains $B$, so $\mu = u$ by uniqueness of measures. Finally, the Fourier transform characterises $\ell^\star \mu$ for all $\ell\in X^\star$ and hence $\mu$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of Gaussian probability measure on separable Banach space and its covariance operator. What is its Fourier transform, and its finite-dimensional distributions?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    A Borel probability measure $\mu$ on a separable Banach space $B$ is called a \emph{(centred) Gaussian measure} if $\ell^\star \mu \in \mathcal{M}_1(\R)$ is (centred) Gaussian for all $\ell\in B^\star$. Its \emph{covariance operator} is \[
        C_\mu\colon B^{\star}\times B^{\star}\to \R;\, (\ell,\ell') \mapsto \int \ell(x) \ell'(x) \mu(\dd x),
        \] which can also be written as $C_\mu(\ell,\ell') = \ell'(\widehat{C}_\mu \ell)$ where \[
        \widehat{C}_\mu \colon B^\star \to B;\, \ell \mapsto \int x \ell(x) \mu(\dd x). \qquad \textup{\tiny (Bochner integral)}
        \] ($C_\mu$ and $\widehat{C}_\mu$ are well-defined and bounded because $\int \left\|x\right\|^2 \mu(\dd x) < \infty$.) This is in fact a compact operator! One can show that there exists $m = m(\mu) \in B$, called its \emph{mean}, such that \[
    \forall \ell\in B^\star\colon \ell(m) = \int \ell(x) \mu(\dd x).
    \] Then $\mu$ is centred iff $m = 0$.
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}
    If $\mu$ is centred Gaussian and $\ell_1, \ldots ,\ell_k \in B^\star$ and $T \coloneqq (\ell_1, \ldots ,\ell_k) \colon B \to \R^k$, then \[
        T^\star \mu = \mathcal{N}(0,K),
    \] where $K_{ij} = C_\mu(\ell_i,\ell_j)$. Furthermore, \[
    \widehat{\mu}(\ell) = \e^{-\frac{1}{2} C_\mu(\ell,\ell)}.
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    By definition, $T^\star \mu$ is Gaussian, so it suffices to find mean and covariance. Indeed, $\ell_i^\star \mu$ is centred and $\int \ell_i(x) \ell_j(x) \mu(\dd x) = C_\mu(\ell_i,\ell_j)$ by definition of $C_\mu$. This implies the second claim by the well-known Fourier transform of the one-dimensional Guassian.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Rotation invariance of centred Gaussian measure $\mu\otimes \mu$ on $B\times B$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\mu$ is a centred Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$, and \[
        R \colon B\times B \to B\times B;\, (x,y) \mapsto (x \sin \varphi + y\cos \varphi, x \cos \varphi - y \sin \varphi),
    \] then $R^\star (\mu \otimes \mu) = \mu \otimes \mu$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    It suffices to show equality of Fourier transforms. If $\ell \in (B\times B)^\star$ then $\ell(x,y) = \ell_1(x) + \ell_2(y)$ where $\ell_1 = \ell(\cdot ,0) \in B^\star$ and $\ell_2\coloneqq \ell(0,\cdot )$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \widehat{R^\star (\mu \otimes \mu)}(\ell)
        &= \int \e^{\i \ell(R(x,y))}(\mu\otimes \mu)(\dd x,\dd y)\\
        &= \int \e^{\i (\sin\varphi \ell_1 + \cos\varphi \ell_2)(x)} \mu(\dd x) \int\e^{\i (\cos \varphi \ell_1 - \sin \varphi \ell_2)(y)} \mu(\dd y)\\
        &= \exp \left( -\frac{1}{2} \Big(C_\mu(\sin\varphi \ell_1 + \cos \varphi \ell_2,.) + C_\mu(\cos\varphi \ell_1 - \sin \varphi \ell_2,.)\Big) \right) \\
        &= \exp \left( -\frac{1}{2} \left( C_\mu(\ell_1,\ell_1) + C_\mu (\ell_2,\ell_2) \right)  \right) \\
        &= \widehat{\mu \otimes \mu} (\ell).
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Fernique's theorem (on tails of rotation invariant measures), and corollary on moments.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Fernique]
    Let $\mu$ be a probability measure on a normed space $X$, such that $\mu \otimes \mu$ is invariant under rotation by $\frac{\pi}{4}$ (for example a centred Gaussian measure). Then there is $\alpha > 0$ such that $\int \e^{\alpha \left\|x\right\|^2}\mu(\dd x) < \infty$. In fact, \[
        \sup_\mu \int \e^{\alpha (\left\|x\right\| / M_\mu)^2} \mu(\dd x) < \infty,
    \] where $M_\mu = \int \left\|x\right\|\mu(\dd x)$ and the supremum is over all $\mu$ satisfying the assumptions. In particular, \[
    \int \left\|x\right\|^{2k} \mu(\dd x) \le c(k)M_\mu^{2k},\quad k\in \N,
\] for universal constants $c(k) = K k! \alpha^{-k}$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
    The magic ingredient is this: If $0 < t < \tau$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \mu(\left\|x\right\| > t) \mu(\left\|y\right\| < \tau)
        &= (\mu\otimes \mu) ( \left\{ \left\|x\right\|> t, \left\|y\right\|<\tau \right\} )\\
        &= \mu \left( \left\{ \left\|\frac{x+y}{\sqrt{2} }\right\| > t, \left\|\frac{x-y}{\sqrt{2} }\right\| > t\right\} \right) \\
        &\le \mu \left( \left\{ \left\|x\right\|\wedge \left\|y\right\|\ge \frac{t-\tau}{\sqrt{2} } \right\}  \right) \\
        &= \mu \left( \left\|x\right\| \ge \frac{t-\tau}{\sqrt{2} } \right) ^2.
    \end{align*}
    Fix $\tau > 0$ sufficiently large such that $\mu(\left\|x\right\|<\tau) \ge 1 / 2$, and put $t_0\coloneqq \tau$, $t_{n+1} \coloneqq \sqrt{2} t_n + \tau$, so that $t_n \le c\tau 2^{n / 2}$\[
        \begin{cases}
            \mu( \left\|x\right\| > t_{n+1}) \le 2 \mu (\left\|x\right\|\ge t_n)^2,\\
            \mu(\left\|x\right\|>t_0) \le \frac{1}{2},
        \end{cases}
        \implies
        \mu (\left\|x\right\|> t_n) \lesssim 2^{-2^n} \le \e^{-\frac{c t_n^2}{\tau^2}}
    \] This implies that $\mu(\left\|x\right\|>t) \le \e^{-\beta t^2 / \tau^2}$ for all $t \ge \tau$ and a constant $\beta > 0$ that does not depend $\mu$. Then, if $\alpha \in (0,\beta)$,
%    \begin{align*}
%        \int \e^{\alpha \left\|x\right\|^2} \mu(\dd x) = 2\alpha \int_{-\infty}^\infty t \e^{\alpha t^2} \mu(\left\|x\right\| \ge t) \dd t \lesssim 1 + 2\alpha \int_\tau^\infty t \e^{\alpha t^2} \e^{-\beta t^2} \dd t < \infty.
%    \end{align*}
    \begin{align*}
        \int \e^{\alpha (\left\|x\right\| / \tau)^2}\mu(\dd x)
        &= \frac{2\alpha}{\tau^2} \int_{-\infty}^\infty t \e^{\alpha t^2 / \tau^2} \mu(\left\|x\right\| > t) \dd t = 2\alpha \int_{-\infty}^\infty t \e^{\alpha t^2} \mu(\left\|x\right\| > t\tau) \dd t\\
        &\le c(\alpha) + 2\alpha \int_1^{\infty} \e^{(\alpha - \beta)t^2}\dd t < \infty.
    \end{align*}
    This upper bound does not depend on $\tau$ or $\mu$, and the corollary follows by taking $\tau = 2M$ (Chebyshev). Finally, note that $\e^{\alpha (\left\|x\right\| / M)^2} \ge \frac{\alpha^k}{k!} \frac{\left\|x\right\|^{2k}}{M^{2k}}$, so \[
        \int \left\|x\right\|^{2k} \mu(\dd x) \le K \frac{k!}{\alpha^k} M^{2k}
    \] for a universal constant.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of covariance operators of centred Gaussian measures in Hilbert spaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    In a Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$, the covariance operators $\widehat{C}_\mu \colon \mathcal{H} \to \mathcal{H}$ of centred Gaussian measures are exactly the positive symmetric trace class operators (in particular compact), and \[
        \trace (\widehat{C}_\mu) = \int \left\|x\right\|^2\mu(\dd x).
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    If $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on $\mathcal{H}$ and $\widehat{C}_\mu \colon \mathcal{H} \to \mathcal{H}$ its covariance operator, then it is symmetric and $\left<h,\widehat{C}_\mu h \right> = \int \left<h,x \right> ^2 \mu(\dd x) \ge 0$, and for any ONB $(e_n)$, \[
        \int \left\|x\right\|^2 \mu(\dd x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \int \left<x,e_n \right> ^2 \mu(\dd x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<e_n,\widehat{C}_\mu e_n \right>  = \trace(\widehat{C}_\mu).
        \] Conversely, if $K$ is trace class, then it is compact so there is an ONB $(e_n)$ and $\lambda_n \ge 0$ with $\sum_n \lambda_n < \infty$ and $K e_n =\lambda_n e_n$. Let $(\xi_i)_{i=1}^\infty$ be i.i.d.\ $\mathcal{N}(0,1)$, and define $\mu$ to be the law of $X\coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sqrt{\lambda_n}  \xi_n e_n$ (this converges absolutely a.s.\ by assumption on $\lambda_n$). If $h \in \mathcal{H}$, then $\left<h,X \right> = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sqrt{\lambda_n} \xi_n \left<h,e_n \right> $. Denote by $S_N$ the $N$'th partial sum, so $S_N \to \left<h,X \right> $ a.s. Then $S_N$ is centred Gaussian with \[
    \V(S_N) = \E \left[ S_N^2 \right] = \sum_{n,m=1}^N \sqrt{\lambda_n \lambda_m}  h_n h_m \E \left[ \xi_n \xi_m \right] = \sum_{n=1}^N \lambda_n \left<h,e_n \right> ^2 \to \left<h,Kh \right> ,\quad N \to \infty.
\] This implies that $\left<h,X \right> \sim \mathcal{N}(0,\left<h,Kh \right> )$ as required.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Relation between Gaussian measures and Gaussian processes in $\R^T$ and $C(K,\R)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $T$ is a topological space, then Gaussian measures on $\R^T$ (with the product topology) are exactly Gaussian processes,
        \item[(ii)] If $K$ is a compact Hausdorff space, then Gaussian measures in $C(K,\R)$ are exactly Gaussian processes.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] One can show that $(\R^T)^\star$ consists exactly of finite linear combinations of point evaluations (see my CS Bachelors thesis), so the law of an $\R^T$ values random variable $(X_t)_{t\in T}$ is a Gaussian measure iff its fidis are Gaussian, i.e.\ iff it is a Gaussian process.
        \item[(ii)] The non-negative elements of the dual of $C(K,\R)$ are exactly Radon measures (finite and inner regular on open sets). Since Dirac delta's are Radon, a Gaussian measure is always the law of a Gaussian process. Conversely, let $f = (f(t))_{t\in K}$ be a $C(K,\R)$-valued Gaussian process. The set of linear combinations of Dirac delta functions is dense w.r.t.\ weak convergence of measures in the set of Radon measures, so for any $\mu$ there is a sequence $\mu_n = \sum_{i=1}^{m_n} a^{(n)}_i \delta_{t^{(n)}_i} \to \mu$, so \[
                \mu(f) \longleftarrow \mu_n(f) = \sum_{i=1}^{m_n} a^{(n)}_i f(t ^{(n)}_i) \sim \mathcal{N}.
        \]
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]For $\lambda_k \in \R$ and i.i.d.\ $\eta_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$, when is $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k \eta_k$ absolutely convergent?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\lambda_k \ge 0$ and $\eta_k \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ are i.i.d.\, then
    \begin{align*}
        \sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k^2 < \infty &\implies \sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k \left| \eta_k \right| < \infty \text{ a.s.},\\
        \sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k^2 = \infty &\implies \sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k \left| \eta_k \right| = \infty \text{ a.s.}.
    \end{align*}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Recall that $\E \left[ \e^{-\lambda \eta_1} \right] \approx \e^{-\lambda^2 / 2}$ for small $\lambda > 0$ (bounded above and below for uniformly in $\lambda \in [0,K]$ for any $K > 0$). We may assume that $\sup_{k\ge 0}\lambda_k < \infty$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \E \left[ \e^{-\sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k \left| \eta_k \right| } \right] = \prod_{k=1}^\infty \E \left[ \e^{-\lambda_k \left| \eta_k \right| } \right] \approx \prod_{k=1}^\infty \e^{-\lambda_k^2 / 2} = \e^{-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k^2}.
    \end{align*}
    Hence if $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k^2 = \infty$ then this is zero so the random sum is zero almost-surely, and if $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \lambda_k^2 < \infty$ then this is positive so the random sum is finite with positive probability and hence with probability one (because it is a tail event).
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: Directional derivatives $f'(x;u)$ of a convex function on $\R^d$. What properties does $f'(x;\cdot )$ have?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $f\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ be convex. Then all directional derivatives \[
        f'(x;u) \coloneqq \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+hu) - f(x)}{h},\quad x \in \interior \dom f,\,u\in  \R^d,
    \] in particular left- and right partial derivatives exist. $f'(x;\cdot ) \colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ is positively homogenous and convex. $f$ is differentiable $\lambda$-a.e.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Existence of directional derivatives follows from the one-dimensional result. Positive homogenity is obvious, and
    \begin{align*}
        f'(x;\lambda u + \mu u')
        &= \lim_{h\to 0} \frac{f(x + \lambda (hu) + \mu (hu')) - f(x)}{h}\\
        &\le \lim_{h\to 0} \left( \lambda \frac{f(x+hu) - f(x)}{h} + \mu \frac{f(x+hu') - f(x)}{h}     \right) \\
        &= \lambda f'(x;u) + \mu f'(x;u').
    \end{align*}
    Differentiability we do not prove here.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of convexity for once and twice differentiable functions $f\colon \R^d \supset A \to \R$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $A\subset \R$ open and $f\colon A \to \R$. Then
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $f$ is differentiable, then $f$ is convex iff $f'$ is increasing,
        \item[(ii)] If $f$ is twice differentiable, then $f$ is convex iff $f'' \ge 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $f$ is convex and differentiable, then $f' = f'_+$ is increasing. If $f$ is differentiable and $f' \ge 0$, let $x,y\in A$ and $\mu + \lambda = 1$, $\mu,\lambda \ge 0$, $z \coloneqq \lambda x + \mu y$, then there are $z_1 \in [x,z]$ and $z_2 \in [z,y]$ such that \[
                \frac{f(z) - f(x)}{z-x} = f'(z_1) \le f'(z_2) = \frac{f(y) - f(z)}{y-z}.
            \] Then, $z - x = \mu(y-x)$ and $y-z = \lambda(y-x)$, so rearranging yields $f(z) \le \lambda f(x) + \mu f(y)$.
        \item[(ii)] $f'$ is increasing iff $f'' \ge 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}
    Let $A\subset \R^d$ be open and $f\colon A \to \R$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $f$ is differentiable, then $f$ is convex iff \[
                \left<\nabla f(x) - \nabla f(y),x-y \right> \ge 0,\quad x,y\in A.
        \]
        \item[(ii)] If $f$ is twice differentiable, then $f$ is convex iff the Hessian $H(x)$ is positive semi-definite for all $x\in A$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{corollary}
[/latex]

front:
[latex]Convex geometry: Definition of support function $h_A\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ of a convex set $\emptyset \neq A\subset \R^d$, and some properties:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] Does $h_A$ characterise $A$?
    \item[(ii)] When is $h_A$ real-valued everywhere?
    \item[(iii)] Monotonicity
    \item[(iv)] Minkowski combinations
    \item[(v)] If $A = \conv \bigcup_{i\in I} A_i$, then what is $h_A$?
    \item[(vi)] If $A = \bigcap_{i\in I} A_i$, then what is $h_A$?
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $A \subset \R^d$ is non-empty and convex, define $h_A\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ by \[
    h_A(u) \coloneqq \delta_A^\star = \sup_{x\in A} \left<x,u \right> .
\]
\begin{proposition}
    $h_A$ is closed, convex, and positively homogenous, and
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $h_A = h_{\cl A}$ and $\cl A = \left\{ x\colon \left<x,\cdot  \right> \le h_A \right\} $,
        \item[(ii)] $h_A$ is real-valued iff $A$ is bounded,
        \item[(iii)] $A\subset B \implies h_A \le h_B \implies \cl A \subset \cl B$,
        \item[(iv)] If $\alpha,\beta \ge 0$ then $h_{\alpha A + \beta B}= \alpha h_A + \beta h_B$,
        \item[(v)] If $A = \conv \bigcup_{i\in I} A_i$ then $h_A = \sup_i h_{A_i}$,
        \item[(vi)] If $A = \bigcap_{i\in I} A_i$ then $h_A = \cl \conv (h_{A_i})_{i\in I}$ (where $\conv$ of functions is largest convex lower bound, i.e.\ convex hull of epigraph).
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    $h_A$ is closed and convex because it is a complex conjugate, and obviously positively homogenous. $h_A =h_{\cl A}$ is also obvious. For $(i)$, $\supset$ is clear, and if $\left<x,u \right> > h_A(u)$ for some $u$ then $x \not\in \cl A$. If $A$ is bounded then $h_A$ is always finite, if $A$ is unbounded then it contains a ray so $h_A$ is unbounded in that direction. (iii) is also clear. For (iv) note that
    \begin{align*}
        h_{\alpha A + \beta B}(u)
        &= \sup_{x\in A, y\in B} \left( \alpha \left<x,u \right> + \beta \left<y,u \right>  \right) = \alpha h_A(u) + \beta h_B(u).
    \end{align*}
    For (v), $\ge$ follows from (iii), and if $x\in A$, then $x = \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i x_i$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \left<x,u \right> = \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i\left<x_i,u \right> \le \sum_{i=1}^k \lambda_i h_{A_i}(u) \le \sup_i h_{A_i}(u).
    \end{align*}
    For (vi), $h_A \le h_{A_i}$ for all $i$ so $h_A \le \conv h_{A_i}$ because $h_A$ is convex so $h_A \le \cl \conv h_{A_i}$ because $h_A$ is closed. Suppose $f \le h_{A_i}$ for all $i$ is closed and convex. Other direction no idea.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Convex geometry: One-to-one correspondence between convex bodies and and support functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    There is a one-to-one correspondence between
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Closed convex non-empty sets and $h\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ closed, convex, and positively homogenous,
        \item[(ii)] Convex bodies and $h\colon \R^d \to \R$ closed, convex, and positively homogenous,
    \end{enumerate}
    via $A \mapsto h_A$ and $h \mapsto \dom h^\star$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    One direction follows by taking $h=h_A$. For the other direction, let $h$ be given (proper, otherwise take $A = \R^d$) and note that positive homogenity of $h$ implies that $h^\star\colon \R^d \to (-\infty,\infty]$ (which is closed convex and proper) takes only $0$ and $\infty$ as values, so $A \coloneqq \dom h^\star$ is closed and convex and non-empty, and $h^\star = \delta_A$, so \[
    h = h^{\star\star} = \delta_A^\star = h_A.
    \] (ii) follows from (i) because $h_A$ is real-valued iff $A$ is bounded.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Embeddings $C(K) \hookrightarrow C_0(\R^d)$ and $C_b(B) \hookrightarrow L^p(B)$ for $B,K\subset \R^d$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $K\subset \R^d$ is compact, then there is an isometric embedding $C(K) \hookrightarrow C_0(\R^d)$,
        \item[(ii)] If $B\in \B(\R^d)$ such that $\lambda(B) < \infty$ and $\lambda(B \cap B(x,r)) > 0$ for all $x\in B$ and $r > 0$, then there is an embedding $C_b(B) \hookrightarrow L^p(B)$ for every $p\in [1,\infty]$. If $\lambda(\partial B) = 0$, then it has dense image.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    (i) in the case $K = [0,1]$ follows by connecting the endpoints linearly with zero, the general statement follows from Tietze's extension theorem. For (ii) note that the natural identification yields a continuous linear map $C_b(B) \to L^p(B)$ because $\lambda(B) < \infty$, it remains to show injectivity. If $f = 0$ a.e.\ then for every $x\in B$ there is $x_n \to x$ with $f(x_n) = 0$ for all $n\in \N$ (by assumption on $B$), so $f(x) = 0$ by continuity, so $f \equiv 0$. If $\lambda(\partial B) = 0$, then $C_c^\infty(B)$ is dense in $L^p(B)$, in particular $C_b(B)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Extension theorem for densely defined linear operators on normed spaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a normed space and $Y$ a Banach space, and $T\colon D\subset X \to Y$ is a densely defined bounded linear operator, then there is a unique extension of $T$ to $\overline{T}\colon X \to Y$ with $\left\|\overline{T}\right\|= \left\|T\right\|$, and if $T$ is an isometry then so is $\overline{T}$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Clearly the extension is unique if it exists. Let $x\in X$ and $x_n \to x$ with $x_n \in D$. Then, $(T x_n)$ is Cauchy in $Y$ so $\overline{T}x \coloneqq \lim_{n\to \infty}T x_n $ exists. This is well-defined because if $x_n'\to x$ as well, then $\left\|T x_n - T x_n'\right\| \le \left\|T\right\| \left\|x_n - x_n'\right\|\to 0$, and obviously linear, and \[
    \left\|\overline{T} x\right\|= \lim_{n\to \infty} \left\|T x_n\right\| \le \left\|T\right\| \lim_{n\to \infty} \left\|x_n\right\| = \left\|T\right\|\left\|x\right\|.
    \] Hence $\overline{T}$ is a bounded linear operator that extends $T$ with $\left\|\overline{T}\right\|\le \left\|T\right\|$, and obviously $\left\|\overline{T}\right\|\ge \left\|T\right\|$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Direct sum and projection for normed spaces and connection.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
A normed space $X$ is the \emph{direct sum} of two closed linear subspaces $X_1$ and $X_2$, written $X = X_1 \oplus X_2$ if $X_1 \cap X_2 = \left\{ 0 \right\} $ and $X_1 + X_2 = X$. A linear operator $P\colon X \to X$ (not necessarily bounded) is a \emph{projection} if $P^2 = P$.
\begin{proposition}
    Let $X$ be a normed space.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $P$ is a \emph{bounded} projection and $X_1 = R(P)$, $X_2 = N(P)$, then $X = X_1 \oplus X_2$.
        \item[(ii)] If $X = X_1 \oplus X_2$, then $P$ defined by $x_1 + x_2 \mapsto x_1$ is a projection.
    \end{enumerate}
    In either case, $\left\|P\right\| \ge 1$ (except if $P = 0$), and \[
        X_1 = R(P) = N(I-P),\qquad X_2 = N(P) = R(I-P).
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If $P$ is a projection, then so is $I-P$, in which case $R(P) =N(I-P) \eqqcolon X_1$ and $R(I-P) = N(P) \eqqcolon X_2$ are closed linear spaces (because $P$ is bounded), $X_1 \cap X_2 = R(P) \cap N(P) = \left\{ 0 \right\} $, and if $x\in X$ then $x = Px + (I-P)x \in X_1 + X_2$.

    If $X = X_1\oplus X_2$ for closed linear spaces $X_1$ and $X_2$, then for every $x\in X$ there is a unique decomposition $x = x_1 + x_2$, put $Px \coloneqq x_1$. This is well-defined, linear, and $P^2 = P$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Metastability (potential theory): Definition of harmonic function $h_{A,B}$ and equilibrium potential $e_{A,B}$[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Let $A,B\subset S$ be disjoint.
\begin{proposition}
    If $S$ is finite, then the unique solution to the Dirichlet problem \[
    \begin{cases}
        -Lh = 0 & \text{on $S\setminus (A\cup B)$}\\
        h = 1 & \text{on $A$}\\
        h = 0 & \text{on $B$}
    \end{cases}\qquad \text{is given by}\qquad
    h_{A,B}(x) = \P^x(\tau_A < \tau_B) \quad (x\not\in A\cup B).
\] Then, \[
e_{A,B}(x) \coloneqq -Lh_{A,B}(x) = \begin{cases}
    \P_x(\tau_B < \tau_A) &, x\in A,\\
    -\P_x(\tau_A < \tau_B) &, x\in B,\\
    0 &, \text{else},
\end{cases}
\] is called the \emph{equilibrium potential}.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If $x\in A\cup B$, then by conditioning on the first jump, $\P_x(\tau_A < \tau_B) = (Ph)(x) = Lh(x) + h(x)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Metastability (potential theory): Green's function (definition, connection with inhomogenous Dirichlet problem, and connection with $h$ and $e$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    The \emph{Green's function} of $X$ killed at $B$ is \[
        G_B(x,y) \coloneqq \E^x \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{\tau_B} \ind_{\left\{X_n =y\right\}} \right] ,\quad x,y\not\in B.
    \] Then the solution to \[
    \begin{cases}
        -Lh = g & \text{on $S \setminus B$},\\
        h = 0 & \text{on $B$},
    \end{cases}
\] is given by \[
h(x) = \E_x \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{\tau_B} g(X_n) \right] = \sum_{y\not\in B}G_B(x ,y) g(y).
\]  In particular, \[
h_{A,B} = \sum_{y\in A} G_B(\cdot ,y) e_{A,B}(y),\qquad h_{a,B}(x) = G_B(x,a) e_{a,B}(a).
\] Also, $x\mapsto \E^x[\tau_B] = \sum_y G(x,y)$ is the solution of $-Lf = 1$.
\end{proposition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Metastability (potential theory): Dirichlet form $\mathcal{E}(f,g)$ on $L^2(S,\mu)$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    Define the Dirichlet form associated with $\mu$ and $S$ by \[
        \mathcal{E}(f,g) \coloneqq \left<f,-Lg \right> _{L^2(S,\mu)} = \frac{1}{2}\sum_{x,y\in S} \mu(x) p(x,y) (f(x)-f(y))(g(x)-g(y)).
    \] In particular, it is positive semi-definite.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    To get the second equality, note that
    \begin{align*}
        \mathcal{E}(f,g)
        = \sum_{x\in S} f(x) (-Lg)(x) &= \sum_{x,y\in S} \mu(x) p(x,y) f(x) (g(x)-g(y))\\
        &= \sum_{x,y\in S} \mu(y) p(y,x) f(x)(g(x)-g(y)),
    \end{align*}
    where reversability was used in the final step. Symmetrising the last two representations yields the claim.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Metastability (potential theory): Capacity $\capc(A,B)$, last-exit biased distribution $\nu_{A,B}$, formula for $\nu_{A,B}(f)$ and corollary on $\E_x[\tau_B]$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{definition}
    Define by \[
        \capc(A,B) = \sum_{x\in A} \mu(x) e_{A,B}(x),\quad, u_{A,B}(x) \coloneqq rac{\mu(x) e_{A,B}(x)}{\capc (A,B)},
    \] respectively the \emph{capacity} of $A$ and $B$ and the \emph{last-exit biased} distribution on $A$. Then, if $-L f = g$ on $B^{c}$ and $f = 0$ on $B$, \[
    u_{A,B}(f) = rac{1}{\capc (A,B)} \mu(h_{A,B}g).
    \] In particular (use $g\equiv 1$), \[
    \E_x\left[ au_B ight] = rac{1}{\capc(x,B)} \mu(h_{x,B}).
    \]
\end{definition}
egin{proof}
    Multiply $\mu(x) G(x,y) = \mu(y) G(y,x)$ by $g(x)e(y)$ and sum over $x,y\in S$ to obtain
    egin{align*}
        \mu(hg)
        &= \sum_{x,y} \mu(x) G(x,y) g(x) e(y) = \sum_{x,y} e(y) \mu(y) G(y,x) g(x) =\sum_y \mu(y) f(y)e(y) \
        &= \capc(A,B) u(f)
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Metastability (Potential theory): Dirichlet and Thomson principles.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Dirichlet and Thomson principles]
    We have \[
        \capc(A,B) = \inf_{\phi \in \Phi_{A,B}} \mathcal{E}(\phi,\phi) = \sup_{u\in U_{A,B}} \mathcal{D}(u,u)^{-1},
    \] where $\Phi_{A,B} = \left\{ \phi\colon S \to [0,1]\colon \phi\!\!\restriction_{A} \equiv 1, \phi\!\!\restriction_{B} \equiv 0 \right\}$, and $U_{A,B}$ denotes the set of unit flows $u\colon S\times S\to \R$ from $A$ to $B$, and \[
    \mathcal{D} (u,u)= \sum_{x,y\in S} \frac{1}{\mu(x)p(x,y)} u(x,y)^2.
\] The infimum is uniquely attained at $\phi = h_{A,B}$, and the supremum is uniquely attained at \[
        u(x,y) = \frac{\mu(x) p(x,y) \big( h_{A,B}(y) - h_{A,B}(x)\big)_+}{\capc(A,B)}.
    \]
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Metastability (potential theory): $h$, $e$, and capacity in the case of nearest neighbout random walk on $\Z$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Consider the nearest-neighbour random walk on $[a,b]\subset \Z$. Define the \emph{resistance} between $u$ and $v$ by \[
        R(u,v) = \sum_{y=u+1}^v \frac{1}{\mu(y) p(y,y-1)},\quad u < v.
    \] (Interpret $\mu(x) p(x,y)$ as conductivity from $x$ to $y$). Then, \[
    h_{b,a}(x) = \P_x(\tau_b < \tau_a) = \frac{R(a,x)}{R(a,b)},\quad a < x < b.
\] The equilibrium measure (in this case the escape probability from $a$ to $b$) \[
e_{a,b}(a) = \frac{1}{\mu(a) R(a,b)},
\] and the capacity is $\capc(a,b) = R(a,b)^{-1}$.
\end{proposition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Quotient space $X/Y$ of a normed vector space. What is the norm of the projection map? When is the result Banach?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $X$ be a normed space and $Y\subset X$ a closed linear subspace. Then, \[
    X / Y \coloneqq \left\{\widehat{x}\coloneqq  x + Y\colon x\in X \right\} ,\quad \left\|\widehat{x}\right\|\coloneqq \left\|x-Y\right\|,
    \] is a normed space, and the map $Q\colon X \to X/Y\colon x \mapsto x+Y$ has $\left\|Q\right\|=1$. If $X$ is complete, then so is $X / Y$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    We may assume that $Y \neq X$. It is clearly a vector space, and $\left\|\widehat{x}\right\|$ is well-defined. It is obviously homogenous and definite, and if $x_1,x_2\in X$, then for any $y_1,y_2\in Y$,
     \begin{align*}
        \left\|\widehat{x}_1 + \widehat{x}_2\right\|
        &\le \left\|x_1 + x_2 - y_1-y_2\right\| \le \left\|x_1-y_1\right\|+\left\|x_2-y_2\right\|.
    \end{align*}
    Taking the infimum over $y_1$ and $y_2$ yields the triangle inequality. Now, $\left\|\widehat{x}\right\| \le \left\|x - 0\right\|= \left\|x\right\|$, so $\left\|Q\right\|\le 1$. Furthermore, for any $\delta \in (0,1)$ there is an $x\in X$ such that $\left\|x\right\|=1$ and $\left\|\widehat{x}\right\|=\left\|x-Y\right\|\ge 1-\delta$, so $\left\|Q\right\|\ge 1$.

    Finally, suppose that $X$ is complete, and $(\widehat{x}_k)$ a Cauchy sequence in $X / Y$. It suffices to show that it has a converging subsequence, so we may assume that $\left\|\widehat{x}_n - \widehat{x}_{n-1}\right\|\le 2^{-n}$. Take any representative $x_1$ of $\widehat{x}_1$. Then if we have chosen representatives $x_1, \ldots ,x_{n}$, take $x_{n+1}\in X$ so that \[
        \left\|x_n - x_{n+1}\right\| \le 2\left\|\widehat{x}_n - \widehat{x}_{n+1}\right\| \le 2^{-n}.
    \] Then, $(x_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence in $X$, hence $x_n \to x$, so $\widehat{x}_n \to \widehat{x}$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Connection between direct sums and quotient for Banach spaces.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X = Y \oplus Z$ is a Banach space, then $Z$ and $X / Y$ are isomorphic (not necessarily isometrically).
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Define $J\colon Z \to X / Y;\, z \mapsto \widehat{z} = z+Y$. Then $J$ is linear and bounded. If $Jz = 0$, then $z\in Y$, so $z = 0$. If $x\in X$, then $x = y + z$, so $Jz = \widehat{x}$, so $J$ is bijective, hence $J^{-1}$ is continuous by the open mapping theorem.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Sum of Banach spaces (not direct sum).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Suppose $X,Y$ are Banach spaces that are subspaces of a topological vector space $Z$ and that the inclusions are continuous. Define
    \begin{align*}
        X+Y &= \left\{ x+y\colon x\in X,y\in Y \right\},\\
        \left\|z\right\|_{X+Y}&\coloneqq \inf \left\{ \left\|x\right\|_X + \left\|y\right\|_Y\colon z=x+y,x\in X,y\in Y \right\} .
    \end{align*}
    Then this is a Banach space with coarser metric, and isometrically isomorphic to $X\times Y / D$, where $D = \left\{ (u,-u)\colon u\in X\cap Y \right\} $.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    $X+Y$ is a vector space. Suppose $\left\|z\right\| = 0$, so there are $z = x_n + y_n$ with $x_n \to 0$ in $X$ and $y_n \to 0$ in $Y$, so $x_n + y_n \to 0$ in $Z$, so $z = 0$ (this uses that addition and the embeddings are continuous in $Z$). Triangle inequality and homogenity are clear, so it is a norm. If $x\in X$, then $\left\|x\right\| \le \left\|x\right\|_X + \left\|0\right\|_Y = \left\|x\right\|_X$. Similar for $y\in Y$.

$D$ is closed, so $X\times Y / D$ is a Banach space. Define $J\colon X\times Y/D \to X+Y;\, (x,y)+D \mapsto x+y$. This is obviously well-defined and linear. Furthermore, if $x\in X$ and $y\in Y$, then
\begin{align*}
    \left\|(x,y)+D\right\|
    &= \inf \left\{ \left\|x+u\right\|_X + \left\|y-u\right\|_Y\colon u\in X\cap Y \right\} \\
    &= \inf \left\{ \left\|x'\right\|_X + \left\|y'\right\|_Y\colon x'\in X,y'\in Y,x'+y' = x+y \right\} \\
    &= \left\|x+y\right\|_{X+Y} \\
    &= \left\|J [(x,y)+D]\right\|_{X+Y}.
\end{align*}
Hence, $J$ is an isometry, in particular injective. If $x\in X$, $y\in Y$, then $J[(x,y)+D] = x+y$, so it is also surjective. Since $X\times Y/D$ is complete, so is $X+Y$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Inner product spaces: Cauchy-Schwartz, lipschitz continuity of $\left<\cdot ,\cdot  \right> $, parallelogram identity.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    In an inner product space, $\left<\cdot ,\cdot  \right> $ is Lipschitz-continuous on balls in $X\times X$, and the \emph{parallelogram identity holds:} \[
    \left\|x+y\right\|^2 + \left\|x-y\right\|^2 = 2 \left\|x\right\|^2 + 2 \left\|y\right\|^2.
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $x,y\in X$, then for any $\alpha \in \R$,
    \begin{align*}
        0 \le \left\|x-\alpha y\right\|^2 = \left\|x\right\|^2 - 2 \alpha \Re \left<x,y \right> + \alpha^2 \left\|y\right\|^2.
    \end{align*} Minimising for $\alpha$ gives $\alpha = \Re \left<x , y \right> / \left\|y\right\|^2$, in which case this becomes \[
    2 \left( \Re \left<x,y \right>  \right)^2 / \left\|y\right\|^2 \le \left\|x\right\|^2 + (\Re \left<x,y \right> )^2 / \left\|y\right\|^2 \implies \left| \Re \left<x,y \right> \right| \le \left\|x\right\|\left\|y\right\|.
    \] Use $\i \alpha$ to get this for $\Im \left<x,y \right> $. For Lipschitz continuity, note that
    \begin{align*}
        \left| \left<x_1,y_1 \right> -\left<x_2,y_2 \right>  \right|
        &\le \left\| x_1-x_2 \right\| \left\|y_1\right\|+ \left\|x_2\right\|\left\| y_1-y_2 \right\| .
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $Y$ is a closed linear subspace of a Hilbert space, then $H = Y \oplus \,?$. What do you know about the associated projection, and about $Y$ and $Y^{\perp\perp}$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $Y$ is a closed linear subspace of a Hilbert space $H$, then $Y = Y^{\perp\perp}$ and $H = Y\oplus Y^\perp$, so there is a unique orthogonal projection $P\colon H\to H$ with $R(P) = Y$ and $N(P) = Y^\perp$. It satisfies $\left\|P\right\| = 1$ (except if $Y = 0$), and \[
    \left\|x-Px\right\|=\min_{y\in Y} \left\|x-y\right\|.
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $x\in X$, and $y_n \in Y$ with $\left\|x-y_n\right\| \to \left\|x-Y\right\|\eqqcolon d$. Then, by the parallelogram identity,
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|y_n - y_m\right\|^2
        &= \left\|y_n - x - (y_m - x)\right\|^2= \underbrace{2\left\|y_n - x\right\|^2 + 2\left\|y_m - x\right\|^2}_{\to 4d^2} - 4\underbrace{\left\|\frac{1}{2}(y_n+y_m) - x\right\|^2}_{\ge d^2}\to 0,
    \end{align*}
    as $n,m\to \infty$. Since $H$ is complete, this implies the existence of a unique(!) closest point $Px$ in $Y$ to $x$. We don't know yet if $P$ is linear! Now show that $Px-x \perp Y$. Let $y\in Y$, then for any $\alpha >0$,
    \begin{align*}
        d^2
        &\le \left\|x - Px - \alpha y\right\|^2 = d^2 - 2\alpha \Re \left<x-Px,y \right> + \alpha^2 \left\|y\right\|^2.
    \end{align*}
    This implies $2\Re \left<x-Px,y \right> \le \alpha \left\|y\right\|$, then let $\alpha \downarrow 0$. Repeat with $- \alpha$ and $\pm \i \alpha$ to get $\left<x-Px,y \right> = 0$. In particular, $x = (x-Px) + Px \in Y^\perp + Y$, and $Y\cap Y^\perp = 0$ and both are closed linear subspaces, so $H = Y \oplus Y^\perp$. Then there exists a unique linear projection with range $Y$ and kernel $Y^\perp$. But since the decomposition is unique, this must be $P$, in particular it is linear. It remains to show that $\left\|P\right\|\ge 1$ and $Y \supset Y^{\perp\perp}$. If $x\in X$, then \[
    \left\|x\right\|^2 = \left\|x-Px\right\|^2 + \left\|Px\right\|^2,
    \] so $\left\|Px\right\|\le \left\|x\right\|$. Now if $y\in Y^{\perp\perp}$, then \[
    \left\|y - Py\right\|^2 = \left<y,y-Py \right> - \left<Py,y-Py \right> = 0,
    \] so $y = Py\in Y$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Riesz representation theorem (Isometric isomorphism $H \simeq H^\star$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $H$ is a Hilbert space, then $\Phi\colon H \to H^\star; \, x \mapsto \left<\cdot ,x\right> $ is an (anti-)linear isometric bijection.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    It is clearly well-defined and antilinear, and $\left\|\Phi\right\|\le 1$, and for any $x\in H$ with $\left\|x\right\| = 1$, \[
        \left\|\Phi\right\|_{\mathcal{L}(H,H^\star)} \ge \left\|\Phi(x)\right\|_{H^\star} = \left\|\left<\cdot ,x \right> \right\|_{H^\star} \ge \left| \left<x,x \right>  \right| _H = 1.
    \] Now let $0\neq \varphi\in H^\star$, and $x_0\in N(\varphi)^\perp$ (which is not trivial because $N \neq H$ and $H = N \oplus N^\perp$) with $\varphi(x_0) = 1$. Then any $y\in H$ satisfies \[
    \varphi(y - \varphi(y)x_0) = \varphi(y) - \varphi(y) = 0,
\] so $y-\varphi(y)x_0\in N$, so \[
0 = \left<y-\varphi(y)x_0,x_0 \right> = \left<y,x_0 \right> - \varphi(y) \left\|x_0\right\|^2,
\] so \[
\varphi(y) = \left<y,\frac{x_0}{\left\|x_0\right\|^2} \right> ,\quad y\in H.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Orthonormal system, orthonormal basis, and Gram-schmidt procedure in an inner product space. Existence of a countable orthonormal basis in a separable Hilbert space.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{definition}
    A subset $\left\{ v_i\colon i\in I ight\} \subset X$ of an inner product space is called \emph{orthonormal system} if $\left<v_i,v_j ight> =\delta_{ij}$ for $i,j\in I$. It is called an \emph{orthonormal basis} if it is maximal.
\end{definition}

egin{lemma}
    For any countable linearly independent set $\left\{ w_i\colon i\in I ight\} \subset X$, there is an orthonormal system $\left\{ v_i\colon i\in I ight\} $ with the same linear span and \[
    v_1 = rac{w_1}{\left\|w_1 ight\|},\qquad \widetilde{v}_{i+1} = w_{i+1} - \sum_{j=1}^i \left<w_{i+1},v_j ight> v_j,\quad v_{i+1} = rac{\widetilde{v}_{i+1}}{\left\|\widetilde{v}_{i+1} ight\|}.
    \] In particular, if $X$ is a separable Hilbert space, then it has a countable orthonormal basis.
\end{lemma}
egin{proof}
    WLOG $I = \N$. We inductively show that $\left\{ v_i\colon i \in [n] ight\} $ is orthonormal with the same span as $\left\{ w_i\colon i\in [n] ight\} $. Clear if $i = 1$, so it remains to show that in the inductive step, $0 eq \widetilde{v}_{i+1} \perp v_j$ for $j\in [i]$. It is non-zero because $w_{i+1} ot\in \lin \left\{ w_j\colon j\in [i] ight\} = \lin \left\{ v_j\colon j\in [i] ight\} $, and for any $j\in [i]$,
    egin{align*}
        \left<\widetilde{v}_{i+1},v_j ight> = \left<w_{i+1},v_j ight> - \sum_{k=1}^i \left<w_{i+1},v_k ight> \delta_{kj} = 0.
    \end{align*}
    If $X$ is a separable Hilbert space, take a countable dense set $\Sigma = \left\{ w_i\colon i\in \N ight\} $, then take $k(1) = 1$, and $k(n+1)$ the first $j$ such that $w_j ot\in \lin \left\{ w_{k(i)}\colon i \in [n] ight\} $, and $v_n \coloneqq w_{k(n)}$. Then $\lin \left\{ v_n\colon n\in \N ight\} = \lin \Sigma$ and is linearly independent, so we can turn it into an orthonormal system with the same dense span, so it is an orthonormal basis.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Projection $P$ onto $\overline{\lin S}$ for an orthonormal system $S$ in a Hilbert space (in particular Bessel's inequality).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $H$ is a Hilbert space and $S = \left\{ v_n\colon n\in \N \right\} $ an orthonormal system, then \[
        P\colon H \to H;\, x \mapsto \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<x,v_n \right> v_n
        \] is (well-defined and) an orthogonal projection with \[
        \left\|Px\right\|^2 = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2 \le \left\|x\right\|^2,\quad \textit{(Bessel's inequality)}
\] (in particular $\left\|P\right\|\le 1$), and $H = \overline{\lin S} \oplus S^\perp$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Firstly, for any $N\in \N$ let $x_N \coloneqq x - \sum_{n=1}^N \left<x,v_n \right> v_n$, so that \[
    \left\|x\right\|^2 = \left\|x_N\right\|^2 + \sum_{n=1}^N \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2 \ge \sum_{n=1}^N \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2\quad \forall N\in \N,
    \] so $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2 \le \left\|x\right\|^2$ (Bessel's inequality), so \[
    \left\|\sum_{n=N}^M \left<x,v_n \right> v_n\right\|^2 = \sum_{n=N}^M \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2 \to 0,\qquad M,N\to \infty,
\] so the limit $Px \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<x,v_n \right> v_n$ exists, $P$ is linear, $P^2 = P$ and $\left\|Px\right\|^2 = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2 \le \left\|x\right\|^2$ (all by continuity of the scalar product). In particular, $N(P) = S^\perp$ and $R(P)$ is a closed linear subspace with $S\subset R(P) \subset \overline{\lin S}$. So $P$ is an orthogonal projection and $H = \overline{\lin S} \oplus S$. (The convergence of $Px$ is unconditional, but not necessarily absolute.)
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of maximality of a countable orthonormal system in a Hilbert space.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $S = \left\{ v_n\colon v\in \N \right\} $ is an orthonormal system in a Hilbert space $H$, then TFAE:
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] $S$ is maximal (i.e.\ an orthonormal basis)
        \item[(ii)] $S^\perp = \left\{ 0 \right\} $,
        \item[(iii)] $X = \overline{\lin S}$,
        \item[(iv)] For all $x\in X$, $x = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<x,v_n \right> v_n $,
        \item[(v)] For all $x,y\in X$, $\left<x,y \right> = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<x,v_n \right> \left<v_n,y \right> $,
        \item[(vi)] For all $x\in H$, $\left\|x\right\|^2 = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left| \left<x,v_n \right>  \right| ^2 $ \emph{(Parseval's equality)}.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Denote by $P$ the orthogonal projection of $H$ onto $\overline{\lin S}$. (i) $\implies$ (ii) is clear, and (ii) $\implies$ (iii) follows from $H = \overline{\lin S} \oplus S^\perp$. If (iii) holds then $R(P) = X$ and $R(1-P) = N(P) = \left\{ 0 \right\} $, so $x = Px + (1-P)x = Px = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<x,v_n \right> v_n$. By continuity of the scalar product (iv) $\implies$ (v), which specialises to (vi). If (vi) holds and $w \perp S$, then $\left\|w\right\| = 0$ so $S$ is maximal.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Baire's theorem (for open and closed sets).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $(X,d)$ is a complete metric space, and $O_n$ are open and dense sets, then $\bigcap_{n=1} ^\infty O_n$ is dense. If $A_n$ are closed and $\bigcup_{n=1} ^\infty A_n = X$, then one of the $A_n$ has non-emtpy interior.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $x_0\in X$ and $\delta \eqqcolon \delta_0 > 0$. Then there is $\overline{B(x_1,\delta_1)}\subset  \in B(x_0,\delta_0) \cap O_1$ with $\delta_1 < \frac{1}{2}\delta_0$. Inductively, take $\overline{B(x_n,\delta_n)} \subset B(x_{n-1},\delta_{n-1}) \cap O_n$ with $\delta_n < \frac{1}{2}\delta_{n-1}$. Then $(x_n)$ is Cauchy so converges to some $x\in X$, which by construction is in every $\overline{B(x_n,\delta_n)} \subset O_n$ ($n\in \N$), and in $B(x_0,\delta_0)$.

    If $A_n$ are as given, then if all of them had empty interior, $O_n \coloneqq X \setminus A_n$ would all be dense open sets, so $\bigcap_{n=1} ^\infty O_n = X \setminus (\bigcup_{n=1} ^\infty A_n) = \emptyset $ would be dense, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Uniform boundedness principle.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Uniform boundedness]
    If $X$ is a Banach space and $Y$ a normed space, then every collection $\mathcal{T}\subset \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ that is pointwise bounded, i.e.\ $\sup_{T\in \mathcal{T}} \left\|Tx\right\|< \infty$ for all $x\in X$, is uniformly bounded, i.e.\ $\sup_{T\in \mathcal{T}}\left\|T\right\|<\infty$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $A_n \coloneqq \left\{ x\colon \left\|Tx\right\| \le n \forall T\in \mathcal{T} \right\} $. Then, $A_n$ is closed and \[
        \bigcup_{n=1} ^\infty A_n = \left\{ x\colon \sup_{T\in \mathcal{T}} \left\|Tx\right\|<\infty \right\} =X.
    \] By Baire, there is $N\in \N$ such that $A_N$ contains a ball, say $B(x_0,\delta)$. Then, for any $x\in X$ with $\left\|x\right\| < 1$, we have $z \coloneqq x_0 + \delta x \in B(x_0,\delta)$, so \[
    \left\|Tx\right\| =\frac{1}{\delta} \left\|T(z-x_0)\right\| \le \frac{1}{\delta } (N + \sup_{T\in \mathcal{T}} \left\|Tx_0\right\|),
    \] which is an upper bound independent of $x$ and $T$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]When does pointwise convergence of operators $T_n \in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ on a subset $S\subset X$ imply strong convergence to some $T$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is normed and $Y$ Banach, and $T_n \in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ are uniformly bounded and converge pointwise on $S\subset X$ with $\overline{\lin S} = X$, then there is a $T\in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ with $T_n \to T$ strongly and $\left\|T\right\|\le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_n\right\|$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    WLOG $S = \lin S$, because $T_n$ converge on $\lin S$ as well. Define $Tx \coloneqq \lim_{n\to \infty} T_n x$ for $x\in S$, then  $\left\|T x\right\|\le (\varliminf_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_n\right\|) \left\|x\right\|$ for $x\in S$, so $T$ is a densely defined bounded linear operator, which extends uniquely to $T \in \mathcal{L}(X,Y)$ with the claimed bound on the norm. Let $x\in X$, and choose $y\in S$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|T_n x - Tx\right\|
        &\le (\left\|T_n\right\| + \left\|T\right\|)\left\|x-y\right\| + \left\|T_n y - T y\right\|.
    \end{align*}
    Then $\varlimsup_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_n x - T x\right\| \le 2 (\sup_n \left\|T_n\right\|) \left\|x-y\right\|$ for every $y\in S$, and letting $y\to x$ gives the claim.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Product rule for weak derivatives.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $U\subset \R^d$ is open, $p,p'\in [1,\infty]$ conjugate, $f\in W^{1,p}(U)$, and $g\in W^{1,p'}(U)$, then $fg \in W^{1,1}(U)$ and  \[
        \partial_j (fg) = (\partial_j f)g + (f \partial_j g)
    \]
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Let $h_\varepsilon \coloneqq G_\varepsilon h \coloneqq \rho_\varepsilon \star \overline{h}$ where $\rho_\varepsilon$ is a mollifier and $\overline{h}$ is the extension to $\R^d$ by zero of a function $h\in L^1_\text{loc}(U)$. Then if $p \in (1,\infty)$, $G_\varepsilon f \tendsto{L^p} f$ on compacts, same for $g$ and derivatives, so by Hölder,
    \begin{align*}
        \int (\partial \varphi) fg
        &= \lim_{\varepsilon\to 0} \int (\partial \varphi) f_\varepsilon g_\varepsilon = -\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0} \int \varphi \left[ (\partial f_\varepsilon) g_\varepsilon + f_\varepsilon(\partial g_\varepsilon) \right] = - \int \varphi \left[ (\partial f) g + f (\partial g) \right] .
    \end{align*}
    If $p = 1$, then $f_\varepsilon \tendsto{L^1} f$ on compacts, same for $g$ and derivatives, so passing to subsequences gives pointwise a.e.\ convergence and we can repeat the argument with DCT.
\end{proof}
[/latex]
