front: [latex]Hardy-Littlewood maximal function and estimates.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
If $f\in L^1_\text{loc}$, then $\mathcal{M}f (x) \coloneqq \sup_{r > 0} \frac{1}{\left| B(x,r) \right| }\int_{B(x,r)} \left| f(y) \right| \dd y$, where $\left| \cdot  \right| $ denotes Lebesgue measure.

\begin{theorem}
    If $f\in L^1(\R^d)$, then \[
        \left| \left\{   \mathcal{M}f \ge \alpha  \right\}\right|  \le \frac{c_d}{\alpha} \left\|f\right\|_{L^1} \quad \bigg(\text{in fact } \le \frac{c_d}{\alpha} \int\limits_{\left\{ \left| f \right| \ge \alpha / 2 \right\} } \left| f \right|\bigg).
    \] If $f\in L^p(\R^d)$ for $p\in (1,\infty]$, then \[
    \left\|\mathcal{M}f\right\|_{L^p} \le c_p \left\|f\right\|_{L^p}.
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    For fixed $\alpha > 0$, if $\mathcal{M}f(x) \ge \alpha$, then there is a ball $B_x$ centred at $x$ such that $\int_{B_x} \left| f \right| \ge \frac{\alpha}{2} \left| B_x \right| $. They will have bounded radius because $\frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \int_B \left| f \right| \le \frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \left\|f\right\|$, so by Vitali's covering lemma there is a countable subset $B_j$ of disjoint balls such that $(5B_j)_j$ covers $\left\{ \mathcal{M}f \ge \alpha \right\} $, so
    \begin{align*}
        \left| \left\{ \mathcal{M}f \ge \alpha \right\}  \right|
        &\le 5^d \sum_j \left| B_j \right| \le \frac{2\cdot  5^d}{\alpha} \sum_j \int_{B_j} \left| f \right| \le \frac{c_d}{\alpha} \left\|f\right\|_{L^1}.
    \end{align*}
    For the refinement, let $g \coloneqq f \ind_{\left\{ \left| f \right| \ge \alpha / 2 \right\} }$, so that $\mathcal{M}f \le \mathcal{M}g + \alpha / 2$, and thus \[
    \left| \left\{ \mathcal{M}f \ge \alpha \right\}  \right| \le \left| \left\{ \mathcal{M}g \ge \alpha / 2 \right\}  \right| \le \frac{2c_d}{\alpha} \left\|g\right\|_{L^1} = \frac{2c_d}{\alpha} \int\limits_{\left| f \right| \ge \alpha / 2} \left| f \right| .
    \] We prove the second estimate with dimension-dependent constant.
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|\mathcal{M}f\right\|_{L^p}^p
        &= \int_{\R^d} \int_0^{\left| \mathcal{M}f(x) \right| } pt^{p-1} \dd t \dd x = p \int_0^\infty t ^{p-1} \lambda \left( \mathcal{M}f \ge t \right) \dd t\\
        &\le p c_d \int_0^\infty t ^{p-2} \int \left| f(x) \right| \ind_{\left\{ t \le 2 \left| f(x) \right|  \right\} }\dd x \dd t\\
        &= 2^{p-1}\frac{p}{p-1} c_d \int \left| f(x) \right| ^p \dd x.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Lebesgue differentiation and density theorems.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $f\in L^1_\text{loc}(\R^d)$, then a.e.\ $x\in \R^d$ is a \emph{Lebesgue point} of $f$, that is, \[
        f(x) = \lim_{r\to 0} \frac{1}{\left| B(x,r) \right| } \int_{B(x,r)} f(y) \dd y.
    \] In particular, if $A\subset \R^d$ is measurable, then \[
    \lim_{r\to 0} \frac{\lambda(A\cap B(x,r))}{\lambda(B)} = \ind_{A}(x) \quad \text{a.e.}
    \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    We may assume that $f$ is compactly supported and thus integrable. Let $g\in C_c(\R^d)$ with $\left\|f-g\right\|_{L^1} < \varepsilon$, then
    \begin{align*}
         \frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \int_B \left|f - f(x) \right|
        &\le \frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \int_B \left| f-g \right| +  \frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \int_B \left|g - g(x) \right| + \left| f(x) - g(x) \right| .
    \end{align*}
    The first term is bounded by $\mathcal{M}(f-g)(x)$, and the second term vanishes as $B \to x$. Hence, for any $\alpha > 0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \lambda \left( x\colon \varlimsup_{B\to x} \frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \int_B \left| f-f(x) \right| \ge 2\alpha \right)
        &\le \lambda \left( \mathcal{M}(f-g) \ge \alpha \right) + \lambda \left( x\colon \left| f(x) - g(x) \right| \ge \alpha \right) \\
        &\le c(\alpha,d) \left\|f-g\right\|_{L^1} \le c(\alpha,d) \varepsilon.
    \end{align*}
    Thus, the LHS above is zero for all $\alpha > 0$, so \[
        \lambda \left( x\colon \varlimsup_{B\to x} \frac{1}{\left| B \right| } \int_B \left| f-f(x) \right| > 0 \right) = 0.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Neumann formula for inversion of sum of operators. In particular, is the set of invertible operators in that setting open, closed, or neither?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a Banach space and $Y$ a normed space, and $T\in \B(X,Y)$ is invertible, and $S\in \B(X,Y)$ with $\left\|S\right\| < \left\|T ^{-1}\right\|^{-1}$, then $S + T$ is invertible and \[
        (S+T)^{-1} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (- T ^{-1}S)^n T^{-1} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty T ^{-1} (- ST^{-1})^n,
    \] with \[
    \left\|(S+T)^{-1}\right\| \le \frac{\left\|T^{-1}\right\|}{1 - \left\|S T ^{-1}\right\|}.
\] In particular, the set of invertible operators is an open subset of $\B(X,Y)$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    The idea is that $T + S = (I + S T ^{-1}) T$. Since $\left\|T^{-1}S\right\|<1$ by assumption and $\B(X)$ is a Banach space, the series in the definition of \[
        R \coloneqq \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-T^{-1}S)^n T^{-1}
    \] converges absolutely and hence converges, and $\left\|R\right\| \le \left\|T^{-1}\right\| / (1 - \left\|ST^{-1}\right\|)$. Furthermore,
    \begin{align*}
        R(S+T)
        &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \left[-(-T^{-1}S)^{n+1} + (-T^{-1}S)^n\right] = I,
    \end{align*}
    and similarly $(S+T)R = I$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

\begin{theorem}[Open mapping theorem]
    If $X,Y$ are Banach spaces and $T\in \B(X,Y)$ is surjective, then $T$ is open. In particular, a bijection $T\in \B(X,Y)$ has a continuous inverse.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Denote $U_r = B_X(0,r)$ and $V_r = B_Y(0,r)$. Then it suffices to show that $V_\varepsilon \subset T U_R$ for some $\varepsilon > 0,\, R> 0$. Since $Y = \bigcup_{n=1} ^\infty \overline{T U_n}$ and $Y$ is Banach, there is $N\in \N$ such that $B_Y(y_0,r) \subset \overline{T U_N} = (2N) \overline{T U_{1 / 2}}$, so $B_Y(z_0,\varepsilon) \subset \overline{TU_{1 / 2}}$. Then, \[
        V_\varepsilon = B_Y(z_0,\varepsilon) - z_0 \subset \overline{TU_{1 / 2}} - \overline{TU_{1 / 2}} \subset \overline{TU_{1 / 2} - TU_{1 / 2}} = \overline{TU_1}.
    \] In particular, $V_{\alpha \varepsilon} = \alpha V_\varepsilon \subset \alpha \overline{TU_1} = \overline{TU_{\alpha}}$ Now it STS that $\overline{T U_1} \subset T U_2$. Let $y \in \overline{T U_1}$. Then there is $x_1 \in U_1$ such that $\left\|y - Tx_1\right\| < \varepsilon / 2$, so $y - Tx_1 \in V_{\varepsilon / 2} \subset \overline{T U_{1 / 2}}$. Inductively we now construct $x_i \in U_{2^{1-i}}$ such that $y - \sum_{i=1}^nTx_i \in V_{\varepsilon 2^{-i}}$. Then $\sum \left\|x_i\right\| \le 2$, so (because $X$ is Banach) $x = \sum_{i=1}^\infty x_i \in U_2$ exists and $y = Tx \in T U_2$.

front: [latex]One-sided bound between complete norms implies equivalence.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is a vector space with complete norms $\left\|\cdot \right\|_1$ and $\left\|\cdot \right\|_2$ such that $\left\|\cdot \right\|_1 \le c \left\|\cdot \right\|_2$ for some $c > 0$, then the norms are equivalent.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    The identity from $(X,\left\|\cdot \right\|_2)$ to $(X,\left\|\cdot \right\|_1)$ is a bijective linear continuous map between Banach spaces, hence the inverse is continuous.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]In Banach spaces, cartesian products and direct sums are the same, and the associated projections are continuous.[/latex]

\begin{theorem}
    Let $X = Y \oplus Z$ be a Banach space with closed subspaces $Y$ and $Z$. Then,
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] The projection onto $Y$ (or $Z$) is continuous,
        \item[(ii)] $X \simeq Y \times Z$ as Banach spaces.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Recall that $Y\times Z$ with $\left\|(y,z)\right\|= \left\|y\right\|+\left\|z\right\|$ is a Banach space. Then the map $T\colon Y\times Z \to X;\, (y,z) \mapsto y+z$ is linear, bounded, and bijective, so it has continuous inverse by the OMT, which proves (ii). Finally, $P = \pi_Y \circ T^{-1}$, where $\pi_Y\colon Y\times Z \to Y; (y,z) \mapsto  y$, is the composition of two continuous linear operators.
\end{proof}

egin{theorem}
    If $(\Omega,\A,\mu)$ is a measure space and $p\in [1,\infty)$, and $\mu$ $\sigma$-finite if $p = 1$, then $(L^p)^\star = L^{p'}$ with the identification \[

egin{proof}
    Assume $\mu$ is finite and $p \in (1,\infty)$. One only needs to show surjectivity of the above identification. Given $\varphi \in (L^p)^{\star}$, let $ u(A) \coloneqq \varphi( \ind_{A})$ for $A \in \A$, then if $A = igcup_{n=1} ^\infty A_n$ is a disjoint union, then $\sum_{n=1}^N \ind_{A_n} o \ind_{A}$ in $L^p$ by DCT, so \[

front: [latex]Hahn-Banach, version with sublinear form[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Hahn-Banach, sublinear form]
    If $X$ is a vector space and $\varphi\colon Y\subset X \to \R$ a linear map on a linear subspace $Y$ of $X$, and $\varphi \le p\!\!\restriction_{Y} $ for a sublinear form $p\colon X \to \R$, then there exists a linear map $\psi\colon X\to \R$ with $\psi \le p$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Take the set of all linear continuations of $\varphi$ that are dominated by $p$ with the obvious order, which has a maximal element $(V,\psi)$ by Zorn's lemma. It suffices to show that $V = X$, so assume there is $x_0 \in X \setminus V$, in particular $x_0 \neq  0$. We let $V' \coloneqq V + \lin \left\{ x_0 \right\} $ and $\varphi'(v + tx_0) = \varphi(v) + \alpha t$, for some $\alpha \in \R$ we have yet to choose. This is a linear continuation, we have to verify that it is dominated by $p$. If $t > 0$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \varphi'(v + t x_0) &= \varphi(v) + t \alpha \le p(v+tx_0) \quad \text{requires}\quad \alpha \le p(v / t + x_0) - \varphi(v / t),\\
        \varphi'(v - t x_0) &= \varphi(v) - t \alpha \le p(v-tx_0) \quad \text{requires}\quad \alpha \ge \varphi(v / t) - p(v / t - x_0).
    \end{align*}
    Such an $\alpha$ exists because, for $x_0,u,w\in X$,
    \begin{align*}
        p(u+x_0) - \varphi(u) \ge \varphi(w) - p(w - x_0)
        &\iff \varphi(u+w) \le p(u+x_0) + p(w-x_0)\\
        &\impliedby \varphi(u+w) \le p(u+w)
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is a normed vector space, then $M\subset X$ is bounded iff $x^\star(M) \subset \R$ is bounded for all $x^\star \in X^\star$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}

\end{proof}

front: [latex]How do separability of $X$ and $X^\star$ relate for a normed space?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a normed space and $X^\star$ is separable, then so is $X$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $\left\{ x_n^\star\colon n\in \N \right\} $ be dense and take $y_n \in X$ with $\left\|y_n\right\| = 1$ and $x_n^\star(y_n) \ge \left\|x_n^\star\right\| / 2$. Then if $Y \coloneqq \left\{ y_n\colon n\in \N \right\} $ was not dense, there would be a non-zero functional $x^\star$ vanishing on $Y$ (by Hahn-Banach), but if $n\in \N$ is such that $\left\|x^\star -x_n^\star\right\| < 1 / 4$, then \[
        \left|x^\star(y_n) - 1 / 2\right| \le \left\|x^\star - x_n^\star\right\| < 1 / 4,
    \] so $x^\star(y_n) \neq  0$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If a subspace of a normed space has finite dimension or codimension, then it has a complement.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If a subspace of a normed space has finite dimension or codimension, then it has a complement.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    If $U \subset X$ is finite dimensional with basis $x_1, \ldots ,x_n$, then it is closed and we let $x_k^\star \in X^\star$ with $x_k^\star(x_j) = \delta_{kj}$, which exist by Hahn-Banach. Then, the map \[
        T \coloneqq \sum_{k=1}^n x_k^\star(\cdot ) x_k
    \] is bounded and linear with $T^2 = T$, so it is a projection, and $R(T) = U$, so $X = U \oplus N(T)$.

    If $Y \subset X$ is closed and $X / Y$ is finite dimensional, let $x_1, \ldots ,x_n \in X$ be representatives of a basis. Then they must be linearly independent in $X$, in particular $V \cap Y = \left\{ 0 \right\} $. Put $V \coloneqq \lin \left\{ x_1, \ldots ,x_n \right\} $, then $V +  Y = X$ and thus $V \oplus  Y = X$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Geomtric Hahn-Banach[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $X$ be a normed space and $A,B\subset X$ non-empty and convex.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $A,B$ are open, then they can be separated by $X^\star$,
        \item[(ii)] If $A$ is compact and $B$ is closed, then they can by strictly separated by $X^\star$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]For $A\subset X$ in a normed space, what is ${}^\perp(A^\perp)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $X$ is a normed vector space and $A \subset X$, then ${}^\perp(A^\perp) = \overline{\lin{A}}$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    We may assume $A$ is a closed linear subspace. $\supset$ is obvious. For the converse assume that $x_0 \in {}^\perp (A^\perp) \setminus A$. Then there is $x^\star$ such that \[
        s \coloneqq \sup_{x\in A}x^\star(x) < x^\star(x_0).
    \] In particular, the LHS is finite, so $x^\star$ vanishes on $A$ (because it is a linear space), so $x^\star \in A^\perp$, so $x^\star(x) = 0$, so $0 \le s < 0$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front:
[latex]Let $X$ be a reflexive normed vector space. Then,
\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(i)] Which subspaces are reflexive?
    \item[(ii)] How do separability of $X$ and $X^\star$ relate?
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $X$ be a reflexive normed vector space.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $X$ is reflexive, then so is every closed linear subspace.
        \item[(ii)] If $X$ is reflexive, then $X$ is separable iff $X^\star$ is separable.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] Let $y^{\star\star} \in Y^{\star\star}$. Define $x^{\star\star} \in X^{\star\star}$ by \[
                x^{\star\star} (x^\star) \coloneqq y^{\star\star}(x^\star \!\!\restriction_{Y} ),\quad x^\star \in X^\star.
            \] Then by reflexivity of $X$ there is $x\in X$ such that $x^{\star\star}(x^\star) = x^\star(x)$ and thus $y^{\star\star}(x^{\star}\!\!\restriction_{Y} ) = x^\star(x)$, so we have to show that $x\in Y$ (then it follows because every $y^\star\in Y^\star$ is the restriction of some $x^\star$ by Hahn-Banach). If $x\not\in Y$, then there is $x^\star \in X^\star$ with $x^\star \!\!\restriction_{Y}  = 0$ and $x^\star(x) = 1$, so that \[
            0 = y^{\star\star}(x^\star \!\!\restriction_{Y} ) = x^\star(x) = 1,
            \] a contradiction.
        \item[(ii)] If $X^\star$ is separable then so is $X$, and if $X = X^{\star\star}$ is separable then so is $X^\star$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]For a Banach space $X$, how do reflexivity of $X$ and $X^\star$ relate?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X$ is a Banach space, then $X$ is reflexive iff $X^\star$ is reflexive.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Assume $X^\star$ is reflexive and $X$ is not. Then by Hahn-Banach there is an element $x^{\star\star\star} \neq  0$ which vanishes on $X \subset X^{\star\star}$, but it corresponds to an $x^\star \in X^\star$, which then vanishes on $X$ but is not zero, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Dual spaces are weak${}^\star$ sequentially complete, and reflexive spaces are weakly sequentially complete.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $X$ be a normed vector space.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $(\left<x^\star_n,x \right>) $ is Cauchy for all $x\in X$, then $x^\star_n \rightharpoonup x^\star$ for some $x^\star \in X^\star$.
        \item[(ii)] If $X$ is reflexive and $(\left<x^\star,x_n \right> )$ is Cauchy for all $x^\star\in X^\star$, then $x_n \rightharpoonup x$ for some $x\in X$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    (i) is clear, just define $x^\star(x) \coloneqq \lim_{n\to \infty} x_n^\star(x)$. For (ii), apply (i) to $(J_X(x_n))_{n\in \N} \in (X^{\star\star})^\N$, which will converge weakly to some $x^{\star\star} = J_X(x)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]``Fatou's lemma'' for strong convergence of operators.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X,Y$ are normed vector spaces, and $T_n \in \B(X,Y),n\in \N$ converge strongly to $T\in \B(X,Y)$, then $\left\|T\right\|\le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_n\right\|$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    If a subsequence $(\left\|T_{k(n)}\right\|)_{n\in \N}$ converges, then for every $x\in X$, $T_{k(n)}x\to Tx$ in $Y$ and so
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|Tx\right\| = \lim_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_{k(n)}x\right\| \le \left\|x\right\| \lim_{n\to \infty} \left\|T_{k(n)}\right\|.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of strong convergence in $\B(X,Y)$ if $X,Y$ are Banach spaces (involving boundedness and dense subsets.)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $X,Y$ are Banach spaces and $T_n \in \B(X,Y)$, and $D\subset X$ with $\overline{\lin{D}} = X$, then TFAE.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $(T_n)$ converges strongly in $\B(X,Y)$.
        \item $\sup_{n\in \N} \left\|T_n\right\| < \infty$ and $(T_n x)$ converges in $Y$ for all $x\in D$.
    \end{enumerate}
    (i) $\implies$ (ii) holds if only $X$ is complete, and (ii) $\implies$ (i) holds if only $Y$ is complete.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    (i) $\implies$ (ii) follows from the uniform boundedness principle. If (ii) holds and $Y$ is complete, then $Tx \coloneqq \lim_{n\to \infty} T_n x$ for $x\in \lin{D}$ extends uniquely to a linear operator $T\in \B(X,Y)$. Then for any $x\in X$ and $z\in \lin{D}$,
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|T_n x - T x\right\|
        &\le \left\|T_n\right\| \left\|x-z\right\| + \left\|T_n z - T z \right\| + \left\|T\right\| \left\|z - x\right\|.
    \end{align*}
    Then let $n\to \infty$ and then $z \to x$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of weak(${}^\star$) convergence in normed spaces (involving boundedness and dense subsets).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $X$ be a normed space and $D^\star\subset X^\star$ with $\lin{D^\star}$ dense. Then $(x_n)$ converges weakly if and only if $\sup_{n\in \N}\left\|x_n\right\|< \infty$ and $x^\star(x_n)$ converges for all $x^\star\in D^\star$.

    For weak${}^\star$ convergence, the converse always holds and $\implies$ requires completeness of $X$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    Weak convergence of $(x_n)$ is strong convergence of $(J_X(x_n))$ in $X^{\star\star} = \B(X^\star,\R)$, and both $X^\star$ and $\R$ are complete. Then the equivalence is just the characterisation of strong convergence for operators between Banach spaces.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Weak(${}^\star$) convergence in $c_0$ and $\ell^p$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item Weak (same as weak${}^\star$ because reflexive) convergence in $\ell^p$ for $p\in (1,\infty)$, and weak convergence in $c_0$ are equivalent to boundedness plus component-wise convergence.
        \item The same holds \emph{only} for weak${}^\star$ convergence in $\ell^1$ and $\ell^\infty$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $D \coloneqq \left\{ e_n\colon n\in \N \right\} $ has dense span in $\ell^{p'} = (\ell^p)^\star$ and $\ell_1 = c_0^\star$ (but not $\ell^\infty$!)
        \item They are dual to the complete spaces $c_0$ and $\ell^1$ respectively, in both of which $D$ from (i) has dense span.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Mazur's theorem (on weak convergence in normed spaces).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Mazur]
    Let $x_n \rightharpoonup x$ be a weakly convergent sequence in a normed vector space $X$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $(x_n) \subset C \subset X$ is closed and convex, then $x\in C$.
        \item[(ii)] There exists a sequence $(y_n)$ such that $y_n$ is a convex combination of $\left\{ x_k\colon k\ge n \right\} $ with $y_n \to x$ in norm.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item[(i)] If $x\not\in C$, then there is an $x^\star\in X^\star$ that strongly separates $x$ and $C$, a contradiction.
        \item[(ii)] For every $n\in \N$, the set $C_n$ of convex combinations of $\left\{ x_k\colon k\ge n \right\} $ is convex and contains almost all $x_k$, so $x\in \overline{C_n}$. Hence we can choose $y_n \in C_n $ with $\left\|y_n-x\right\|\le 1 / n$, say.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Banach-Alaoglu theorem (and extension to Bolzano-Weierstraß theorem).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Bolzano-Weierstraß]
    The unit ball in a complete Banach space which is adjoint to a separable normed space is weak${}^\star$ sequentially relatively compact.
\end{theorem}

\begin{theorem}[Banach-Alaoglu]
    Let $X$ be a normed vector space
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item If $X$ is separable, then the unit ball in $X^\star$ is weakly${}^\star$ sequentially relatively compact.
        \item If $X$ is reflexive, then the unit ball in $X$ is weakly sequentially compact.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item Let $(x_n^\star)$ be bounded, and $\left\{ x_k\colon k\in \N \right\} $ dense in $X$. Then we can extract a subsequence $(x_{k(n)}^\star)$ which converges on $x_k$ for every $k\in \N$ (by a diagonal argument and because of the boundedness), so $(x_{k(n)}^\star)$ is bounded and converges pointwise on a dense subset of $X$, so it has a strong limit $x^\star$ with $\left\|x^\star\right\|\le \varliminf_{n\to \infty}\left\|x_{k(n)}^\star\right\| \le \varliminf_{n\to \infty} \left\|x_n^\star\right\|$.
        \item Let $(x_n)$ be a bounded sequence, and replace $X$ by the separable reflexive space $\overline{\lin \left\{ x_n\colon n\in\N \right\} }$. Then, $X^\star$ is separable and $(J_X(x_n)) \subset X^{\star\star}$ is bounded and by (i) has a weakly${}^\star$ convergent subsequence, which by reflexivity implies that the corresponding subsequence of $(x_n)$ converges weakly in $X$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $X$ is a Banach space with a measure $\mu$, what is the connection between $X^\star$ and $L^p(\mu)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    Let $X$ be a Banach space with a measure $\mu$ that has finite $p$'th moments for some $p\in [1,\infty)$.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $x^\star_n \rightharpoonup x^\star$ implies $x^\star_n \tendsto{L^p} x^\star$.
        \item If $X$ is separable then $X^\star \hookrightarrow L^{p}(\mu)$ is compact.
    \end{enumerate} 
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    By definition we have $x_n^\star(x) \to x^\star(x)$ for all $x\in X$, and because $X$ is complete, $(x_n^\star)$ is bounded in $X^\star$, so \[
        \int |x^\star_n(x) - x^\star(x)|^p \mu(\dd x) \to 0
    \] by dominated convergence. Now if $X$ is separable and $(x_n^\star)$ bounded, then by Banach-Alouglu there is a weakly${}^\star$ convergent subsequence which is $L^p$-convergent.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]The covariance operator $\widehat{C}_\mu \colon X^\star \to X$ of a centred Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space is compact.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proof}
    By Banach-Alouglu, it suffices to show that if $x_n^\star \rightharpoonup ^\star x^\star$, then $\widehat{C}_\mu(x^\star_n) \to \widehat{C}_\mu(x^\star)$. Indeed, $x^\star_n \tendsto{L^2(\mu)} x^\star$ (because $\mu$ has moments), so by Hahn-Banach
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|\widehat{C}_\mu(x^\star_n) - \widehat{C}_\mu(x^\star)\right\|
        &= \sup_{\left\|y^\star\right\|\le 1} \left| C_\mu(x^\star_n,y^\star) - C_\mu(x^\star,y^\star) \right| \le \sup_{\left\|y^\star\right\|\le 1} \left\|(x_n^\star-x^\star) y^\star\right\|_{L^1(\mu)}\\
&\le \left\|x_n^\star - x^\star\right\|_{L^2(\mu)} \int \|x\|^2 \mu(\dd x)\to 0.
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $\varphi,\varphi_1, \ldots ,\varphi_n$ are linear functionals on a vector space $X$, when can you conclude that there are $\lambda_i$ such that $\varphi = \sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i \varphi_i$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\varphi,\varphi_1, \ldots ,\varphi_n$ are linear functionals on a vector space $X$ such that $\bigcap_{i=1} ^n \ker \varphi_i \subset \ker \varphi$, then there are $\lambda_i$ such that $\varphi = \sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i \varphi_i$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $\ell \colon X \to \R^n;\, x \mapsto (\varphi_1(x), \ldots ,\varphi_n(x))$. Then there is a linear map $\varphi' \colon \R^n \to \R$ such that $\varphi = \varphi' \circ \ell$. Indeed, define $\varphi'$ on $\img \ell$ by $\varphi(\ell(x)) \coloneqq \varphi(x)$ which is well-defined by assumption and linear, then extend it to all of $\R^d$. Then $\varphi'(y) = \sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i y_i$, that is $\varphi = \sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i \varphi_i$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front:
[latex]If $F$ is a vector space of linear functionals over a vector space $X$, and we equip $X$ with the weak $F$-topology, then what is the topological dual of $X$?
[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $F$ is a vector space of linear functionals over a vector space $X$, and we equip $X$ with the weak $F$-topology, then the topological dual of $X$ is $F$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $\varphi\colon X \to \R$ be $w_F$-continuous. Then $\varphi^{-1}((-1,1))$ is open, so there are $f_1, \ldots ,f_n \in F$ and $\varepsilon > 0$ such that \[
        \cap_{i=1}^n f_i^{-1}((-\varepsilon,\varepsilon)) \subset \varphi^{-1}((-1,1)).
    \] In particular, if $x \in \cap_{i=1}^n \ker f_i \subset \text{LHS} \subset \varphi^{-1}((-1,1))$ then this is also true for $\lambda x$ for all $\lambda > 0$ and thus $\lambda |\varphi(x)| < 1$ for all $\lambda > 0$, so $x\in \ker \varphi$. But then $\varphi$ is a linear combination of the $f_i$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $X$ is a topological vector space of functions such that point evaluations are continuous, then point evaluations are weak${}^\star$ dense in $X'$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $X$ is a topological vector space of functions such that point evaluations are continuous, then point evaluations are weak${}^\star$ dense in $X'$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    The topological dual of $X'$ with the weak topology (i.e.\ $\varphi_n \to \varphi$ iff $\varphi_n(f) \to \varphi(f)$ for all $f\in X$) is exactly $X$. Now if point evaluations weren't dense then there was by Hahn-Banach (for topological vector spaces) an $f\in X$ such that $f\neq  0$ but $\delta_x(f) = f(x) = 0$ for all $x$ in the domain of $f$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cameron Martin space of a Gaussian measure on a space of functions as RKHS[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on a Banach space $B$, and $D^\star \subset B^\star$ is weak${}^\star$-dense, then $\widehat{C}_\mu(D^\star)$ is dense in $\mathcal{H}_\mu$. In particular, if $B$ is a space of functions on which $\delta_t,t\in T,$ are continuous, then $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ is the completion of the inner product space defined by \[
\mathcal{H}_\mu^K \coloneqq \lin \left\{ k(t,\cdot )\colon t\in T \right\} ,\quad \left<k(t,\cdot ),k(s,\cdot ) \right> = k(t,s),
\] where $k(t,s) =C_\mu(\delta_t,\delta_s) = \E \left[ f(t)f(s) \right] $. Furthermore, for $f\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$ and $t\in T$, \[
f(t) = \left<f, k(t,\cdot ) \right>_{\mathcal{H}_\mu} .
\]
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    For the first claim simply recall that $\ell_n \to \ell$ weak${}^\star$ implies $\ell_n \to \ell$ in $L^2(\mu)$, hence $\widehat{C}_\mu (\ell_n) \to \widehat{C}_\mu(\ell)$ in $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ (by the isomorphism between $\mathcal{R}_\mu$ and $\mathcal{H}_\mu$). Now if $B$ is a space of functions (over $T$), then point evaluations are in $B^\star$, whose dual w.r.t.\ weak${}^\star$ convergence is just $B$, so by HB (the span of) point evaluations is dense, so $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ is the completion of \[
        \widehat{C}_\mu(\delta_t) = \int f(t) f \mu(\dd f) = \int f(t) f(\cdot ) \mu(\dd f) = k(t,\cdot ),\quad t\in T,
    \] where we used that $g\coloneqq \int f(t) f \mu(\dd f)$ satisfies $g(s) = \delta_s(g) = \int f(t) f(s) \mu(\dd f) = k(t,s)$ for all $s\in T$, w.r.t.\ \[
    \left<k(t,\cdot ),k(s,\cdot ) \right> = C_\mu(\delta_t,\delta_s) = \int f(t)f(s) \mu(\dd f) = k(t,s).
\] The final statement follows through denseness.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definition of Cameron-Martin space of a Gaussian measure $\mu$, and $\mathcal{H}_\mu \subset B$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    The CM space of $\mu$ is the closure of the inner product space \[
        \widehat{C}_\mu(B^\star) = \left\{ h\coloneqq \int x h^\star(x) \mu(\dd x)\colon h^\star\in B^\star \right\} ,\quad \left<h,k \right> _{\mathcal{H}_\mu} \coloneqq C_\mu(h^\star,k^\star).
    \] This is well-defined, $\mathcal{H}_\mu \subset B$, and \[
    \left\|h\right\|_\mu^2 \ge \frac{1}{\left\|C_\mu\right\|} \left\|h\right\|^2.
    \]
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    To show well-definedness, by polarisation it STS that $\left\|h\right\|_\mu^2 = C_\mu(h^\star,h^\star)$ does not depend on the choice of $h^\star$. Indeed, if $h = \widehat{C}_\mu(h_1^\star) = \widehat{C}_\mu(h_2^\star)$, then (putting $k\coloneqq h_1^\star + h_2^\star$),
    \begin{align*}
        C_\mu(h_1^\star,h_1^\star) - C_\mu(h_2^\star,h_2^\star) = C_\mu(k,h_1^\star) - C_\mu(k,h_2^\star) = k(h) - k(h) = 0.
    \end{align*}
    For the next statement, if $h^\star \in B$ then \[
        \left\|h\right\|^2 = \sup_{\left\|\ell\right\|\le 1} \ell(h)^2 = \sup_\ell C_\mu(h^\star,\ell)^2 \le \sup C_\mu(h^\star,h^\star) C_\mu(\ell,\ell) \le \left\|C_\mu\right\| \left\|h\right\|_\mu^2.
    \] In particular, Cauchy-sequences in $\mathcal{H}_\mu^\circ$ are also Cauchy-sequences in $B$ so the closure is $\subset B$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Gaussian measures: Definition of $\mathcal{R}_\mu$ and isomorphism with $\mathcal{H}_\mu$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    The canonical identification $B^\star \to \mathcal{H}_\mu^\circ;\, h^\star \mapsto  h = \widehat{C}_\mu(h^\star)$ extends to an isomorphism \[
        \iota\colon \mathcal{R}_\mu \to \mathcal{H}_\mu;\, h^\star \mapsto h\coloneqq  \int_B x h^\star(x) \mu(\dd x),
    \] where $\mathcal{R}_\mu$ is the closure of $B^\star$ in $L^2(B,\mu)$. In particular, $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ is separable, and for $h, k \in \mathcal{H}_\mu$, $\left<h,k \right> _{\mathcal{H}_\mu} = \int h^\star k^\star \dd \mu$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Firstly $B^\star \subset L^2(B,\mu)$ by Fernique. The map $B^\star \to \mathcal{H}_\mu^\circ;\, h^\star \mapsto h \coloneqq \widehat{C}_\mu(h^\star)$ is linear and surjective, and \[
        \left\|h\right\|_\mu^2 = C_\mu(h^\star,h^\star) = \int h^\star(x)^2 \mu(\dd x) = \left\|h^\star\right\|_{L^2}^2,
    \] so it is an isomorphism. Then taking the closure on both sides gives an isomorphism $\iota \colon \mathcal{R}_\mu \to \mathcal{H}_\mu$. Now let $f\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ and $f_n \in B^\star$, $f_n \tendsto{L^2} f$. Then $\iota(f_n) = \int x f_n(x) \mu(\dd x) \to \iota(f)$ in $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ hence also in $B$, but
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|\iota(f_n) - \int x f(x) \mu(\dd x)\right\|_B \le \left\|[x\mapsto x]\right\|_{L^2(\mu)} \left\|f_n - f\right\|_{L^2(\mu)} \to 0,
    \end{align*}
    so in fact $\iota(f) = \int x f(x) \mu(\dd x)$.

    Then separability of $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ follows from separability of $L^2(B,\mu)$ ($\mu$ is a finite measure and the Borel $\sigma$-algebra on $B$ is countably generated), and the final claim from the scalar product on $L^2(B,\mu)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Gaussian measures: In what sense are elements of $\mathcal{R}_\mu$ almost linear?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    Every $\ell\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ is $\mu$-a.e.\ equal to a linear map. In fact, $\mathcal{R}_\mu$ consists exactly of (equivalence classes of) measurable maps $B\to \R$ which are linear on a measurable linear subspace of $B$ with full $\mu$-measure.
    %For every $\ell \in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ there is a linear subspace $V_\ell \subset B$ with $\mu(V_\ell) = 1$ and a linear map $\ell'\colon V_\ell \to \R$ such that $\ell = \ell'$ on $V_\ell$ (in particular $\mu$-a.s.).
\end{lemma}
%\begin{remark}
%    If the linear map $\ell'\colon V_\ell \subset B \to \R$ to which $\ell\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ is $\mu$-a.e.\ equal had a \emph{measurable} linear extension $B\to \R$, then it would already be bounded so $\ell\in B^\star$. Hence if $\dim B = \infty$ than this is not true, in particular there is a measurable set $A\subset B$ and $v\in B$ such that $A + \left<v \right> $ is not measurable (otherwise we could use Zorn's lemma to construct a measurable linear extension).
%\end{remark}
\begin{proof}
    Let $\ell\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$, then there exists $\ell_n \tendsto{L^2(\mu)} \ell$ with $\ell_n \in B^\star$. By passing to a subsequence, $\ell_n(x) \to \ell(x)$ for $\mu$-a.e.\ $x$, so \[
        V_\ell \coloneqq \left\{ x\in B\colon \lim_{n\to \infty} \ell_n(x) \text{ exists} \right\}
    \] is a (measurable!) linear space with $\mu(V_\ell) = 1$, and $\ell = \ell'$ $\mu$-a.e.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Guassian measures: What is the distribution of elements of $\mathcal{R}_\mu$ (as random variables $(B,\mu) \to \R$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    Every $h^\star\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ is centred Gaussian (as a random variable $(B,\mu) \to \R$) with variance $\left\|h^\star\right\|_{L^2(\mu)} = \left\|h\right\|_\mu^2$. The covariance of $h^\star$ and $k^\star$ is $\left<h^\star,k^\star \right> _{L^2(\mu)} = \left<h,k \right> _\mu$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Take $h_n^\star \in B^\star$ with $h_n^\star \to h^\star$ in $L^2(\mu)$, which we can choose to have $\left\|h_n^\star\right\|_{L^2} = \left\|h^\star\right\|_{L^2} ( = \left\|h\right\|_\mu)$. Then $h_n$ is $\mathcal{N}(0,\left\|h\right\|_\mu^2)$ for all $n\in \N$, and $L^2$-convergence implies convergence in law. About the covariance, \[
        \E \left[ h^\star k^\star \right] = \int h^\star(x) k^\star(x) \mu(\dd x) = \left<h^\star,k^\star \right> _{L^2} = \left<h,k \right> _\mu.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of weak${}^\star$ denseness of $D^\star \subset X^\star$ for a topological vector space $X$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
$D^\star \subset X^\star$ is weak${}^\star$ dense iff $\varphi(x) = 0$ for all $\varphi\in D^\star$ implies $x=0$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
The dual of $X^\star$ w.r.t. the weak${}^\star$ topology is just $X$, so by Hahn-Banach a subset is dense iff the only dual element (i.e. element of $x$) vanishing on all of the elements is zero.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]If $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure and $\dim \mathcal{H}_\mu = \infty$, then dilations of $\mu$ are mutually singular.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $\mu$ be a centred Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$ with $\dim \mathcal{H}_\mu = \infty$. If $c\in \R$ and $D_c\colon B\to B;\, x \mapsto cx$, then $D_c(\mu)$ and $\mu$ are mutually singular except if $c = \pm 1$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $(e_n)$ be an orthonormal sequence in $\mathcal{R}_\mu \subset L^2(\mu)$. Then $e_n\colon B \to \R$ are i.i.d.\ standard Gaussians, so if $S_N \coloneqq \frac 1N \sum_{n=1}^\infty e_n^2$ then \[
        \lim_{N\to \infty} S_N(x) = 1 \quad \mu-\text{a.a. } x\in B.
    \] Now $D_c(\mu)$ is also a centred Gaussian measure w.r.t.\ which $e_n \in \mathcal{N}(0,c^2)$ are also i.i.d., so \[
    \lim_{N\to \infty} S_N(x) = c^2 \quad D_c(\mu)-\text{a.a. } x\in B.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cameron-Martin theorem: If $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure, for which elements $h\in B$ is $T_h(\mu)$ and $\mu$ mutually absolutely continuous, and what is the density?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Cameron-Martin]
    Let $\mu$ be a centred Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$, and $T_h\colon B \to B; x \mapsto x+h$. Then $T_h(\mu)$ and $\mu$ are mutually absolutely continuous iff $h\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$, in which case $T_h(\mu)$ has density \[
        G_h(x) \coloneqq  \e^{h^\star(x) - \left\|h\right\|_\mu^2 / 2},\quad x\in B,
    \] w.r.t.\ $\mu$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose that $h\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$. Then, for $\ell\in B^\star$,
    \begin{align*}
        \widehat{T_h(\mu)}(\ell)
        &= \int \e^{\i \ell(x)} T_h(\mu)(\dd x)
        = \e^{\i \ell(h)} \e^{C_\mu(\i\ell,\i\ell) / 2} = \e^{\i \ell(h)} \e^{-C_\mu(\ell,\ell)  /2}.
    \end{align*}
    On the other hand,
    \begin{align*}
        \widehat{(G_h \mu)}(\ell)
        = \int \e^{\i \ell(x)} G_h(x) \mu(\dd x)
        &= \e^{-\left\|h\right\|_\mu^2 / 2} \int \e^{(\i \ell + h^\star)(x)} \mu(\dd x)\\
        &= \e^{-\left\|h\right\|_\mu^2 / 2} \e^{\frac{1}{2} C_\mu(\i\ell+h^\star,\i \ell+h^\star)}\\
        &= \e^{\frac{1}{2}C_\mu(\i\ell,\i\ell)}  \e^{\i C_\mu(\ell,h^\star)}\\
        &= \e^{\i \ell(h)} \e^{-\frac{1}{2}C_\mu(\ell,\ell)}.
    \end{align*}
    Now suppose that $h\not\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$, so that there are $\ell_n\in B^\star$ with $C_\mu(\ell_n,\ell_n) = 1$ and $\ell_n(h) \to \infty$. Then $\ell_n \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ under $\mu$, and $\ell_n \sim \mathcal{N}(\ell_n(h),1)$ under $T_h(\mu)$ (because $\ell(T_h(\cdot )) = \ell(h) + \ell(\cdot )$). Then \[
        \left\|\mu - T_h(\mu)\right\|_{\text{TV}} \ge \left\|\ell_n(\mu) - \ell_n(T_h(\mu))\right\|_\text{TV} = \left\|\mathcal{N}(0,1) - \mathcal{N}(\ell_n(h),1)\right\| _\text{TV} \to 2,
    \] so $\mu$ and $T_h(\mu)$ are mutually singular.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Connection of Cameron-Martin space with linear subspaces of full measure. What is $\mu(\mathcal{H}_\mu)$?[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{proposition}
    Let $\mu$ be a centred Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$. Then $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ is the intersection of all measurable linear subspaces of full measure. If $\dim \mathcal{H}_\mu = \infty$, then $\mu(\mathcal{H}_\mu) = 0$
\end{proposition}
egin{proof}
    Let $V$ be a measurable linear subspace of full measure and $h\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$. Then $V-h$ has full measure by the Cameron-Martin theorem, in particular $(V-h)\cap V eq  \emptyset $ so $h\in V$.

    Now suppose that $h ot\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$, so that there are $\ell_n\in B^\star$ with $C_\mu(\ell_n,\ell_n) = 1$ and $\ell_n(h) \ge 2^{n / 2}$. Then put $\varphi(x) \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty 2^{-n} \ell_n(x)^2$ for $x\in B$, which is measurable so a non-negative random variable, and
    egin{align*}
        \int_B \varphi(x) \mu(\dd x) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty 2^{-n} C_\mu(\ell_n,\ell_n) < \infty,
    \end{align*}
    so $\varphi(x) < \infty$ for $\mu$-a.a.\ $x\in \mathcal{B}$. Then $V \coloneqq \left\{ x\in B\colon \varphi(x) < \infty ight\} $ is a measurable linear subspace with full measure and $x ot\in V$.

    Finally if $\dim \mathcal{H}_\mu = \infty$, take an orthonormal sequence $(e_n)$ in $\mathcal{R}_\mu$, so that $\sup_n |e_n(x)| = \infty$ for $\mu$-a.a.\ $x\in B$, say for $x\in \Omega_0$ (they are i.i.d.\ Gaussians). Then if there exists $x\in \mathcal{H}_\mu \cap \Omega_0$, we would have \[
        \infty > \left\|x ight\|_\mu ^2 = \left\|x^\star ight\|_{L^2(\mu)}^2 = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<e_n,x^\star ight>^2 _{L^2(\mu)} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty C_\mu(e_n,x^\star)^2 = \sum_{n=1}^\infty e_n(x)^2 = \infty.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Gaussian measures: Representation of $\left\|\cdot \right\|_\mu$ that allows for extension from $\mathcal{H}_\mu$ to $B$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    Let $\mu$ be a centred Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space, and define \[
        \left\|x\right\|_\mu \coloneqq \sup_{C_\mu(\ell,\ell) \le 1} \ell(x),\quad x\in B.
    \] Then $\mathcal{H}_\mu = \left\{ x\in B\colon \left\|x\right\|_\mu < \infty \right\} $, and $\left\|\cdot \right\|_\mu$ coincides with the norm on $\mathcal{H}_\mu$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $h\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$. Then,
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|h\right\|_{\mathcal{H}_\mu}
        = \sup_{k\in \mathring{\mathcal{H}}_\mu\text{ normed}} \left<h,k \right> _{\mathcal{H}_\mu} = \sup_{k^\star \in B^\star} k^\star(h) = \left\|h\right\|_\mu,
    \end{align*}
    and this is finite. Recalling the isomorphism $\iota\colon \mathcal{R}_\mu \subset L^2(\mu) \to \mathcal{H}_\mu$, it now suffices to show that if $x\in B$ with $\left\|x\right\|_\mu < \infty$ then there is $x^\star\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ with $\iota(x^\star)=x$. Indeed, let us define \[
        \varphi\colon \mathcal{R}_\mu \to \R;\, f \mapsto f(x).
    \] This is linear and bounded, because for $\ell \in B^\star$ (which is dense),
    \begin{align*}
        \left| \varphi(\ell) \right| ^2 = \ell(x)^2 \le C_\mu(\ell,\ell) \left\|x\right\|_\mu^2 = \left\|\ell\right\|_{L^2(\mu)}^2 \left\|x\right\|_\mu^2,
    \end{align*}
    so by Riesz there is $x^\star \in \mathcal{R}_\mu$ with
    \begin{align*}
        \ell(x) = \varphi(\ell) = \left<\ell,x^\star \right> _{L^2(\mu)} = \ell(\iota(x^\star))
    \end{align*}
    for all $\ell\in B^\star$, so $x = \iota(x^\star)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Extension of Hilbert-Schmidt operator $A\colon \mathcal{H}_\mu \to \mathcal{H}$ to $\widehat{A}\colon B\to \mathcal{H}$.[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
Suppose $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$.
egin{theorem}
    If $A\colon \mathcal{H}_\mu o \mathcal{H}$ is a Hilbert-Schmidt operator into a separable Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$, then there exists a measurable extension $\widehat{A}\colon B o \mathcal{H}$ which is linear on a measurable linear subspace of full $\mu$-measure, and such that $ u \coloneqq \widehat{A}^\# \mu$ is Gaussian with $C_ u(h,k) = \left<A^\star h, A^\star k ight> _\mu$.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}
    Let $(e_n^\star)$ be an ONS in $\mathcal{R}_\mu$, and $V\subset B$ a linear measurable subspace of full measure on which all $e_n^\star$ are linear, and put, for $N\in \N$, \[
        \widehat{A}_N(\cdot ) \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^N e_n^\star(\cdot ) (A e_n)\colon B o \mathcal{H}.
    \] Then $\widehat{A}_N$ is an $\mathcal{H}$-valued martingale ($(e_n^\star)$ are i.i.d.\ standard normals), and
    egin{align*}
        \E^\mu \left[ \left\|\widehat{A}_N ight\|_\mathcal{H}^2 ight]
        = \int_B \left<\widehat{A}_N(x),\widehat{A}_N(x) ight> _\mathcal{H} \mu(\dd x)
        &= \sum_{n,m=1}^N \left<A e_n,A e_m ight> _\mathcal{H} \int e_n^\star(x) e_m^\star(x) \mu(\dd x)\

        C_ u(h,h)

        = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<A^\star h,e_n ight> _\mu^2

        %= \sum_{n,m=1}^\infty \delta_{n,m} \left<h,Ae_n ight>_\mathcal{H} \left<k,Ae_n ight> _{\mathcal{H}}

front: [latex]Unique measurable extension of $A\colon \mathcal{H}_\mu \to B'$ to $A\colon B \to B'$ (provided a suitable Gaussian measure on $B'$ exists).[/latex]
back:
"[latex]
Suppose $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$.
egin{theorem}
    Suppose $A\colon \mathcal{H}_\mu o B'$ is a bounded linear operator into a separable Banach space $B'$, and there exists a centred Gaussian measure $ u$ on $B'$ with $C_ u(\ell_1,\ell_2) = \left<A^\star \ell_1,A^\star \ell_2 ight>_\mu $. Then there exists a unique measurable extension $\widehat{A}\colon B o B'$ that is linear on a linear measurable subspace of full measure. It satsifies $ u = \widehat{A}^\# \mu$.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}[Proof (Existence).]
    We first show that there is such a map $\widehat{A}$ which satisfies $ u = \widehat{A}^\# \mu$. Let $\mathcal{H}$ be a Hilbert space in which $B'$ embeds densely and continuously. Then let $ u' \coloneqq \iota^\# u$ where $\iota\colon B' \hookrightarrow \mathcal{H}$ is open by OMT, so that $ u'(B') = 1$, and if $\ell,\ell'\in \mathcal{H}^\star \subset B'^\star$, \[
        C_{ u'}(\ell,\ell') = \int_\mathcal{H} \ell(x) \ell'(x) u'(\dd x) = \int_{B'} \ell(x)\ell'(x) u(\dd x) = \left<A^\star \ell,A^\star\ell' ight> _\mu.
        \] Now there exists a measurable map $\widehat{A}'\colon B o \mathcal{H}$ which is linear on a measurable linear subspace of full $\mu$-measure $V$ and which coincides with $A$ on $\mathcal{H}_\mu$, and such that $\widehat{A}'^\# \mu = u'$ (because it is Gaussian with the same covariance as $ u'$ above). Then, $V' \coloneqq \left\{x\colon \widehat{A}'x \in B_2 ight\}$ satisfies $\mu(V') = u'(B_2) = 1$, so $V \cap V'$ is linear measurable of full $\mu$-measure, and \[
    \widehat{A}x \coloneqq egin{cases}
        \widehat{A}'x &, x \in V\cap V',\
        0&, ext{ else},
    \end{cases}
    \] satisfies
    egin{align*}
        (\widehat{A}^\# \mu)(C) = \mu(x\colon \widehat{A}x \in C) = \mu(x\colon \widehat{A}'x \in C) = u'(C) = u(C).
    \end{align*}
    and all other requirements.
\end{proof}
egin{proof}[Proof (Uniqueness).]
    It suffices to show that if $A\colon B o B'$ is measurable, linear on a measurable linear subspace $V\subset B$ with full measure, and $A = 0$ on $\mathcal{H}_\mu$, then $A = 0$ $\mu$-a.e.

    Let for $c\in \R$ and $\ell\in B'^\star$ the set $V_{c,\ell} \coloneqq \left\{ x\in V\colon \ell(Ax) \le c ight\} $. This is measurable, and if $h\in \mathcal{H}_\mu \subset V$ and $x\in V$, then $x + h \in V$ and $\ell(A(x+h)) = \ell(Ax + Ah) = \ell(Ax) \le c$, so \[
        \mu(V_{c,\ell}) = \mu(V_{c,\ell} + \mathcal{H}_\mu) = egin{cases}
            1 &, \mu(V_{c,\ell}) > 0,\
            0 &, \mu(V_{c,\ell}) = 0,
        \end{cases}
    \] so there is $c_\ell \in\R$ with $\mu(V_{c,\ell}) = 0$ for $c < c_\ell$ and $1$ for $c > c_\ell$ (it can't always be one or always be zero by $\sigma$-additivity of $\mu$ and because $\mu(V) = 1$). Since $\mu$ is reflection-invariant, $c_\ell = 0$, that is $\ell(Ax) = 0$ for $\mu$-a.e.\ $x\in B$ and every $\ell\in B'^\star$, so  $Ax = 0$ for $\mu$-a.e.\ $x\in B$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]
"

front: [latex]Gaussian measure theory: Zero-one law for linear measurable subsets.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$.
\begin{proposition}[$0$-$1$-law]
    If $V\subset B$ is linear and measurable, then $\mu(V) \in \left\{ 0,1 \right\} $.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    It suffices to show that $\mu(V) > 0$ implies $\mu(V) = 1$. If there is $h\in \mathcal{H}_\mu$ with $h\not\in V$, then $\alpha h + V$ for $\alpha \in \R$ are uncountably many disjoint linear subspaces of positive measure, a contradiction, so $\mathcal{H}_\mu \subset V$, but then \[
        \mu(V) = \mu(V+\mathcal{H}_\mu) = 1
    \] by the isoperimetric inequality.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Isoperimetric inequality for Gaussian measure theory.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$.
\begin{lemma}[Isoperimetric inequality]
    If $A\subset B$ with $\mu(A) > 0$, then there is $\alpha \in \R$ with $\mu(A) = \Phi(\alpha)$, and for all $\varepsilon > 0$, $\mu(A + B_\varepsilon^\mathcal{H}) \ge \Phi(\alpha + \varepsilon)$. In particular, $\mu(A + \mathcal{H}_\mu) = 1$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}[Proof Idea.]
    In $d = 1$, we obtain the standard normal by projecting the uniform measure on $\partial B_d(0,\sqrt{d} )$ for large $d$. Then the statement is just saying that the volume of $A^\varepsilon$ for $A\subset \partial B(0,1)$ is at least that of the fattening of an ``initial segment'' on the circles surface with the same volume as $A$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Every separable Banach space can be continuously embedded into a Hilbert space.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    Every separable Banach space $B$ can be continuously embedded into a Hilbert space.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $(x_n)_{n\in \N}$ be dense in $B$, and $\ell_n \in B^\star$ with $\ell_n(x_n) \ge \left\|x_n\right\| / 2$ and $\left\|\ell_n\right\| = 1$. Then put \[
        \left<x,y \right> _\mathcal{H} \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty 2^{-n} \ell_n(x) \ell_n(y).
    \] This is bilinear, $\left\|x\right\|_\mathcal{H} \le \left\|x\right\|_B$, and definite. The completion is a Hilbert space in which $B$ is continuously embedded.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Restriction of a centred Gaussian measure to a $\mu$-full continuously embedded Banach space is a Gaussian measure.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
Suppose $\mu$ is a Gaussian measure on a separable Banach space $B$.
egin{lemma}
    If $B_0\subset B$ is a continuously embedded Banach space such that $\mu(B_0) = 1$, then $B_0^\star \hookrightarrow \mathcal{R}_\mu$ (by setting to zero on $B\setminus B_0$), and $ u \coloneqq  \mu ig\vert_{B_0}$ is a Gaussian measure.
\end{lemma}
egin{proof}
    First note that $\iota\colon B_0 o B$ is continuous and injective, so open and hence bi-measurable by the open mapping theorem. That is, subsets of $B_0$ are measurable in $B_0$ iff they are measurable in $B$. Hence we can extend $\ell_0\in B_0^\star$ to a map \[
        \ell(x) \coloneqq egin{cases}
            \ell_0(x)&,x\in B_0,\
            0 &, ext{ else},
        \end{cases}
    \] which is measurable, and linear on the measurable linear subspace $B_0$ which has full $\mu$-measure, so $\ell\in \mathcal{R}_\mu$. But then for $A\subset \R$,
    egin{align*}
        u(\ell_0\in A) = \mu(B_0 \cap \left\{ \ell\in A ight\} ) = \mu(\ell\in A) = \P(\mathcal{N}(0,\left\|\ell ight\|_\mu^2) \in A),
    \end{align*}
    so $\ell_0( u) = \mathcal{N}(0,\left\|\ell ight\|_\mu^2)$, and $\left\|\ell ight\|_\mu^2 = \int \ell(x)^2 \mu(\dd x) = \int_{B_0} \ell_0(x)^2 u(\dd x)$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cameron-Martin space of a Gaussian measure on a Hilbert space in terms of its covariance operator.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $\mu$ be a Gaussian measure on a Hilbert space with covariance operator $K$. Then $\mathcal{H}_\mu^\circ = \rng K $ with $\left<h,k \right> _\mu = \left<K^{-1}h, k \right>$. If $K e_n = \lambda_n e_n$ denotes the eigendecomposition of $K$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \mathcal{H}_\mu &= \left\{ h\colon \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda_n} \left<h,e_n \right> ^2 < \infty \right\}, \\
        \left<h,k \right> _\mu &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda_n} \left<h,e_n \right> \left<e_n,k \right> .
    \end{align*}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    For $h\in \mathcal{H}$,
    \begin{align*}
        \widehat{C}_\mu(h) = \int \left<h,x \right> x \mu(\diff x) = k \mapsto \int \left<h,x \right> \left<k,x \right> \mu(\diff x) = k \mapsto \left<Kh,k \right> = Kh,
    \end{align*}
    and $\left<Kh,Kk \right> _\mu = C_\mu(h,k) = \left<Kh,k \right>$. Now if $h\in \mathcal{H}$, then
    \begin{align*}
        \left\|h\right\|_\mu
        = \sup \left\{ \left<k,h \right> \colon C_\mu(k,k) = 1 \right\},
    \end{align*}
    and for any such $k$, $C_\mu(k,k) = \left<Kk,k \right> = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \lambda_n \left<k,e_n \right> ^2$, so
    \begin{align*}
        \left<k,h \right> ^2
        = \left(\sum_{n=1}^\infty (\lambda_n^{1 / 2} \left<k,e_n \right> ) (\lambda_n^{-1 / 2} \left<h,e_n \right> ) \right)^2
        &\le \left( \sum_{n=1}^\infty \lambda_n \left<k,e_n \right> ^2 \right) \left( \sum_{n=1}^\infty \lambda_n ^{-1} \left<h,e_n \right> ^2 \right) \\
        &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \lambda_n^{-1} \left<h,e_n \right> ^2.
    \end{align*}
    Choosing $\left<k,e_n \right> = \alpha \lambda_n^{-1} \left<h,e_n \right> $ for $n \le N$ and $\left<k,e_n \right> = 0$ for $n > N$ with $\alpha$ such that $C_\mu(k,k) = 1$ gives equality in Hölder, so $\left<k,h \right> ^2 = \sum_{n=1}^N \lambda_n^{-1} \left<h,e_n \right> ^2$, and letting $N\to \infty$ gives the claim.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]General Brownian motion in a Hilbert space, and its Cameron-Martin space.[/latex]
[latex]Motivation, definition, and Cameron-Martin space of ``standard normal'' and cylindrical Brownian motion in a Hilbert space (using larger Hilbert space).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\textbf{Motivation.} We would like to make sense of something like $\sum_{n=1}^\infty N_n e_n$ for $N_n \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ i.i.d. For that purpose, let $(\varepsilon_n > 0)$ be a summable sequence and let $\mathcal{H}'$ be the separable Hilbert space of formal linear combinations $\sum_{n=1}^n \alpha_n e_n$ with $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \varepsilon_n \alpha_n^2 < \infty$. This can be made precise by letting $\mathcal{H}'$ be the closure of $\mathcal{H}$ under the norm \[
\left\|h\right\|_{\mathcal{H}'} \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty \varepsilon_n \left<h,e_n \right> ^2.
\] (This is a complete inner product space, and $\mathcal{H}$ is dense in it by construction. The $(e_n)$ are still an orthogonal basis, so the elements of $\mathcal{H}'$ are exactly $ h = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \alpha_n e_n$ with $\left\|h\right\|_\mathcal{H}'^2 = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \varepsilon_n \alpha_n^2 < \infty$.)

Then let $X \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty N_n e_n$, which is a.s.\ absolutely convergent in $\mathcal{H}'$, and
\begin{align*}
    \E \left[ \left<h,X \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} \left<k,X \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} \right] = \sum_{n,m=1}^\infty \delta_{nm} \left<h,e_n \right>_{\mathcal{H}'} \left<k,e_n \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left<\iota^\star h,e_n \right> _{\mathcal{H}} \left<\iota^\star k,e_n \right> _{\mathcal{H}} = \left<\iota^\star h, \iota^\star k \right> _{\mathcal{H}} = \left<\iota \iota^\star h,k \right> _{\mathcal{H}'},
\end{align*}
so the covariance operator in $\mathcal{H}'$ is $\iota\iota^\star$, which is trace-class.

\begin{definition}
    A \emph{standard normal variable in $\mathcal{H}$} is a Gaussian measure on $\mathcal{H}'$ with covariance operator $\iota \iota^\star$. Its Cameron-Martin space is $\mathcal{H}$.
\end{definition}
\begin{proof}
    $\mathcal{H}_\mu^\circ$ is the range of $\iota \iota^\star$ with \[
    \left<\iota \iota^\star h, \iota \iota^\star k \right> _\mu = \left<\iota \iota^\star h, k \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} = \left<\iota^\star h, \iota^\star k \right> _\mathcal{H}.
\] Thus with the identification $\iota$, $\mathcal{H}_\mu^\circ $ is isomorphic to the range of $\iota^\star$ with the norm of $\mathcal{H}$, whose completion is $\mathcal{H}$ (it contains all $e_n$).
\end{proof}

\begin{definition}
    A \emph{cylindrical Wiener process on $\mathcal{H}$} is a $\iota\iota^\star$-Brownian motion in $\mathcal{H}'$, that is a Gaussian measure on $C([0,1],\mathcal{H}')$ with \[
        \E \left[ \left<h,W(t) \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} \left<k,W(s) \right>_{\mathcal{H}'}  \right] = (t\wedge s) \left<\iota\iota^\star h, k \right> _{\mathcal{H}'}.
    \] Its Cameron Martin space is $H^{1,2}_0([0,1], \mathcal{H})$.
\end{definition}

If it was true that $W$ was $\mathcal{H}$-valued, and $h = \iota^\star h'$, $k = \iota^\star k'$, then
\begin{align*}
    \E \left[ \left<h,W(t) \right> _\mathcal{H} \left<k,W(s) \right> _\mathcal{H} \right]
    = \E \left[ \left<h', \iota W(t) \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} \left<k', \iota W(s) \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} \right]
    = (t\wedge s) \left<\iota \iota^\star h', k' \right> _{\mathcal{H}'} = (t\wedge s) \left<h,k \right> _{\mathcal{H}}.
\end{align*}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Hauptsatz der Integralrechnung für Pfadintegrale in $\C$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    If $f\colon D \subset \C \to \C$ is continuous with antiderivative $F\colon D \to \C$ and $\gamma\colon I \to D$ is a pdb path, then \[
        \int_\gamma f(z) \diff z = F(\gamma(b)) - F(\gamma(a)).
    \] In particular, $\int_\gamma f(z) \diff z = 0$ if $\gamma$ is closed.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \[
        \int_\gamma f(z) \diff z = \int_a^b F'(\gamma(t)) \gamma'(t) \diff t = \int_a^b \frac{\diff }{\diff t} F(\gamma(t)) \diff t = F(\gamma(b)) - F(\gamma(a)).
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Umlaufzahl $n(\gamma,z)$ for path $\gamma$ and  $z\in \C\setminus |\gamma|$.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $\gamma$ be a piecewise db closed path and $z \not\in |\gamma|$. Then, \[
        n(\gamma,z) \coloneqq \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_\gamma \frac{1}{w-z} \diff w
    \] is $\Z$-valued, constant on connected components of $\C \setminus |\gamma|$ and $0$ on the unbounded component.
\end{proposition}

Intuitively, this is just the Hauptsatz ($\int_\gamma 1/w \diff w = \log \gamma(b) - \log \gamma(a)$) except that we can end up on different branches of the logarithm at the start and end of the path.

\begin{proof}
    WLoG $z = 0$. Then, \[
        \varphi(t) \coloneqq \exp \left( \int_a^t \frac{\gamma'(s)}{\gamma(s)} \diff s \right)
    \] satisfies $\varphi' = \gamma' \varphi / \gamma$, so $(\varphi / \gamma)' = 0$, so \[
    \frac{\varphi(b)}{\gamma(b)} = \frac{\varphi(a)}{\gamma(a)} = \frac{1}{\gamma(a)}\implies 1 = \varphi(b) = \exp \left( \int_\gamma \frac{1}{w}\diff s \right) ,
    \] so $\int_\gamma \frac{1}{w}\diff w = 2\pi k$ for some $n(\gamma,z) \coloneqq k\in \Z$. Since $n(\gamma,\cdot )$ is continuous on $\C\setminus |\gamma|$ (DCT) and $\Z$-valued, it is constant on connected components. For the unbounded component, note that \[
|n(\gamma,z)| \le \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_a^b \left| \frac{\gamma'(t)}{\gamma(t) - z} \right| \diff t \to 0
\] as $|z| \to \infty$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Local Cauchy Theorem (and Lemma von Goursat)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    Let $D \subset \C$ open and convex, $p\in D$. If $f\colon D \to \C$ is continuous and holomorphic on $D\setminus \left\{ p \right\} $, then
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item (\textbf{Lemma von Goursat}) $\int_{\partial \Delta} f(z) \diff z = 0$ for every triangle $\Delta \subset D$.
        \item (\textbf{Local Cauchy Theorem}) $f$ has an antiderivative on $D$
        \item $\int_\gamma f = 0$ for every closed path $\gamma$ in $D$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item If $\Delta$ is degenerate there is nothing to show. Suppose that $p\not\in \Delta$. Half all sides to obtain a decomposition in four trianges, and we have $\int_{\partial \Delta} = \sum_{j=1}^4 \int_{\partial \Delta^j}$. Hence at least one of the triangles must satisfy $|J| \coloneqq \left| \int_{\partial\Delta} f\right| \le 4 |J_1|$. Inductively we obtain a decreasing sequence of triangles $\Delta_n$ with $|J| \le 4^n |J_n|$. Their diameter tends to zero, so their intersection is a singleton $z_0 \in \Delta$. Now, the function $z \mapsto f(z_0) + f'(z_0) (z-z_0)$ has an antiderivative so
        \begin{align*}
            |J_n|
            = \left| \int_{\partial \Delta_m} f(z) \diff z \right|
            = \left| \int_{\partial \Delta_m} \left( f(z) - f(z_0) - f'(z_0)(z-z_0) \right) \diff z \right|
        \end{align*}
        Furthermore $\left|\frac{f(z) - f(z_0)}{z-z_0} - f'(z_0)\right| < \varepsilon|z-z_0|$ for $z$ sufficiently close to $z_0$, so \[
            |J_n| \le \varepsilon L(\partial \Delta_m)^2 = \varepsilon 4^{-m} L(\partial \Delta)^2.
        \] so $|J| < \varepsilon L(\partial \Delta)^2$ for any $\varepsilon > 0$.

        If $p$ is one of the three corners we can use a sub-triangle and use continuity in the triangle's corner points, if it is inside or on one of the edges we can subdivide into triangles that have $p$ as their corner.
    \item Pick $a \in D$ and put $F(z) \coloneqq \int_{[a,z]}f(w)\diff w$, so for $z_0,z \in D$ with $\Delta = (a,z,z_0)$,
            \begin{align*}
                0 = \int_{\partial \Delta} f = F(z) + \int_{[z,z_0]}f - F(z_0),
            \end{align*}
            so
            \begin{align*}
                \varphi(z) \coloneqq \frac{F(z) - F(z_0)}{z-z_0} - f(z_0) = \frac{1}{z-z_0} \int_{[z,z_0]} (f(w) - f(z_0))\diff w
            \end{align*}
            satisfies $|\varphi(z)| \le \sup_{w\in [z,z_0]} \left| f(w) - f(z_0) \right| \to 0 $ as $z \to z_0$.
        \item Follows from (ii).
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cauchy Integral Formula[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Local Cauchy Integral Formula]
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open and convex, $\gamma$ a closed ssd path in $D$, and $f\in H(D)$. Then,\[
        f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi \i n(\gamma,z)} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w,\quad z\in D\setminus |\gamma|.
        \]
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Fix $z\in D\setminus |\gamma|$, and define \[
        g(w) \coloneqq \begin{cases}
            \frac{f(w) - f(z)}{w-z},& w \neq z,\\
            f'(z) ,& w = z.
        \end{cases}
    \] Then $g\in H(D\setminus \left\{ z \right\} )$ and continuous at $z$, so \[
    0 = \int_\gamma g(w)\diff w = \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w - f(z) \underbrace{\int_\gamma \frac{1}{w-z}\diff w}_{= 2\pi \i n(\gamma,z)}.
    \]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Infinite differentiability and local power series for holomorphic functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $D\subset \C$ is open and $f\in H(D)$ then $f'\in H(D)$ (so all derivatives) and for any $z_0\in D$ and $z\in B(z_0,r) \subset D$, \[
        f(z) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_n (z-z_0)^n
    \] where $a_n = \frac{f^{(n)}(z_0)}{n!}$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    On any $B(z_0,r)$, by Cauchy's integral formula for $\gamma = z_0 + r' \e^{\i t}$, \[
        f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w,
    \] and the integrand can be expanded as a power series. In particular $f'\in H(D)$, and the coefficients of the power series have to have this form.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Morera's theorem (converse of Goursat's lemma)[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $D\subset \C$ is open and convex, $f\colon D\to \C$ is continuous, and $\int_{\partial \Delta} f(w) \diff w = 0$ for all triangles, then $f\in H(D)$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    $F(z) = \int_{[z_0,z]}f(w)\diff w$ is an antiderivative as in the proof of the local Cauchy theorem, so $f = F' \in H(D)$.
\end{proof}

back:
"[latex]
egin{theorem}[Identit""atssatz]
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open and connected, $f,g\in H(D)$ such that $\left\{ f=g ight\} $ has a limit point in $D$. Then $f = g$.
\end{theorem}
egin{proof}

Let $f(z_0) = 0$, and let $m = \min \left\{ n\in \N\colon a_n(z_0) eq 0 ight\} $ where $(a_n(z_0))$ are the coefficients of the power series of $f$ in $B(z_0,r_0)$. front: [latex]Riemannscher Hebbarkeitssatz (classification of removable singularities).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Riemann'scher Hebbarkeitssatz]
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open and $f\in H(D\setminus \left\{ a \right\} )$. Then $f$ has a removable singularity at $a$ iff $f$ is bounded in a neighbourhood of $a$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $f$ is bounded in $\dot{B}(a,r)$, and put \[
        h(z) \coloneqq
        \begin{cases}
            (z-a)^2 f(z), & z \neq a,\\
            0, &z = a,
        \end{cases}\qquad z\in B(a,r).
    \] Then $h\in H(D\setminus \left\{ a \right\} )$ and \[
    \frac{h(z) - h(a)}{z-a} = (z-a) f(z) \to 0,\quad z \to a,
\] so actually $h\in H(D)$ with $h(a) = h'(a) = 0$, so $h(z) = a_2 (z-a)^2 + a_3(z-a)^3+\ldots $, so $f(z) = a_2 + a_3(z-a) + \ldots $
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Definitions of pole and essential singularity.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{definition}
    If $D\subset \C$ is open and $f\in H(D\setminus \left\{ a \right\} )$, then $a$ is called a \emph{pole of order $m\in \N_0$} if there is $g\in H(D)$ with $g(a) \neq 0$ and \[
        f(z) = \frac{g(z)}{(z-a)^m},\quad z\in D\setminus \left\{ a \right\} .
    \] (A pole of order zero is a removable singularity.) If $f$ does not have a pole at $a$ then it is called an \emph{essential singularity}.
\end{definition}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Großer Satz von Picard (and proof of simpler version Casorati-Weierstraß).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Großer Satz von Picard]
    If $D\subset \C$ is open and $f\in H(D\setminus \left\{ a \right\} )$ has an essential singularity at $a$, then there is $c\in \C$ such that \[
        \C\setminus \left\{ c \right\} \subset f(B(a,r))
    \] for all $r > 0$ for which $B(a,r) \subset D$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    We proof instead that $\overline{f(B(a,r))}= \C$, known as Casorati-Weierstraß. Let $r > 0$ and suppose there was $w_0\in \C$ and $\varepsilon > 0$ with $|f(z) - w_0| \ge \varepsilon$ for all $z\in B(a,r)$. WLOG $w_0 = 0$ (consider $f - w_0$), then define $g(z) = \frac{1}{f(z)}$ which has a removable singularity at $a$ because $|g(z)| \le 1 / \varepsilon$. Also $g\not\equiv 0$ so there is $m\in \N_0$ and $h\in H(D)$ with $h \neq 0$ in $B(a,r')$ with $g(z) = (z-a)^m h(z)$, so \[
        f(z) = \frac{h(z)^{-1}}{(z-a)^m},\quad z\in B(a,r')
    \] has a pole at $a$, a contradiction.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of poles (in general, and of specific order).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{lemma}
    Let $D\subset \C$ open and $f\in H(D\setminus \left\{ a ight\} )$.
    egin{enumerate}
        \item $f$ has a pole (of any positive order) at $a$ iff $\lim_{z o a}|f(z)| = \infty$.
        \item $f$ has a pole of order $m\in \N_0$ at $a$ iff $\lim_{z o a}(z-a)^m f(z) eq 0$ exists.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
egin{proof}
    egin{enumerate}
        \item If $f$ has a removable singularity then $|f(z)| ot o \infty$, and if it has an essential singularity then $\overline{f(B(a,r))} = \C$, and if it has a pole then \[
                |f(z)| = \left| rac{g(z)}{(z-a)^m} ight| o \infty.
        \]
    \item Clearly if $f$ has a pole of order $m$ this is true by definition. Suppose $L \coloneqq \lim_{z o a} (z-a)^m f(z) eq 0$ and $m > 0$ (we know this for $m = 0$ already). Then \[
            |f(z)| = \underbrace{\left| z-a ight| ^{-m}}_{ o \infty} \underbrace{\left| (z-a)^m f(z) ight| }_{ o L} o \infty,
    \] so $f$ has a pole, and then it is easy to show that the order must be $m$.

front: [latex]Cauchy integral formula for derivatives.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open and convex, $f\in H(D)$, $\gamma$ an ssd path in $D$. Then for $z\in D \setminus |\gamma|$ and $n\in \N_0$,
    \begin{align*}
        f^{(n)}(z) = \frac{n!}{2\pi \i n(\gamma,z)} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{(w-z)^{n+1}}\diff w.
    \end{align*}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    WLOG $z = 0$. We know this for $n = 0$, suppose it is true for $n\in \N_0$. Then for $h \in \dot{B}(0,r)\subset D\setminus |\gamma|$ and $n_\gamma \coloneqq n(\gamma,0) = n(\gamma,h)$,
    \begin{align*}
        \frac{f^{(n)}(h) - f^{(n)}(0)}{h}
        &= \frac{n!}{2\pi\i n_\gamma h} \int_\gamma \left(\frac{f(w)}{(w-h)^{n+1}} - \frac{f(w)}{w^{n+1}}\right)\diff s\\
        &\to \frac{(n+1)!}{2\pi \i n_\gamma} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{w^{n+2}}\diff w,
    \end{align*}
    where we used
    \begin{align*}
        \frac{1}{(w-h)^{n+1}} - \frac{1}{w^{n+1}}
        &= \frac{w^{n+1}(1 - (1 - h / w)^{(n+1))}}{w^{n+1}(w-h)^{n+1}}\\
        &= (1+o(1)) \frac{w^{n+1}(n+1) h / w}{w^{2n+2}} \\
        &= (1+o(1)) h \frac{n+1}{w^{n+2}}
    \end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Cauchy's derivative bounds for holomorphic functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $f\in H(B(z_0,R))$, then \[
        \left| f^{(n)}(z_0) \right| \le \left\|f\right\|_\infty \frac{n!}{R^n},\quad n\in \N.
    \]
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $\gamma(t) = z_0 + r \e^{\i t}$ with $r \in (0,R)$, so by Cauchy's integral formula,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| f^{(n)}(z_0) \right| = \left| \frac{n!}{2\pi \i} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{(w-z_0)^{n+1}}\diff w \right| \le \frac{n!}{2\pi}  \frac{\left\|f\right\|_\infty}{r^{n+1}}L(\gamma) = \left\|f\right\|_\infty \frac{n!}{r^n},
    \end{align*}
    because $L(\gamma) = 2\pi r$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Liouville's theorem (on bounded whole functions).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    If $f\in H(\C)$ is bounded, then $f$ is constant.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Let $M \coloneqq \left\|f\right\|_\infty < \infty$, then for any $z\in \C$ and $R > 0$, by Cauchy's derivative bounds,
    \begin{align*}
        \left| f'(z) \right| \le \frac{M}{R},
    \end{align*}
    so $f'\equiv 0$, so $f$ is constant.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Kleiner Satz von Picard (without proof).[/latex]
back:

\begin{theorem}
    If $f\in H(\C)$ then $\left| \C\setminus f(\C) \right| \le 1 $.
\end{theorem}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Fundamentalsatz der Algebra.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Every non-constant polynomial over $\C$ has a zero.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Suppose $p$ has no zeros. Then $\frac{1}{p} \in H(\C)$ is bounded ($1 / |p| \colon \C \to [0,\infty)$ is a continuous function with $1 / |p(z)| \to 0$ as $|z| \to \infty$), so constant.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Gebietstreue (open mapping theorem for holomorphic functions).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Gebietstreue]
    If $D\subset \C$ is open and $f\in H(D)$ then $f(D)$ is open. If $D$ is connected then so is $f(D)$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Connectedness is just continuity of $f$. It suffices to show that if $f\in H(D)$ with $0\in D$ and $f(0) = 0$, then there is $\varepsilon > 0$ with $B(0,\varepsilon) \subset f(D)$. Let $r > 0$ such that $B(0,2r)\subset D$ and $f \neq 0$ in $\dot{B}(0,r)$.

    Let $w \in B(0,\varepsilon)$ and suppose $w \not\in f(D)$. Then $g \coloneqq \frac{1}{f - w} \in H(D)$, \[
        |g(0)| \ge \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \to \infty,\qquad \max_{|z| = r} |g(z)| \le \frac{1}{\min_{|z| = r} |f(z)| - \varepsilon} \to \frac{1}{\min |f(z)|} > 0,
    \] but also $|g(0)| \le \max_{|z| = r} |g(z)|$ by Cauchy's integral formula, a contradiction if $\varepsilon$ is small enough.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Maximum principle for holomorphic functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Maximum principle]
    Let $D\subset \C$ open and $f\in H(D)$ not constant.
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $|f|$ has no local maxima in $D$.
        \item If $D$ is bounded and $f$ continuous on $\overline{D}$, then $|f(z)| < \max_{\partial D} |f|$.
    \end{enumerate}
    If $f$ has no zeros in $D$, then corresponding statements hold for the minimum.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    (i) follows from the fact that $f(D)$ is open, (ii) follows because the continuous function $|f|$ attains a maximum in the closed set $\overline{D}$ but it can't be attained in $D$ by (i). If $f$ has no zeros, we can apply this to $1 / f$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Schwartz' Lemma (on holomorphic $f\colon \mathbb{D} \to \mathbb{D}$ where $\mathbb{D} = B(0,1)$).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}[Schwartz]
    Let $f\in H(\mathbb{D})$ with $f(\mathbb{D}) \subset \mathbb{D}$ and $f(0) = 0$. Then
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $|f(z)| \le |z|$ and $|f'(0)| \le 1$.
        \item If either inequality is attained anywhere in $\mathbb{D}$, then $f(z) = cz$ for some $c \in \C$ with $|c| = 1$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
    Let $g(z) \coloneqq \frac{f(z)}{z}$ for $z\neq 0$. Then $g(0) = f'(0)$ and $g\in H(\mathbb{D})$. By the maximum principle, for $z\in \mathbb{D}$,
    \begin{align*}
        |g(z)| \le \max_{|z| = r} \left| \frac{f(z)}{z} \right| \le \frac{1}{r} \to 1,
    \end{align*}
    so $|g| \le 1$ on $\mathbb{D}$. If either inequality in (i) is attained it means $|g|$ attains its maximum in $\mathbb{D}$ so it must be constant.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Local invertability of holomorphic functions.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{lemma}
    If $D\subset \C$ open and $f\in H(D)$ and $f'(z_0) \neq 0$, then there is $r > 0$ such that $f$ is injective on $B(z_0,r)$ and $f^{-1} \in H(f(B(z_0,r)))$ with $(f^{-1})'(w) = \frac{1}{f'(f^{-1}(w))}$.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
    By continuity of $(z,w) \mapsto \frac{f(z)-f(w)}{z-w}$ (with the obvious extension; continuity is not trivial but straightforward), there is $r > 0$ such that $|f(z_1)-f(z_2)| \ge \frac{1}{2}|f'(z_0)| |z_1-z_2|$ for all $z_1,z_2\in B(x_0,r)$. This implies injectivity and Lipschitz continuity of $f^{-1}$. Then
    \begin{align*}
        \lim_{w' \to w}\frac{f^{-1}(w) - f^{-1}(w')}{w-w'}
        &= \lim_{w' \to w} \frac{f^{-1}(w) - f^{-1}(w')}{f(f^{-1}(w)) - f(f^{-1}(w'))}\\
        &= \lim_{z'\to z} \frac{z-z'}{f(z) - f(z')}\\
        &= \frac{1}{f'(z)},
    \end{align*}
    where we used that $z' \coloneqq f^{-1}(w') \to f^{-1}(w) \eqqcolon z$.
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]A necessary and a sufficient condition for $f\in H(D)$ to be injective.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
egin{lemma}
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open, and $f\in H(D)$.
    egin{enumerate}
        \item If $f$ is injective, then $f' eq 0$.
        \item If $\Im f' eq 0$ or $\Re f' eq 0$, then $f$ is injective.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
egin{proof}
    egin{enumerate}
        \item Suppose $f'(z_0) = 0$. Then there is a neighbourhood of $f(z_0)$ in which all valued are attained by $f$ on $D$ at least twice ($f$ locally looks like $f(z_0) + c z^m$ for $m\ge 2$), so $f$ is not injective.
        \item Say $\Im f' eq 0$ on $D$. Then for any $z,w$, with $\gamma = z o w$,
            egin{align*}
                \Im f(z) - \Im f(w) = \int_\gamma \Im f'(a) \diff a = \int_0^1 \Im f'(\gamma_s) \cdot \gamma_s \diff s,
            \end{align*}
            and $s \mapsto \Im f'(\gamma_s) \cdot \gamma_s$ is either everywhere positive or negative, so the integral is not zero.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Konvergenzsatz von Weierstraß (on locally uniform limits of holomorphic functions).[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $D\subset \C$ open, and suppose that $f_n \in H(D)$ converge locally uniformly to $f\colon D\to \C$. Then $f\in H(D)$ and $f_n' \to f'$ locally uniformly.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Firstly $f$ must be continuous. Now let $\Delta \subset D$ be a triangle; then $f_n \to f$ uniformly on $\Delta$, so \[
    \int_{\partial \Delta} f = \lim_{n\to \infty} \int_{\partial \Delta} f_n = 0.
\] Now let $B(z_0,2r) \subset D$. Then by Cauchy's inequalities, since $f_n - f\in H(D)$,
\begin{align*}
    \sup_{|z-z_0| < r} |f_n'(z) - f'(z)| \le \frac{1}{r} \sup_{|z-z_0| < 2r} |f_n(z) - f_n(z_0)| \to 0.
\end{align*}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Global Cauchy Theorem.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}[Global Cauchy Theorem]
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open and $f\in H(D)$. Then if $\Gamma$ is cycle in $D$ homologous to zero (i.e.\ $n(\Gamma,z) = 0$ for all $z\not\in D$), \[
        n(\Gamma,z) f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_\Gamma \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w,\quad z\in D\setminus |\Gamma|.
    \] In particular, $\int_\Gamma f(w)\diff w = 0$ for all $f\in H(D)$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
    For $z\in D$ we can put \[
    h(z) \coloneqq \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_\gamma \underbrace{\frac{f(w) - f(z)}{w-z}}_{\eqqcolon h(w,z)} \diff w,
    \] where we use the continuous continuation on $z\in |\Gamma|$. Note that wherever $n(\gamma,z) = 0$, this is equal to \[
    h(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w,\quad z\not\in D,
    \] which serves as a definition in $\C\setminus D$. Using continuity and Goursat's lemma we can show that $h\in H(\C)$, but also $|h(z)| \to 0 $ as $|z| \to \infty$ (because the second formula holds on $D^{c}\cup \left\{ z\colon n(\gamma,z) = 0 \right\} $ whose complement is bounded), but then $h$ is bounded so it must be constant zero, so for $z\in D\setminus |\Gamma|$, \[
    0 = h(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_\gamma \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w - n(\Gamma,z) f(z).
\] For the final statement, let $F(w) \coloneqq f(w)(w-z)$, so $F\in H(D)$ and \[
\int_\Gamma f(w) \diff w = \int_\Gamma \frac{F(w)}{w-z} \diff w = 2\pi \i n(\Gamma,z) F(z) = 0.
\]
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Existence of holomorphic logarithms and antiderivatives for holomorphic functions on simply connected domains.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{proposition}
    Let $D\subset \C$ be open and simply connected, and $f\in H(D)$
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item $f$ has an antiderivative on $D$.
        \item If $f \neq 0$ in $D$ then there is $g\in H(D)$ with $\e^{g} = f$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
    \begin{enumerate}
        \item
            Fix $a\in D$, then for any $z\in D$ let $\gamma$ be a path from $a$ to $z$ and put \[
                F(z) \coloneqq \int_\gamma f(w)\diff w,
            \] which does not depend on the choice of $\gamma$ by the global Cauchy theorem because $D$ is simply connected. Now if $B(z,r) \subset D$ we show $F'(z) = f(z)$ as before.
        \item $f' / f\in H(D)$ so it has an antiderivative $g$. Then \[
                (f \e^{-g})' = \e^{-g} \left[ f' -f g' \right] = 0,
        \] so $f = c \e^g = \e^{c'+g}$ where $\e^{c'} = c$.
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Laurent series of a holomorphic function. Definition of residue.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $f\in H(A(r,R,a))$ for $R > r \ge 0$ and $a\in \C$. Then there exists a unique sequence $(a_n)_{n\in \Z}$ such that \[
        f(z) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} a_n (z-a)^n,\qquad z\in A(r,R,a),
        \] with locally uniform convergence. In fact (for any $r < \rho < R$), \[
    a_n = \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_{\partial B(0,\rho)} \frac{f(w)}{(w-a)^{n+1}} \diff w.
    \] The residue of $f$ at $a$ is $\text{Res}(f,a) \coloneqq a_{-1}$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    First note that $a_n$ does not depend on $\rho$, because $w \mapsto \frac{f(w)}{(w-a)^{n+1}} \in H(A(r,R,a))$ for any $n\in \Z$ by the global Cauchy theorem. Now let $z\in A(r,R,a)$, $\gamma_r,\gamma_R$ cycles around $\partial B(0,r_1)$ and $\partial B(0,r_2)$ where $r < r_1 < |z| < r_2 < R$. Then by the global Cauchy theorem,
    \begin{align*}
        f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_{\gamma_R} \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w - \frac{1}{2\pi \i} \int_{\gamma_r} \frac{f(w)}{w-z}\diff w.
    \end{align*}
    Then, if $w\in |\gamma_R|$,
    \begin{align*}
        \frac{1}{w-z} = \frac{1}{w-a} \frac{1}{1 - \frac{z-a}{w-a}} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(z-a)^n}{(w-a)^{n+1}},
    \end{align*}
    and if $w \in |\gamma_r|$, \[
    \frac{1}{w-z} = - \frac{1}{w-a} \frac{\frac{w-a}{z-a}}{1 - \frac{w-a}{z-a}} = - \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(w-a)^{n-1}}{(z-a)^n} = - \sum_{n=-1}^{-\infty} \frac{(z-a)^n}{(w-a)^{n + 1}}.
\] Plugging this back in gives $f(z) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty a_n (z-a)^n$
\end{proof}
[/latex]

front: [latex]Characterisation of singularities in terms of Laurent series.[/latex]
[latex]Residue theorem.[/latex]
back:
[latex]
\begin{theorem}
    Let $f\in H(D\setminus A)$ for $D\subset \C$ open and $A\subset D$ discrete, and $\Gamma$ a cycle in $D\setminus A$ homologous to zero. Then \[
        \int_\Gamma f(w)\diff w = 2\pi \i \sum_{a\in A} n(\Gamma,a) \Res(f,a),
    \] and the sum is finite.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
    Assume there were infinitely many $a_k \in A$ with $n(\Gamma,a_k) \neq 0$. Because none of them are in the single unbounded component of $\C\setminus |\Gamma|$ the sequence is bounded say $a_k \to a$. Since $A$ is discrete in $D$ we must have $a\in \C\setminus D$, so $n(\Gamma,a) = 0$ because it is homologous to zero. The connected component of $\C\setminus |\Gamma|$ that contains $a$ is open, so almost all $a_k$ are in it, but then $n(\Gamma,a_k)=0$ for those $k$, a contradiction.

    Let $A_0 \subset A$ be the finite set of circled singularities, and denote \[
        L_a(z) \coloneqq \sum_{n=-1}^{-\infty} a_n(a) (z-a)^n
    \] the negative part of the Laurent series of $f$ around $a\in A_0$. Then $D_0 \coloneqq D\setminus A \cup A_0$ is open, $\Gamma$ is homologous to zero in $D_0$ and $f - \sum_{a\in A_0} L_a \in H(D_0)$ because all of the singularities are removable. Thus by the global Cauchy integral theorem,
    \begin{align*}
        \int_\Gamma f(w) \diff w = \sum_{a\in A_0} \int_{\Gamma} L_a(w) \diff w,
    \end{align*}
    and for any given $a\in A_0$,
    \begin{align*}
        \int_{\Gamma} L_a(w) \diff w = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_{-n}(a) \int_\Gamma \frac{1}{(w-a)^{n}} \diff w = a_{-1}(a)\cdot 2\pi \i n(\Gamma,a) ,
    \end{align*}
    because all the terms with $n\ge 2$ have antiderivatives.
\end{proof}
[/latex]
